HEADLINE: Time Travel on Rails

BYLINE: By VALERIE GLADSTONE; VALERIE GLADSTONE is a freelance writer who travels to Spain frequently.

 BODY:
STANDING in the big, bright, modern Santa Justa railway station in Seville, Al Andalus looked anachronistic, like Greta Garbo surrounded by hip 90's starlets. The brown-and-gold luxury train, most of its cars built in the 1920's, exuded understated class in the midst of the other sleek but characterless trains. Over the loudspeaker the names of cities rang out, and people hurried to their gates. No such public fanfare for those of us who were soon to travel on Al Andalus -- reservations must be made weeks in advance.
Except for the generator wagon, kitchen car and engine, all 14 of Al Andalus's cars were built in Britain, France and Spain between 1928 and 1930, a time when rail travel enjoyed enormous cachet. King Edward VIII of Britain used the sleeping cars in the 1930's on his travels between Calais and the Cote d'Azur. But during World War II and for decades afterward they languished in rail yards, until 1983, when Spain's Minister of Tourist Transportation, Julian Garcia Valverde, decided to restore and reinvent them as a tourist train. 
 With the Orient Express as inspiration but not as model -- the Orient Express didn't make sightseeing stops and was far more expensive -- Al Andalus began limited runs in 1983 in southern Spain. Every year it becomes more popular.
In June, a friend, Terry Hudson, and I joined more than 60 other travelers on Al Andalus for six days and five nights, its last trip until September. It runs in spring and fall only. Although the train can be chartered anywhere in Spain, its customary route, two dozen times yearly, starts and ends in Seville, with stops in Cordoba, Granada, Antequera, Carmona, Ronda and Jerez de la Frontera, ancient cities with tumultuous histories and remarkable architecture.
As on a cruise ship, we debarked at each stop for touring and meals, then returned in the evening. The train traveled from two to six hours every day, often in the middle of the night and occasionally in the late afternoon.
Climbing aboard, we entered a small, elegant reception area. A young woman, one of five who looked after the passengers, greeted us and gave us the key to our sleeping compartment. Besides being fluent in English, French and German, these women knew the region thoroughly, and patiently tended to our motley group, mostly Spaniards but also a French couple, eight Britons, four Germans, one Japanese and four other Americans besides ourselves. The nationalities change every trip, but, a staff member told me, usually they're seasoned travelers.
It hadn't occurred to me that most people wouldn't take a vacation on an old-fashioned train unless they were either train buffs or looking for something a little different or had traveled a good deal. I, as it happens, fit into the last two categories and Terry loves trains.
Then one night halfway through the journey, I understood the implications of my choice. A group of us hanging out in the bar car, built in France in 1928 and named Giralda after Seville's graceful tower, marveled at how a few couples were managing to look romantic on the tiny dance floor as they swayed to such familiar tunes as "Autumn Leaves" and "The Girl From Ipanema."
Amused by the surreal quality of the scene, I remarked how peculiar it was to be in a sumptuous railway car in a tiny station in the remote Spanish countryside, drinking and dancing. "But my dear," piped up a woman from Manchester, England, "Didn't you realize the trip would be quirky?"
No, in fact. If I'd begun the trip with this in mind, I might not have been so upset by our small quarters. Worn and disheveled after a flight from New York to Madrid and a two-and-a-half-hour train trip from Madrid to Seville, we eagerly anticipated sprawling out for a couple of hours before joining the tour in Cordoba, our first stop.
As it turned out, a miniature poodle would have had trouble sprawling out in our allotted space. Al Andalus offers sleeping compartments in three sizes: standard, double superior, and club. Standard, our class, is fit for only one person, or perhaps newlyweds -- very young and extremely enamored newlyweds.
Two bunk beds practically filled the compartment, which otherwise included a pretty end table and lamp. The mahogany walls, elegantly inlaid with seashell patterns, did nothing to make things better when Terry and I bumped into each other four times in the first three minutes.
A garment bag provided the only space for hanging up our clothes. Luckily, Terry was the only clotheshorse. In a corner, behind a panel, we found a sink and mirror. While the bathrooms, outfitted with gold-plated faucets and shared with four other passengers, took only seconds to reach from our compartment, getting to the modern shower stalls involved a trek through several cars. Fine, if you don't mind walking what seemed like a quarter of a mile in a bathrobe, clutching toiletries, in a train reeling along at what seemed like 100 miles an hour.
I couldn't blame the travel agent or Al Andalus; no one misrepresented the facilities. We'd just economized and hoped for the best. Peeking into the rooms of our neighbors, I saw that the bigger compartments, some with toilets and showers, would have been quite comfortable and were as handsomely decorated as our own.
To keep the peace, I left Terry to unpack and hurried through the train to join the group boarding a bus into Cordoba. How ever small our quarters, I admired Al Andalus's decor. The interiors of the vintage cars, paneled in burnished mahogany, look like the elegant libraries you imagine in private houses in the 20's. Heavy ivory brocade curtains, tied with satin tassels, frame the windows.
In the reception car, which doubles as a lounge, a room divider of frosted glass etched with birds and flowers separates the front desk area from an attractive space decorated with dark green leather armchairs and large wooden tables and equipped with a television set, board games and playing cards. In the two restaurant cars, small cozy sofas upholstered in a rococo pink and dark gray filigree pattern nicely substitute for chairs on each side of the dining tables. Lamps shaped like seashells cast a rosy hue in all the public cars.
The visit to Cordoba revived me. Nothing like the fragrance of orange trees, the sight of red and pink bougainvillea, and the splashing of fountains in patios to soothe the soul. On the way to the Great Mosque through the ancient Jewish quarter, we passed old houses with flower-filled window boxes squeezed onto tiny terraces.
Then we came upon the mosque. Construction began when the Moors first occupied the city in 796 and continued for two centuries. With its endless forest of rose-hued, intricately inlaid columns, long arcades and interlocking arches, it creates an extraordinary harmony. Our guide pointed out some of the finer details -- the ingenious weave of arches, resembling a piece of monumental lacework, that lead to Hakam II's prayer niche and within it, the inscriptions in shimmering gilt mosaic on a blue background. For an hour, we listened as she explained its evolution.
Al Andalus picks its guides well. Almost every one -- in Cordoba, the Alhambra in Granada, the dramatic mountain town of Ronda, the sherry winery in Jerez de la Frontera, and Seville -- provided just the right amount of information, without suffocating us with extraneous data. A profound sense of irony tends to keep Spaniards from pedantry.
The combination of intelligent guides, a wise selection of stops, meals at colorful, traditional restaurants and a few entertaining folkloric performances means that you come away from the trip with a good understanding of Andalusia -- one that would take far longer to get on your own. Also, you are immersed in the countryside. Fertile green fields alternated this season with plots of brilliant yellow sunflowers. Steep, rocky terrain planted with olive groves gives way to sandy, marshy monotony. Every tone and color and rise and fall of the land brings you closer to its essence.
When I returned to the train that first evening, Terry and I agreed that it might be nicer to eat on board than to go into Cordoba for dinner with the other passengers. Except for the bountiful buffet breakfasts and the last dinner of the trip, we passengers ate in restaurants at our stops, many of them in paradores, the excellent Spanish government-run hotels in converted villas, forts, convents and castles. We were never disappointed by the well-prepared four-course meals.
Although our request was unexpected, the staff didn't hesitate to call the chef, Gines Navarrete Alonso, and ask him to prepare a meal for us. And how good it was -- a fresh white wine, some grilled sardines, still with the scent of the sea, puff potatoes, a green salad, a slice of tender beef with a light tomato sauce and for dessert sweet pears.
By morning, as we rode the bus up the steep streets to the Alhambra in Granada, we were in the swing of things.
This great palace, the last refuge of Spanish Muslims on the Iberian peninsula, rises dramatically on a hill. At the end of the 14th century its royal residents enjoyed a palace with a decor of faience, stucco and wood, elaborately adorned with patterns based on geometric, vegetal and epigraphic motifs. There are no harsh accents, no garish colors, only austere, subtle harmonies.
Although we spent part of most days learning about Andalusian cities, there were breaks. We spent one morning and afternoon at the Hotel La Bobadilla, a 1,000-acre country estate an hour's drive from Granada or Malaga, deep in the countryside. A few famous people have found it worth a stay, among them King Juan Carlos of Spain, Placido Domingo, Jessye Norman, Brad Pitt and Tom Cruise. Some of its highlights: several pools, lush grounds, limitless riding trails, tennis courts, and spacious suites, each one different.
In time, on the train, we made a few good friends: Americans from California who had just sold their insurance company to study religion and who gave us insight into how the Moors and Spanish Catholics wrestled for control of Andalusia 500 years ago; a witty English couple with Cockney accents, and then, of course, the woman from Manchester, who wanted to know what we "really felt about the English," and her husband, who soothed her when their kosher meals occasionally arrived cold. The efficient staff was apologetic and usually managed to correct such mishaps. The shared routine had a lot to do with the camaraderie that developed.
After dinner at the parador in Antequera, a few of us decided not to take the bus back to the train, and walked through the deserted town, some quietly singing, happy to be outside in the starlit night and having the unusual experience of returning to a rail station to go to bed.
In Jerez de la Frontera, an English couple who owned carriage ponies reacted as negatively as I did to the famous horse show presented to tourists by the Royal Andalusian School of Equestrian Art -- it struck me as circus tricks.
Thus, having bonded with almost everyone who spoke English, our last dinner felt like those final nights at summer camp when you can't bear the thought of leaving all your newfound friends. It was by far the best meal of the trip, beginning with waiters serving us a wonderful variety of tapas. The surprising, and very un-Spanish, piece de resistance was a baked Alaska.
Afterward, we retired to the Giralda. Imagine, at 2 a.m., they closed us down!
The next morning we toured Seville and finally and inevitably, in the train station where we'd begun, we exchanged addresses and said our goodbyes. On Terry and I went by car to the coast. Oddly, that night, alone in our hotel in our big roomy suite in our big roomy bed, we felt a little lost and a trifle lonely.

HEADLINE: The Lives They Lived: Louise Patterson, b. 1901;
The Red And The Black

BYLINE: By Robert S. Boynton; Robert S. Boynton writes often for the magazine. His last article was about Martha Nussbaum.

 BODY:
What a sight they were, the 22 young African-American artists, writers, journalists and scholars who boarded the German steamer Europa on June 14, 1932, for an adventure in the Soviet Union. Still giddy from the gala send-off the night before in Harlem, they milled around the Brooklyn pier waiting for Langston Hughes, who at the last minute ran up the gangplank with a typewriter, Victrola and a boxful of Louis Armstrong records. Most of them had never been abroad, but now they were on their way to Moscow to make "Black and White," a film about "Negro life" in America.
Sponsored by a committee of prominent literary radicals -- Malcolm Cowley, Whittaker Chambers and Waldo Frank, among others -- the trip was led by Louise Patterson, a fiercely intelligent woman at the center of New York's African-American intellectual scene during the final days of the Harlem Renaissance. A founder of the Friends of the Soviet Union, Patterson turned her spacious Convent Avenue apartment into a leftist salon, called Vanguard, for discussions of the Russian Revolution and the party's position on the "Negro question." 
 Like many Depression-era intellectuals -- black and white -- she was captivated by the promise of a society where racism supposedly dissolved under revolutionary conditions. A cum laude graduate of Berkeley with a degree in economics, Patterson had taught at several colleges before coming to New York, where she assisted Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston, who were writing the play "Mule Bone." With her literary connections and leftist politics, she was the obvious choice to lead the trip.
 Arriving in the U.S.S.R. on the heels of the infamous Scottsboro Boys trial, the members of the group were treated like celebrities. "Wherever we go we are surrounded by workers, greeted and cheered," Patterson wrote in an unpublished memoir. In Leningrad, their train was met by a brass band playing the "Internationale." In Moscow, a fleet of Lincolns and Buicks whisked them to the luxurious Grand Hotel. Bus seats were emptied for them; they would be ushered to the front of every line. "For all of us who experienced discrimination based on color in our own land," she wrote, "it was strange to find our color a badge of honor." The trip served as a sort of a turning point for African-American intellectuals, providing concrete evidence of a full-blown international antiracist movement that supported their struggle for dignity and equality in America.
The movie they had come to make was another matter. The German-born director spoke neither Russian nor English; his only previous film had been an anti-imperialist documentary, "Strange Birds of Africa." When rehearsals began, he was shocked to learn that his "actors" had no performance experience to speak of. "Europeans, as well as Americans, seem to be victims of that old cliche that all Negroes just naturally sing," wrote Hughes in "I Wonder as I Wander," his memoir. "Other than two or three, the 22 of us who had come to Russia could hardly carry a tune."
The script was similarly misconceived, depicting an alliance of white Northern proletarians and black Alabama steelworkers who join together in Birmingham to fight capitalism as "brothers." Hughes suggested that this scenario was far-fetched. "But it's been approved by the Comintern!" a Soviet bureaucrat replied indignantly.
"Black and White" received caustic international coverage ("Negroes adrift in 'Uncle Tom's' Russian Cabin," read a New York Herald Tribune headline), and with its cancellation the group split into two. One accused the Soviets of sacrificing the film to win diplomatic recognition from the United States, while Patterson's group insisted that the movie had simply fallen victim to its own best intentions -- a sentiment that earned her the sobriquet "Madame Moscow."
At summer's end, the disillusioned faction left in a huff, while the others traveled through Central Asia, where they were impressed by the enlightened treatment the Soviets showed the dark-skinned minorities. Three members of the group settled permanently in the U.S.S.R. and Hughes continued touring for a year longer. ("Good-morning, Revolution:/You're the very best friend/I ever had. . . . " he wrote.) Patterson returned to New York that fall to take care of her ailing mother and spent the rest of her life working for progressive, antiracist causes. "Russia today is the only country in the world that's really fit to live in," she told The New York Amsterdam News. "I'd live there anytime in preference to America."

HEADLINE: Q & A/Christopher Wigren;
Making a Job of Preserving Old Houses, and Buildings, Too

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER WIGREN, an architectural historian who is the assistant director at the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, sees hundreds of historic homes in Connecticut and has a variety of suggestions where others can see them too.
He recommends, for example, a drive through the exceptional colonial history districts of Guilford and Litchfield. Then there are Woodbury and Southbury, which together make up one of the longest historic districts in the state and include many antique shops. Downtown Ridgefield, meanwhile, has beautiful colonial, federal, 19th century and turn-of-the-century homes that often served as summer homes and country estates. 
 He cites the Seaside Village Historic District in Bridgeport as unusual and unexpected. "These are small brick row houses in the Colonial Williamsburg style with beautiful landscaping and curved streets. They were very well constructed by the federal government during World War I and served as workers' housing."
He tells homeowners, "If you have an old house you don't have to make a museum of it. Buildings grow and change. It's okay to adapt old buildings to modern uses. Just be careful, look at the house and think about what makes it desirable. Those are the things to pay attention to."
Recently Mr. Wigren met at the trust's 1827 headquarters in New Haven to offer advice and discuss some of the issues surrounding preservation of old structures in Connecticut. Following are some excerpts from that conversation:
Q. What does the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation do?
A. The Trust is a nonprofit organization that promotes historic preservation throughout the state. We hold conferences and workshops. We work with local groups, We are advocates, standing up to say "Preservation! Don't tear that building down. It can be used!" We give what I call the "advice to the lovelorn service" to tell people where to find information and people qualified to work on old buildings.
Q. Where can people go for information about buildings?
A. Libraries are usually the best place to start for local information. The Connecticut Historical Commission does surveys of historic buildings across the state. They haven't got every town covered yet but they have a lot. They are a state agency located in Hartford.
We have just published a directory of people who are experienced in working with old buildings, such as, contractors, craftsmen, consultants who can research a building, architects, people who do roofs, stained glass, painting. We haven't checked their references. We always recommend that people ask for and check references.
Q. Is there any money to help owners of historic homes?
A. Very little. And no direct money. The state has just approved a tax credit for owner-occupied homes targeted to lower income areas in parts of Bridgeport, Stamford, Norwalk and other cities. It's set up in a complicated way. The tax credit is for rehabilitation of houses listed on the state or national register. It is a corporate income tax credit. The homeowner doesn't get the credits. The credits go to a corporation that participates in funding the project.
There is a federal income tax credit for income producing buildings either rental housing, offices or other commercial buildings. That's been around for many years. There are efforts in Congress to pass a homeowners tax credit on the federal level. It was in a tax reduction bill that the president vetoed. It had rather a broad base of support so there is a good chance it will be passed next year.
Q. How do you shop for a historic house?
A. If you're interested in a particular area, drive around a bit and look. Some real estate agencies have departments that specialize in historic buildings. The National Trust for Historic Preservation runs training sessions for realtors. We've done that in a small way too. We've taught a little basic architectural history to realtors.
We also publish a special flyer, the Historic Properties Exchange, that advertises endangered buildings that are for sale. These are buildings someone has threatened to tear down or are in very bad condition. Or the owner decided to give away a house to be moved. These buildings are often on their last legs.
Q. Are any significant historic buildings in danger in Connecticut?
A. We publish another list in our newsletter of buildings that are historic sites of great importance and are endangered. We targeted several kinds. We did a general entry about buildings that are endangered because they are not being maintained. That's called "demolition by neglect." Sometimes homeowners do it on purpose. Sometimes it's a homeowner who doesn't have the money or knowledge to maintain the building properly. Maintenance is the single most important factor to preserving an individual building.
There is a house in Bridgeport that is on a site marked for a community center. Late in the process the local preservation society discovered this problem. It's an 18th century building and in very bad shape. They want to make it a part of the community center. There's probably not much chance of it being saved.
We also listed modern style houses in New Canaan. They are part of another preservation issue called "tear downs." It's happening a lot in Fairfield County these days. Relatively modest houses are situated on pieces of land that are extremely expensive. The people who can afford to buy the land want a much more elaborate, larger house on the site. We wanted to call particular attention to New Canaan because it has a large concentration of modern style houses. A group of modernist architects settled in New Canaan after World War II. Philip Johnson is the best known. His Glass House is here. A large number of important modern houses were extensively discussed in the architectural press in the 1940's-50's. They had a big influence on the development of modern architecture in this country.
They played a role in the history of Connecticut. They are reaching the 50-year mark which is the basic requirement for listing on the National Register. Some would be absolutely eligible. The New Canaan Historic Society has been doing a lot of work to record the history of these houses for the last 10-15 years. One was torn down this summer. Some are being added to in thoughtful ways that preserve their original character. Some are being added to in ways that do not preserve their historic character. There is that economic and stylistic factor.
They were designed with a particular lifestyle in mind. They were consciously simple, designed very often with living room and dining room in one room. They had small bedrooms. They had an idea of family carrying on in one room in a way that people do not always want to live now.
Q. What's the difference between the state and federal historic designations?
A. There are registers that are basically lists of historic buildings. Connecticut has a state register and the federal government has the national register. The federal register is more difficult to get on. It requires more documentation. The basic requirement is one of four things: A historic event took place there. It's associated with a historic person. Third is important architecture. And the fourth is archaeological sites like Indian sites or the ruins of an old mill, factory or a house.
There are the same basic requirements for the state and national registers but the national register requires a higher level of importance.
Sites can be listed either individually or as part of a district or neighborhoods. It's easier in a sense to become part of a historic district because a house can be part of a neighborhood that creates it's own level of importance. There are hundreds of these.
The local historic districts are the only ones with controls. If you are listed on the federal register you can do anything you want to it except tear it down unreasonably. That's a state law.
The local district is set up by a town or city that establishes a commission who must approve any alteration to the exterior of a building visible from a public right of way except paint. You can paint it any color, add stripes or polka dots.
Q. What advantages are there to owning a historic house?
A. They can include good architecture, a sense of connection with the past. Sometimes it can even be a monetary advantage. There is a specialized market for people who value these qualities and are willing to pay more for such a house.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 6; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: On the Books, It's Still the 19th Century

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER

 BODY:
DON'T think about trotting a horse on a Garden City sidewalk. And if you happen to ride south to Rockville Centre, it would be foolhardy not to slow the steed to a walk. Either transgression could bring a stiff fine and some jail time.
Operating a roadhouse is illegal in Flower Hill. Fat-rendering factories are outlawed in New Hyde Park. And you can't keep geese and ducks in Asharoken. 
 It will, of course, take more than the mere dropping of a ball or the turning of a calendar page to banish the 1900's from Long Island. But some of the laws still on the books in many of the Island's 95 incorporated villages hark back not to the 20th century, but the 19th. Even some ordinances dating only to mid-century evoke a pastoral era that had already vanished by the time the laws were enacted.
Many of the vestigial laws provide a window on early local efforts to preserve the Island's bucolic character. The codes tried to fend off industries that might have tarnished beachfront communities or marred agrarian and rural landscapes. And the laws had teeth: penalties included jail terms up to 50 days and fines to $250, a tidy sum when inflation is taken into account.
Take the anti-rendering ordinance in New Hyde Park, backed by a maximum $100 fine and 50-day prison term. The 70-year-old code prohibits "obnoxious bone-boiling, fat-rendering" refineries, where animal fat, waste and scraps were converted into tallow for candles, soap and glue, and carbon for refining sugar.
"Bone boiling and rendering of fat was a terrible thing in the neighborhood," said Vincent Seyfried, a Long Island and Queens historian. "It smelled God-awful, and people on a hot day couldn't open their windows because the stench was so bad."
Mr. Seyfried said western Long Island communities such as New Hyde Park probably were protecting themselves from the threat of encroachment by commercial rendering plants in Long Island City. But Long Island's vast farmlands likely sprouted a crop of independent renderers, said Tom Cook, executive director of the National Renderers Association in Alexandria, Va. "Wherever you saw farmers there was someone out there doing rendering," Mr. Cook said.
Apparently it's not so easy just to strike obsolescent laws from the books. A thorough recodification can cost villages up to $30,000 and a year's work, said Colleen Wight, managing editor of General Code Publishers Corporation, a Rochester, N.Y., company that publishes many Long Island codes.
To keep pace with changes in state and federal laws, General Code and some village attorneys recommends that municipalities overhaul their codes every 10 to 15 years. But villages often simply update their codes piecemeal as needs arise.
Martha Krisel, Rockville Centre's village attorney, said her municipality was overhauling its zoning code for the first time in nearly 40 years. But she said Rockville Centre is likely to retain an old ordinance forbidding "fortune-telling, clairvoyance and phrenology" as well as a prohibition against "breeding poultry, pigeons, horses and livestock."
Why? The village's zoning makeover is cumbersome enough, Ms. Krisel said. The village started the process during the summer of 1998 and expects it to continue for another six months, she said.
"It's a nightmare," she said. "It's a tremendous amount of work."
In November, the Village of Flower Hill tentatively adopted a revised code for the first time in 30 years, deleting obsolete restrictions on hunting and operating steam whistles. But after three public hearings, Flower Hill officials said they expect to wrestle with the recodification again this month because of some public opposition to new revisions in the village zoning laws.
Villages may have other reasons for retaining old laws. "Courts have ruled that certain code provisions are unconstitutional, but villages may keep them anyway because they serve as a deterrent," said A. Thomas Levin, a municipal attorney for seven Nassau County villages. "People who read them don't understand that they are unenforceable. The ones that come to mind are noise ordinances or loitering. Most of the old coded provisions have been invalidated by the courts."
Some village officials believe old codes supplement their zoning laws and underscore that certain uses are prohibited. The old codes are added protection in an increasingly litigious society where municipalities cannot afford legal ambiguities, they say.
In Bayville, bans on slaughterhouses and glue factories have remained intact despite three overhauls of the community's codes since the municipality incorporated as a village in 1919. The most recent recodification was in 1993.
"The code says we do not allow glue factories," said Victoria Siegel, Bayville's four-term mayor. "You can laugh at that, but it makes a statement about our village not wanting industry."
But Ms. Wight, of General Code Publishers, cautioned that municipalities could confuse the public as well as their own code enforcers by keeping antiquated codes. And because old laws are generally not enforced, Ms. Wight added, a municipality could find itself accused of selective enforcement.
Sometimes, however, a village code's drafters sometimes prove prescient. Eleven years ago, Garden City officials notified 75 homeowners that the basketball backboards mounted on free-standing poles in front of their homes violated a 1924 village code restricting "accessory structures." Although basketball was invented in 1891, the code was more likely aimed at sheds and fences.
Garden City officials still cringe at the memory of the international media attention attracted by the basketball enforcement. But the effort, as well as the village's ban on horses on sidewalks, was concordant with the careful planning and passion for esthetics that Alexander T. Stewart, Garden City's founder, brought to the area in 1869, said John Ellis Kordes, the village historian.
"He instilled in the village what he might have instilled in a child if he had one," Mr. Kordes said of Stewart. "From the beginning here, zoning and a certain standard of beauty and order set the tone for the village."
A similar application of an old code to a modern offense took place in Asharoken, a Suffolk beach community with a population of about 800. William Kelly, Asharoken's eight-term mayor, said that the village prevented a resident from using an extension cord across a road while building a deck by enforcing a 1926 code that prohibits stringing telegraph wires over streets.
Mayor Kelly said he considered citing the village's 1934 ban on keeping fowl to stop another resident from feeding the pigeons. The mayor and neighbors said the feeding has created a nuisance. But any effort to apply the code could be complicated. As written, the code prohibits only "chickens, geese, ducks and other fowl and domestic birds used for food purposes."
The mayor conceded that he had little recourse. "They're out on her property, on the roof and she feeds them and they fly all over the place leaving their stuff and then hover back on her property," the mayor said. "It's a 'fowl or domestic bird,' that's for sure, but she doesn't cook them."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 4; Column 4; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: Tenants for Office Space Grow In New Westchester Prosperity

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
FOR more than a decade, the vacant International Business Machines building here served as a harsh reminder of not only this city's persistent economic tribulations but also of the weak economy of the entire county.
Now the building's renaissance -- thanks to a facelift that includes a new lobby, a health club and renovated office suites -- confirms what many have been hoping for: that Westchester has entered a new period of prosperity. 
 In many respects during the last 10 years, the former I.B.M. office building was a bellwether for Westchester's economic health.
During much of the 1990's, when the 381,000-square-foot building at 360 Hamilton Avenue sat empty with no suitors, the rest of the county was also struggling.
Throughout Westchester, large companies had moved away, and others like I.B.M. had downsized and consolidated, leaving large tracts of office space empty.
White Plains, the center of corporate activity in the 1980's and the hardest-hit area during downsizing, became "the poster child for the malaise of the market," observed Dean J. Shapiro, the executive director for Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate concern.
Commercial vacancy rates in White Plains soared above 30 percent as recently as the fourth quarter of 1998, with buildings, like the one formerly occupied by I.B.M. here, standing empty.
But about a year ago, after Reckson Associates, a real estate investment trust in Valhalla, spied a rebound in the offing, it poured $15 million into renovating the structure in White Plains and sought new tenants. They were right to do so, because by the end of 1999, the vacancy rate for White Plains had dropped to 22.35 percent, and the rate for the county was also falling.
Merrill Lynch further confirmed Reckson's optimism by signing a lease for part of the Hamilton Avenue property, and many other deals are pending for space in the building, said Mr. Shapiro, whose real estate concern has offices in Manhattan, Stamford and Elmsford.
From the point of view of Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's Director of Economic Development and Real Estate, at least part of the economic success in Westchester can be attributed to the fact that for the second year in a row, property taxes are down.
As a result, most property owners are looking forward to a 1.8 percent or more decrease in their tax bills this year.
"Tax decreases are the kind of news that individuals and businesses like to hear," said Larry S. Schwartz, the chief adviser to County Executive Andrew J. Spano.
But contrary to the trends of the 1980's when corporate giants like I.B.M. ruled, the majority of business growth for 2000 and beyond is likely to take place among moderate-size companies, both Mr. Schwartz and Mr. Carrera predicted.
"We're focusing on the small companies rather than waiting for the big players, the full-building tenants," Mr. Carrera said, "because it just might turn out to be a long wait for the latter group."
Looking ahead this year, the county plans to announce the opening of a high-speed fiber optics network -- a 125-mile above-ground loop around Westchester that will enable small and medium-size companies to hook up to the Internet and thereby expand.
The private real estate sector, however, is not enjoying such optimism about the future -- even though sales of luxury homes in Westchester as last year drew to a close topped similar sales figures for the previous year. The picture is worrisome -- paradoxically the result of too much success, it seems.
P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that home sales fell off in the last three months "by double-digit amounts."
The reason was a daunting lack of inventory, which is "putting a terrible brake on the market," Mr. Mercurio said.
He continued: "In a sense, we have been victims of our success, of too much of a good thing. If we don't rebuild inventory quickly, the sad fact is that the market won't stay good."
New construction, he said, is failing to keep up with demand, with the biggest lack being condominiums, followed by single-family homes.
The median sale price of a single-family dwelling in Westchester was $365,000 last year, 7 percent higher than for the third quarter of 1998, "the highest median price ever," Mr. Mercurio said.
Of 306 properties being sold for $1 million or more in Westchester, Dutchess and Rockland Counties in the first nine months of last year, 301 were in Westchester. Moreover, 74 properties sold for $2 million or more as of Sept. 30, with the highest reported sale being a $7.75 million transaction for a home in Larchmont.
Most of the luxury homes sold and built are in Bedford, Pound Ridge, Katonah, Chappaqua, Armonk, Somers, North Salem, South Salem and Mount Kisco.
But there were also seven sales for $1 million-plus in Pelham Manor and New Rochelle during the period, compared with only three for all of last year in those two municipalities.
New businesses, meanwhile, continued to flock to the county. Atlas Air, the third largest air cargo carrier in the United States, said this fall that it would lease 120,000 square feet of space at Texaco's Corporate Center in Harrison beginning in the spring.
The company, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange as CGO, is planning to invest $8 million in Westchester on construction and new equipment and add jobs over the next five years as part of an expansion plan.
Initially, 295 employees will be moved from a division at Kennedy International Airport, and an additional 55 will come from its headquarters in Golden, Colo.
Its fleet of 18 Boeing 747's will continue to operate out of Kennedy. Atlas is a United States-certified air carrier for some of the world's leading international carriers, operating scheduled flights on behalf of its customer airlines to 101 cities in 46 countries.
Michael Chowdry, chairman, chief executive officer and president of Atlas, said that new contracts and customers had produced a 42 percent increase in the company's revenues last year, prompting staff increases.
"We had outgrown our facilities in Golden and at JFK, and the lease on the JFK facility was set to expire in June of next year," Mr. Chowdry said.
In Yonkers, after much planning and debate, a large shopping center finally opened in September with Stew Leonard's, a Disneyesque supermarket featuring animated dancing cows and singing milk cartons.
The 135,000-square-foot market is part of a retail complex with a 103,000-square-foot Home Depot -- scheduled to open on Thursday -- and a 135,000-square-foot Costco, which opened on Oct. 28. Edward A. Sheeran, executive director of economic development for Yonkers, said that the complex would be responsible for "the largest influx of jobs in a six-month period in Yonkers' history."
Several more projects are expected to add even more jobs.
The Marriot and Hilton hotel chains have each signed contracts to build at the new shopping center in Yonkers, and discussions are under way for a convention center, to be built across the highway from Stew Leonard's by the Philadelphia-based Fort Washington Expo Center.
Also, the Yonkers City Council last month approved plans for a 75,500-square-foot Super Stop & Shop supermarket at the Cross County Shopping Center despite vocal and persistent opposition from neighbors.
Still undecided is the future of the 100-acre Yonkers Raceway, "the best piece of commercial property going," Mr. Sheeran said. The raceway has been for sale for more than a year.
Another southern Westchester city, New Rochelle, also experienced an economically robust year in 1999 with the opening of the New Roc City entertainment center, built by New Roc Associates in White Plains. Capelli also built a 220-foot-high replica of the 984-foot Eiffel Tower at the family entertainment center on the site of the former New Rochelle Mall.
In Mount Vernon, city officials have just announced the hiring of Hospitality Valuation Services International of Mineola on Long Island to conduct a feasibility study for a proposed $110 million hotel and sports complex.
And in White Plains after several delays, the city is finally "close to wrapping up negotiations" on a proposal by Tishman Speyer Properties for a $175 million mega-movie theater and shopping center in the former Macy's building on Mamaroneck Avenue, said George Gretsas, a spokesman for Mayor Joseph M. Delfino. The project will include a 24-screen, 5,200-seat theater and a garage for 2,000 cars.
Also, the Westchester division of New York Presbyterian Hospital last month released its master plan for a 300,000-square-foot shopping center, 450 single-family homes and a 61-acre park, which would be open to the public. "All that, and building permits are exploding off the charts," Mr. Gretsas said.
As a result of all the economic activity, the number of jobs in the county in November was 414,300, which is the best for that month since 1988, when it was 415,000 jobs, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor. "Just over the last year, the economy has expanded by 9,900, which represents a job growth rate of 2.4 percent," Mr. Surdey said. "That's extremely encouraging."
Manufacturing jobs in the county grew by 900 or 2.4 percent -- "which bucks national trends," Mr. Surdey also observed, explaining that the nation's manufacturing sector actually contracted by 1.5 percent.
The jobs most in demand in Westchester employ the skills of computer programmers and software developers, he said. The average annual pay in the county for such jobs is $71,548.
Growth is also being seen in both the goods producing sector, which includes construction and manufacturing, and in the service industries.
During 1999, construction jobs were up by 1,800 or 8.3 percent to 23,500 in November -- the healthiest for that month in the county since 1989.
Adding to the economic glow, the average work week in manufacturing in November was 42.7 hours -- almost three hours overtime -- which matches February 1995 for the busiest work week in Westchester.
Not only were workers putting in overtime but full-time hiring also increased, which was "a double positive," Mr. Surdey said.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Charter Schools Enroll Few of Learning Disabled

BYLINE: By LISA SUHAY

 BODY:
When state education officials released a report last week showing that charter schools lagged behind public schools in the number of students with learning disabilities, advocacy groups representing parents were ready to say "I told you so."
About 6.3 percent of charter school students have learning disabilities, while in public schools the number is 12.5 percent, according to the report released by the Department of Education's Joint Committee on the Public Schools. The contents of the study ranged from recommendations for adding funding for districts where students move directly from nonpublic schools to charter schools to details of charter schools' weaknesses in dealing with special needs students. 
 Since 1996 the group Statewide Parent Advocacy Network (SPAN), which is based in Newark, has lobbied the state to pay closer attentions to how charter schools handle children with learning disabilities.
"Most charter schools in the state are ill equipped to deal with special-needs children and are turning them away," said DianaAutin, executive co-director of SPAN. "Worse, their early intervention programs are almost nonexistent and so the children who should be picked up are being missed."
According to Ms. Autin, SPAN has been getting calls from frustrated parents across the state who say charter schools turned their children away.
Jeff Osowski, assistant commissioner for the state's division of Information and Management, said there could be many reasons for the difference in enrollments.
"One is that a smaller percentage of parents are entering the pool because they don't want to pull their kids out of special schools and programs that they worked hard to develop," Mr. Osowski said. "Second is, is there an outreach problem here in that they're not getting to these parents? Also, maybe there is a problem out there with program availability."
In response, Ms. Autin said: "We told them over and over again that this was going to be a problem and they told us not to worry, that it wouldn't happen. In this case we really hate to be right."
In addressing another point of contention, the charge that the charter schools are "creaming" or collecting only the best and brightest students from public schools, the report flatly stated: "No so-called 'creaming' is occurring."
The study included a profile showing that black students make up 63 percent of the population at charter schools and 51 percent at public schools.
According to the report there are 47 charter schools serving approximately 9,000 students in the state for the 1999-2000 school year. That number is out of a total public school population of 1.2 million.
The report concludes that there are approximately 2,888 students on waiting lists to get into charter schools in the state.
The report also concluded that the schools' populations are "clearly representative of the districts in which they are located in terms of academic achievement, economic status and minority status."
Asked if he was aware of students being refused entrance to charter schools because they had special needs, Mr. Osowski said, "I won't dispute that SPAN may be getting these calls, but we haven't gotten any such complaints here in our office."
Mr. Osowski said the legislation that created charter schools in New Jersey required them to provide for the needs of children with disabilities just as public schools do.
However, SPAN contends that charters were given an out, a loophole, when language was included that allows the schools to seek waivers from all regulations except those pertaining to assessment, testing, civil rights and student health and safety.
When asked to comment on the waivers, Mr. Osowski said he was "unfamiliar with that procedure."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2661 words

HEADLINE: Will New York Be Necessary In the 21st Century?;
Some of the City's Bright Lights Ponder the Future of the Metropolis

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
NEW YORK came of age when all that was new seemed to flow from the city, when crowded streets and the world's tallest building were matters of civic pride. Like all great cities in their times, New York thrived in the 20th century because it was a place where the energetic and the talented -- many from distant lands -- gathered to form a critical mass. It was the quintessential modern city, unrivaled in America, if not the world.
But New York is vastly different from what it was even a decade ago. Shopping-mall culture has expanded from the suburbs into the heart of the city, eliminating many of New York's idiosyncrasies. Newer cities and suburban centers have lured jobs along with innovators. And many have argued that the sweeping technological advances of recent years, from faxes to cell phones and especially the Internet, have undercut the need for a central city in fields like the arts, communications and finance, the very areas in which New York has been pre-eminent. Today, people can opt for lives that are less frantic than those typically led in New York. They can move to the country, or to newer, cleaner towns and cities, while continuing to do business with the click of a mouse or a remote control. 
 And so the question arises: In this new technological era, will New York lose its edge? Will it still be a magnet for talent and an incubator of progress? Will New York be necessary in the 21st century?
The New York Times asked some prominent New Yorkers, past and present, to explore these issues.
 
Jane Jacobs
Author, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities"
Cities become necessary because they make themselves necessary. It's not some mysterious bestowal from heaven; it's what they do. And the great service of cities has always been to solve problems as they become acute and provide the wherewithal, especially the knowledge, to other places on how to do them. That's how epidemics have been overcome, to a great extent. It's how drudgery has been removed from lots of tasks. It's how there have been new kinds of housing and new standards of living and new ways of educating people -- these all started in cities, and always have. So that's one service that cities do, and it is a service that New York has provided, and if it continues to be innovative in this practical, essential way, it'll continue to be necessary. If it doesn't, it won't be necessary.
Another great service is that they enrich civilization and New York has done that. And if it keeps on doing that, it will continue to be necessary.
But I can't prophesy whether it will continue doing that or not, and neither can anyone else. Cities make themselves up as they go along, just as languages do, and whether they're going to do it in a creative and useful way, or whether they're going to muff it, who can know in advance?
 
Felix G. Rohatyn
United States Ambassador to France
Maybe absence makes the heart grow fonder, but the more I'm away from New York, the more indispensable it appears to me.
New York is already the 21st-century city because it is the city that encompasses both total cultural diversity and a total commitment to intellectual property, which is what the 21st century is going to be all about. Whether it's publishing, whether it's finance, whether it's fashion, whether it's the arts, whether it's communications, whether it's information technology, or architecture, whether it's being a transport and communications hub, New York is actually going to increase in importance.
Every time I come back I get this jolt. Paris is beautiful, but Paris doesn't have the electricity of New York. Paris is like Greta Garbo, compared to Michelle Pfeiffer as New York.
 
Drew Nieporent
Restaurateur
Restaurant-wise, nothing beats the variety and the value of New York as a food town, and I don't see that changing. If anything, it's just becoming more vibrant, and there are that many more choices and places than before.
We used to take concepts from outside, like French and Italian, and we'd do all that food and bring it to New York. But now you have some really talented chefs who are taking the craft they developed in New York and bringing that to other places, and there are markets that really appreciate a New York product, not the same French extract or Italian extract. New York is developing its own cuisine culture that's past matzoh ball soup and corned beef sandwiches.
 
Luc Sante
Author, "Low Life: Lures and Snares of Old New York"
New York is not necessary for me. After living here 27 years, I am within a few months of moving out, probably to the country. For me, the things that I loved about New York are gone. They may come back at some point, if New York goes through another spin cycle, but right now they're not in existence. New York was the magnet for the members of the worldwide fringe, the eccentrics, the unemployables, the visionaries, the whatevers back in the days when you could still kind of live marginally here, which is to say until sometime in the early 1980's.
But now that it's so expensive to live in New York, it seems to have only one face. The city has always been about money, of course, but it had that other aspect, it had more than one face. At one time it was a seemingly endless labyrinth I could wander around forever. But now I have no desire to walk down streets of condo conversions.
 
The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d
Pastor, Abyssinian Baptist Church, Harlem
If there wasn't a place on this planet called New York, God would have to create it. It is the best experiment in democracy that the world knows. The most diverse city in the world, it has a great mixture of the heavy, secular greed that is necessary for this kind of place to exist, but also the kind of balance provided by the deep spiritual nature of the people who live here and the institutions that represent that spirit.
If you are looking for a real attempt to get to one world, a real example of what the new millennium will look like, New York is it. And so we need New York as an example of how we can get along and work together.
 
Vartan Gregorian
President, Carnegie Corporation of New York
New York is still going to be the center of the world, more so than it is now. There are several factors: No. 1, the entire culture is becoming urban culture, worldwide, and New York is the epitome of that. Second, this is the most international city anywhere in the world, and I include London, Paris, Berlin -- name it. New York is also the ethnic capital of the world. It's a vibrant city, the perpetual revolving door for immigrants where one wave displaces the other. New York is not just an actuality, it's a potentiality.
As for the idea that people will never leave their homes because of the Internet, well, I'll tell you, I heard about that a long time ago, that videos were going to displace movie houses. People still need people. They like to feel the vibration. They like to walk on Fifth Avenue.
 
Jane Friedman
Chief executive, HarperCollins
The center of publishing in America has been New York City for eons and I think that that will absolutely continue. I think there is talent coming from everywhere entering the publishing world, but I think that the publishing companies themselves -- the editorial staffs, the marketing staffs, the promotions staffs, the advertising staffs -- will almost definitely be located in what will still be seen as the center, which is Manhattan.
I believe wholeheartedly in the Internet, and we are looking forward to the expansion of the Internet Age, but I still believe that just as people still want to go into a bookstore and touch the product, I believe that proximity to human beings is very important. So someplace is going to be necessary in the 21st century, and in my opinion, New York is the best of those someplaces.
 
Leonard S. Riggio
Chief executive, Barnes & Noble
As long as it's still here, New York will still be necessary. And the Internet and e-commerce are not changing that. On the contrary, New York City is on the way to becoming -- is -- the world's greatest shopping center. Retail space is gone, retail rents are at all-time highs, and moving up every day. If anything, the city is threatened with being run over by retailers. The thing we need in our New York City stores now are wall-stretchers.
To me, the Internet is delivering, and it will only get better. Some people and some companies and even some cities may become victims, but New York sure as hell isn't one of them.
 
Ada Louise Huxtable
Architecture critic
I think New York will be absolutely necessary, and I don't think it depends on the architecture. I think it depends on the creative energy of this place; it's not just an economic center, it's an arts center, a place where everybody comes to do creative work, as well as to make a lot of money. And that makes New York unique, and absolutely irreplaceable.
So that if that's the way life is still going to be going in the next century, then it's still going to be necessary.
 
George E. Rupp
President, Columbia University
I am convinced that New York City will be even more essential in the 21st century. Globalization, in the end, enhances the eminence of world cities. Global cities will continue to be irreplaceable as centers for face-to-face interaction, intergovernmental deliberations and international finance and as the indispensable locus for global media and world-class arts and performance. That will only be more the case as the world becomes more interconnected.

Dr. Arnold J. Levine
President, Rockefeller University
There's a study at the Institute of Medicine that I haven't seen in detail, but I've looked at it a little bit, and it actually projects a very rapid growth rise in science here in New York. Universities like Mount Sinai Medical School, Cornell Medical School, Rockefeller University are planning expansions in the biological and medical sciences. There will literally be thousands of new scientists who will be coming into the New York City environment over the next 10 years and who are going to be working in brand new laboratories that are being built.
 
Mike Wallace
Historian, co-author, "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898"
From a planetary perspective, New York has for centuries been a crucial node in the global circulation of capital, labor, information, commodities and cultures. After World War II, we emerged as the center of the capitalist world system, and though we now must share the global spotlight with other world cities, so long as the United States remains the world's dominant economic and military power, New York's status -- and hence, "necessity" -- is not likely to change fundamentally. Still, given the vigorous competition, sustaining our position will require public and private initiatives as smart and bold as our forebears' digging of the Erie Canal.
From a national perspective, the city's "necessity" -- which had waxed steadily from the 1790's -- began to wane after the 1930's, a consequence of the growth of the Federal state, the rise of sunbelt/gunbelt competitors, the loss of manufacturing and commercial pre-eminence, the erosion of hegemony over cultural production. Yet if political competition and disaggregative economic forces have seriously undermined our former national supremacy, we remain a major hub of commerce, finance, business services, fashion, arts, media, specialized manufacturing and tourism. We are well positioned to maintain this status quo, but only if we keep moving, keep building on inherited advantages and seizing upon new possibilities.
From a third, local perspective, New York will continue to be "necessary" for the millions of us who live here. Indeed the city has long thrived in part by generating -- and meeting -- its own vast demand for food, transport, shelter and entertainment. Happily, many of the interventions we should make to maintain and enhance our quality of life will also improve our standing in global and national arenas.
 
Robert A. Caro
Author, "The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York"
Of course New York will be necessary -- for the same reasons it has always been necessary. New York is the melting pot, the great cauldron of the planet. Into it are thrown all of the diverse peoples and cultures of the entire world, and in New York those cultures mix and churn and swirl together. Each of them retains its identity, but somehow out of all of this churning and swirling comes something greater than all of them put together.
The reasons New York fulfills this function have to do, in part, with density and a concentration of peoples. Because there are so many people here, and they live so closely side by side, there are enough of them and enough interactions between them to reach a critical mass that produces a unique vitality, energy, creativity -- an explosion of vitality and creativity, really.
 
Judith Jamison
Artistic director, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater
If great artists still come here, this will still be the place. This is where the world discovers great artists, everybody knows that: New York is for the arts. All those old cliches about how you can play anywhere if you can play New York, they're all true. That won't change.
Anybody who is creative will tell you that they can do it in the dark, in the closet -- wherever they are, they're going to shine. But if you're going to have this brilliance be delivered in Technicolor and in three dimensions, then you have to come to New York.
 
Graciela Daniele
Theater director and choreographer
I don't know whether New York will be necessary -- is any city really necessary? Great cities throughout history, in great cultures -- as great, or many greater than America -- disappeared, and the world continued and new communities were formed some place else. So, taking the big picture, I don't know if the word is necessary.
If nothing catastrophic happens to New York, or to America or to the world, I think New York would always be the point in the world where people will come, like bees in search of pollen.
It is something that appeals to artists from all over the world, and in that sense, I believe it doesn't matter what happens -- corporations coming into the theater, or Disney taking over -- it will always be the place people come to, not for the myth of Broadway, but because it's a very extraordinary cultural island.
 
Shelly Lazarus
Chief executive, Ogilvy & Mather
In advertising, you have to go where people want to live, and creative people love living in New York. There are other places, of course, London, Singapore, for example; Johannesburg and Cape Town are also wonderful sources of talent. But New York is absolutely key for what we deliver to clients. This is a business of ideas, and for ideas you need some stimulation. And if you're looking for stimulation, New York is still the place to be.
 
Nathan Leventhal
President, Lincoln Center
I think New York has always been irreplaceable as the cultural capital of the world. Look around this country today and show me a city that has one-tenth the number of theaters and performance spaces New York has, or even a twentieth. That has not changed in the whole course of the 20th century, nobody has seriously challenged New York in the area of live performance either in this country or around the world, and I suspect that will continue well into the next millennium.
Basically, life everywhere else is a tryout for New York.
 
Lorne Michaels
Executive producer, "Saturday Night Live"
New York is kind of a mythic city, a place where just about anything can happen, and where almost nothing is shocking -- both the worst and the best.
Will it still be necessary in the future? It depends on whether you think frustration is good for people.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 7; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;
An Immigrant's View, the Art of Trash, a Phantom's Lair: All Between Covers in 1999

 BODY:

'TIS
By Frank McCourt
Scribner
(Hardcover, $26)
The first officer told me Albany was a city far up the Hudson River, capital of New York State. He said Albany had all the charm of Limerick, ha ha ha, a great place to die but not a place where you'd want to get married or rear children. He was from Dublin and knew I was from Limerick and when he sneered at Limerick I didn't know what to do. I'd like to destroy him with a smart remark but then I'd look at myself in the mirror, pimply face, sore eyes, and bad teeth and know I could never stand up to anyone, especially a first officer with a uniform and a promising future as master of his own ship. Then I'd say to myself, Why should I care what anyone says about Limerick anyway? All I had there was misery. 
 Then the peculiar thing would happen. I'd sit on a deck chair in the lovely October sun with the gorgeous blue Atlantic all around me and try to imagine what New York would be like. I'd try to see Fifth Avenue or Central Park or Greenwich Village where everyone looked like movie stars, powerful tans, gleaming white teeth. But Limerick would push me into the past. Instead of me sauntering up Fifth Avenue with the tan, the teeth, I'd be back in the lanes of Limerick, women standing at doors chatting away and pulling their shawls around their shoulders, children with faces dirty from bread and jam, playing and laughing and crying to their mothers.
 
WASTE AND WANT: A SOCIAL HISTORY OF TRASH
By Susan Strasser
Metropolitan Books
(Hardcover, $27.50)
Artists employed found materials to make statements specifically about the environment and about the connections between trash and consumerism. Jac Leirner, a Brazilian artist, used airplane boarding passes and plastic shopping bags from museum shops around the world. "Can Man," a New York Performance artist named Gene Pool, rode up to public places on his unicycle, wearing a suit made of five hundred aluminum cans. Mierle Laderman Ukeles, the unsalaried artist-in-residence of New York's Department of Sanitation, constructed "Ceremonial Arch Honoring Service Workers in the New Service Economy" from the castoffs of the city's public sevice agencies, including gauges from the Fresh Kills landfill, mailbags, police walkie-talkies, street cleaning brushes, and hundreds of used gloves. Trash was Ukeles's topic as well as her medium; her other pieces included "Touch Sanitation" (1979-80), an eleven-month performance in which she shook hands with all eighty-five hundred of the city's sanitation workers, and "The Social Mirror" (1983), a sanitation truck resurfaced in mirrors.
 
THE PHANTOM OF MANTHATTAN
By Frederick Forsyth
St. Martin's Press
(Hardcover, $30)
Every day, summer or winter, rain or shine, I rise early. I dress and come up from my quarters to this small square rooftop terrace atop the pinnacle of the highest skyscraper in all New York. From here, depending upon which side of the square I stand, I can look west across the Hudson River toward the open green lands of New Jersey. Or north towards the midtown and uptown sections of this amazing island so full of wealth and filth, extravagance and poverty, vice and crime. Or south towards the open sea, which leads back to Europe and the bitter road I have traveled. Or east across the river to Brooklyn and, lost in the sea mist, the lunatic enclave called Coney Island, the original source of my wealth.
And, I, who spent seven years terrorized by a brutish father, nine an animal chained in a cage, eleven an outcast in the cellars below the Paris Opera and ten fighting my way up from the fish-gutting sheds of Gravesend Bay to this eminence, know that I now have wealth and power beyond the dreams of Croesus. So I look down on this sprawling city and I think: how I hate and despise you, Human Race.

He graduated from the Catholic University of America and is studying for a master's degree in public policy from Trinity College in Hartford. His father is a judge on the Connecticut Appellate Court in Hartford. The bridegroom's mother teaches English at Northwest Catholic High School in West Hartford.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Revolution Built In Mr. Ford's Factory

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
IN 1942, in the face of the bloody tyrannies and colonial empires that covered nearly the entire globe, Aaron Copland composed "Fanfare for the Common Man." How defiant, even naive, it looked then. How prescient it looks now.
For all the real power that political rulers, corporate masters and technological forces have over our lives, the century just ended (I know, I know: supposedly another year to go) was shaped more than anything else by the passions and desires of millions upon millions of ordinary men and women. 
 Think how unprecedented that was. Before 1900, the middle class in Europe and the United States was a relative drop in the bucket -- mostly small merchants and a sprinkling of professionals; it scarcely existed elsewhere in the world. Few industrial workers earned a living wage. The largest group of people, even in the most advanced countries, still worked the land from dawn to dusk. Domestic servants of the rich were another big part of the work force.
Aristocracies and caste systems were the order of the day. Genuinely representative democracy existed in only a handful of countries, and even in those, all women and many men, including nearly all blacks in the United States, were barred from voting.
For all our worries today about economic inequality, wealth in the era before World War I was really concentrated. "In the half-century before 1914, most capital flows traced back to a few thousand wealthy European families," David Hale, chief global economist for Zurich Financial Services in Chicago, recently wrote. "Today they are driven by fund managers allocating the savings of hundreds of millions of people in pension funds and mutual funds."
WHAT brought about this revolutionary change, in which workers themselves came to own much of the means of production? Many things, of course, including the spread of democratic practices and public education. And one product above all others powered this transformation: the automobile, built on a moving assembly line.
At the turn of the century, the horseless carriage was widely derided: contemporary observers said it was simply a plaything for the rich, a machine to impress the ladies. But in 1908, Henry Ford introduced the Model T. And in paying his workers what was then the princely wage of $5 a day to make a car selling for $850, he helped create a consumer mass market at the same time he was offering something to satisfy it. The combination released a torrent.
"The mass-production automobile broke all the traditional boundaries that held people in place," said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates and author of "The Prize," a Pulitzer Prize-winning history of the oil industry. "Everywhere you go, it represents independence, mobility, freedom."
So, before we bury the 20th century, let us praise its essential icon. For despite the environmental ills that cars have brought in their exhaust trail, nothing else so represents the empowerment of ordinary people.
Mr. Ford knew exactly what he was after. "I will build a motor car for the great multitude," he said, "constructed of the best materials, by the best men to be hired, after the simplest designs that modern engineering can devise." It would be, he added, "so low in price that no man making a good salary will be unable to own one and enjoy with his family the blessings of hours of pleasure in God's great open spaces."
Well, maybe he miscalculated a bit on the open spaces. Our bottomless demand to own and drive automobiles has transformed the landscape almost beyond recognition, inexorably producing the highways we crowd onto and the suburbs where most of us in America now choose to live.
For all the attention devoted to computers and the Internet, the auto industry still defies comparison. Roughly 7.5 million people, about 6 percent of the American work force, are involved in building, selling or repairing cars and light trucks, almost four times as many as are employed by all electronics and computer makers. Three of the four largest companies in the nation by sales -- General Motors, Ford and Exxon Mobil -- make cars or fuel them. In 1999, Americans bought a record 17 million of the vehicles.
The phenomenon is global; there are more than 550 million cars around the world. Americans own the most -- one car for every 1.7 residents -- but even in crowded Japan there is one for every 2.1 people, and there is one for every 5.3 Britons.
Do all these automobiles represent too much of a good thing? Perhaps, but good luck persuading people to stop buying them. No matter what is done in the form of taxes or regulation to discourage their use, as soon as incomes in any nation reach a certain level -- on average, around $6,000 a person -- sales of cars invariably skyrocket.
In the United States, higher gasoline taxes would at least encourage the production of more efficient autos and slightly restrain driving. New technologies, like electric/internal-combustion hybrids and, eventually, fuel cells, should help further reduce the air pollution they cause. But don't expect more.
As long as democracy and free markets persist, personal transportation in some form will be ubiquitous. Why? Because that's the way we want it.
