HEADLINE: Digital Commerce;
An unregulated Internet may be exaggerating the movements on globalized, fluid financial markets.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
AFTER a year of big gambles, the biggest of all may be the wager that our exalted Internet, held together with baling wire and chewing gum in every conceivable way -- legally, structurally, economically -- is going to be able to withstand the coming heavy weather of a truly global, unregulated economy.
Or perhaps the question is whether we will be able to withstand a global, unregulated Internet. 
 In either case, here at ground zero -- in the United States, capital of global capitalism -- stock market experts are beginning to acknowledge what some of us have suspected for a long time: technology stocks, in particular, are being kept aloft on their own hot air.
People buy them because they are performing better than regular stocks; they are performing better than regular stocks because people keep buying them.
And the mystery surrounding Internet stock valuations -- what are the criteria? -- may have been solved last week by Michael Mauboussin, the chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The more popular the World Wide Web site, he declared, the higher its "ranking," the more the company is worth.
Just like in high school: Web sites with the highest valuations are like football captains or cheerleaders, whose top-of-the-chart popularity ratings give them far greater currency in the social order than, for example, the shy, geeky nerds who may excel in art or science.
Upon these things our new economy is built.
Now take this relatively microcosmic situation -- that the Internet stock market in the United States is a popularity contest, based on consumer moods and filled with millions of networked investors bluffing the financial markets like a poker game -- and consider what the ripple effect might be on an expanding global economy.
In so doing, some big thinkers -- most notably, Manuel Castells, author in 1998 of "The Information Age: Economy, Society and Culture" -- start to get a little skittish about our big Internet gamble. In an essay titled, "Information Technology and Global Capitalism," Mr. Castells presents a chilling argument:
As a result of the globalization of largely unregulated and increasingly fluid financial markets, he says, "we may have created an automaton." By that, he means "an electronic-based system of financial transactions which overwhelms controls and regulations by governments, international institutions and private financial firms, as well as individual investors, consumer and citizens."
Mr. Castells' essay is included in a book to be published in London early this year called "On the Edge: Essays on a Runaway World," edited by Anthony Giddens, the director of the London School of Economics, and Will Hutton, the editor of The Observer in London.
Mr. Castells does not mean the term "automaton" literally. There are as yet few instances of financial transactions fully automated beyond the bounds of human intervention -- particularly after computer programs helped induce the stock market crash of October 1987 and the Securities and Exchange Commission began setting some limits on program trading.
But he cites a trend toward the computerization of trading systems: Nasdaq in the United States; Eurex in the German bond market; M, the French futures exchange; the London International Financial Futures Exchange, and private trading networks like Instinet, owned by Reuters.
Mr. Castells argues that these increasingly interconnected electronic networks, combined with domestic deregulation, the liberal flow of financial transactions across national borders and a constant, international flow of market-related news and information over the Internet make a "nightmare" of watching machines take control seem "on the edge of becoming reality."
The idea of networked computers with minds of their own is not new. But the computers envisioned in science fiction may belong to Mensa, the social network for those with the highest I.Q.'s; the network of Mr. Castells' nightmare is a dumb brute, knee-jerking to information turbulences that are amplified by inputs from millions of individual investors, creating ever-greater complexity and volatility.
The automaton is only the first problem that Mr. Castells cites for the future of today's go-go Internet economy.
Although American industry has managed to gut its labor movement, he says, Europe and Japan are less thrilled about the potential for "productivity" technology that first takes away jobs, then dismantles government supports.
Whether we like it or not, he continues, if they believe that network technology will do either of these things, "there will be a backlash of social struggles, and political reactions, that will simply block reform and innovation."
And because the United States is now interdependent on global economic performance, such a backlash "will ultimately exhaust the growth capacity of the U.S. economy," he warns.
Mr. Castells' belief, which is bound to be deeply unpopular in the United States, is that healthy global capitalism requires global financial regulations. Further, he argues that those regulations must take into account not only technological productivity and growth spurred by capital investment but also "socio-institutional engineering" that respects, values and includes people and cultures.
Virtually no one in the United States government, and certainly no one who is rolling in Internet clover, wants to touch this issue. Why would they? The United States is far and away the world leader in the information industries. And access to more and more global markets -- in part by dismantling regulations and government controls -- has been one of the hallmarks of the Clinton administration.
We ignore such issues at our own peril, Mr. Castells says. The fragility of global capitalism is such that a new round of instability, "perhaps induced by the collapse of Internet stocks, or by a sudden panic around electronic trading networks," he writes, could trigger a stampede toward the exits.
But this time, "there could be governments or significant segments of society opting out of global capitalism," he suggests -- "not necessarily to build an alternative system, but just to recover some degree of control over their lives and values."

HEADLINE: Euro Is Seen Rising Against Dollar

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, said today that he expected the euro to rise against the dollar this year as the European economy grows faster than that of the United States.
"We expect the euro to recover in the course of the year," Mr. Duisenberg said in an interview with the Dutch television program "Buitenhof." 
 Mr. Duisenberg said that he did not expect the euro to fall below $1 and that he thought the euro's exchange rate would "go in the other direction this year" after falling to $1.009 from a starting rate of $1.16 in 1999.
The euro's expected recovery will be the result of stronger economic growth in the 11 countries using the euro than in the United States this year as well as next, he said.
Unexpectedly strong economic growth in the United States in 1999 led to the dollar's appreciation against the euro, which had already fallen from a high start-up level, Mr. Duisenberg said.
"We began the euro at a level that was much higher than it had been in the previous two years," he said. "Due to the 'europhoria' that arose from the fact that it was really going to happen, it was a little overestimated -- the average level in 1997 and 1998 was $1.08."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Business Day, Part Two: The Year in the Markets
The story of the financial markets in 1999 was of stocks that flew higher than at any time over the last decade. Enough of them soared that the major market indexes all closed the year at record highs. 
 And yet, all that prosperity hid some weakness. With interest rates rising and oil prices soaring, many stocks struggled. The Nasdaq composite index leaped 85.6 percent -- a performance that exceeded the gain for any major index in any year. But there were a lot of Nasdaq losers as well. Coverage of the year in stocks, including tables, starts on Page C17.
 
F.C.C. to Pick Chief Technologist
The Federal Communications Commission plans to announce today that it has appointed David J. Farber, a pioneering computer scientist and telecommunications expert, as the agency's chief technologist. Mr. Farber, a University of Pennsylvania professor, drew attention last year when he served as a Justice Department expert witness in the bitter Microsoft antitrust trial. C6.
 
The Peril of Direct Internet Sales
Just as Amazon.com has led millions of would-be entrepreneurs toward the e-commerce promised land, so too has the success of Dell Computer led countless manufacturers to believe that their future success rides on the ability to sell directly to consumers over the Internet. But manufacturers who have ventured onto the Web have found that unless they can convince their retail partners and distributors they are not out to steal sales from them, bad things can happen to the bottom line. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C7.
 
St. Petersburg Times Pays Off Debt
The company that publishes The St. Petersburg Times has paid off a $30 million debt to the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, the nonprofit group that owns it, ensuring the durability of one of the country's most unusual newspaper ownership arrangements. C13.
 
Israel Bank Chief to Stay a Week
Jacob Frenkel, the chief of Israel's central bank, who was to have stepped down, agreed to stay another week while Prime Minister Ehud Barak continues to look for a successor. C12.
 
Web Stocks as Popularity Contest
Stock market experts are beginning to acknowledge what many have suspected for a long time: technology stocks are being kept aloft on their own hot air. The mystery surrounding the stock valuations may have been solved last week by the chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, who declared that the more popular the Web site, the higher its "ranking" and the more the company is worth. Digital Commerce. C4.
 
U.S. Markets Resume Regular Hours
United States stock and bond markets, which closed early on Friday for the New Year's holiday, will return to regular hours today. Many markets in Asia and some markets in Europe are closed today.

HEADLINE: Internet Pioneer to Be Named Top F.C.C.Technologist

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission plans to announce today that it has appointed a pioneering computer scientist and telecommunications expert as the agency's chief technologist.
The appointee, David J. Farber, a University of Pennsylvania professor, drew attention last year when he served as a Justice Department expert witness in the Microsoft antitrust trial. 
 Mr. Farber, who is currently the Alfred Fitler Moore Professor of Telecommunications Systems at the University of Pennsylvania, will keep his teaching position there even after moving to Washington to work full-time for the F.C.C. later this month.
A pioneer of the Internet, Mr. Farber helped develop the first electronic telephone switches while at Bell Laboratories in the 1960's. During the 1970's, he conducted ground-breaking work in networked computing systems at the University of California at Irvine.
Notably outspoken on technology policy issues, Mr. Farber is perhaps best known in the Internet community for his influential e-mail distribution list, which he calls "Interesting People." To about 25,000 people each day he sends tidbits of information, forwarded from other e-mails and a steady stream of his own thoughts and opinions.
An inveterate traveler and a self-described gadget freak, Mr. Farber has been known to brief his e-mail correspondents on such adventures as his visit to Akihabara, the high-technology shopping district in Tokyo.
In a telephone interview on Saturday, Mr. Farber said that he would be allowed to maintain his list while working for the F.C.C. "I couldn't have accepted the job otherwise," he said.
As a government witness at the Microsoft trial last year, Mr. Farber argued against one of Microsoft's main contentions: that the way the company had chosen to integrate its browser software into its Windows operating system was the only possible technical alternative.
"In general, designers have a huge amount of flexibility in how to package these files, the same way you have a large amount of flexibility in how you put things in a grocery bag, as long as you don't crush stuff," he said in court. "Software is infinitely malleable."
His point rebutted Microsoft's argument that its decision to integrate its browser into the operating system was purely technical and not motivated by a desire to cripple the company's competition.
Mr. Farber, 65, said that he would get involved in a variety of technology issues at the F.C.C., including high-speed and wireless networks, and the impact of the Internet on media the agency now regulates.
"There is a struggle for radio spectrum," he said, "and that is one of the issues we will have to grapple with." Another focus will be the convergence of communications and computing technologies and the infusion of Internet technology into the nation's communications system.
One of the first to understand and speak out on the social, political and economic implications of the Internet, Mr. Farber has maintained a quirky sense of independence from many of the bureaucratic positions of both large high technology companies and governments.
For a time recently, his e-mail carried the following tag line, alluding to the movement of electronic information: "Photons have neither morals or visas."

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE MARKETS;
1999: Extraordinary Winners and More Losers

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
When they were hot, they were very, very hot. But when they were not, they were losers.
The story of the stock market in 1999 was of stocks that flew higher than at any time in the last decade. Enough of them soared that the major market indexes all closed the year at record highs. The best-performing stocks leaped not by hundreds, but by thousands of percentage points. Applying that standard, it was the year of the decade. 
 And yet, all that prosperity hid some weaknesses. With interest rates rising and oil prices soaring, many stocks struggled. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 19.5 percent during the year, but more issues in the index fell than rose.
The Nasdaq composite index leaped 85.6 percent -- a performance that exceeded the gain for any major index in any year in the history of stock markets in the United States. But there were a lot of Nasdaq losers as well, and the index of financial stocks listed on that market ended the year down 9 percent.
To appreciate just how great a year it was for the winners, compare Qualcomm, the best-performing stock of 1999 (among those that began the year over $5 a share) with the top performers of previous years. Qualcomm rose 2,619 percent in 1999. Twelve other stocks on Nasdaq that started the year over $5 managed to climb at least 1,000 percent. A further seven issues rose at least 900 percent.
By contrast, in the first nine years of the decade, only one such stock ever rose as much as 900 percent in a year. That was Amazon.com, which soared 966 percent in 1998.
Perhaps the most amazing stock of the year was Xcelera.com, formerly known as Scandinavia. Once a closed-end fund specializing in Scandinavian stocks, and then an operating company that owned a hotel in the Canary Islands, it made a small investment in an Internet company last year. Before it disclosed that investment, the family of Alexander Vik, the company's chief executive, was given options to buy a million shares of stock, at a price of $3.25 each. The shares ended 1998 at $3.75, or $1.25 adjusted for two subsequent splits. They ended 1999 at $139.50, an increase of 11,060 percent. The Viks' option position is now valued at $415 million.
There was also no shortage of hot initial public offerings in 1999. Where it once was deemed embarrassing for an offering to double during the first day, since it indicated that the underwriter had underestimated demand and failed to get the best deal for the company going public, it now seems to be a badge of honor.
Just why that should be so is an interesting question. Perhaps companies think that the amount of money being raised is relatively small compared to the prestige of having a stock deemed to be hot, and figure that in any case, they can always raise more capital later. Perhaps they are happy to be able to provide a quick profit for friends and family members allowed to buy shares at the offering price.
Or perhaps the market is just too hot for the underwriters to deal with. Last month, Goldman, Sachs tripled the planned offering price for FreeMarkets, one of a number of companies trying to find a niche helping businesses get better deals, at lower transaction costs, by using the Internet. Priced at $48 a share, up from a planned range of $14 to $16, the shares leaped to $290 the first day and ended the year at $341.31.
General Motors was involved in two initial public offerings during the year. One was for a company with a long business history that included substantial profit. Buyers in that deal suffered. The other had almost no history. It became one of the most successful offerings of the year.
The poor performer was Delphi Automotive Systems, G.M.'s parts operations. It went public in February at $17 a share and ended the year down 7 percent, at $15.75.
The other offering was Commerce One, a company hoping to prosper in the business-to-business Internet arena, and which G.M. has agreed to use to buy products from suppliers. Commerce One went public in July at $7 a share (adjusted for a subsequent split), closed the first day at $20.33 and ended the year at $196.50, for a gain from the offering price of 2,707 percent.
G.M. hopes to save money by buying through Commerce One, but it will be a long time, if ever, before its savings from those purchases equal its paper profit on its investment in Commerce One. It has an option to buy 14.4 million shares of Commerce One -- now valued at $2.8 billion -- for a total price of $480.
Commerce One's offering was the second most successful of 1999, in terms of performance from the offering price, according to calculations by Thomson Financial/Securities Data. The winner was the Internet Capital Group, a company that invests in other Internet companies. It more than doubled its first day of trading, Aug. 5, and that was just the beginning.
By the time the year ended, the stock was at $170 a share, even after splitting two for one. That compared with an offering price, adjusted for the split, of $6, and a first-day close of $12.22. The company, which since its inception in 1996 has reported losses of $112 million on revenue of $15 million, now has a market value of $44 billion.
Some initial offerings that looked great the first day, however, soon looked quite ill. Value America, an Internet retailer, went public in April at $23 a share and traded as high as $74.25 the first day. It ended the year at $5.06 after announcing plans to lay off many of its employees. Another retailer, eToys, ended the year at $26.25, above its offering price of $20, but far below the high of $86 reached in October.
The size of the moves made by the winners reflects the speculative fever gripping the market and is based on hopes that as the Internet transforms the economy, companies that did not exist a few years ago will become giants.
In all that, the example of Yahoo, one of the first of the Internet companies to go public, stands out as the shining example. It more than doubled the day it went public -- April 15, 1996 -- and within a few months had fallen back to the offering price. But an investor who put $1,000 into the stock at the close of trading that first day, and held on, would now have stock worth $80,500. That is more than 10 times as much as someone who bought Microsoft the day it went public in 1986 would have had after the same amount of time.

As if to gloat, the market's new eight-story, $37 million electronic sign began glowing on Times Square in late December.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE MARKETS;
Foreign Stocks Outperformed U.S. Equities

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Americans have not shopped abroad for stocks with fervor since 1993. And the truth is, they have had little need to wander the globe.
Last year, the three major American stock indexes produced double-digit returns for the fifth consecutive year -- an unprecedented feat -- and the technology-heavy Nasdaq index popped off the charts. 
 But investors with wanderlust were probably rewarded in 1999. After running ahead of the pack for four years, the American stock market trailed the foreign market average. From 1995 to 1998, United States stocks outperformed those elsewhere by an average of 22.9 percentage points a year, according to performance indexes compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International.
Last year, though, the rest of the world's stock markets, taken as a whole, rose 28.8 percent, ahead of the 20.9 percent gain in the United States, according to Morgan Stanley.
Stocks in emerging markets rebounded from a dismal 1998 to lead the way with a gain of 63.7 percent. Europe, which was fairly competitive with the United States in 1997 and 1998, did well again for local investors. But the unexpected decline of Europe's new 11-nation currency, the euro, against the dollar, eroded most of the gains for American investors. The Morgan Stanley index of the 11 euro markets and Britain, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland rose 14.1 percent in dollar terms last year. In local currency, the index gained 27.9 percent.
Still, the big surprise was Japan, where stocks rose 60.6 percent in dollar terms. From its high at the end of 1989, the Japanese stock market plunged 58 percent in dollar terms to its low in October 1998. Even with last year's rally, Japanese stocks were still 16.1 percent below their 1989 peak in dollar terms.
With the exception of Japanese equities, Americans have been selling more foreign stocks than they have been buying recently.
But that could change. Many Americans are noticing that their portfolios are not doing as well as the big-name stock indexes might suggest. At the end of 1999, according to Salomon Smith Barney, about two-thirds of the stocks on the New York Stock Exchange were at least 20 percent below their 52-week highs.
And a failure of American stock indexes to meet investors' expectations could spur more portfolio adjustments.
Abby Joseph Cohen, market strategist at Goldman Sachs, said opportunities in foreign markets could attract American investors. "First, if U.S. returns are good, not great, investors may be willing to move out along the perceived risk curve," she wrote in her outlook for 2000. "Second, global economic conditions are less worrisome than they have been in recent years."
The rally last year in emerging markets was powered by a faster-than-expected improvement in local economies.
Among the best performers in dollar terms were: Russia, up 246.2 percent; Turkey, up 244.4 percent; Malaysia, 111.6 percent; Indonesia, 92 percent; South Korea, 90.2 percent; India, 84.7; and Brazil, 73 percent. Except for South Korea, all those markets had fallen sharply in 1998. Russia's stock index, in dollar terms, is still 141 percent from its 1997 high, although it rallied sharply New Year's Eve on the news of President Boris N. Yeltsin's resignation.
The leading performers among major companies in emerging markets were: Infosys Technologies of India, up 858.3 percent; SK Telecom of South Korea, up 620.9 percent; and United Microelectronics of Taiwan, up 228.5 percent.
Some analysts contend that these markets, which suffered during the global financial crisis of 1997 and 1998, should outdo Wall Street this year, though past performance does not guarantee future returns.
Jay Pelosky, the global emerging markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said that gains could become more concentrated in a few big and well-known companies, mirroring some of the shift to a narrow group of leaders in the American stock market. "The top 100 stocks in the Morgan Stanley emerging markets index have already significantly outperformed the rest of the stocks in the index this year," he said.
The surge in European stocks was led by technology, media and telecommunications companies, as was the American stock market. Over the last three months, the technology, media and telecommunications stocks in a Merrill Lynch index of European stocks have jumped 57 percent while the rest of the stocks in the index are up just 6 percent.
The top gainers included: Nokia of Finland, up 194.7 percent; Ericsson of Sweden, up 168.9 percent; and Deutsche Telekom of Germany, up 116.3 percent. The best markets, in dollar terms, were: Finland, up 150.7 percent, France, up 28 percent; and Germany, up 18.7 percent. Italy fell 1.5 percent, while Belgium plunged 15.8 percent.
This year could be more difficult for European stocks if, as some analysts expect, the rebound in economic growth is strong enough to force the European Central Bank to raise interest rates. Higher rates make financing more costly for companies and serve to depress corporate profits.
"We are reasonably cautious on the European market for the year," said Plum Shipton, the European equity strategist for Merrill Lynch in London, because of the threat of higher interest rates and the already high valuation of the stock market.
In Japan, investors began scrambling back into stocks as the government worked to shore up the banking system and as the first signs of economic recovery appeared. The rush of mutual fund managers and institutional investors -- who had ignored Japan for years -- was one of the more important market moves of 1999. Their purchases of Japanese stocks increased demand for the yen and pushed the currency to a four-year high against the dollar. The yen's surge forced the Japanese government to intervene repeatedly in the currency markets in a futile attempt to curb the currency's rise, lest Japanese exports be priced out of foreign markets.
Like Europe and the United States, much of the stock rally in Japan has come on the back of technology and telecommunications stocks. And like Europe, Japan provided a currency lesson for American investors. In this case, it was a positive one, with about 25 percent of the returns posted by American investors coming from the rise in the yen.
Among the big stocks to post outsized gains were the Softbank Corporation, up 1,485 percent, but still well below its 1996 high, and the Kyocera Corporation, up 389.2 percent.
Elizabeth Allan, a senior vice president and longtime Japan watcher at Scudder Kemper Investments, said the pace of economic growth bears watching. "Many Japanese are still worried about losing their jobs," she said, and that fear is dampening the consumer spending needed to push the economy ahead.
"Increased consumer spending is key for a second leg of the economic recovery," she added.

HEADLINE: Essay;
McCain Could Win

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A sea change has taken place in the American election system without our noticing it. The "independentation" of the primaries will determine our next president.
In olden times -- a decade or so ago -- state primary elections were often battlegrounds for partisans within each party. Liberal Democrats would wrestle with "new" or "blue dog" Democrats to choose candidates, just as economic conservatives would joust with social conservatives to pick G.O.P. nominees. Nor was it only ideological: Young Turks would go up against entrenched leadership. 
 There was a tidiness to this. Voters were given an incentive to join a party: by signing up, you could vote twice -- first to choose your party's nominee and then for whomever you preferred in the general election. Independents didn't get to vote in the primaries.
It's all been changing. In the crucial early primaries of the next seven weeks, unaligned voters -- not hard-core party regulars nor activists in organized pressure groups of left and right -- will decide the nominees of both parties.
This was unplanned. It has given an unremarked kick in the head to the two-party system. The generation-old rise of the primary was supposed to devolve power from party bosses to party members. But this year the opening of both parties' gates is transforming presidential politics. No party registration is required in the three launch-pad states. Independent voters will be decisive in choosing party standard-bearers.
In New Hampshire, independents may vote in either party's primary, which is why both Bill Bradley and John McCain are polling so well against the party establishments' Al Gore and George W. Bush. The bigger the independent turnout, the likelier a pair of insurgent victories.
In South Carolina -- Bush's "firewall state" in case McCain beats him in New Hampshire -- there also is no party registration. Jennifer Martin Donohue of WNDS-TV in New Hampshire, a distant cousin who awakened me to this phenomenon, reports that the South Carolina G.O.P. expects a turnout of 300,000 this year, 5 percent more than in 1996. Polls of Republicans have been showing Bush with a four-to-one lead.
That's largely because pollsters fail to take into account the new political paradigm. One-third of S.C.'s two million voters are habitual switchers, and the only primary action this year is Republican on Feb. 19 (the Democratic "firehouse caucuses" come weeks later).
Bush is counting on the previous governor's "machine" and on Pat Robertson's marshaling of the religious right's support of soft money. But McCain has Representative Lindsey Graham, the most popular figure in the state, saying that campaign finance reform bolsters sound conservative government.
The state's 400,000 veterans -- highest percentage anywhere -- are largely independents. All they have to do to become eligible on primary day is to declare a G.O.P. preference.
Then comes Michigan, also with no party registration, which has its G.O.P. primary three days later on Feb. 22. Again, Bush is heavily favored because Bushie Gov. John Engler has the party machinery. But any of Michigan's two million independents charged up by coverage of a South Carolina upset can walk in and become a Republican for a day.
Michigan's Democratic caucuses should be duck soup for Gore, with his union backing. But Bradley's secret weapon is the mail-in ballot: any independent (who may have voted for McCain two weeks before) can send in a ballot declaring Democratic preference and choosing Bradley. Those "absentee" votes probably will count. (This recalls Jack Valenti's "When I die, bury me in Texas because I want to remain politically active.")
What will the addition of the new "party temporaries" to the old-fashioned party regulars mean to 2000's primaries? Gore and Bush strategists will deplore "the invasion of the party snatchers" because they know it will strengthen Bradley and McCain -- by how much, nobody knows. But certainly on the G.O.P. side, the coming three-state unregistered ramble requires a re-thinking of Philadelphia Conventional wisdom.
McCain, by virtue of the wide-openness of the three launch-pad primaries, is no longer a long shot. And if independents in party clothing do help make the happy hero the G.O.P. nominee, McCain could claim to be more likely than Bush to beat the Democrat. (Unless it's the maverick Bradley. Then everything's up for grabs.)

HEADLINE: THE YEAR 2000: THE WORKERS;
For Year 2000 Fix-It Crew, New Tasks or No Jobs

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
When Paul J. Maszczak was tapped more than three years ago to head his company's Year 2000 computer repairs, he recalled, "I considered it the kiss of death." Instead of developing new software using the latest technology, he would be relegated to fixing programs written years or decades earlier.
But Mr. Maszczak now says that becoming Year 2000 manager at C. R. Bard Inc., a medical device manufacturer in Murray Hill, N.J., was one of the best moves in his 30-year career in data processing. The job lifted him out of the narrow confines of the information technology department, exposing him to all aspects of his company's business. 
 Now, with those efforts winding down, Mr. Maszczak thinks his broader business knowledge has prepared him for a bigger management job. As for day-to-day systems work, "I could never go back," he said. Now, he said, "we're free agents."
The year 2000 has finally arrived, and the vast Y2K repair corps is being scattered to the winds, having apparently saved the world from the widespread disasters once feared.
But while there is relief that few Year 2000 problems emerged over the weekend, some Y2K workers, having completed a task that has long consumed them, must now struggle with what to do next.
Like Mr. Maszczak, some workers expect to go on to bigger and better things. Most others are simply going back to previous jobs, as corporate information processing departments return to work put aside in their race to repair Year 2000 flaws. Yet for many, the end of the readiness efforts means the end of their jobs.
For Randall Bart, for instance, Year 2000 work proved to be a short-lived bonanza. After being laid off from Unisys, the computer maker, in 1988, Mr. Bart did not find work as a programmer until 10 years later, when Y2K made what he calls his "obsolete experience" worth $45 an hour. But his last job ended in August and Mr. Bart, 43, who lives in Los Angeles, has been unable to find work since.
"I'm hoping for some big disaster somewhere to hit," he said, only half joking.
To be sure, Year 2000 work is not ending abruptly. It has been ratcheting down for months, and thousands of people have already been dismissed, but work will continue because computer problems might still arise over the coming months.
Howard Rubin, a consultant and head of the computer science department at Hunter College in New York, who surveyed big corporations about their preparedness activities, estimates that as many as a fourth of the two million information technology workers in big companies in the United States did Y2K repairs at one time or another.
Of course, computer people are not the only ones who got involved. Many others were swept up in the effort -- contacting suppliers and customers to assess their readiness, surveying factory machinery, planning for contingencies and so on.
All told, many millions of people throughout the world were involved in Year 2000 preparations in one way or another.
Many people profited handsomely, taking their share of the more than $250 billion the world is estimated to have spent to enable computers and other electronic machinery to recognize that a year can begin with 20 instead of 19.
"It absolutely made our company," said Peter A. Allen, president of Data Dimensions Inc., a computer consulting concern that grew from $1 million in annual revenues in the early 1990's to $115 million in 1998, 80 percent of it from Year 2000 work.
But that work has already slowed significantly, and the Bellevue, Wash., company has laid off about 300 of its 850 workers.
Mr. Allen said the customer contacts and skills the company has developed doing Year 2000 work will help it move into other areas, like electronic commerce. But investors are not so sure. Data Dimension's stock price has fallen from almost $40 in late 1997 to under $3 today.
About two years ago, there were predictions that the world would not have enough programmers to scan billions of lines of code and fix any date problems. Some programmers were lured out of retirement to fix programs they had written decades earlier, and there was even talk of enlisting prison inmates.
In fact, salaries for programmers and systems analysts did jump, and many companies offered retention bonuses to keep programmers from jumping ship until well into 2000. Union Bank of California, for instance, gave Year 2000 workers bonuses equal to 10 percent of their salaries in 1998 and 1999. Those who stay until March will be eligible for an additional bonus equal to 20 percent of their salaries.
But the great shortage never materialized. Many companies that were started to do Year 2000 work for others got far less business than they had anticipated. While early predictions were that repairs would cost $1 or $2 for each line of code, prices dropped to 25 cents a line or even lower. And many retirees did not find jobs.
One reason is that the repairs turned out to be less complex than imagined, in part because software was developed to help automate the process. Indeed, the Year 2000 was quickly transformed from a problem involving older computer programs to a generalized business, political and legal issue as companies wrestled with contingency planning, supplier and customer relationships and questions of legal liability and public relations.
"The code really has been the smallest issue in all of this," said Lou Marcoccio, research director at the Gartner Group, another consulting company. In many companies, he said, the nonprogrammers working on the problem outnumbered the programmers.
Ultimately, companies were able to handle it, even if they occasionally had to strain to do so.
Mr. Rubin, the consultant, said that on average, big companies spent about 10 percent of their information technology budgets over three years of Year 2000 repairs, although for peak periods, the issue consumed as much as half the computer budgets of some. Merrill Lynch, for instance, spent $520 million over several years on its Year 2000 effort, but the brokerage firm spends $3.2 billion a year on information technology.
Most companies did the job in-house, even if it meant pushing other work aside. It was cheaper that way and the company's own programmers were most familiar with the software that had to be fixed. Edison International, which owns Southern California Edison, did its Year 2000 work for $70 million after rejecting a contractor's offer to do it for $171 million, said Eric Trapp, who managed the job for the utility.
Some companies contracted work to firms in India, where wages are lower. But some industry officials say there was also less of that than had been predicted.
For repair companies and individual programmers wondering what to do next, the good news is there is an overall shortage of computer people, especially as software work postponed to deal with the Year 2000 problem moves back up priority lists. The bad news is that the greatest demand is for designers of Internet software, especially for electronic retailing; the expertise of most Year 2000 companies and workers lies in older computers and programs, known as legacy systems.
"These people built up the Latin of technology," Mr. Rubin said.
Still if the episode taught the world anything, it is that these legacy systems are vital and are not going away soon. There is still much work to be done on them, including enabling them to connect to Internet software. And many companies have put off these other jobs to focus on the Year 2000 problem.
"We've been building up a really nice backlog of things to do," said Lee Kirkpatrick, senior vice president and Year 2000 manager for Union Bank, who said the priority would shift to electronic commerce.
Merrill Lynch rushed to finish most Year 2000 work by June 30 so it could devote more resources to designing its online stock trading system, said John McKinley, the brokerage firm's chief technology officer. Now, he said, former Year 2000 programmers are being put on jobs like getting the company ready for 24-hour stock exchanges and decimalization of stock prices.
With Y2K, computer professionals, often stereotyped as geeks and loners, found themselves the life of the party, sought out by laymen friends for counsel on whether the world was really going to end on Jan. 1. More people within corporations and in society came to appreciate the importance of their work.
But the limelight was not always comfortable. After all, programmers created the Year 2000 problem by representing years using two digits instead of four, a tactic that seemed rational in the early days of computing as a way to conserve scarce processing and data storage capacity. If Jan. 1 had brought a rash of mishaps, the computer profession would have faced even more criticism for shoddy work, and perhaps pressure for government regulation.
Paradoxically, now that the date rollover appears to be going smoothly, some critics are saying that the threat was exaggerated by computer professionals out to make a buck.
While there were clearly some charlatans, many programmers still recovering from an exhausting, nerve-racking race against an immutable deadline are now feeling as if they have become victims of their own success.
"I'm already hearing that from my own family -- that it's all been overblown," said Celia Murray, a systems analyst with the Office of Real Property Services, a New York State agency. "I think it could have been really bad, no question about it. A lot of people worked really hard. That's the reason people can sit here and say it's all overblown."

HEADLINE: Putin Appears Ready to Reap the Benefits of Incumbency as Russian Vote Approaches

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 2

 BODY:
A top assistant to Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, said today that it would be all but impossible for Mr. Putin to lose the presidential election tentatively set for March. For now, at least, no one seemed to disagree.
After cramming his first two days as acting president with campaign-style speeches, news conferences, a trip to a war zone and a chat with President Clinton, Mr. Putin kept away from cameras today. 
 But his staff kept the publicity going, suggesting in a briefing for reporters that Mr. Putin is so confident of victory in March that he will do little traditional campaigning.
"I don't think Putin will run any special election campaign as he will have to combine the duties of president and prime minister," said Igor Shabdurasulov, the first deputy chief of the presidential staff.
Although he said he was reluctant to make political forecasts, Mr. Shabdurasulov said it was unrealistic to believe that anyone could beat Mr. Putin.
It will be better if Mr. Putin wins an outright majority in the first round of voting, he said, because a runoff election would only "waste time."
The Kremlin had been working hard to establish just such an air of invincibility about Mr. Putin even before President Boris N. Yeltsin dumbfounded the nation on Friday by resigning and handing Mr. Putin the job of running the country. But for once the optimism seems justified, even though political half-lives here are as often measured in months as in years.
Mr. Putin's only serious rival so far, Yevgeny M. Primakov, the former foreign minister and prime minister, suffered a huge blow when his political party, Fatherland-All Russia, stumbled in parliamentary elections last month. Another contender, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko Party, also faded after the party's candidates did not do as well in that election as it had hoped.
That leaves only the Communist Party, which can count on a solid 25 to 30 percent of the vote in any election, but not much more.
In Washington today, President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, warned that the mounting casualties among Russian soldiers in the fierce battle for Chechnya's capital, Grozny, could pose political problems for Mr. Putin if the conflict is not settled soon.
"If he can't bring this to an end -- a peaceful end -- quickly, if the costs become too high for the Russians, and the resistance is increasing, this could become an albatross around his neck in March," Mr. Berger said on the ABC program "This Week."
If Mr. Putin or his assistants share that view, however, they are concealing it nicely. Despite complaints from the West about the brutality of the war, it has remained the engine of Mr. Putin's popularity.
Returning Saturday afternoon from a highly publicized trip to the Chechnya front, Mr. Putin said he believes that "everything we have done so far has been justified."
Later, in remarks carried on the Moscow news station Echo Moskvy, Mr. Putin added that the Kremlin has "no intention to liberate anything by acting hastily."
"We plan to act in the best possible way, which means as few losses as possible among our servicemen and no losses among the civilian population," he said.
As part of what is already starting to look like an event-a-day campaign schedule, Mr. Putin had planned to meet today with newly elected members of the lower house of Parliament. But all Russia traditionally rests and celebrates in the days after the New Year, and not enough legislators could be rounded up for a meeting.
Instead, Mr. Shabdurasulov, the presidential aide, sketched out in barest detail Mr. Putin's plans for his transition into the presidency and for the campaign -- plans more notable for what was not mentioned than for what was.
He said, for example, that Mr. Putin probably will make few changes in the government he inherited from Mr. Yeltsin, although one presidential adviser, Tatyana Dyachenko, "probably would change her status."
Ms. Dyachenko, Mr. Yeltsin's 39-year-old daughter, is a crucial Kremlin political strategist who is rumored to have been behind Mr. Putin's swift rise to power. Mr. Shabdurasulov's ambiguous language left it unclear whether she will remain in the Kremlin or leave with her father.
Similarly, Mr. Shabdurasulov said no one had decided whether to accept the offers of two of Mr. Yeltsin's allies, Anatoly B. Chubais and Boris Berezovsky, to work in Mr. Putin's presidential campaign.
Mr. Chubais, an architect of the economic reforms that ended with a disastrous financial collapse last year, now runs the nation's electricity monopoly. Mr. Berezovsky, a tycoon who was a major financier of Mr. Yeltsin's 1996 re-election campaign, is said to be a close friend of Ms. Dyachenko.
Moscow's political class will be closely watching the fates of the three to see whether Mr. Putin is setting an independent course or is -- as critics charge -- a tool for extending the Yeltsin clan's reign beyond that of its patriarch.
The only sour note today came from the media empire of another tycoon, Vladimir Gusinsky, a bitter foe of Mr. Berezovsky and now, it seems, of Mr. Putin.
The weekly news magazine program "Itogi," broadcast tonight on Mr. Gusinsky's NTV network, charged that Kremlin strategists and K.G.B. veterans like Mr. Putin had plotted Mr. Yeltsin's resignation for months -- perhaps without Mr. Yeltsin's consent -- in an effort to prolong their own power.
The program also suggested that they had probably succeeded.
"Broad opportunities now open up for Putin," it said. "The chances of his competitors for the post of president are now at an incredibly low level.
"Putin has now received a full arsenal of power, almost unlimited power, and with all of his qualities there is no need to doubt that the president will use all of the levers to hold onto this power."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Willing Contenders at a Premium In Fierce Fight to Rule Congress

SERIES: TESTING POLITICS/The Candidates

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WINTER HAVEN, Fla.

 BODY:
Rick and Julie Dantzler thought they had made their decision back in April: Despite the pleas of party leaders, despite the lure of an open seat, Rick would not run for Congress this year.
They were still burned out and bruised from his unsuccessful campaigns for both the Democratic nomination for governor and the lieutenant governor's job in Florida in 1998. Their daughters, Liz, 13, and Margaret, 10, were thriving, and as Julie put it: "We get one shot at 10 and 13. We only get one shot at that." 
 But as 1999 wound to a close, and there was no Democratic candidate in the race, the Dantzlers found themselves wrestling with the decision one more time, while Democrats in Florida and Washington watched in suspense. One question kept coming up. "Can you make enough of a difference there to really justify what you're going to be missing here?" Mr. Dantzler asked, surrounded by his family on a quiet December afternoon.
In a year like 2000, when the two parties are locked in a furious battle for control of the House, the civics books would suggest that candidates like Mr. Dantzler would be lining up to join the fray. In fact, while both parties hail their success in getting experienced, high-quality candidates to run, many potential candidates will agonize over the decision and quite a few will ultimately say no.
The reluctance of these candidates is part of the explanation for a striking reality of American politics this year. For all the talk about the battle for the House, perhaps as few as a tenth of the Congressional districts will have truly competitive races, with a fair contest of ideas and agendas. And the more that strong candidates bow out, the fewer real battles there will be.
In most districts, held by well-financed incumbents, there will probably not be much of a battle at all, many political professionals say.
"I think the dirty little secret is out, that 94 percent of all incumbents win," said Charles Cook, a longtime analyst of Congressional campaigns who publishes a political newsletter.
It is a paradox for what was intended by the framers as "the people's house," so responsive and closely attuned to the voters that it needed the Senate to keep it in check.
And this lack of competition has consequences for how Congress operates, some scholars and analysts say -- such as the creation of an ever more polarized House, with incumbents increasingly insulated from challenges from the other party that would push them to the center. It may also help explain such political puzzles as the impeachment of a president in defiance of the public opinion polls, some say.
It is too early to tell exactly how many districts will have hotly contested races this year, but some analysts predict no more than 35 to 45. In 1998, 94 districts were completely uncontested by a major political party, the highest number since 1958. And many more are contested in name only; in a third of the contested races in 1996, for example, one candidate outspent the other by more than 9 to 1.
The deterrents to running for Congress these days are huge -- the all-consuming nature of modern campaigns, the extraordinary demands of fund-raising, the cost in time and stability to young families and dual career marriages, the slender prospects of defeating an incumbent.
And many campaign strategists say that at the end of the decade, there are special reasons for an ambitious politician to sit it out: Even if that candidate wins, he or she faces the possibility of having to begin all over again in a reconfigured district, with a lot of different voters, after the Congressional districts are redrawn following the 2000 census.
Moreover, in an election like 2000, at the very end of a redistricting cycle, Congressional elections tend to become far more stable; the obvious mismatches and political opportunities -- a liberal congressman representing a conservative district, or vice versa -- have been corrected by the voters by now.
Then there is the current political climate, a time of relative peace and prosperity, with much less anger toward Washington than was bubbling before the great upheaval of 1994, when the Republicans took control of Congress.
"You give me a recession, a gridlocked Congress and a war, and I'll show you candidates coming out the woodwork to run," said Stuart Rothenberg, another Congressional analyst who publishes a political newsletter.
Some analysts say it is to the parties' advantage to contain their field of battle and thus focus their resources on a small number of targets; a net shift of just five seats would change control of the House, meaning that neither party needs to move a lot of seats.
But political scientists say it is hardly healthy for much of the country to be excluded from the battle for the House.
"I think it's a terrible aspect of our politics, if voters are not even offered an opportunity to vote for the party of their choice," said James E. Campbell, professor of political science at the State University of New York at Buffalo.
Thomas E. Mann, an expert on Congress at the Brookings Institution, sees it as an odd tradeoff: After four decades in which the Democrats seemed a permanent majority in the House, the two parties are now nearly evenly matched; the Republican majority of 222 is among the smallest of the century.
So there is intense competition between the two parties, he says; it is simply being brought to bear on a small percentage of the seats, like cold war superpowers vying for a tiny piece of strategic terrain.
Congressional politics has a way of bucking longterm predictions and transforming itself very quickly, and nobody knows how enduring this pattern will be. What is clear is that running a serious race for Congress these days is a series of high hurdles.
And Sandy Maisel, a professor of government at Colby College in Maine, said, "I think the cumulative effect of those deterrents is that high-quality candidates for one reason or another opt out."
 
Money
The Chilling Effect Of Raising Funds
In 1997, in a study financed by the National Science Foundation, Mr. Maisel and Walter J. Stone of the University of Colorado began to survey potential candidates in 200 Congressional districts, trying to determine who runs for office, who does not, and why. Among all the deterrents, from a loss of privacy to a fear of negative advertising, one factor was cited twice as often as any other: having to raise the vast amounts of money necessary to run.
This is particularly true for potential candidates considering a run against incumbents, who nearly always have an easier time raising money. Larry Makinson, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, an independent group that tracks campaign finance, said that the average incumbent had $315,000 in the bank at the end of June, 18 months before the next election. "You've got to be nuts to jump in as a challenger in a situation like that," Mr. Makinson said.
The money factor also has a chilling effect on potential candidates for open seats, which ordinarily invite competition. Even those who decide to take the plunge swallow hard over the money and what it portends.
State Representative Adam Putnam, 25, a political whiz kid who is already in his second term in the Florida Legislature, has estimated that it will take $750,000 to $850,000 to wage his campaign for Congress this year in the 12th District, a seat now held by Representative Charles T. Canady, a Republican who is retiring. And then there's the money that will pour into the district from outside groups, said Mr. Putnam, who is considered the leading Republican in the race.
"It really just gives you heartburn to think about," he said at a restaurant in Bartow not long ago. "Not as much the financial implications as what that message is going to be that these out-of-towners are going to be saying about you or on your behalf, which you have no control over. That's spooky to me."
State Representative Lori Edwards, a 42-year-old Democrat who has won four terms in this region, also saw a campaign for Florida's 12th as a "natural progression" -- at least initially.
The 12th District is a slice of "Old Florida" in the central part of the state, east of Tampa, dotted by lakes and citrus groves and still largely oriented toward agriculture. When she first looked at the race, the money needed to run there seemed "real doable" to Ms. Edwards, who describes herself as solidly middle class: Mr. Canady had never had to spend more than $350,000 on a campaign. But the popular incumbent had managed to avoid a huge television campaign.
As Ms. Edwards began to prepare for the race, she learned this was no longer possible. "All of a sudden the price tag for this race was going up to $1 million," Ms. Edwards said, an assessment not that far off Mr. Putnam's.
On top of that was the prospect of immediate redistricting, at the hands of a State Legislature led by Republicans. "So even if I was elected, not only would I have to turn around and raise $1 million again, but the Republican-controlled State Legislature is not going to be too happy about losing this seat," Ms. Edwards said.
In October, five months after she entered the race, Ms. Edwards withdrew, with money a major factor. "It wasn't even that I didn't think it could be done," she said. "It was because I didn't want to do it. My deepest worry was that after you do all that begging, and after all those people give you all that money, how can you keep your independence? My experience in the State Legislature showed it can be done, but I never had to beg for a million dollars."
Representative Martin Frost of Texas, who for several years was chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said of the money demands: "I'd prefer that it be different, but you play the hand you're dealt. But it does discourage some people from running."
 
Family
Weighing the Cost Of Time and Travel
It was not the money that deterred Joe Hogsett, who considered running for an open seat in Indiana this year. It was the sheer amount of time and energy that it takes to run in a competitive district these days, balanced against the demands of family.
Mr. Hogsett, a 43-year-old Democrat, was no political novice, after six years as Indiana's secretary of state, an unsuccessful Senate race in 1992 and an unsuccessful bid for Congress in 1994. He said he knew what it would take, and he knew it was too much.
"I have a very young family," he said. "My spouse and I have a young son and we hope to add to our family in the future. So ultimately the decision this year weighed what I knew on the one hand were the enormous responsibilities of running for Congress -- the time, the energy, the resources -- with maintaining my obligations as a spouse, as a father, with work, practicing law here in Indianapolis."
Many political professionals say that running a competitive campaign essentially means giving up your job for a year. Then there is the privacy factor, at a time when personal lives are just one more line of inquiry in a political campaign.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who for several years was chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said people would tell him: "I don't want the scrutiny. I don't want the divorce I had 20 years ago to be examined. I don't want my kids to go through it."
Even if candidates make it through these pitfalls, they face the complicated task of working in Washington, keeping a strong presence in the district on the weekends, and somehow fitting a family life in between. Representative Anne M. Northup, the Kentucky Republican who heads her party's effort to recruit candidates for the House, said "everybody asks the same questions" and the logistics of family life are at the top of the list.
"When you're looking at candidates who have a lot to offer, one of the reasons they have a lot to offer is because they've carried big responsibilities," Ms. Northup said. "They have a whole demanding life -- jobs, responsibilities -- and there are going to be a lot of people who have to make adjustments if they run."
Mark James, a Republican state senator in Nevada, was another top-tier candidate who was urged to run this year -- against a Democratic freshman who won with less than 50 percent of the vote in 1998 -- but decided he could not because of his family. Mr. James, who is 40, has a 10-year-old son and a 12-year-old daughter; he could not see how he could maintain a bicoastal household and spend enough time with them.
"It isn't that I don't want to serve, or don't want to make sacrifices," he said, adding that he would not rule out a race in the future.
And the Dantzlers were torn over whether the difference Mr. Dantzler could make in Washington would be worth the cost in family life. They were a seasoned political family, having lived through a statewide campaign and several high-profile races for the State House and Senate, where Mr. Dantzler had served for 15 years.
But they have a rooted life in Florida, they said. Mrs. Dantzler works as a mental health counselor, the daughters are involved in soccer and theater, their families go back several generations in the state. If he ran and won, the Dantzlers think the family would stay in Florida, at least in the beginning, which would mean a bifurcated life.
"I'm sure that my kids will be fine," Rick Dantzler said as he envisioned that life. "And I'm sure that Julie and I will stay together. But I'm not sure that I want to miss it. The idea of getting on a plane on Monday and coming back on Friday and asking Julie how it was with the girls for the last three days -- ."
On the other hand, he said, "I'm only 43, I enjoy public service and I like to think there's another race in me yet."
He and Julie said they planned to make their decision after the holidays.
 
Consequences
An Electoral Process With Fewer Battles
The sum total of all these personal decisions is less competitive politics, some analysts say. They disagree on how much of that is because of short-term causes -- the peace-and-prosperity political climate, the stable Congressional politics that is often a hallmark of the end of a decade -- and how much is because of deterrents less likely to change, like huge fund-raising requirements and virtually nonstop campaigns.
But some scholars say that whatever the causes, the lack of competition has consequences, particularly when incumbents grow accustomed to it. As Mr. Maisel and Mr. Stone wrote in their study, "Representative democracy depends fundamentally on a competitive electoral process."
In the meantime, some potential candidates are looking elsewhere. Ms. Edwards has decided to run for supervisor of elections in Polk County, Fla. She says it is a good and interesting job where she believes she can make a contribution.
And, she added, "The cost of the race is a manageable one, and the outcome of the race will depend much more on my grass-roots effort, talking to people, shaking hands."
She was clearly looking forward to the coming campaign.
 
Testing Politics
This article is the second of a series that will appear during the election year, exploring the condition of the American political system through the prism of the campaign. Other articles will examine the participation of campaign volunteers and the degree to which the system assimilates new voters.

HEADLINE: Home Aides for Elderly in Short Supply

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2

 BODY:
The booming economy is worsening a severe shortage of the low-wage workers who care for the nation's growing numbers of frail elderly people, health care experts say.
The shortage of home health care nurses and aides and nursing home assistants has deepened in the last two years as better paying jobs with better conditions have opened up for the women who have traditionally filled those positions, which have few benefits as well as low wages. 
 And many in the industry say cuts in Medicare have made the strenuous jobs even more demanding as agencies have made up for reduced income by requiring workers to deliver more care in less time.
Almost every state is grappling with the shortage, according to a national survey conducted this year by North Carolina. New Jersey recently put the recruitment of home health care workers at the top of its list of priorities for elderly care, and states including Florida, Pennsylvania and Maryland have established task forces to study the issue.
In Connecticut and New York, home care trade organizations have also formed task forces to look for ways to find more workers.
Some experts say one solution is to pay home health aides better and treat them with more respect.
"As a nation, if we truly are concerned about our elders, we need to become more concerned about those people who are caring for them on a daily basis," said Andy Van Kleunen, director of work force policy for the Paraprofessional Healthcare Institute, a health advocacy group that has opened three worker-owned home health care agencies, in the South Bronx, New Hampshire and Philadelphia.
As it stands now, even the experts cannot find help when they need it. Mary Mongan, a registered nurse who is vice chairman of the New Hampshire State Council on Aging and a former state health commissioner, knows how to negotiate the health services world as well as anyone. But when her 83-year-old sister-in-law developed cancer three years ago and wanted to stay at home, in Manchester, N.H., Ms. Mongan could not find home health care aides who could provide 24-hour help.
Her sister-in-law was forced to move to Maryland to live with her daughter, Ms. Mongan said. "We couldn't put together enough dependable help," she said. "They didn't have the manpower."
The shortage involves the people, most of them women from their mid-20's to mid-40's, who do basic and often unpleasant and dangerous work -- bathing, feeding, changing diapers, cleaning bedsores, lifting and transferring people in and out of bed -- for the nation's fastest growing population, the very old. And these days, more and more of those workers find they can earn about the same pay at McDonald's, or Target.
With some home health care aides financed by Medicare, the federal health insurance for the elderly, others by Medicaid, the federal insurance for the poor, and even more through private pay, it is difficult to accurately estimate the number of home health care aides.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics puts the figure of aides financed by Medicare and Medicaid at 697,000 in 1996, a number that also includes paid housekeepers.
Tens of thousands of additional home health care workers will be needed in the coming years, experts say, with the number of jobs to be filled expected to increase by 76 percent between 1996 and 2006.
"In a bad economy, when you can't get any other job, and you have a sixth-grade education, being a home health aide is an attractive job," said Carol Keintz, executive director of the Home Health Assembly of New Jersey, a nonprofit trade association. "In a good economy, when Dunkin' Donuts doesn't care if you've got a sixth-grade education, it's tough to find people."
In addition, Ms. Keintz said, fast food restaurants and retail stores like Target offer steady, full-time work, often with benefits.
Home care, with clients whose needs constantly change and with Medicare limiting visits, tends to be part-time and unpredictable.
"Agencies can't say, 'We can promise you a job every day,' " Ms. Keintz said. "Suddenly, five of their patients die, or go to the hospital, and they say to the worker, 'Don't come in today.' "
Here in Philadelphia on Tuesday, Charmane Ellis, 33, had just finished giving Antonietta Mannino, 81, a sponge bath in her small row house.
Now, Ms. Ellis was kneeling before the older woman, pulling on her support stockings, orthopedic shoes and the brace she wears on her right leg. Mrs. Mannino, who once worked in the garment industry, has severe arthritis and has suffered a series of small strokes.
Because Mrs. Mannino just spent a month in the hospital after falling down her front steps, Medicare pays for Ms. Ellis's time.
Mrs. Mannino's husband, Thomas, a retired milkman, died five weeks ago. Talking about him with Ms. Ellis, Mrs. Mannino began to weep. Ms. Ellis stroked her arm. "It's O.K. to cry, Mrs. Mannino," she said.
Ms. Ellis is a certified home health aide with HomeCare Associates, one of Paraprofessional Healthcare's agencies. She earns $7.65 an hour, a little more than average for home health care aides in Philadelphia.
On such wages, plus health insurance, she is raising four children alone in a housing project here.
In an industry where most home health agencies report a 40 percent to 60 percent turnover in aides every year, Charmane Ellis is an anomaly. She has been doing this work for 14 years. For her taking care of the elderly is a calling.
"I feel like this is my thing to do in life," Ms. Ellis said. "It makes me feel appreciated. I figure I'm going to be there one day."
"They're like our founding fathers," she added, talking about her clients. "They have a lot to tell."
Ms. Ellis began her morning with a 45-minute trolley ride, and then a 10-minute walk, to spend an hour bathing and dressing Connie Prendergast, 77, in her row house. Mrs. Prendergast has cancer and is tethered to an oxygen tank 24 hours a day.
When someone dies on her watch, Ms. Ellis said, there is no time to grieve. "They pay you to go on to the next person like they're just a number," she said. "I'm a sensitive person. The aide needs an hour to pull themselves together."
Not all of her clients are appreciative. One or two clients, who were white, made it clear they did not want a black woman touching them, Ms. Ellis said. Other clients are severely cognitively impaired, and one man threw feces at her, she said. She cleaned herself off and went about her job.
After Mrs. Prendergast, Ms. Ellis spent a hurried hour with Mrs. Mannino. She would have had twice as much time a couple of years ago, before the Medicare cuts. With the new constraints, she said, she was unable to make Mrs. Mannino's bed or do the light housecleaning that her job description includes. Mrs. Mannino is too weak to do any of those things. She is fortunate to have family members who can fill in.
Leaving Mrs. Mannino, Ms. Ellis made a 45-minute trolley trip to the home of Emanuel Saunders. Mr. Saunders, a 75-year-old retired truck driver, has Alzheimer's disease. He cannot talk or walk or feed himself. His wife, Lillian, 58, who works in a car assembly plant, and his daughter Kia, 28, greeted Ms. Ellis warmly. With Kia Saunders's help, Ms. Ellis carefully lifted Mr. Saunders from his wheelchair into bed and changed the dressing on his bedsore. His diaper did not need changing this time.
Gertrude Warren is an aide with Paraprofessional Healthcare's agency in the South Bronx, Cooperative Home Care Associates. She is the reason Al Saturn, 92, and his wife Goldye, 91, have been able to remain in the apartment on the Grand Concourse where they have lived for 55 years. Mr. Saturn, who managed sporting goods stores, is severely diabetic. Mrs. Saturn, who used to make hats, suffered two strokes a year ago and is paralyzed on one side.
Now, with the couple's three children scattered around the country, Mrs. Warren, 52, looks after both of them. She went to four stores in the Bronx last month in search of Hanukkah candles for the couple's menorah. You have to love people to do this job, Mrs. Warren said.
All three of Paraprofessional Healthcare's agencies pay 20 percent more than the industry average, provide health benefits and compensate aides for the time they spend traveling to clients. The agencies offer four weeks of training -- the industry norm is 75 hours -- and they try to give their aides full-time work, as well as opportunities for advancement. The agencies, which have won praise from the home health care industry and experts on aging, report job turnover of less than 20 percent.
"In the past, we could always assume there were going to be a lot of low-income men and women out there to do the work," said Mr. Van Kleunen of Paraprofessional Healthcare. "We didn't have to worry about creating good jobs they'd be interested in staying in. If we want to have enough caregivers for the elderly, we're going to have to invest in those caregivers."

HEADLINE: Pataki Proposing a Hudson River Research Institute

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday that he would propose establishing a 500-employee research institute to study the Hudson River, an initiative that several environmental leaders said could represent a milestone in the decades-long struggle to restore the river.
The governor said that the center, to be called the Henry Hudson Institute for Riverine and Estuarine Research and Education, would be modeled after the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute in Massachusetts. 
 "When you think of oceans, you think of Woods Hole," Mr. Pataki said in an interview. "We think we have the potential to do the same when you think about the Hudson River and estuaries."
Previewing part of his State of the State address on Wednesday, Mr. Pataki said he would propose spending up to $1 million this year for a task force that would address such questions as where the institute would be located, how it would be financed and who would control its operations and research. The financing would have to be authorized by the State Legislature. But Mr. Pataki said that he hoped the institute would be up and running in 5 to 10 years with an annual operating budget of about $50 million.
By comparison, Woods Hole has 850 employees and an annual budget of $85 million.
"An idea like this has been discussed for 30 years and never gotten anywhere," said John Cronin, chief advocate of Riverkeeper Inc., a nonprofit conservation group that closely monitors the Hudson River. "This is the first time a governor has proposed this, which is why I think it's going to happen."
Mr. Cronin said that debates over the pace of industrial and residential development along the Hudson are perpetually bogged down by the absence of credible, independent research on the river. "What we don't know about the Hudson is a lot," he said.
With a major research institute unbeholden to either industry or public interest groups, Mr. Cronin suggested, this void could be filled, helping to shape development along the river. Mr. Pataki's initiative, he added, comes at a time when there is an "unprecedented push" to "reindustrialize" the Hudson basin, particularly by utility companies hoping to build power plants along the river.
"This is a substantial, bold proposal," Mr. Cronin said.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, said he was proposing the institute as a way to build on the advances already made in cleaning up the Hudson, once a struggling ecosystem with a river bottom despoiled by industrial wastes along much of its 275 nautical miles. While the Hudson is cleaner than it has been in decades, parts of it are still contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, cancer-causing industrial chemicals that were dumped for many years by factories in the upper reaches of the river.
"We've made tremendous progress with our environmental initiatives," Mr. Pataki said. "We were thinking, 'What's the next step?' "
The governor said he rejected an early idea to start with a small teaching center, or perhaps an aquarium, and instead urged his environmental aides to "take it to the largest possible vision of what we could have."
While the state would most likely pay a major part of the cost, private foundations, colleges and the Federal government might also be asked to contribute, aides to the governor said. Mr. Pataki has designated John P. Cahill, commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, to flesh out the details.
Calling the revival of the Hudson "an incredible opportunity economically," the governor said that the proposed institute could expand and coordinate existing research efforts and provide a firm foundation of science for tapping the Hudson's economic potential.
"We want to be looking to the future and that requires academic research," he said.
At the same time, he added, a "world-class and world-renowned" science center focusing solely on rivers and estuaries could yield important research results with broader benefits for environmental policy makers across the country.
While there are several well-respected oceanographic research centers like Woods Hole and Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, which lies on the Hudson, Mr. Pataki said that rivers and estuaries had gotten less attention.
"We just think it is an unbelievable opportunity and the time is right," the governor said.
Ned Sullivan, executive director of Scenic Hudson, an environmental and land trust organization, said Mr. Pataki's plan had the potential "to significantly and dramatically expand the amount of scientific research" into the Hudson, which, he added, remains at risk both from contaminated sediments and a new generation of power plants. Such plants kill fish by drawing them into their intakes, along with cooling water.
"It is particularly long-sighted of the governor to propose establishing an institute that could build a baseline of data about the condition of the river," he said, "so that citizens and policy makers can work together to set long-term goals for improving the quality of the river, cleaning up the toxic threats and restoring the fisheries that have been suffering.
"This project holds real promise for realizing the full potential of the Hudson River."
