HEADLINE: Fiasco in Urban Renewal: A Case Study in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Gennie Phillips, president of the Helpline Soul Rescue Ministry in Brooklyn, said that until two years ago, her group had never fixed up a house or renovated an apartment building.
But that lack of expertise did not stop the group from joining in a federal urban renewal program and buying more than 100 buildings to renovate. And it did not stop the federal government from guaranteeing $20 million that Helpline borrowed to finance the renovations. 
 Thus in 1997, Helpline, which had for years been chiefly involved in drug counseling and food distribution, began to buy and renovate 106 buildings in some of New York City's poorest neighborhoods.
Today, the project is a fiasco. Some of the buildings have had little work done on them; others remain in poor shape, with leaking pipes and peeling plaster. And Helpline has informed the Department of Housing and Urban Development that it cannot make payments on the $20 million in loans.
Ms. Phillips said many of the buildings had not been repaired, Some are still in bad shape, city records show. One four-family apartment building on Essex Street, in Brooklyn, has 612 housing violations, according to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. They include citations for leaking pipes, peeling plaster and a broken ceiling.
Sorting out what went wrong has not been easy.
Helpline officials said they did not receive proper support either in managing the money or in repairing the property. The bank that lent Helpline the money says responsibility rests solely with Helpline -- and bank officials argue that Helpline was approved to borrow by the federal government. Both HUD's inspector general and New York State's attorney general are trying to find out what happened.
Amid the ruins, though, there is at least widespread agreement on one thing: the Helpline debacle is just one in a series of mistakes that have plagued one of HUD's most problematic efforts at providing affordable and decent housing to poor and working-class families.
The HUD inspector general's office has written a series of reports criticizing the program that Helpline used -- known as the 203(k) loan program, named after a section of federal law. The loans under that program, which are made by banks, pay for the purchase and repair of dilapidated housing. HUD promises to repay the loans if the borrower cannot.
"The program is still a very risky one" for the government, said Nancy Cooper, a HUD deputy inspector general, who has written a report that detailed the program's problems.
The 203(k) program has provided loan guarantees for individuals and nonprofit groups seeking to renovate housing since 1978. But the program was not well known until 1996, when HUD streamlined application requirements and began advertising the 203(k) loans. Then it exploded -- HUD insured $400 million in such loans in 1996 and $3.6 billion last year.
Criticism has grown with use. The General Accounting Office -- Congress's investigative arm -- reported last year that HUD had to make good on $8 million in 203(k) loans in 1998, and predicted mounting losses in coming years.
A big chunk of those losses are expected to come from the Helpline project. Most of the loans are in default, and HUD predicts that $19 million worth will go bad.
HUD's own inspector general has said the program is vulnerable to errors and fraud. But HUD officials say the program is a crucial element in rehabilitating urban areas.
And senior HUD officials say it is unfair to condemn the entire program because of infrequent mistakes.
"This program does a lot of good," said William C. Apgar, HUD's assistant secretary for housing. "We can focus on the loans that went bad, or the 95 out of 100 loans that go well."
Investigators say the 203(k) program is risky by nature, mainly because it provides extra money for repairs. The repair work opens the door for fraud and for costly mistakes in estimating the costs and in ensuring the work is done properly.
To protect the program, HUD sets minimum experience levels for nonprofit groups that want to participate. Its rules say nonprofit groups must have at least two years' experience in providing housing for low- and moderate-income people.
Helpline was certified to participate in the program in 1996. Ms. Phillips said the group never claimed to have experience in housing construction. She said Helpline had assisted people in finding housing but had no experience in construction or renovation work.
Ms. Phillips said Helpline submitted a proposal to HUD that described its experience. She added that "we may have told them we had experience with housing, but in a general way."
"We were not experienced in this, but certainly we were told we would be able to learn as we go with the bank in this program," Ms. Phillips said, referring to the assistance she said Helpline expected from the lender. Bank officials said they regularly offered education programs to all borrowers in the 203(k) program.
HUD officials confirmed that Helpline was certified to participate in the program. They said the required experience did not have to include construction or rehabilitation.
"It could include housing education, housing counseling," said Chris Walz, a HUD spokesman. "It could include service for people in getting them connected with housing."
Mr. Walz said HUD was now considering whether it should increase the experience requirement, or restrict the amount of money that inexperienced groups can borrow.
In a report last summer, the General Accounting Office found that nonprofit agencies with little or no housing experience were often approved for 203(k) loans.
"A concern we ran into was the experience, expertise and resources that nonprofits bring to the program," said Stan Czerwinski, a General Accounting Office official, who supervised preparation of the report, which did not examine the Helpline loans. He said auditors found other cases in which nonprofit groups with no experience were allowed to borrow, typically to buy a small number of properties. He said HUD did not have the staff to check the background of nonprofit groups.
A HUD manager in the Denver office, which is responsible for programs in 17 states, told General Accounting Office investigators that the Denver office did not have enough travel money to monitor any of the housing programs it supervised.
"We have really ramped up our monitoring activity," said Mr. Apgar, the assistant secretary. He said HUD did four times as many loan reviews in 1998 as it did in 1997.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Final Chapter: Single-Minded, Full-Steam Run at a Global Agenda

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty last fall to a tear-gas-filled week in Seattle that badly damaged his global economic agenda.
But some of his biggest victories in 1999 were also scored abroad, from the air campaign over Serbia that largely halted ethnic bloodshed to the Northern Ireland accord that offers the first prospect of peace there. 
 And now Mr. Clinton's aides describe a president who has determined -- for reasons as practical as political reality and as personal as the emptiness of his residence -- to make foreign policy the focus of his last 12 months in office.
It is the one arena where he believes he can continue to wield power as two major political campaigns -- one starring his wife, the other his vice president -- take more and more of the spotlight, his aides say. And it is an escape from a White House that a close adviser calls "a very lonely place these days."
Mr. Clinton's schedule calls for a stream of trips, each casting him in a different role: peacemaker, international financial architect and missionary seeking converts to American-style democratic capitalism.
He starts this week by shuttling in and out of Shepherdstown, W.Va., by helicopter to coax Israel and Syria toward what could be a peace accord as important as Camp David.
But that will be only the opening in a blur of diplomacy -- driven by his desire to avoid looking like a lame duck, and fueled by his determination to make up for time lost during the impeachment battle.
"He never uses the word 'legacy' but he talks about it all the time," one of his longtime friends said.
Others say Mr. Clinton is driven to look abroad in part because there is little reason to stay in Washington. While there is still a chance of a deal with Republicans on Medicare, the president has told aides that the likelihood is fading.
Meanwhile, Hillary Rodham Clinton is making one of the most public early departures from the White House by any first lady in anticipation of a possible run for the Senate. She is moving the family's scant collection of furnishings to a new house in Chappaqua, N.Y., a place where few expect the president to spend much time next year.
Chelsea Clinton has accompanied her father on two major foreign trips in the last four months, but she has a life of her own at Stanford University. The president's associates describe him as eager not to rattle around the White House alone.
"He's happier on the road," said one cabinet member who has accompanied the president on several recent trips, ticking off the possible stops in 2000: India, Nigeria, Okinawa, several destinations in Europe, a possible trip to Russia after the March election of a new president there, and perhaps even a visit to a place about which he spent much of his youth debating: Vietnam.
"He can't campaign for Gore," the cabinet member said during a holiday party, referring to the vice president's effort to distance himself from Mr. Clinton. "Fund-raising is a chore. But he's come to love the puzzle of the geopolitics."
If so, it was a love that took time to kindle. But since this past August, when he interrupted his vacation with regular morning calls to Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and other Middle East leaders, Mr. Clinton has acted like a man in a race against time to bring about a final settlement with the Palestinians and, now, with Syria.
Starting on Monday in Shepherdstown, he will once again insert himself into the negotiations. Dipping in and out of the talks at strategic moments, aides say, Mr. Clinton is expected to play a critical role, both coaxing the two sides and offering American financial and technological assistance to Israel and Syria as they negotiate over mutual security arrangements that would be part of the return of the Golan Heights.
White House aides say Mr. Clinton has blocked out most of the next two weeks for the negotiations, and he is prepared for another round in February if Shepherdstown proves inconclusive.
But any deal that calls for an increase in American aid to Israel or the beginning of financial assistance to Syria -- probably a total in the billions of dollars over the next few years -- would require Congressional approval. In an election year, that could prove tricky, and Mr. Clinton's recent track record, as evidenced by the defeat of the test ban treaty, is hardly reassuring.
Moreover, a vote on the Middle East aid package, if an accord is reached, could come at roughly the same time as a vote on granting China permanent trade status, part of the deal under which it is to enter the World Trade Organization.
The issues are completely different, and so are the constituencies pressing for passage. But both will be difficult votes, and some in the White House are quietly questioning if Mr. Clinton has the clout to prevail in two major foreign policy votes, both in an election year.
The China vote may become the most visible symbol of two other aspects of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy legacy. It will determine whether he has any claim to have changed the nature of America's influence on the world's most populous nation. And it will be a major test of whether his signature effort to redefine America's role in the world -- through a strategy of economic integration and globalization -- can recover from the damage done in Seattle.
Both will be uphill battles.
Mr. Clinton has argued that if China is inside the World Trade Organization, which sets global trading rules, the world will have a far better chance of influencing its behavior.
But the same groups that took to the streets of Seattle, arguing that the trade organization places the priorities of trade above those of workers' rights and human rights, have vowed to block permanent trade status for China. Mr. Clinton's biggest argument will be with his own party, not with Republicans, especially as Democratic candidates in November try to maintain the party's traditional constituencies that support these two causes.
And the Republican leadership, relishing the opportunity to embarrass Vice President Gore, has already hinted that it would seek to delay the vote several months so that a fractious split among the Democrats will occur in the midst of the presidential campaign.
The President's advisers vow to press on. "I don't think there was lasting damage from Seattle," Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative and chief architect of both the successful China negotiations and the Seattle fiasco, said in an interview before Washington emptied out for the holidays. "The reality is that the W.T.O. will continue to function and global trade will continue to grow. So we'll go full bore."
Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, himself a former trade lawyer, expressed similar optimism that the setback is temporary. In retrospect, he said, the divisions between developing countries and wealthy countries, and between Europe, Japan and the United States, make it "hard for this to congeal -- in hindsight, even without the people outside" breaking windows and blocking Seattle's streets.
Mr. Clinton himself made the problem far worse at Seattle. By announcing that he ultimately wanted to make labor and environmental standards a part of all trade agreements, he cemented the opposition from developing nations, especially India, that are convinced that the United States is trying to rig the system to its advantage. That issue, along with peace with Pakistan, would probably dominate Mr. Clinton's tentative trip to India, which he would like to take in March.
Those, of course, are the predictable problems Mr. Clinton will face abroad.
Among the unpredictable, though, are his two biggest nuclear challenges -- defusing the India-Pakistan confrontation and taming North Korea -- are both situations that could veer into crisis at any moment.
So could Russia, where the administration is seeing how Boris N. Yeltsin's resignation and designation of an heir apparent plays out while pulling back on its early enthusiasm for spending large sums to convert Russia to capitalism. In the next three months, each decision to extend or withhold aid will inevitably be seen in Russia as an indicator of Washington's attitude about the acting President, Vladimir V. Putin, whether it is really intended to be or not.
"It's plenty," one of Mr. Clinton's aides said this week, "to keep him going all year."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
An End Run Around Tax On Cigarettes

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
DOCTORS and scientists are thrilled with New York's new tax on cigarettes, and with good reason. Once the higher tax kicks in, cigarettes in New York will be more expensive than anywhere else in the country. The price will inevitably turn some smokers into nonsmokers and deter many young people from ever picking up one of those noxious weeds.
But the medical community and lawmakers who approved the new tax aren't the only ones cheering. 
 So is Larry Ballagh, proprietor of a smoke shop on an Indian reservation in Irving, near Buffalo. Customers at his shop do not pay taxes, so the State Legislature has made him one happy fellow. "God bless them," said Mr. Ballagh, a member of the Seneca nation. "Every time they do it, more people come," he said, referring to the Legislature's decision to raise the tax. "I guess there is some indication that an increase in prices does encourage a certain number of people to quit, which may be a good thing. But New York State taxes make our product more attractive."
It would seem so. The folks at the Shinnecock Smoke Shop in Southampton recently bought a full-page ad in The New York Post illustrated with an Indian in feathered headdress. And the Web is crowded with cigarette come-ons. Just one site --
webmaster@discount-cigarettes.org/ -- lists screen after screen of vendors, from BigIndian.com to SmokemCheap.com.
All, from the small mom-and-pop operation to the established business enterprise, undersell traditional stores by at least $10, selling top brands for $22.35 to $24.99 a carton (plus $1.50 for shipping).
One regular customer of an Indian smoke store in Shirley, Long Island, where several smoke shops dot suburban streets, stocks up every month. "It's a big saving," he said. "Why not?"
Non-Indians are supposed to pay state and local taxes in reservation shops, but they do not, and now the Internet brings the tax-free benefits of reservation shopping to smokers without cars.
With the tax soon almost doubling to $1.11 a pack, cigarettes will cost more in New York than anywhere else in the country: about $4 a pack and $42 a carton in New York City. The incentive to find bargains will be greater than ever -- as will the incentive to provide those bargains.
Hence a few troubling predictions along with the happy ones about declines in smoking: that the higher price will energize Internet, mail order and reservation sales, as well as the already healthy black market in cigarettes smuggled in from other states. People with conventional stores in Binghamton and other towns near Pennsylvania, where the taxes are lower, worry about losing customers.
Nobody keeps reliable statistics, but estimates are that tax-free sales online and in reservation shops now account for a very small percentage of cigarette sales. The same for the black market. But there are signs of growth.
According to the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, states with the highest cigarette taxes in 1998 were losing $100 million a year in potential tax revenues to smuggling. After Maryland raised its tax last year to 66 cents a pack from 36 cents, state authorities said that in three months, they made more arrests for cigarette smuggling (nine) than in the entire previous year (five). In previous years, when New York raised taxes much higher than neighboring states, truckloads of cigarettes were smuggled in from states with lower taxes.
THE new tax is to help to finance health care coverage for up to one million uninsured New Yorkers. If too many sales go untaxed, then what?
"Good things are going to happen for the uninsured, but we are concerned about uncollected taxes," said John McCardle, a spokesman for the Republican majority in the State Senate. "It's a mixed bag."
Joseph Conway, spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki's budget division, said that the budget office considered uncollected taxes and potential declines in smoking in its calculations. He said details would have to wait until the governor's budget presentation later this month.
Dr. K. Michael Cummings, with the State Department of Health's Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, said what matters is that cigarette smoking will decline. "Yes, there are people who will buy on the Internet and on Indian reservations, but a big proportion? No. Will the tax have a deterrent effect on cigarette smoking? Yes."
Cigarette sales declined elsewhere when taxes went up. Nobody can say with certainty, though, whether those figures represented fewer smokers, or more enterprising shoppers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: ISRAEL AND SYRIA MEET TODAY IN U.S. ON TANGLED ISSUES

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2

 BODY:
Having done little more than break the ice in their first encounter last month, Israeli and Syrian leaders enter knottier terrain on Monday as they resume American-brokered negotiations ambitiously aimed at reaching a peace accord by the summer.
The mere fact of their meeting was achievement enough when the Israelis and the Syrians revived their peace effort in December after a four-year stalemate. This time the two sides will be forced to tackle directly the tangle of issues that have bedeviled their previous efforts at peacemaking: borders, security and the opening of normal relations. 
 But Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria, both of whom left today for the United States, have agreed to lock themselves and their delegations away with American mediators in a West Virginia hotel for the next week to 10 days, trying to demonstrate determination to overcome their differences.
American, Syrian and Israeli officials have been careful to damp expectations that the talks will produce anything concrete, and Israeli officials distanced themselves from earlier assessments that a general declaration of principles or some kind of written document would emerge.
Still, Mr. Barak's departing words as he left Ben-Gurion Airport near Tel Aviv made clear that he saw his trip as significant enough to be placed in the context of history.
"Here on this runway Menachem Begin took off to Camp David, and this is where he returned from Camp David," Mr. Barak said, invoking the legacy of the prime minister who made peace with Egypt 20 years ago.
"And here from this runway Yitzhak Rabin took off to bring peace with Jordan, and thereafter with the Palestinians," Mr. Barak said, referring to the assassinated prime minister who was his mentor.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright today described the renewed negotiations as "a huge historic opportunity," but she declined to predict how many rounds of talks it might take to reach an agreement.
Reflecting the dour public posture that Damascus has taken since talks resumed last month, Syria's official newspaper expressed pointed doubts. "The outcome of the first round does not give us reason to be optimistic," the daily Al Thawra said.
But Mr. Barak's goal is clear. And in recent weeks he has started to build a case for why Israelis should coalesce to support a withdrawal from the Golan Heights -- the sine qua non of a Syrian-Israeli accord.
It is a mixed message, combining scare tactics with appeals to a battle-scarred nation's yearnings for peace. But it presumes that the negotiations, to be held at a hotel in Shepherdstown, W.Va., will bear fruit in the next few months.
On one hand, Mr. Barak dreams aloud of a near-utopia if the peace effort succeeds: not only an end to battle but harmony in the Middle East, "unprecedented economic growth" in Israel and a "sky high" international image for his country. On the other, he warns of violent cataclysm if it fails.
Mr. Barak has also tried to lure Israelis with the prospect of bringing Israeli soldiers home from southern Lebanon by summer, even of shortening the compulsory three-year military service. Israeli officials disclosed this week by means of leaks that the prime minister had approved a plan to withdraw from Lebanon, which is controlled by Syria, as soon as April if the atmosphere in the negotiations is positive.
Trying to revive an old-fashioned Zionist righteousness, Mr. Barak has also appealed to "this generation" to be unselfish enough to make sacrifices that will benefit the next.
"The price of even the most successful war is immeasurably more expensive than the price of peace, no matter how heavy," he wrote this weekend in a rare published message to the nation. "So we must not be deterred from this decision. At the moment of truth, Israel will discover its courage for the sake of peace and security. This will be the complete triumph of Zionism, its pinnacle and realization."
Mr. Barak has scrupulously avoided public discussion of the issues that will be on the table in this week's high-level talks. Instead, already strategizing for a national referendum on peace -- in which he is expected to enlist American consultants as during his election campaign -- he aims to focus Israelis on the grand picture.
But the details are what will sit between Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara when they meet behind very closed doors at the Shepherdstown Clarion Hotel, 68 miles from Washington.
Israeli officials were describing "Sing-Sing" or "siege" conditions for the negotiators, who will be prevented from entering or leaving at will to create an airtight -- and leakproof -- diplomatic environment. And while depriving Israelis of their cellular phones is tantamount to cutting off a critical life support mechanism, the rules of the game will require them to turn the phones off.
It is unclear if Mr. Barak will stay put or come and go. Several world political leaders, including Russia's recently resigned president, Boris N. Yeltsin, are expected to pass through Israel when they travel to Bethlehem later this week for an Orthodox Christmas celebration organized by the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.
Mr. Barak will be accompanied to the United States by a delegation of about 25 negotiators, including Tourism Minister Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, who held negotiations with the Syrian Army leader when he was Israel's army chief of staff in the mid-1990's, and Foreign Minister David Levy.
As in December, Mr. Shara will represent President Hafez el-Assad, 69, who is considered too weak to travel and reluctant to do so at this stage.
After a welcome by President Clinton, the Israelis and the Syrians are expected to break into working groups. American officials will assist the sides whenever they are called on, but the goal will be to get them talking directly to each other.
Mr. Barak's office said security and water would be discussed before the thorny issue of borders, but the Syrians have maintained that the issue of borders is paramount and must come first.
Syria demands the full return of the Golan Heights, which Israel captured during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, down to the June 4, 1967, border. They see that border as reaching the shoreline of the Sea of Galilee. While Israel appears ready to concede territory, it is unwilling to withdraw beyond the international border established in 1923.
The difference is a few square miles, what Mr. Barak has called "a stone's throw," but it is a crucially located few miles, and the dispute has stymied the negotiations for years.
To avoid getting bogged down and to better assess Syria's flexibility on another issue, Mr. Barak prefers to start with a discussion of security issues. The Israelis would demand an internationally run monitoring station on Mount Hermon, on the new Israeli-Syrian border. Israelis have long insisted that there should be an Israeli force in that station, a proposal the Syrians reject entirely.
The Syrians reportedly prefer a satellite and aerial inspection system, according to accounts in several Arab newspapers. They hope to convince Mr. Barak, a former general, that warning stations on the ground would provide inferior intelligence to aerial systems.
Israel and Syria will also negotiate the deployment of Syrian troops and their proximity to the border.
"In the next week or 10 days, we will learn a lot about their readiness to accept our security demands," said Cabinet Minister Haim Ramon.
In his campaign for public opinion, Prime Minister Barak has received a direct assist from President Ezer Weizman, who is expected to stay neutral. Endorsing a withdrawal from the Golan Heights, Mr. Weizman has called this a critical juncture in which "peace has to come before everything else."
If an agreement is reached but a peace referendum fails an Israeli national vote, Mr. Weizman said he would "go home." When rightists protested that he should be the president of everyone and not take sides, Mr. Weizman shrugged and said that was "too hard."
Protesting Mr. Barak's "campaign of propaganda," Uzi Landau, a Likud Party legislator, called on fellow members of the opposition to reveal "the throwing of sand in the eyes." Some, indeed, have criticized the way that former generals, colleagues of Mr. Barak, are now reassessing the strategic value of the Golan Heights, which was long considered an invaluable geographic defense against Syrian aggression.
"Was it all a fraud?" Emmanuel Halperin, who anchors a television news program, asked a former general, Ori Orr, recently. "Was it 30 years of brainwashing? Were the opinions of all those American generals who said the Golan was indispensable to Israel's survival completely invalid?"
And even some ardent members of the peace camp have questioned the eagerness of many Israelis to accept a new reality overnight. Eitan Haber, a former senior aide to Mr. Rabin, responded to Mr. Barak's constant praise of Mr. Assad and to a glowing account in an Israeli newspaper from a reporter who sneaked into Syria.
"Suddenly it turns out that the Syrian dictator, Hafez Assad, is a brave, visionary, intelligent leader, a pursuer of peace, a great man and a real sweetheart," Mr. Haber wrote in a newspaper column. "And the Syrian people? Darlings. Damascus is wonderful. Generations of Syrians have been praying for nothing but peace. Every morning they wake up to the sound of 'Hatikva,' " the Israeli anthem, "and kiss the picture of Theodore Herzl."

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN THE MARKETS;
The Race toUnderwrite Nearly Sets a Record

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
On Wall Street, the 1990's ended in a virtual dead heat.
The total amount of money raised in the United States by investment banks, $2.1 trillion, almost reached the record amount raised in 1998. And the total number of stock and bond offerings in American markets -- 17,030 -- also fell just shy of 1998's total, according to Thomson Financial/Securities Data. 
 Still, in many ways, 1999 was a phenomenal year that will be remembered on Wall Street mostly for its feverish market for first-time stock offerings and for the era of European mega-mergers it ushered in. "It was a pretty extraordinary year in a whole bunch of respects," said Mark Tercek, co-head of the stock-underwriting business at the Goldman Sachs Group.
Never before had investors pumped so much money into shares of companies selling stock for the first time, many of them technology-based start-ups that had not earned a nickel of profit. Never before had the shares of so many newly public companies proceeded to soar, routinely doubling and often tripling from their offering prices.
Previous years are linked in the minds of many investors to the spectacular debuts of particular companies: Netscape in 1995, Yahoo in 1996, eBay in 1998. But 1999 was so chock-full of stock offerings that rose like rockets, it is likely to be remembered for its strength and breadth, rather than for specific success stories.
"The powerful aftermarket performance has been in the tech, telecom and media area," said Richard Kauffman, managing director of stock underwriting at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. "If a company is outside that area, it is very hard to get deals done."
As is usually the case, at least 90 cents of every dollar raised from investors came through sales of bonds, but the $2 trillion American bond market drew relatively scant attention. Certainly, it was a year in which technology stocks reigned and almost all other investments got short shrift.
"It is truly a reflection that this whole notion about this new economy that everyone's talking about, is, in fact, real," said Alan Sheriff, managing director of stock underwriting at Credit Suisse First Boston. To understand just how much the sands have shifted, Mr. Sheriff said, "Don't just look at what deals got done, look at what didn't get done."
With the exception of a small number of big stock offerings by blue-chip corporations, such as United Parcel Service's $5.47 billion initial public offering, traditional industries barely tapped the American stock market in 1999. In general, investment bankers wanted to sell stock for two kinds of companies: dominant, extremely profitable franchises or anything with a dot-com attached to it.
Two investment banks separated themselves from the competition, underwriting plenty of both kinds of stocks. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company ran neck-and-neck all year as the leading managers of stock offerings, which yield considerably bigger fees than bond offerings do.
In the end, Goldman, Sachs came out ahead, raising $33.7 billion to Morgan Stanley's $32.7 billion. Goldman's own initial public offering, which raised $3.66 billion in May and transformed the last big private partnership on Wall Street, made the difference.
Merrill Lynch & Company, the perennial leader in total underwriting, though not this year in fees, ranked a distant third in stock underwriting with $17.8 billion, followed closely by Credit Suisse First Boston. Powered by the technology banking team it hired away from Deutsche Bank, First Boston became a formidable competitor to the biggest investment banks in stock underwriting. First Boston managed 111 offerings that raised $15 billion last year, up from just $4.5 billion in 34 offerings in 1998.
Merrill again was the dominant underwriter of bonds, raising $299 billion through more than 1,800 offerings in a year that was disrupted by concerns about whether the coming of the year 2000 would alter investor behavior.
Jim Quigley, head of Merrill's global debt-origination business, said corporate borrowers rushed to issue bonds, in some cases in mammoth offerings, in the first half of the year out of fear that demand would dry up as the year-end approached. For their part, investors stored up cash with the hope of swooping in on bargains created by the anticipated dislocation in bond markets, he said.
"In the fourth quarter, people realized that that investment strategy was somewhat flawed and they had to fast-forward their investment plans," Mr. Quigley said. "Those fears really dissipated and money started coming back in the marketplace. We finished the year pretty strong."
Mr. Quigley said he expected that strength to carry into January, as some borrowers rushed to sell bonds before the Federal Reserve Board meets again in early February. The Fed governors are widely expected to raise interest rates again at that meeting.
Mark Siegel, the head of Morgan Stanley's bond-underwriting business, said the most notable development in 1999 was the speed with which corporations, such as Ford Motor and DuPont, were able to sell billions of dollars' worth of bonds to investors around the world. In one case last fall, he said, Morgan Stanley rounded up buyers for $7 billion of DuPont bonds in 24 hours.
"That's a great example of the tremendous liquidity in the market," Mr. Siegel said. "The fourth quarter was the slowest quarter of the year in terms of new-issue volume but activity didn't fall off a cliff as some were expecting."
Mr. Siegel said an ongoing boom in corporate mergers and acquisitions should continue to fuel activity in the bond markets. "Some borrowers have pent-up financing needs that they've delayed because of concerns over Y2K," he said.
Throughout the year, Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs also battled with Merrill for the crown in mergers and acquisitions. Each of the three New York-based firms advised on deals announced in 1999 with a combined value of more than $1 trillion.
Goldman ranked first, with 417 deals globally, worth $1.3 trillion. Morgan Stanley edged out Merrill Lynch, with each advising on deals worth about $1.1 trillion.
As long as the economies in Europe and the United States remain healthy, merger activity is likely to continue unabated, said Steven Heller, the head of Goldman's mergers business. "It is hard to find a geographic or industry sector that will not be active" in 2000, he said.
A wave of mergers swept across Europe in 1999, some of them leaping across national borders and others having a distinctly American, hostile flavor to them. At year-end, Vodafone AirTouch, a British telecommunications company, was pressing an unsolicited $148 billion bid for Mannesmann of Germany. Goldman is Vodafone's main adviser and Morgan Stanley and Merrill are among the firms advising Mannesmann on its defense.
Jack Levy, the head of Merrill's mergers business, predicted that 2000 would be a much bigger year for mergers. "The celestial bodies are all going to be in alignment this year for a very, very active merger business," he said.
One big factor, Mr. Levy said, will be the pressure some American companies will feel to complete acquisitions before accounting rule changes eliminate transactions structured as "poolings of interests," in which the acquiring company simply combines the other company's financial statements. Mr. Levy said he also expected financial-services companies to take advantage of recent changes in laws that have kept banks, investment banks and insurance companies out of one another's businesses for decades.
All told, investment banks took in about $3.23 billion in fees for advising on mergers that were consummated in 1999, up about 11 percent from $2.9 billion in 1998, according to Securities Data. That came on top of $12.1 billion in disclosed fees from underwriting sales of stock and bonds.
Morgan Stanley came out ahead of Goldman, Sachs in fees from underwriting that were reported to Securities Data, taking in about $1.9 billion, compared with about $1.75 billion for Goldman, Sachs. Merrill Lynch, which ranked third with $1.5 billion in fees, was the only one of the top five firms to take in less in fees for underwriting last year than in 1998.
Those standings demonstrate how much more lucrative it is to underwrite stocks than bonds. Investment banks receive as much as 7 percent of the proceeds from initial public offerings of stock, compared with fractions of 1 percent of the proceeds from big corporate bond offerings.
That is why investment bankers are cheering for a continuation of the boom in initial stock offerings and are happy to see newly public technology companies lining up to sell more stock in follow-on offerings. "There could be more I.P.O.'s this year than last year," said Mr. Tercek of Goldman. "But we think there could be more volume done on the follow-on side. It's going to be the follow-ons that make or break those companies."

HEADLINE: A Good Year for Family Fireworks Company

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
New Year's business was very, very good for Fireworks by Grucci, the pyrotechnics company in Brookhaven, N.Y., that the Grucci family has run for 130 years.
"This was probably the most important entertainment date in the history of the world," said M. Philip Butler, who is married to a Grucci daughter, Donna, and insists his title is chief operating brother-in-law. 
 It certainly was an important date in the history of Grucci. Typically, the Fourth of July is the big occasion for fireworks, with New Year's Eve a puny also-ran. But that was not the case last Friday.
Grucci, the highest-profile and most expensive of the country's fireworks providers, took in about $2.1 million for July 4, 1999; its revenue on Friday topped $3 million -- six times the amount the company pulled in on New Year's Eve in 1998. That year, it ran 12 fireworks shows; on Friday, it set off fireworks displays at 31 different places, places as disparate as the harbor in Dublin, private homes in the Hamptons and Jamaica, the Atlantis Casino on Paradise Island in the Bahamas and the exclusive Yellowstone ski club in Montana. It even lit up the Washington Monument.
Long-time clients, like the city of Honolulu, which would normally order a $30,000 show, paid $50,000 and more. And although Grucci did not raise its prices for the day, it refused to accept new clients who wanted to spend less than $100,000. "People doubled and tripled their budgets," Mr. Butler said.
They did get more for their money. Last year, Mr. Butler said, most clients were happy with 4-inch shells that would yield a display of 120 feet or so in diameter. This year, far more wanted 6-inch shells, which exploded into a 200-foot light show.
Delivering all the glitz was no mean feat. All year, Grucci had sent out feelers, through its Web site and by word of mouth, to lure the 100 extra technicians it knew it would need. Perhaps because Grucci paid them well over the $200 a technician would normally get for a few hours of holiday-night work, more than enough people came in for training.
To hear Mr. Butler tell it, all the programs went off without a hitch. There was one "annoyance," though, he said: In Washington, the schedule called for a short light show at midnight, followed by a longer one at 12:55 a.m., after another concert. On Saturday, several newspapers reported that the first show had been truncated by a computer problem.
"We didn't have one glitch, yet we were perceived as having a Y2K problem," Mr. Butler said.
The fireworks industry had reason to set off celebratory fireworks of its own. According to Mr. Butler, the industry's sales have been soaring since 1993. Corporations are using fireworks as a promotional tool, while rich individuals -- and, Mr. Butler notes, there are many more of them today than there were when the decade was young -- use them to make their parties special.
"It's the economy, pure and simple," Mr. Butler said. In the 1980's, he noted, some 70 percent of the company's revenues came from local governments putting on a show for the citizenry; today, 80 percent of the money is corporate or private.
Will the fireworks boom end now that the millennium hoopla has ended? Not if the economy keeps steaming along, Mr. Butler said.
"There'll be the 'first Labor Day of the 21st Century,' the 'first birthday of the 21st century,' any number of reasons to throw a show," Mr. Butler said. "As long as there's wealth, there will be people wanting to add some bang to their parties."

HEADLINE: Factories and Industries Continue Their Expansion

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
United States manufacturing expanded for the 11th consecutive month in December, and more companies reported paying higher prices for materials.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said today that its factory index was 55.5 last month, holding above 50 for the 11th time since January. That means more businesses reported improved conditions. December's reading was lower than November's 56.2, reflecting a slowdown in new orders and inventories. 
 "Even though the overall index was down, it's still so far ahead of break-even it shows the manufacturing side of the economy retains considerable momentum," said Ken Mayland, chief economist at KeyCorp in Cleveland.
Bonds and most stocks fell on expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers will push up interest rates to keep inflation in check.
The association's index of prices paid rose to 65.7 in December from 65.3 in November, indicating more companies reported price increases.
The overall National Association of Purchasing Management factory index has been above 50 since February, after declining in December 1998 to 45.3, the lowest reading since May 1991 when the economy was emerging from the last recession.
Prices manufacturers pay for some of the raw materials used to produce their goods have been rising for several months. Chief among them is oil. Since reaching a low last year of $11.37 a barrel in mid-February, crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange have more than doubled.
Crude for February delivery rose last week to $26.82 a barrel, near a nine-year high of $27.07 a barrel set Nov. 22.
Prices also have risen for metals, especially aluminum and copper used in manufacturing, and a variety of chemicals.
The December National Association of Purchasing Management price index was nonetheless below the October peak of 69.4, the highest in more than four years. "Prices paid for goods continue to rise, but at least they aren't accelerating," said Joel L. Naroff, chief economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
The drop in the association index was largely the result of a slower pace of domestic and export orders. The new orders index fell to 55.5 in December from 59.9 in November. The December level was the lowest since July. The export index, a gauge of international demand, fell to 53.4 in December from 54.5 in November.
The inventory index, a gauge of pent-up demand, fell to 47.2 in December -- the lowest in four months -- from 50 in November. The production index rose to 58.7 in December from 57.4 during November.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall Amid Concern Fed Will Raise Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on the first trading day of the new year. As investor fears about the Year 2000 problem eased, they were replaced with a new one: that the Federal Reserve will begin raising interest rates aggressively.
Bonds came under pressure early, falling victim to the selling of issues bought as a safe haven before the changeover to 2000, sending yields to their highest levels in more than two years. Yields inched higher when the National Association of Purchasing Management's index of factory activity showed it had expanded for the 11th month in a row, and an index of prices paid by manufacturers rose. 
 The price of the 30-year bond posted its biggest decline since May, dropping 1 23/32, to 93 20/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.62 percent from 6.48 percent on Friday.
Yesterday's purchasing report provided more evidence of a strong economy and raised concern that the Fed, which meets next month, would increase short-term rates to keep the economy's nine-year expansion from causing inflation to accelerate.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said that the overall fundamental issues regarding the economy were still fine and that consumer confidence remained high for the right reasons. That indicates continued economic growth of more than 4 percent in the first quarter, he said.
Mr. Donne said he thought the Fed had been holding back on raising rates in case any Year 2000 problems emerged. But with the smooth transition, companies will continue strong capital spending in technology, he said.
"The market appears to be en route to pricing a 50-basis-point move by the Fed in the first quarter. Some futures market participants feel it will come in two 25-basis point moves, while others think it could happen in one step," he said.
"Also," he added, "people expect that the Fed will begin to take back all that extra liquidity it provided the market in anticipation of the millennium turn in the fourth quarter. And just as they provided that liquidity gradually they will likely withdraw it slowly."
Another factor dwelling on the market was improved global economic performance, Mr. Donne said. That will make non-United States assets more appealing than they have been recently. Yesterday, the dollar fell against the euro and the Japanese yen, which Mr. Donne said produced a more balanced distribution of global investment dollars. That kept many foreign investors from buying United States securities.
The market is now waiting for employment numbers on Friday, with many market watchers expecting the average number of jobs added to the economy to come in at 240,000. The 12-month moving average has been just more than 225,000 a month, an indication of strong economic expansion.
"Pyschologically, last year was not a good year for bonds in the face of the strong stock market," Mr. Donne said. "Asset allocations could be a factor now."
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A struggling J. C. Penney begins a search for a new agency to handle its $110 million account.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
FOR the last month, Madison Avenue has been wondering whether holiday sales results would set off significant shifts in the advertising plans of the myriad dot-com start-up retailers, particularly those that poured vast sums into campaigns to attract shoppers.
As it turned out, the first big change of the post-Christmas period is being made by a bricks-and-mortar retailer, the J. C. Penney Company, rather than an upstart dot-com. Penney, which has been struggling to improve the performance of its 1,150 department stores in an increasingly competitive retail field, is dismissing its agency, Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., after almost nine years. 
 The dismissal comes before Penney and other traditional retailers announce holiday shopping results. But analysts said they expected the company to continue its recent disappointments and also lag its primary rival, Sears, Roebuck & Company. Sales have declined for Penney, the nation's fifth largest retailer, as have earnings, and in December Penney reduced its quarterly common-stock dividend for the first time in 40 years. Tellingly, Sears has just revamped its own ad plans, arranging for its two principal agencies to collaborate on a national campaign for the first time.
The Penney decision puts into play an account with billings estimated at $110 million to $115 million, out of a total budget for Penney estimated at $300 million. That figure includes ads like preprinted circulars, which Temerlin McClain does not produce.
Temerlin McClain has handled assignments for Penney since the summer of 1991 like the creation of national corporate campaigns carrying themes including "The best place to spend this holiday season," "Doing it right" and "The look. Look who." Media buying has been handled by Mediavest in New York, part of the MacManus Group.
Temerlin McClain's hold on the Penney account, one of its largest, has been slipping as the client continued to encounter difficulties in finding a niche between specialty chains like Gap, operated by Gap Inc., and discounters like Wal-Mart Stores and the Target unit of Dayton Hudson.
In the last year, Temerlin McClain lost two important Penney tasks to the Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, owned by the Omnicom Group. One was the Arizona Jeans account, for the denim duds sold under that brand name at Penney stores, and the other was the Penney home lines account. Each assignment had billings estimated at $20 million.
"J. C. Penney is a company with a lot of potential," Dennis McClain, chief executive and executive creative director at Temerlin McClain, part of True North Communications, said yesterday, confirming a report about the review in the trade publication Advertising Age, "and we had a great relationship for many years."
"But there have been tremendous management changes," he added, "and the business was not what we'd all like it to be. This was a move they felt they had to make in terms of getting their house in order."
Mr. McClain described the Penney decision to place its account in review and not ask Temerlin McClain to take part as "mutually agreed upon," adding that he was formally notified by the retailer yesterday.
"We're sad to lose any major piece of business," Mr. McClain said, "but changes happen when things aren't working right."
Penney accounted for about 10 percent of Temerlin McClain's annual revenue of $80 million. About 100 of the agency's 700 employees have worked on Penney assignments in some fashion; of the 100, 32 to 37 are considered the core group.
"There will be some modest reduction in staff," Mr. McClain said, "but this will not amount to a tremendous economic issue for us." The agency will continue creating campaigns for the St. John's Bay line of apparel sold in Penney stores.
Mr. McClain said he was told by Penney executives that True North would be "invited to participate" in the review "as a holding company, putting together a group to pursue the business" that would not include Temerlin McClain. Among other True North agencies are the Bozell Group and FCB Worldwide.
Kathryn Woods, a spokeswoman in New York for True North, said the agency company had not heard from Penney but "would welcome the opportunity to participate" in the review. Pat Sloan, a spokeswoman in New York for DDB, said, "If asked, we'd be happy to participate."
Stephanie Brown, a spokeswoman for Penney, which is based in Plano, Tex., said she could not identify the agencies being asked to take part in the review, which is to be completed in March. "Temerlin McClain has been greatly valued for its contributions," she added, but "it's time for a change."
The decision to "hold a review came after several months of careful consideration regarding the needs of our business," Ms. Brown said, adding that the successor to Temerlin McClain would handle that agency's duties as well as tasks like media planning and buying.
Temerlin McClain won its Penney assignments from what is now the N. W. Ayer & Partners unit of MacManus, which had worked for the retailer since 1983. A major makeover for Penney in the 1980's, emphasizing clothing and home furnishings rather than mass merchandise like appliances, helped sales throughout most of the 1980's; Ayer conveyed that in campaigns carrying the theme "Fashion comes to life." However, in the early 1990's, when Penney sales slumped during the recession, Ayer became a casualty.
And for those who keep track of such things, the Penney Internet retailing operation (www.jcpenney .com) came in 19th among the 20 most-visited shopping Web sites from Nov. 14 to Dec. 26, according to Media Metrix, a market research company. Penney was the only bricks-and-mortar department store on the list.

HEADLINE: American Leadership at the U.N.

 BODY:
This month is America's turn to preside over the United Nations Security Council. That duty rotates among the body's 15 members. While the powers of the council presidency are limited, the job involves close coordination with Secretary General Kofi Annan and considerable control over the council's agenda. Washington can use this opportunity to press for action on a global front.
Richard Holbrooke, the United States' permanent representative, properly wants to make the long-neglected problems of Africa a theme of his tenure as council president. But while doing so, he must also work on trouble spots like Iraq, Kosovo and East Timor, where timely U.N. action is imperative. 
 Mr. Holbrooke encountered African issues like ethnic persecution, brutal civil war and AIDS firsthand on a recent visit to the continent. On his return, he announced plans to hold council sessions on such strife-torn countries as Burundi, Congo and Sierra Leone. He also wants to devote at least one session to the social and economic devastation wrought by AIDS, especially in southern Africa. Those sessions are welcome and appropriate, although past United Nations debates on Africa have offered little more than pious talk.
But other, non-African issues also demand the council's attention. In Iraq, the first steps must be taken to put a hard-won new Security Council resolution on arms inspections into effect. Mr. Holbrooke needs to ensure that an independent and credible chief is chosen for the new arms inspection agency that will be created. He also ought to urge France and Russia to persuade Saddam Hussein to accept the resolution. It offers the prospect of suspending some economic sanctions in return for cooperating with the monitoring.
In Kosovo, start-up problems that have plagued U.N. administrators, particularly in policing, have to be addressed before they become intractable. Mr. Holbrooke, who knows the Balkans well, should help Bernard Kouchner, who directs U.N. operations in Kosovo, get the political backing from U.N. headquarters that he needs to succeed. Mr. Holbrooke should also prod European governments to follow through on their financial commitments to the Kosovo operation and urge all countries to live up to their commitments to provide volunteers for the international police force there.
In Indonesia, some 100,000 East Timorese refugees are still being terrorized by pro-Indonesian militias in West Timor. Mr. Holbrooke, who played a firsthand part last summer in persuading Jakarta to accept a more active U.N. role in Timor, can now help press Indonesia's new democratic government and its military leaders to disarm those militias and let the refugees return home.
After a long period of estrangement between the United States and the United Nations, the elements are now in place for a more constructive relationship. Congress has at last agreed on a plan to pay most of America's back dues. Mr. Annan is showing himself to be one of the bolder leaders to hold the secretary general's job in recent years, raising the U.N.'s public profile and helping to restore its reputation with the release of self-critical reports on past failings in Bosnia and Rwanda.
Mr. Holbrooke brings political clout and diplomatic skills to the job of American representative. This month is the Clinton administration's last chance to preside over the Security Council and America's first chance to shape the international diplomacy of a new millennium. Mr. Holbrooke should make bold use of this opportunity.

HEADLINE: Lehman Hires Former Salomon Analyst

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. named David Shulman, the former chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers Inc. who lost his job in 1997 after years of being incorrectly bearish on the United States stock market, as senior real estate investment trust equity analyst.
Mr. Shulman, 56, will report to Steven Hash, who was Lehman's top REIT analyst before being promoted to director of United States equity research last year for the concern, the fourth-largest United States securities firm. Mr. Shulman started covering the real estate industry in 1986 while at Salomon Brothers. 
 Since January 1998, Mr. Shulman has been with Ulysses Management, where he was an investment manager for two private funds.
Mr. Shulman was ousted from Salomon Brothers after the firm merged with Smith Barney He was known for his longstanding pessimistic view of United States stocks and saying Asian economies were much worse than many believed.
In his last weekly strategy note for Salomon in December 1997, Mr. Shulman said he remained bearish and that the Dow Jones industrial average could fall to 6,600 to 7,000, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stox index could drop to between 770 and 815.
The Dow Jones average closed yesterday at 11,357.51, while the S.& P. 500 ended at 1,455.22.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil Having Second Thoughts About Foreign Bank Inroads

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Perhaps no trend has made its mark on Sao Paulo's changing cityscape more than the proliferation of foreign-owned banks. After a wave of takeovers and heavy investments in recent years, many Brazilian banks have been nudged aside by institutions with un-Portuguese sounding names, like Santander, HSBC and BankBoston.
However, the growth of these banks -- with their colorful nameplates, billboard advertisements and increasing clout in this nation's financial services industry -- is coming under criticism. Fearful of the encroachment of foreign financial institutions, some of Brazil's most powerful bankers are urging the government to limit the power of foreign financial institutions. 
 "The richest countries of the world are wise enough to realize that national interests coincide with a strong, domestically led financial system," said Fernao Bracher, a former central bank president who now heads Banco BBA-Creditanstalt, a Sao Paulo bank with Austrian shareholders, though majority owned by Brazilians. "Why should Brazil, a developing country, be run roughshod over?"
A reminder of the foreign banking industry's expansion in Brazil came today with news that the government had approved a request by the Bank of New York, one of the biggest and oldest banks in the United States, to purchase a controlling interest inCredibanco, a Sao Paulo bank with large corporate lending and asset management operations. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but the Bank of New York had owned 50 percent of Credibanco for some time.
Much of the simmering debate over limiting foreign banks has to do with the privatization planned for later this year of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo, one of the country's largest banks. Institutions as diverse as Citigroup's Citibank unit, and Banco Bradesco, the largest Brazilian bank not owned by the government, have shown interest in buying Banespa, as the bank is called.
After the central government said last month that it would authorize foreign institutions to bid for Banespa, domestic competitors grew nervous. According to local reports, they began a behind-the-scenes lobbying effort to ensure that foreigners would be limited in trying to buy Banespa by, for instance, being forced to bid in a consortium controlled by a Brazilian partner.
Their reasoning is based on what they view as excessive foreign bank incursions in recent years. There have been multibillion-dollar acquisitions by Britain's Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, a unit of HSBC Holdings, and ABN-Amro, the Dutch giant. Other institutions, notably Spanish banks like Banco Santander Central Hispano and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya, have also made large forays into Brazil's financial system.
"The foreigners have extremely deep pockets," said Paul Bydalek, the president of Atlantic Rating, a Brazilian banking analysis company. "They don't necessarily understand the nuances of Brazil's magnificent chaos."
Essentially, this means that Brazilian banks tend, in some instances, to support the stability of the financial system in times of crisis. For instance, in the tumult that followed the devaluation of the currency nearly a year ago, some foreign banks counseled their clients to avoid purchasing Brazilian government bonds and other securities, citing the risk of default.
Yet the largest Brazilian banks, such as Bradesco and Banco Itau, continued to refinance government bonds much as they had done during the last several decades. In fact, the Brazilian institutions that buy more than 90 percent of the country's domestic bonds made out well in 1999 since most of these securities were linked to the dollar or to interest rates, which remained high for most of the year.
There are signs that the government is acknowledging this type of argument. "Foreign banks could cause a problem in not wanting to roll over our debt so some type of ceiling on their share of the system might be a good idea," Rubens Barbosa, Brazil's ambassador to the United States, said in a telephone interview.
Advocates of opening the banking system to greater foreign participation say this thinking is misguided and exaggerates the influence of foreign banks in Brazil's economy. Foreign banks account for about 30 percent of banking assets in Brazil, but they account for more than half of assets in neighboring Argentina, where privatization and deregulation have been carried out to a larger degree.
"I think it is pure self-interest in avoiding competition," said Gustavo Franco, a former president of the central bank who was responsible for engineering Brazil's opening of the financial system to foreign investment in the 1990's.
"Ask the consumer if he prefers a foreign or Brazilian bank and you'll be told his choice is the one which provides the best service," Mr. Franco said.
The debate surrounding foreign banks is largely limited to the area of consumer banking, which provides clients with services like checking and savings accounts. In the more exclusive world of investment banking, foreign institutions have made enormous inroads in Brazil, including the purchase of the country's leading investment bank, Garantia, by the Credit Suisse Group.
Whereas two or three years ago Brazilian investment banks like Garantia or Banco Pactual of Rio de Janeiro dominated areas like trading equities on the Sao Paulo stock exchange, or underwriting stock and bond issues for Brazilian companies, today foreign banks account for much of these business areas.
This trend shows few signs of letting up, as reflected in the Bank of New York deal for Credibanco.
After the deal is completed, 53 of the 118 banks in Brazil that are not controlled by the government, whether in the areas of consumer or investment banking, will be foreign-owned.

HEADLINE: Chicago Minority Program Aids Firm Run by White Men

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 3

 BODY:
An investigation ordered by City Hall has found that a major beneficiary of a program intended to help entrepreneurs outside the old-boy network is a company run by a white former union official and his sons.
Like many other big cities, Chicago reserves 25 percent of its contracts for businesses run by women or members of racial minorities. One of the big winners under the set-aside program has been a janitorial business, Windy City Maintenance, which lists its chief as Patricia Green. The city awarded the company tens of millions of dollars in contracts during the 90's. 
 But the investigation found that the company is being run by Ms. Green's husband, John Duff Jr., a former vice president of the Allied Distillery and Wine Workers International Union, and their two sons -- scarcely the kind of outsiders the program is designed to help.
The investigation was ordered after The Chicago Tribune reported in July that Mr. Duff and his sons were running the company. The newspaper said the Duff family controlled businesses that reaped $100 million in city contracts in the 1990's. Mr. Duff served 17 months in prison in the early 1980's for embezzling union funds.
Lawyers at City Hall said on Friday, in announcing the findings of the investigation, that Windy City Maintenance had been stripped of its status as a woman-run company and would lose its contract within 60 days. City officials also said they would monitor businesses that claimed to be run by women and minorities, to guard against fraud.
A spokeswoman for Windy City said today that no one would comment on the matter.
Mayor Richard M. Daley, who has sought to portray fairness to minorities as a hallmark of his administration, will speak about the Duff case at a news conference on Tuesday, aides said. Mr. Daley's support among blacks is considered softer than his rock-solid white base, so the mayor has been careful to guard against anything that would stir resentment among minority voters.
The set-aside program has been seen as a potentially dangerous issue for Mr. Daley, especially if it seems that white men are taking advantage of programs intended to help women and minorities.
Mayor Daley last week announced a program to recruit more companies owned by women and minorities, especially blacks, to do business with the city. Some black aldermen have complained that only 9 percent of the $1.3 billion in contracts awarded by the city through September 1998 have gone to blacks.
Mr. Daley, who said he agreed that the percentage of blacks getting city business was too low, said "the pool has to be expanded in some way." The mayor named Barbara Lumpkin, the city treasurer, to head a task force to determine the best way to find more minority-run companies.
Until now, city officials have simply accepted the word of companies that say they are run by women or minorities, said Jacqueline Heard, a spokeswoman for the mayor.
"We've had to rely on the integrity of the companies we do business with," Ms. Heard said.
But now, to guard against fraud, city officials will conduct on-site checks at the companies and talk to customers to make sure that businesses are complying with the law.
Ms. Heard said Windy City had been deserving of its status as women-run until recently. "It was in fact owned and operated by a woman," she said, adding that company officials still insisted that Ms. Green was the head of the business.
But Ms. Heard said it was clear to city officials that Ms. Green had stepped down from her day-to-day management of Windy City and largely handed over business responsibilities to her sons.
That transfer of power has made Windy City ineligible to retain its status as a women-run business, Ms. Heard said.
For the Daley administration, the problem with the set-aside program was a rare setback. Less than a year after his latest landslide election victory, Mr. Daley commands overwhelming support with the 50-member City Council.
In its report, The Chicago Tribune said that the Duff family and enterprises they control had contributed more than $30,000 to Mayor Daley's campaigns. The newspaper said the Duffs had played host to at least two fund-raisers for the mayor, including a breakfast last February attended by Mr. Daley.

HEADLINE: Few Year 2000 Glitches Are Reported on First Working Day

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Year 2000 computer glitches began appearing as much of the world headed back to work yesterday after the New Year's holiday, but they remained scattered and, for the most part, trivial.
The nation's financial institutions, including the New York Stock Exchange, opened Year 2000 trading without a hitch. The relatively smooth sailing continued not just in the United States, which spent over $100 billion on Year 2000 preparations, according to government estimates, but also in foreign nations that had spent far less. 
 "We're seeing that there were no threatening effects in the companies," Salvador Bellido, vice president of the Spanish Confederation of Medium and Small Businesses, told the news agency Europa Press. "We're beginning to think that all this has been set up for someone's benefit. I don't know if it was Bill Gates or who," he added, referring to Microsoft's chief executive.
As they have been doing ever since the rollover to 2000 occurred on Saturday with no major disruptions, computer experts and government officials repeated their convictions that testing in recent years had amply proved that the threat had been real. They also said that the similar outcomes around the world for such varying investments were not surprising once the different levels of dependence on computer technology were taken into account.
Basic services like power, telephones and water run with little or no help from computers in many countries, said Bruce W. McConnell, director of the International Y2K Cooperation Center, the United Nations-sponsored Year 2000 information clearinghouse in Washington. And late starters at home and overseas benefited from the experience of others. "It was possible to catch up with a modest expenditure because the tools had become very efficient," Mr. McConnell said.
In addition, where computers are used overseas, they are often older systems with much simpler programming and fewer links to other equipment, making repairs simpler, according to the Gartner Group, an information technology consulting firm in Stamford, Conn.
But Mr. McConnell and others monitoring Year 2000 incidents said the continuing good news did not close the books on Year 2000 risks. He cited as an example the unknown status of government systems in numerous developing countries. "We haven't seen their payrolls run yet," he said.
Others cautioned that even in the United States, things have not been going quite as flawlessly as the public reports to date might suggest. Gartner Group said it had received confidential reports of about 400 Year 2000 flaws by midafternoon, mostly among midsized and smaller clients and nearly all of them fixed within hours of their discovery.
"That's a significant increase over yesterday, about 50 percent," said Louis Marcoccio, Gartner's Year 2000 research director.
Many of the flaws showing up are too silly to even be irritating. For a time Vice President Al Gore's Town Hall Web page (www.algore2000
.com) informed visitors it was Jan. 3, 19100 if they arrived via a Netscape browser and Jan. 3, 192000 if they came to the site using Microsoft's Internet Explorer. An automated selection program of a telephone service that reads The New York Times and other newspapers to blind New Yorkers informed clients they would be hearing the Jan. 3, 1900, issue.
But some problems reflect the kind of flaws that consultants fear could put pressure on some computer users as the days go by. One electronics company told Gartner that it had discovered a Year 2000 error that generated faulty orders. It caught the mistake before any shipments went astray but not before the bad data had been sent to a larger database including records used for other activities like telemarketing.
"It's going to take several days to clean up the database," Mr. Marcoccio said. "Meanwhile, they have set up a temporary database to handle orders and they will eventually have to go back and mix the two."
Mr. Marcoccio said his concerns about small business were reinforced yesterday morning when he visited his dentist in suburban Boston and encountered an apparent Year 2000 problem. He was the first patient of 2000, and when the secretary tried to set up his next appointment, the computer system crashed. Efforts to get it started generated error messages suggesting that some patient records may have been destroyed, he added.
Over all, though, Gartner and others say the news continued to be encouraging. The Tokyo stock exchange, which was closed yesterday, opened without trouble this morning. Hubs in the distribution system like McKesson HBOC, a San Francisco-based pharmaceutical distributor, reported no problems with orders and shipments. Industrial giants like General Motors began manufacturing with no discernible hitches.
"It's definitely looking good," said Jeffrey Cripps, who has overseen DaimlerChrysler's Year 2000 interactions with its many suppliers.
One problem cited by government officials yesterday morning as potentially critical prevented kidney dialysis equipment manufactured by Gambros, a Swedish company, from running through an automated cleaning cycle at the end of the day. But that failure was actually discovered during testing Saturday in Scotland in two models that are not sold in the United States, according to Tim Schoenberg, a Gambros spokesman in Aliso Viejo, Calif., who added that no patients had been harmed and that it was easily circumvented.
Perhaps the most widely reported problem over the weekend -- the failure Friday night of a ground station that processes information from military satellites -- was put to rest when the Pentagon reported it was operating normally today.
John A. Koskinen, chairman of the President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion, said he did not expect any of the disruptions likely to arise from here on to be broad enough to have any impact on the national economy.
Other signs of growing confidence included a trickle of consumers returning propane heaters and other devices purchased as insurance against disruptions to Home Depot, Sears Roebuck and other retailers. Sears is charging 20 percent of the cost for "restocking." Charity groups like Second Harvest began collecting food donations from consumers who had decided they no longer needed some of the food supplies they had put aside.
Susan Earl, director of development for the Second Harvest chapter in Nashville, said, "The calls started coming in right after we arrived at 9 a.m."
