HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks Begin The New Year On Mixed Note

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks began the new year with a topsy-turvy performance yesterday, as technology and Internet shares bolted to new records even as broad swaths of the market slumped in the wake of a sharp rise in long-term interest rates.
Observers who only note the closing quotes for major market averages would probably comment that the Nasdaq composite index continued to perform as it did throughout much of December, when it rose in what seemed like a straight line. 
 Indeed, the Nasdaq, which ended 1999 with a record, did so again yesterday. Led by companies like JDS Uniphase, Yahoo and CMGI, the index gained 61.84 points, or 1.52 percent, to 4,131.15.
But the road to the close was bumpy.
Within minutes of the opening, the Nasdaq was up more than 122, to as high as 4,192.19. The index then reversed and fell as low as 3,989.71 -- a swing of 202.48.
By contrast, the performance of the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was more consistent: both measures moved lower shortly after the opening bell, and stayed down throughout the session.
The bond market's bad day hit financial service stocks particularly hard as investors feared the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates now that Year 2000 computer glitches have not materialized.
The Dow closed at 11,357.51, down 139.61 points, or 1.21 percent. American Express, General Electric and J. P. Morgan were the Dow's biggest losers. Cyclical stocks like Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing and Alcoa -- companies whose businesses are also sensitive to rising rates -- also registered declines.
Weakness in bank and brokerage stocks, as well as oil and big retailers helped to drag down the S.& P. 500 index by 14.03 points, or 0.95 percent, to 1,455.22.
And the Russell 2000 index of smaller cap stocks was also hammered. The index fell 8.33 points, or 1.65 percent, to 496.42.
"It is very difficult to back out an investment thesis from today's session, even though the backup in bond yields was dramatic," said Satya Pradhuman, director of small cap research at Merrill Lynch & Co.
"Some of this might be an unwinding of the fast run-up we saw last week."
Indeed, while many spent much of December worrying the Federal Reserve would move to raise short-term interest rates at its February meeting, nearly as many said they expected to see investors take advantage of the strong move in December stock prices and take some profits early in the new year, thereby delaying capital gains taxes until 2001.
"An awful lot of people have expected tremendous tax selling," said Fred Kobrick, president and chief executive of Kobrick Funds, a Boston-based mutual fund company.
Despite the big swings in prices, traders said the market was fairly quiet. On the New York Stock Exchange, more than 931.8 million shares changed hands. Volume on the Nasdaq stock market was 1.48 billion shares.
"The volatility would connote there was more activity than was actually going on," said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jefferies & Company.
JDS Uniphase led the rise in the Nasdaq, climbing 26 3/16, to 187 1/2. The stock jumped after the manufacturer of parts used in fiber-optic equipment announced plans for its third 2-for-1 stock split since July.
CMGI gained 49 9/16, to 326 7/16. America Online was up 7 1/8, to 83. And Yahoo jumped 42 5/16, to 475.
Strength in technology was not limited to companies whose corporate history did not begin at some point in the 1990's.
I.B.M. gained 7 11/16, to 115 9/16. Hewlett-Packard was up 3 11/16, to 117 7/16. And Intel rose 4 5/8, to 86 15/16. All three companies are components of the Dow Jones industrial average.
Among financial stocks, American Express slid 9, to 157 1/4. J. P. Morgan fell 5 3/16, to 121 7/16. Citigroup fell 3, to 52 11/16. And General Electric shed 4 3/4, to 150.
Brokerage stocks also fell. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter tumbled 7 3/4, to 135. Merrill Lynch fell 2 11/16, to 80 5/8. And Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette lost 1 7/16, to 46 15/16.
It was a good day for biotechnology stocks. Amgen rose 2 15/16, to 63, on expectations that it will beat fourth-quarter earnings estimates and is on track to win approval of two new drugs. Genentech rose 1 1/2, to 136.

HEADLINE: U.A.W. Chief Uses Contract To Recapture Political Sway

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 3

 BODY:
In the past, presidents of the United Automobile Workers union, men like Walter Reuther and Douglas A. Fraser, were well-known national figures not just because they could shut down the world's largest companies but also because they were politically influential and frequently on television.
Stephen P. Yokich, the union's president since 1995, has taken a different approach, shunning the limelight and focusing on contract issues. Believing that he can communicate most effectively with his members through local union leaders, he has said virtually nothing in public during strikes and other showdowns with auto makers. While he has visited Washington frequently to discuss issues like trade and global warming, he has favored private meetings with politicians. 
 But now Mr. Yokich is trying to rebuild the political power of the union, most notably by negotiating paid holidays for 400,000 workers at General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler on Election Day in 2000 and 2002. The prospect that more union workers might turn out to vote, hand out pamphlets and drive other Democrats to polling booths has alarmed Republicans.
The tricky part for Mr. Yokich, pollsters and politicians said, will be persuading the rank and file to vote for candidates endorsed by union leaders. Earning $50,000 to $120,000 a year, the union's members are too affluent to benefit from Democratic social spending, and prosperous enough to be concerned about income tax rates. Many members are conservative on social issues.
Yet the leadership has tended to support Democrats, particularly for president, perceiving them as friendlier on workers' rights.
Mr. Yokich said the union must emphasize political concerns that apply to all members and transcend partisan politics. "We support those who support us; the party doesn't matter," he said in an interview.
Two such concerns, he said, are international trade and global warming. The problem is that neither former Senator Bill Bradley nor Vice President Al Gore has taken Mr. Yokich's positions on either issue. The union will endorse a presidential candidate next month; it had opposed the A.F.L.-C.I.O's decision to endorse Mr. Gore early, in October.
Mr. Yokich advocates balancing free trade with what he calls "fair trade," requiring other countries to follow rules similar to those in the United States on safety, the environment and workers' rights to form unions. He is particularly critical of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which he says has destroyed more high-paying jobs than it has created, an assertion questioned by many economists.
But Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore have track records of supporting free trade. Mr. Yokich said he had been disappointed that they were not at a peaceful protest by union members at the recent meeting of the World Trade Organization in Seattle.
Global warming is another difficult issue for Mr. Yokich. With each gallon of gasoline they burn, automobiles release heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, so environmentalists have begun lobbying for more stringent fuel-economy rules. But the union contends that tougher rules are unnecessary because many other industries contribute to the problem and because developing nations have not agreed to limits on their emissions of such gases. Mr. Bradley and particularly Mr. Gore have both called for tighter fuel-economy rules. While Mr. Bradley has been less outspoken than Mr. Gore, he supported a Senate resolution calling for stiffer fuel-economy rules on sport utility vehicles and other light trucks, which are allowed much worse fuel economy than cars. The measure was narrowly defeated on Sept. 15 after the union joined automakers in strenuous lobbying against it.
Mr. Yokich said he had expressed concerns to Mr. Gore about the Clinton administration's policies on global warming, but quickly added that he was a friend of the environment.
"I talk to the Sierra Club, so you can't just say, 'he's about jobs for his members'," Mr. Yokich said. "I belong to the Sierra Club, I belong to Ducks Unlimited."
Mr. Fraser said that Mr. Yokich had to become more active politically because the most pressing issues facing the union, like international competition, environmental protections and health care, could not be settled at the bargaining table with auto makers.
"The future of the members of the U.A.W. rests with Congress and the legislative process more than it ever did in the past," Mr. Fraser said. "That's why you have to get more involved in the political process."

HEADLINE: 1763 Tavern Is Shutting Its Doors For a While

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
In its 237 years, Fraunces Tavern has survived the American Revolution, a devastating fire and a terrorist bombing.
For the most recent half-century or so, the historic tavern where Gen. George Washington gave his farewell speech to his troops in 1783 has been run by the Norden family. 
 But the establishment faces a modern-day Manhattan problem, high real estate costs, and the owner, Robert Norden Jr., says he is being evicted.
Last-minute negotiations yesterday with the building's owner, a historic society called the Sons of the Revolution, failed, Mr. Norden said. So he began loading much of his office equipment into moving vehicles, and when the restaurant's employees report to work today, they will come to move, not to cook.
For the last eight years, Mr. Norden said, he has run the tavern on a month-to-month lease that amounted to about $300,000 each year.
But late last year, he said, the board refused to act on a 10-year lease he proposed that would have kept the rate steady.
Last night, Mr. Norden said, the owners rejected his request to extend the lease for a few more months while both parties try to reach an agreement on a long-term lease, and they told him he had to leave.
Board members of the Sons of the Revolution could not be reached yesterday by phone.
"You may think that the real estate is worth more because it's Wall Street, the economy is good, but it is a tavern," Mr. Norden said, adding that because of the location in the financial district, which is busy only on weekdays, it was not feasible to open on weekends.
The New York City Landmarks and Preservation commissioner has designated the building, which also includes a museum, a historic site. City officials say this limits the types of uses and alterations that can be made to the building, so even if Mr. Norden's family is pushed out, it is likely that it would probably be leased to someone who would operate some sort of bar or tavern.
The original Fraunces Tavern building was erected in 1719 as a Georgian-style house for Steven DeLancey. In 1763, the building was converted into a tavern by Samuel Fraunces, and it was there 20 years later that General Washington gave his famous farewell address to the officers who helped the United States gain its freedom from Britain. In a second-floor room just above the restaurant, the general told his troops, "with a heart full of love and gratitude, I now take leave of you."
Later, in 1900, the original building was destroyed in a fire that tore through Lower Manhattan.
Seven years later, the tavern was rebuilt at the same location. In 1975, 4 people were killed and 53 injured when a bomb set by the F.A.L.N., a group of Puerto Rican terrorists, went off in the building. More recently the tavern has been a popular tourist spot.

HEADLINE: Tobacco and Its Money Have Minority Allies in New York

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
State Senator Efrain Gonzalez Jr. of the Bronx decided to open a Washington office for a Hispanic legislators' association a few years ago, figuring that he would have little trouble raising the necessary $40,000. Following something of a tradition among black and Hispanic members of the New York Legislature, Mr. Gonzalez called a lobbyist for Philip Morris, and came away with the entire amount.
A colleague from the borough, Assemblywoman Gloria Davis, receives $5,000 annually from Philip Morris, the world's largest tobacco company, for a Thanksgiving meal for the poor in her predominantly black district. Seeking aid for a program to teach nonviolence to young people, Ms. Davis said that she raised $22,000 from another cigarette giant, R. J. Reynolds. 
 Such corporate grants are not only a cornerstone in a decades-old campaign by the cigarette companies to foster good will in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, an important cigarette market. The grants have also helped the industry cement ties to black and Hispanic officials, who are often one of the few factions in the Democratic Party to oppose new restrictions on smoking.
While the industry is increasingly ostracized by many politicians in New York, some black and Hispanic state lawmakers depict it as a kindhearted corporate citizen, playing down the health consequences of smoking and asserting that they are not in a position to reject assistance from companies making legal products.
That alliance in New York, which has parallels in Washington and other state capitals, has until recently been a significant factor in the industry's enviable record in Albany. Even last month, when the tide suddenly turned against the tobacco companies in the Legislature for the first time since 1993, some black and Hispanic lawmakers came to their defense.
The lawmakers questioned a move by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders to pay for an expansion of health care for the uninsured in part by nearly doubling the cigarette tax, a measure that delighted antismoking groups. Ultimately, the lawmakers said they supported the bill because they did not want to hinder a new health-care program, but among Democrats, their views stood out.
"Another cigarette tax is a little out of hand," said Mr. Gonzalez, who until last month was president of the legislators' group, the National Hispanic Caucus of State Legislators. "It just looks sexy politically."
Antismoking groups say they are dismayed by the lawmakers' stances, contending that because blacks in particular smoke more and suffer higher rates of smoking-related illnesses than whites, the lawmakers should treat the industry more harshly. Such criticism has arisen before. But documents disclosed recently by the industry in smoking litigation cast the dispute in a new light, showing the extent of its generosity -- and links to policymaking.
An internal Philip Morris document from 1988, for example, lists roughly 125 black groups that the company assisted across the nation: from the Bedford-Stuyvesant Real Estate Board (which received $200), to the Georgia Legislative Black Caucus ($6,000) to the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Club ($12,000).
Next to some of the listings are the names of black politicians from New York and elsewhere who requested the grants. There is also a column titled "support on issues," which describes how some of the groups backed Philip Morris's effort to block smoking restrictions and cigarette taxes.
While Philip Morris did not disclose documents on its current giving, interviews indicate that it has not significantly diminished -- indeed, the company is now seeking to soften its image by highlighting its philanthropy.
It donated $30,000 in 1998 to sponsor conferences for groups representing black and Hispanic New York lawmakers. The Bronx Democratic Committee, which is led by Assemblyman Roberto Ramirez, the most influential Hispanic politician in Albany, received $19,000 in the last three years from Philip Morris, and $10,000 more from R. J. Reynolds, according to campaign finance records.
In interviews, several black and Hispanic lawmakers scoffed at what they said was the heavy-handed approach of smoking opponents. They acknowledged that they were sympathetic to the industry because of its financial assistance, but dismissed suggestions of a quid pro quo.
And they said it was wrong to scrutinize their relationship to the tobacco industry while ignoring white lawmakers, especially Republicans, with similar ties.
"I don't think that I was sent to Albany to govern somebody's bedroom," Ms. Davis said. "We have enough laws on the books now."
The lawmakers said that in the past, when corporate America shunned black and Hispanic causes and had little interest in diversifying the work force, the tobacco companies were different.
"I can tell you that 25 years ago, when you could only get 10 people to show up for a caucus event, Philip Morris was always there," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., a Harlem Democrat who is the most powerful black lawmaker in Albany. He was referring to the Black, Puerto Rican and Hispanic Legislative Caucus in the State Legislature.
"Of course, today, it is looked upon as something nefarious," Mr. Farrell said. "Maybe we're addicted to that like you become addicted to cigarettes."
Peggy Roberts, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris, said the company was proud of its involvement with black and Hispanic lawmakers.
"Our history with diversity and minority employment goes back to the 50's," she said. "We are very anxious to build relationships with lots of different groups. These relationships are important to us, and if they help us get an understanding, or at least an audience with legislators from these communities, that is great."
Asked whether the company linked grants to official action, she said, "That's unfair. What we are trying to do is build relationships so that we can have a dialogue, and that is as far as it goes."
Representatives of R. J. Reynolds did not respond to several requests for comment.
Debates have long simmered over charitable giving by the tobacco companies, especially Philip Morris, which is among the biggest such benefactors in the nation and has carved a large role in financing the arts in New York City. Nonprofit groups have grappled with whether to refuse such money because it is generated in large part by profits from smoking. Many continue accepting it.
In places like Harlem, some groups have gone on campaigns against what they say is the tobacco companies' policy of flooding black and Hispanic neighborhoods with advertising and of aiming menthol-flavored brands like Newport, Kool and Salem at black smokers. Even so, many local politicians have remained on the sidelines.
A few have spoken out, including Assemblyman Albert Vann of Brooklyn. More common are the sentiments of black and Hispanic members of the Assembly Health Committee, which has been a battleground on the issue in recent years, particularly over a bill that would impose a state ban on smoking in restaurants.
In 1998, the bill's sponsors suffered a startling rebuff when four black and Hispanic Democrats on the Democratic-controlled committee -- Ms. Davis, Mr. Ramirez, James Gary Pretlow of Westchester County and Darryl C. Towns of Brooklyn -- voted with Republicans and killed the bill.
Saying that one of his primary concerns was economic development, Mr. Ramirez explained that he could not ignore the economic effects of more restrictions on his district. If fewer people smoke, then bodegas, which are often the backbone of Hispanic neighborhoods, will lose cigarette sales, he said.
White lawmakers, he said, "have the luxury and the flexibility of taking positions that are much more popular, because the consequences of their actions are never going to be felt in their districts."

HEADLINE: A Harlem Power Zone Weakens Some

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN 

 BODY:
Richard Martin had long dreamed of building a television studio in Harlem. Mr. Martin, a former cameraman at NBC and WOR News who is now an adjunct professor in New York University's film and television department, wanted a place that would "reach out to people of all racial and ethnic backgrounds."
Money, or the lack of it, always stood in his way. But five years ago, with the creation of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone -- one of nine such zones designated in 1994 to spur economic development and job creation in upper Manhattan and the South Bronx -- he decided to go for it. 
 For a while, it seemed that his dream would survive, but after years of effort, it has run into a wall, part of the mixed legacy of an ambitious economic experiment.
Like many of his neighbors, Mr. Martin has yet to see the fruits of Harlem's economic renaissance. Many mom-and-pop shops that have been local institutions for decades maintain that the area is being overrun by chains like Starbucks, Barnes & Noble and Blockbuster video, forcing smaller merchants to close their doors. But defenders of the empowerment zone say the current changes will be best for the local economy over the long run.
Since its inception in May 1996, the empowerment zone has invested $113.5 million in central, eastern and western Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood. Loan recipients included Harlem USA, a 275,000-square-foot retail and entertainment complex on West 125th Street ($11.2 million); the Vibe Store, a 7,500-square-foot entertainment superstore ($600,000); Broadway Video Duplication Center, at 132nd Street and Broadway, owned by Lorne Michaels ($439,000), and Minton's Playhouse restaurant ($570,000).
Yet small businesses feel they have been ignored.
"There is no renaissance for the community-based businesses," said Sikulu Shange, owner of the Record Shack, a 125th Street landmark for over 50 years. "Harlem is an auction block and everything is up for grabs. They're bringing in entities which already exist in the community. HMV is coming across the street from me, a record shop. The renaissance is a big fiasco."
Mr. Martin's experience is instructive. He envisioned his studio as a modern-day drum circle, comparable, he said, to the ones African villages used to communicate with those who spoke different languages or dialects. He invested about $100,000 of his own cash and, with the help of student and community volunteers, he gutted, painted and renovated a 2,500-square-foot space on West 125th Street, just east of Broadway.
By November 1996, Drum Television Network had an office, a studio, a control room and editing suites, and began broadcasting Monday through Friday from 4 to 6 p.m. on Channel 35.
During that time Mr. Martin also applied for a $50,000 loan from the Business Resource and Investment Service Center, the arm of the empowerment zone that provides loans to small businesses and start-ups.
But Mr. Martin's request was denied, and by May 1997 Drum was off the air.
"To get a loan they said you have to have a three-year track record of being in a business," he said. "If I'm a new business, how could I have three years of bookkeeping and records? What's the use of an empowerment zone if not to help entrepreneurs get going?"
Officials insist the smaller businesses have the wrong idea, and that the empowerment zone is supposed to create jobs, not act as a social services program.
"We had a deficit of 12,000 jobs when this started, and you can't reduce that kind of deficit with family-owned business," said Jim Capel, chief of staff in the office of Representative Charles B. Rangel, who led the passage of the Federal Empowerment Zone legislation and is now a director on the New York City Empowerment Zone board. "This community has got to experience the same kind of economic realities that other communities do."
Local businesses, however, assert that a brick wall has been put in their way. "They told me it wasn't feasible to have an office-supply store in Harlem, but there's been talk of bringing a Staples up here," said Dorothy Pitman Hughes, owner and chief executive of Harlem Office Supply, which has been in business for 18 years. "If that happens, it will crush us to death."
After Ms. Pitman Hughes's $360,000 loan request was denied, she began selling over-the-counter shares in her company for $1 apiece. This year she plans to go public. She is also hoping to open Harlem Office Supply stores on college campuses nationwide. "Right now the schools get their supplies from non-black vendors," she said. "Where we spend our money is where we get our power."
As for Mr. Martin, who also offers video production training courses in his studio and is the executive director of the Community Film Workshop Council, a broadcast training program for minority groups and women, he is preparing to apply to the resource center yet again. To help pay bills, he does freelance camera work and teaches at N.Y.U.
Still, he hasn't given up on his dream of turning Drum (which has been doing video production work for clients like General Electric, Popular Mechanics and Wilson Sports) into the all-inclusive circle he has always imagined.
"I'm going to do it with or without the empowerment zone," he said. "I don't want anyone to give me anything -- just make it possible to get this business up."
"Don't get me wrong, the empowerment zone is good for Harlem, and it's going to get better as it goes along," he added. "We just worry that the wave will come and go, and that we'll get washed away."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Names Trusted Aide to Manage Campaign

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that Bruce Teitelbaum, the man he has relied on in recent years to defend his administration and carry out many of his political orders, will manage his campaign if the mayor runs, as expected, for the United States Senate this year.
His afternoon announcement coincided with a carefully worded statement issued by Mr. Teitelbaum's lawyer saying that, according to federal prosecutors and the Brooklyn district attorney's office, Mr. Teitelbaum is "presently neither a target nor a subject" of a criminal investigation into the collapse of a Brooklyn building that killed a construction worker in November. The accident has stirred questions about City Hall's influence over building practices in the Orthodox Jewish section of Williamsburg. 
 Mr. Teitelbaum, the mayor's former chief of staff, was the administration's liaison to the city's Orthodox and Hasidic Jews. Federal prosecutors and investigators for the district attorney's office have been waiting to talk to him for several weeks. His lawyer, Richard Weinberg, said in the statement that Mr. Teitelbaum planned to meet shortly with investigators -- as a potential witness, he emphasized -- "to answer all questions posed and to assist with any ongoing investigation."
A spokesman for the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn, Bill Muller, declined to comment. Kevin Davitt, a spokesman for Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, said that "every word" in Mr. Weinberg's statement was accurate.
"Now the investigation can go forward," Mr. Davitt said.
In addition to specifying Mr. Teitelbaum's role in a campaign that has yet to be announced officially, the mayor said Randy L. Levine was stepping down as a deputy mayor to join the New York office of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, the Washington law firm. New York Yankees officials also said that Mr. Levine would soon assume a significant management position with the baseball team, which would include labor issues and salary arbitration negotiations. But the mayor stressed that Mr. Levine, who is his main conduit to the national Republican Party, would stay on as a senior campaign adviser and "have a very important role in guiding" the campaign.
The mayor's naming of a campaign manager reflects a certain faith in the mostly untested abilities of Mr. Teitelbaum, who now serves as his top paid fund-raiser. Although he has essentially served as Mr. Giuliani's one-man campaign operation for the last year, Mr. Teitelbaum has no other experience in managing political campaigns and will be pitted against Bill de Blasio, an experienced political manager who will be running the campaign of Mr. Giuliani's expected opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
During his news conference yesterday, Mr. Giuliani was asked about the investigation and Mr. Teitelbaum, and he said he was not paying much attention to it because "I know what it's about."
In recent weeks, the Republican mayor has adamantly denied that Mr. Teitelbaum or anyone else in his administration had done anything untoward, and he has accused Mr. Hynes of running a politically motivated investigation.
It also speaks to the mayor's disinclination to widen his tight-knit coterie of advisers, to which both Mr. Teitelbaum and Mr. Levine belong.
Mr. Levine, 44, has often been in the background. He has been deputy mayor for economic development, planning and administration since June 1997. Before that, he was labor relations commissioner. In his four and a half years in city government, he negotiated contracts with school principals, sanitation workers, firefighters and transportation workers. (Mr. Levine is to serve as an adviser in the city's upcoming labor negotiations.) He has also been the mayor's link to upstate Republicans who have distrusted Mr. Giuliani ever since he endorsed former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, for re-election.
Akin, Gump is the law firm of such prominent Democrats as Robert S. Strauss and Vernon E. Jordan, President Clinton's friend and adviser, but has in recent years reached out to Republicans in what its chairman, Bruce McLean, said was an attempt "to cover both sides of the aisle."
State Republicans and City Hall officials said yesterday that Mr. Levine's role in the campaign was for now undefined and that Mr. Teitelbaum would run the campaign from day to day. Peter Powers, the former first deputy mayor and one of Mr. Giuliani's oldest and closest friends, is also expected to have a major advisory role in the campaign.
Mr. Giuliani said last night that he had not made individual assignments beyond that for Mr. Teitelbaum. "All the rest of it is self-serving speculation," he said.
Mr. Teitelbaum, 36, has often found himself in the news. That has been the price for being Mr. Giuliani's zealous personal assistant, the man called upon to weed out the unfaithful, to issue threats when deemed necessary. He is also the man who courted the mayor's Orthodox Jewish supporters.
That reputation is one reason investigators want to talk to Mr. Teitelbaum. Gaston Silva, a former city buildings commissioner, has told prosecutors that Mr. Teitelbaum pressured him to remove Joseph Trivisonno, a building inspector whose style had prompted some developers in Williamsburg to complain to City Hall.
Mr. Trivisonno resigned in late 1998, and later said he felt pressure from City Hall. Aides to Mr. Giuliani have said the treatment of Mr. Trivisonno represented a responsive government at best, heavy-handed politics at worst, but not anything that could be construed as illegal.

HEADLINE: The Secret to Snaring Hottest Ticket in Town

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
Ever wondered why tickets are sold out at the box office for a basketball game or a Broadway show, but ticket agencies seem to have a large supply? There is often a reason, says the New York State Attorney General's Office: bribery.
A continuing investigation by the office has found that ticket brokers use bribery to obtain tickets for Broadway shows, concerts and sporting events, tickets that should be available to the public at box office prices. The brokers are able to acquire hundreds of seats, creating a virtual stranglehold on the most-sought tickets, according to investigators. 
 "Insiders are taking bribes to make tickets available to ticket brokers, and the average Joe doesn't have a shot," said Elizabeth Block, the attorney general's lead investigator into ticket sales.
Although investigators acknowledged the existence of scalpers who resell tickets in front of arenas and theaters, those people are not the focus of the investigation.
"We want to root out corruption in the box office itself," said Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer. Mr. Spitzer said his office was close to filing a series of criminal complaints against people who take or pay bribes for tickets.
If the problem of brokers illegally obtaining large blocs of tickets could be eliminated, Mr. Spitzer said, the Attorney General's Office would consider supporting the removal of price restrictions on ticket resales. "I am certainly tempted by a free market for tickets once we have eliminated bribery in the ticket office itself," he said.
The widespread bribery has inflated prices beyond those that a free market would bear for three reasons, Mr. Spitzer said. First, he explained, brokers snap up so many tickets that it worsens the scarcity of tickets in high demand. Then brokers have to recoup the cost of the bribes. Finally, businesses support the brokers by paying inflated prices for seats that the companies use to impress clients. The money that companies spend entertaining is tax deductible.
"Companies can spend virtually unlimited dollars," Mr. Spitzer said. One New York brokerage firm spent almost $370,000 on tickets in a single year, a report issued by the Attorney General's Office in May said.
The problem is not limited to New York. "I've spoken with people in other states," Mr. Spitzer said. "And this has not become a multistate enforcement action, but the problem is, in fact, nationwide."
The attorney general acknowledged that the problem may be more apparent in New York. Even though New York has more shows, concerts and venues than most cities, the audience, fed by tourism, outstrips demand. There is also a concentration of major companies willing to pay the high ticket prices, he said.
Broker markups on tickets commonly range up to 600 percent, but can go higher depending upon the event.
In August, during the United States Open tennis tournament in Queens, more than 900 people received citations for scalping tickets, said Michael Mansfield, chief of the Economic Crimes Bureau for the Queens district attorney. There, $25 tickets were going for $2,500.
In 1994, the New York securities firm cited in the attorney general's report paid a ticket broker in New Jersey, $367,980 for tickets -- including $3,250 each for four U.S. Open tickets, according to officials.
Such markups are illegal in New York under a law that restricts resale price to $5 or 10 percent, whichever is greater, plus tax. Lobbyists for the East Coast Ticket Brokers Association have supported a bill that would repeal that provision. Repeated calls to the organization's lawyers, the firm of Davidoff & Malito, for comment about the Attorney General's report were not returned.
Still, even with the law in place, brokers skirt New York statutes, Mr. Spitzer said. Many operate in New Jersey, where the scalping laws do not cover out-of-state sales.
Gerald B. Lefcourt, a criminal defense lawyer in New York, said, "If brokers do end up in court, they usually get adjourned in contemplation of dismissal." In these cases, as long as the defendant is not arrested again for six months, the charges are automatically dismissed.
The Internet has seemingly made scalping easier. A search of eBay under tickets yesterday brought 2,418 responses. Ebay's policy is that the seller must conform to local laws, which causes enforcement problems because the seller does not have to list a location. Ebay will remove any tickets that the police say are being sold illegally. But that has never happened, a spokesman said.
In 1996, Madison Square Garden conducted an investigation that led to the dismissal of five employees in the subscription department and the removal of many brokers from the subscription list. Some of those brokers were reinstated in 1997. That same year, state investigators found, 75 percent of the Knicks's subscriptions were given to people found to have connections with management. The 25 percent sold to the public were in the upper tier, the report found.
A spokesman for Madison Square Garden said in a statement: "In each of the past three years Madison Square Garden, as part of its ongoing policy regarding the unauthorized resale of season tickets, revoked an average of more than 500 tickets per year. Reports have stated that a handful of people who had their subscriptions revoked have been able to subsequently purchase new subscriptions. The garden is investigating and if appropriate, will revoke these subscriptions."
The attorney general's office has asked for changes in legislation that deals with scalping. Specifically, the office has asked that taking or giving bribes for tickets, now a misdemeanor, be made a felony. It also wants to set up a system to track sales of individuals tickets, to make it easier to identify box office employees who make illegal sales.
The issue probably will not be taken up by the New York Legislature until the current state law expires next June. Even then, it is unclear if there is a legislative solution.
As the report itself pointed out, New York has regulated resale and sellers of tickets for 77 years and has not beaten scalping yet.

HEADLINE: Opposition Party in Croatia Leads in Early Vote Returns

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Tuesday, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Preliminary results from the parliamentary elections in Croatia on Monday, released early this morning, indicate that a six-party opposition coalition should be able to form a new government, ousting the party founded by Franjo Tudjman, the late president.
With a little more than a quarter of the vote counted, the election nonetheless appeared to be a serious defeat for Mr. Tudjman's Croatian Democratic Union, the umbrella nationalist party that has governed Croatia since it became independent in 1991. 
 Mr. Tudjman died last month after a long illness, with his party deeply unpopular because of economic distress, high unemployment and widespread allegations of corruption.
The new prime minister is likely to be Ivica Racan, 55, the leader of the Social Democrats, the former Communist Party, who has promised closer and less abrasive relations with the United States, the European Union and the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague. He promises more attention to human rights and press freedom. In return, he is seeking Western help to ease the pain of economic restructuring.
While officials of the governing party conceded the loss of the election, another senior party official, Vladimir Seks, the deputy speaker of Parliament, warned: "We all have to wait for the final results to come first. I suggest that the temporary winners not rejoice too much."
Some Croatia experts have warned about vote-rigging and other irregularities. Foreign election observers are to speak about their findings this afternoon.
The Clinton administration, which sees an opposition victory in Croatia as a model for squabbling democrats in nearby Serbia, has made no secret of its support for the Racan-led coalition. It is expected that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will make an early visit to Zagreb if the results hold up. That would be a sharp contrast to the low level of diplomatic representation at Mr. Tudjman's funeral, at which the United States was represented only by its ambassador.
The coalition of the Social Democrats and Social Liberals will need support from another allied four-party coalition in order to have a stable majority in the new Parliament.
The state electoral commission, releasing the preliminary results after midnight, said the opposition alliance was ahead in 9 of Croatia's 10 constituencies. An 11th constituency is made up of votes by 350,000 expatriates who hold Croatian citizenship, most of them Bosnian Croats; they favor the governing party, which has supported them with subsidies.
But in general, the vote for the governing party is down in a high turnout of more than 70 percent of 4.2 million registered voters. The party is getting about a quarter of the vote, down from 44 percent in 1995.
The main opposition bloc of Social Democrats and Social Liberals is getting about 40 percent of the early vote, while the second opposition alliance is getting 16 percent. But the country's proportional system of representation means that voting percentages do not translate directly into seats, and the number of seats for each party is unlikely to be known until tonight or Wednesday.
Mr. Racan expressed optimism about becoming prime minister, saying, "Together with the other opposition bloc, I think we will have a very stable majority."
In a concession statement, the moderate foreign minister, Mate Granic, who lost in his own Zagreb constituency, said that on the basis of preliminary results, "it is clear that we have lost the elections."
Elections to replace Mr. Tudjman as president will be held Jan. 24. The opposition has pledged to reduce the constitutional powers of the presidency, but will need the cooperation of the Tudjman party to secure the necessary two-thirds majority in Parliament.
Mr. Granic is Washington's favorite for the presidency, but he has had trouble getting his own party's endorsement and is considering running as an independent in a large field. The main opposition candidate will be Drazen Budisa, the leader of the Social Liberals and Mr. Racan's coalition partner. The election is likely to require a second round runoff, probably on Feb. 7.
The results so far in these parliamentary elections are not encouraging for the governing party, which some experts think might break apart in opposition.
Nikica Valentic, the governing party's candidate for prime minister, said: "Although we are only talking about a small sample, the results are realistically below our expectations. Obviously the electorate has been critical of our rule."

HEADLINE: BRADLEY AND GORE RENEW THE BATTLE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore, 1,125 miles apart, argued today about the virtues of experience and accused each other of having a vision too limited to deal with problems that concern most Americans.
"Only those who have never left Washington have missed the lessons of the last decade," Mr. Bradley told an audience of 400 here. The audience first giggled and then applauded at the obvious reference to Mr. Gore, who has held office in Washington since 1977. 
 "Only those who have embodied the ways of Washington have failed to notice that Americans see Washington as a place that has nothing to do with their lives," he continued.
A few hours later, before 1,000 students and supporters in Davenport, Iowa, Mr. Gore accused Mr. Bradley of having a passive and narrow sense of what a president can do.
"The presidency is not an academic exercise," Mr. Gore said. "It's not a seminar where you get to entertain a single grand theory."
The two Democratic presidential hopefuls, who were resuming their campaigns after the holiday, will debate in person twice this week, on Wednesday in Manchester and on Saturday in Des Moines. Today they warmed up, in speeches their staffs advertised as important, with the ideas they think will play best in Iowa's Jan. 24 caucuses and New Hampshire's Feb. 1 primary.
The Bradley approach reflected some of the anti-Washington themes that won primaries here for Jimmy Carter in 1976, Ronald Reagan in 1980 and Patrick J. Buchanan in 1996. In a line that recalled Mr. Carter's promise to provide a government as "full of love as the American people," Mr. Bradley said, "I'm not prepared to settle for anything less than America realizing the potential embodied in our ideals, in the creativity of our minds and the goodness of our people."
Without directly naming his rival, Mr. Bradley called the vice president no more than a tinkerer. He referred briefly to his major campaign proposals: providing universal access to health insurance, ending child poverty, putting 600,000 new teachers in public schools, registering all handguns and reforming the campaign finance system.
Then, in a comment that the audience took to be aimed at Mr. Gore, he said:
"There are those voices that say we cannot do big things any more, that we must tinker around the edges offering small solutions to big problems. But I say now is not the time to be timid. Above all, now is not the time to settle."
Mr. Gore took on his rival much more bluntly, scoffing at his emphasis on health care.
"Senator Bradley," he said, "seems to believe that America should address only one thing at a time, or only a very small number of things at a time, health care is the only challenge deserving of a comprehensive proposed solution."
"The promise of America," Mr. Gore added, "means more than a single proposal, done in the wrong way, at a price that leaves us helpless to take on other great national priorities."
He suggested that Mr. Bradley's approach was, if not un-American, at least un-Democratic: "Can you imagine John Kennedy saying, 'We have to fight the cold war; we can't explore the heavens or put a man on the moon?' He knew we could do more. Can you imagine Lyndon Johnson saying, 'We can wage war on poverty, but we'll have to postpone the creation of Medicare and Medicaid. He knew we could do more."
The characterization of Mr. Bradley as a man of "limited vision" was meant to puncture the image that the former senator has gained with his call for universal health insurance. The Gore campaign is worried that this is undermining support for the vice president, who is offering a more incremental approach.
As a result, Mr. Gore seized on Mr. Bradley's self-proclaimed affinity for Ronald Reagan as an advocate for a few big ideas, saying a Bradley administration would lack the can-do American spirit that Mr. Gore promised to bring to the presidency.
As he chastised Mr. Bradley for what he called a single-minded approach to health care, he promoted his own education plan by saying it would "bring the greatest single increase in our federal commitment to education since the G.I. Bill and the greatest single increase in our federal commitment to pre-K through 12 education since the beginning of public schools."
He then turned Mr. Bradley's language against him, dismissing Mr. Bradley's education proposals in nearly identical phrasing that Mr. Bradley has used to describe the vice president. "We can't settle for the minor extension of a few existing programs," Mr. Gore said. "We can't settle for simply nibbling around the edges."
And he emphasized the theme that he is a fighter, fighting both for the nomination and suggesting that as president he would fight for the country. In an aside that revealed something of his combative strategy, Mr. Gore told the audience: "How one campaigns is some prediction of how one might serve."
For Mr. Bradley, cultivating the rocky New Hampshire soil of anti-Washington feeling requires a bit of juggling, since he served in the Senate for 18 years and boasts of his experience there as evidence that he can get things done. So he emphasizes the years since he retired in 1995 as a time when he got reacquainted with a nation that has "an abiding sense that Washington doesn't have a clue as to where people really live their lives."
Speaking in a state where he may be ahead because independents can vote in the Democratic primary, Mr. Bradley attacked Washington, and, by implication, Mr. Gore, for excessive partisanship.
"Only those who have been mired in the battles of partisanship have failed to realize that Americans are tired of partisanship," he said.
As he has before, Mr. Gore suggested today that Mr. Bradley made a cowardly retreat, not an intellectual exploration, when he retired from the Senate. Speaking of the seven-year Clinton-Gore economic record, he said, "There were many good individuals -- even in high places in our own party -- who thought that it couldn't be done. When Senator Bradley retired from the Senate during President Clinton's first term, he spoke about a 'budget stalemate,' of a political process that was, and I quote, 'paralyzed' . . . on creating jobs, on reforming welfare . . . a continual deadlock. And he said that part of the problem was that Democrats 'cling to old programs.' "
Mr. Bradley's other main topic today, raised perhaps as a counter to Mr. Gore's experience in the area, was the contradictions of technology, which "brings us closer and makes us distant at the same time."
"With cell phones and pagers and e-mail, we're never out of touch, but we're not face-to-face, either," he said. "We're both more connected and more isolated. Now we have so many different avenues of communication that about the only thing Americans do at the same time any more is watch the Super Bowl."
But he said this did not worry him because "every new form of information and knowledge creates more liberty, not less."
"Democracy always benefits from more information, more transparency, more ideas," Mr. Bradley said.
Each candidate closed with an effort at inspiration, though Mr. Gore's was more programmatic. The vice president said, "Imagine what this country will be like when every child has health coverage, when we save Medicare and Social Security, when we invest in world-class public schools, when we make bold new strides for opportunity and justice.
"Let us raise our sights and broaden our vision. Let us reach for the America that is in our dreams -- and also within our grasp."
Mr. Bradley concluded by saying, "What does it profit us to expand the boundaries of knowledge if we don't expand the circle of justice. For though we're expanding the frontiers of knowledge, the coordinates of the human heart remain the same, and that is the ultimate challenge of politics, to touch the goodness that is in all our hearts."
"We are living in an age of new possibilities," he said. "Some people say we can never achieve our special destiny, but I say, in a world of new possibilities, guided by goodness, we can and we will."

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform Hasn't Eradicated Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You make the stunning assertion that Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare has "left far fewer people on welfare" and "put more people to work" (front page, Dec. 30). 
 I suggest that you consider at least one alternative theory for why people went from welfare to work.
Have you noticed that the United States has now experienced the greatest economic expansion ever? I would propose the obvious: that the lowest unemployment rate in the history of modern times is responsible for poor people's taking jobs. If the business cycle turns and sends unemployment back up, we will see if harsh welfare programs actually cause people to work. I suggest that neither whips nor hunger will move people to take nonexistent jobs.
 
DOUGLAS LASDON
Exec. Dir., Urban Justice Center
New York, Dec. 30, 1999

HEADLINE: ISRAEL AND SYRIA RETURN TO SEARCH FOR MAJOR ACCORD

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Talks between Israeli and Syrian leaders on a comprehensive peace accord opened today behind closed doors. The meetings began with a sense of urgency, American officials said, but they pointed to signs that the path would not be easy and that a single round of negotiations would probably not conclude the talks.
The discussion resumed where the parties left off three weeks ago in Washington, with both sides indicating a common determination to engage in days or weeks of round-the-clock discussions. 
 The thorniest issues are before them, involving security, borders, water rights and political relations.
In a sign of the difficulty of the talks, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Syrian foreign minster, Farouk al-Shara, did not meet directly with each other at all today. President Clinton left Shepherdstown this evening after a second meeting with Mr. Shara, but without being host to a planned session that would have included the Israeli and Syrian leaders.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said he could not report any progress at the end of the day of discussions.
"These are very hard issues," Mr. Rubin said. "You can't have a fully scripted procedure with talks this complex."
President Clinton came by helicopter to open this round of talks between Mr. Barak and Mr. Shara, who made no public comment. President Clinton said through a spokesman only that he believed that the talks were "off to a good start."
The negotiations are being held in Shepherdstown, a tranquil town on the Potomac River about 70 miles from Washington. It was selected for its isolation, depriving the negotiators of distractions and increasing the pressure for serious talks.
American mediators have successfully used the technique of enforced isolation in Middle East peace talks before -- with Israelis and Egyptians at Camp David in 1978, and with Israelis and Palestinians at Wye River Plantation in 1998.
Israel has sent a delegation of about 55 officials, including David Levy, the foreign minister; Elyakim Rubinstein, the attorney general; Amnon Lipkin-Shahak, the minister of tourism and a former army chief of staff; Zvi Shtauber, the prime minister's security adviser; and dozens of lawyers, military officers and technical experts.
Syria's delegation consists of 25 to 30 officials, including two deputy foreign ministers, Yusuf Shakkur and Majeed Abusaleh, Syria's former ambassador to the United States, Walid Muallim, and several generals and legal advisers.
Hafez al-Assad, the president of Syria, is not attending this stage of the talks but his presence at a more decisive stage has not been ruled out. Mr. Assad has assured Mr. Clinton that Mr. Shara carries "plenipotentiary powers" to conclude an agreement with the Israelis, Mr. Rubin said.
American officials said that delegates were not being held incommunicado, but that the normally talkative Israelis had agreed to turn off their cellular telephones to lessen the possibility of news leaks. The Syrian government has never been particularly leak-prone.
The negotiations began at the National Conservation Training Center, which is operated by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. Mr. Rubin and Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary, provided the only public information about today's meetings to members of the press, who are sequestered at Shepherd College.
Just before the talks started, Mr. Clinton strolled through the grounds of the training center with Mr. Barak on his right and Mr. Shara on his left. In what was clearly a made-for-television moment, the three leaders stepped onto a 200-foot-long pedestrian bridge over a 25-foot-deep gully, pausing about two-thirds of the way across to gaze out at the Potomac River about 300 yards to the north.
Cameras clicked and reporters shouted, but Mr. Clinton only smiled and waved. The three men then walked silently into the gray stone Commons Building, where Mr. Clinton met privately with each leader for about an hour to discuss a negotiating strategy for the next few days, officials said. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright also met individually with the Israeli and Syrian leaders.
The American team that is expected to remain behind for negotiations included Dennis Ross, the administration's special Middle East envoy, and his deputy, Aaron Miller; Martin Indyk, the assistant secretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs; Bruce Reidel, the senior director for Middle East policy at the National Security Council, and his deputy, Robert Malley; and a supporting cast of regional experts, note-takers and translators.
Lt. Gen. Donald Carrick, military adviser to Dr. Albright, was also present for today's talks, and additional Pentagon experts were expected to arrive on Tuesday as the parties begin to grapple with regional security arrangements and the expected United States role in monitoring them.
"In these negotiations the devil is in the details, and the detail men will be the men that are going to play a critical role," Mr. Rubin said. "And we do expect that during this round, that all of the issues, one way or another, will be discussed in detail. But that's a very different thing than expecting that, having discussed them, that they will achieve agreement."
No one would predict how long the talks here might last. Mr. Rubin said he packed enough clean shirts for "more than a week," and Mr. Barak is said to be willing to stay as long as two weeks if progress is evident.
Mr. Clinton has said he will return to Shepherdstown as often as is necessary to help resolve conflicts or to offer top-level assurances of America support for difficult concessions.
Beyond serving as mediator and broker for the talks, the United States is certain to emerge as guarantor and paymaster of any accord reached here. Israel is expected to ask for military upgrades to compensate for the loss of the strategic Golan Heights and economic aid to help pay for the resettlement of some 17,000 Israelis who moved into territories seized from Syria in the 1967 war.
Syria, for its part, is looking for a substantial package of economic and technical aid to boost its dormant economy and bring it into the age of computers and global trade.
The Clinton administration has not yet begun to consult with Congressional leaders on the terms of any new aid package for the Middle East. It is not certain whether the Republican-led Congress will agree to pick up some part the tab, which is estimated to be between $10 billion and $100 billion over the next several years.
"This is a big, big deal, and a deal this big is going to carry with it a price tag," Mr. Rubin said. "But we believe the peace is so important, and our vital interests could so be strengthened by a peace agreement, that it is worth our playing an important role."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1806 words

HEADLINE: From the Pipeline To the Courtroom;
Gap on BP Amoco-ARCO Deal Is Wide

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Senators and governors from the West Coast and Alaska, as well as oil executives and lawyers, have been flocking to the Federal Trade Commission in recent weeks in what has quickly turned into one of the most contentious political and regulatory campaigns of the season.
Even as the F.T.C. approved the largest industrial merger in history a few weeks ago -- Exxon's $81 billion acquisition of Mobil -- the agency's staff recommended that a second large oil merger be blocked. Negotiations ensued among the Government and the two companies involved, BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield. But the gap over the proposed $29 billion deal remains wide, with the companies and government officials unable to agree on what impact the merger would have on gasoline prices on the West Coast, the primary recipient of crude oil from Alaska's North Slope. 
 Both sides are preparing for what would be the biggest courtroom challenge to a corporate merger in American history. Yet even as they do so, the companies and their allies in Congress, in state capitals and from their Alaskan oil operations are waging an intensive lobbying effort to try to force a settlement.
As Robert Pitofsky, the F.T.C. chairman, ponders whether to try to block the deal, he has been besieged by hundreds of e-mail messages, telephone calls and visits from lawmakers, as well as an array of corporate executives and consumer groups. He has heard conflicting views about the deal from senators, governors and state officials from Alaska, California and Oregon, some lawmakers said.
"There is a full-court Congressional press to get this deal approved quickly from BP and ARCO and their supporters, folks who carry a tremendous amount of influence," said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. Mr. Wyden met recently with Mr. Pitofsky to present what he said was clear evidence of antitrust problems and to urge him to reject the merger on any terms.
The central issue is whether Alaska and the West Coast are such closely related markets that production in Alaska affects prices in California and neighboring states. While BP Amoco and ARCO pump more than 97 percent of the crude oil on the North Slope, they refine about 70 percent of the oil sold from the Alaska pipeline. F.T.C. officials have concluded that Alaska production and California prices are indeed closely related, while the companies and a number of private analysts maintain that prices on the West Coast are, instead, set by the world market.
Gov. Tony Knowles, Democrat of Alaska, joined by the state's two Republican senators, Frank H. Murkowski and Ted Stevens, has told F.T.C. officials that any delay in completing the merger could have a devastating effect on the state's economy. The state's oil production has sharply declined over the last decade, to 1.1 million barrels a day from more than 2 million, as prices have plummeted. New investment in exploration by BP Amoco holds the promise of sharply increasing supply and heading off thousands of layoffs, he said.
"I recognize that the F.T.C. has a different responsibility than we do," Governor Knowles said in a recent interview. "We also have a strong antitrust act. But I also have other concerns, such as the long-term health of the industry, and the economy of the state, and none of those are the responsibility of the F.T.C. They have just a narrow antitrust issue. Their focus is solely on the downstream, on the California gas pump."
Supporters of the deal say the commission's staff has fundamentally misunderstood the realities of the market, and there is no legitimate reason to fear that the domination of the oil fields on Alaska's North Slope by BP Amoco if it acquires ARCO would affect prices at gas stations on the West Coast.
"The government is talking ideology and theory, not reality," said Roger Diwan, managing director of the Petroleum Finance Company, an industry consultant in Washington. "There is no evidence of a connection between production in Alaska and the price in California." Mr. Diwan said gasoline prices were higher in California largely because of higher taxes and a state requirement that consumers buy cleaner, more expensive gas.
Critics of the deal reply that the ties between Alaska production and West Coast prices are obvious.
"The notion that there is no connection between the North Slope and Oregon is absolutely preposterous," Senator Wyden said. "It's laughable." He said Oregon was a good laboratory of how prices at the pump are dictated by North Slope crude. Oregon has neither California's high local taxes nor its requirements for cleaner gas, but prices are still among the nation's highest, by some calculations as much as 31 cents above the national average last year.
To satisfy the states, the two oil companies have offered a variety of benefits -- what one lawyer has called "grease" -- that have nothing to do with antitrust issues. They have pledged to spend at least $15 million to clean up "orphan" environmental sites caused by other companies. They have agreed to give $2 million annually, in perpetuity, to the University of Alaska. And they have vowed to raise their charitable contributions in California by more than 25 percent, to at least $100 million over the next decade. Sir John Browne, BP Amoco's chief executive, has also pledged to California's governor that he will continue ARCO's program of providing gasoline at lower prices than competitors.
The merger's critics, meanwhile, have been seeking to embolden the F.T.C. to take on the oil companies and undo the deals struck by state officials in Alaska and California. They say the deal would give the newly merged company a stranglehold on Alaskan production, leading inevitably to price gouging on the West Coast.
The commission, though, needs little to lift its confidence. It is coming off its strongest year in decades, exemplified in recent weeks by a stream of multibillion-dollar deals that failed after running into skepticism from antitrust officials. BP Amoco and ARCO executives insist they will not cave in, as the other companies did, and are so confident of their legal arguments and their view of the marketplace that they say it makes little sense to propose huge divestitures when the odds are strongly in favor of a court victory.
Officially, the F.T.C. and BP Amoco and ARCO are still negotiating, as government officials and the companies' executives try to reach an accommodation and close a deal that would greatly realign power over Alaska's vast reserves.
The decision is clearly in the hands of Mr. Pitofsky, a former antitrust law professor whose grip on his agency is perhaps best illustrated by his voting record. In his nearly five years on the job, he has not cast a single dissenting vote.
Lawyers and others who follow his agency closely say it is inconceivable that his staff would recommend barring the deal without coming to believe that such an action had the support of Mr. Pitofsky, who has taken an active role in negotiations with the companies.
In an interview, Mr. Pitofsky declined to answer questions about the merger. In general comments about the industry, though, he has hinted at his skepticism about the merger unless there are more significant divestitures. He noted in particular that the spate of oil mergers in recent years was reaching the point that requires particularly careful scrutiny.
"I don't think people understand how de-concentrated oil was just five years ago," he said. "It used to be that the top eight companies barely controlled even 40 or 50 percent of the market. Then Texaco and Shell did a joint marketing venture. BP merged with Amoco. Exxon bought Mobil to become Exxon Mobil. Now the top four firms have 40 to 50 percent of the market in the United States. We're approaching the zone of moderate to high concentration under the antitrust guidelines."
Senior executives at BP Amoco and ARCO were reluctant to talk publicly while the deal is pending. Privately, however, some executives expressed deep frustration and anger with Washington, saying they are the victims of a particular hostility toward big oil companies.
"There is a lot of anger and frustration, and a strong conviction that we have a strong legal case," one executive said. "There is a limit to how much this procrastination can go on. We have made it clear that we won't roll over and die."
The companies have also made it clear that since North Slope production is a crown jewel of the merger, they will not make any huge concessions beyond those already made to the state of Alaska. The largest concession is the divestiture of 175,000 barrels a day of the 800,000 they produce. That divestiture would leave the merged company -- which some in Washington refer to as BP ARCO, even though no official name has been settled on -- with about a 60 percent share of production, which is still too much for the F.T.C. The companies also say they have ameliorated any potential problems through long-term contracts with independent West Coast refiners for an additional 100,000 barrels or so a day.
Critics of the deal say Alaska's interests as the owner of the oil fields are different from those of West Coast states that consume the refined oil.
The commission's staff has apparently rejected the argument that Alaska and the West Coast have not been a single market for a long time. In making that argument, the companies have noted that the decline in North Slope production forced West Coast refiners to look to other sources for crude oil and that the government ended the ban on exports of Alaska crude to foreign countries three years ago.
As a result, the companies say, they have no power over West Coast prices because the market is competitive enough and refiners would look to other sources. In addition, ARCO has employed a highly successful strategy of marketing gasoline at a discount by using higher volumes and lower margins and has no interest in abandoning that strategy.
But skeptics of the deal, like Senator Wyden, Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, and a group of consumer organizations in Alaska and California, say the divestiture still leaves BP Amoco with too much control over North Slope crude, and would inevitably result in still higher prices on the West Coast.
Mr. Wyden said he had told Mr. Pitofsky the deal was fatally flawed, would do great harm to consumers in Oregon and adjoining states and could not be fixed.
"If Pitofsky is asked to approve it in some other form, they will have to attach so many conditions and riders that the F.T.C. would not have the resources to monitor it," he said. "The companies would run circles around everybody. It may be bad news now, but it would be even worse. We would need a new federal department of BP ARCO to supervise it."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 6, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article and a chart in Business Day on Tuesday about the proposed merger between BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield referred incorrectly to oil operations in Alaska. BP Amoco owns about 40 percent of the oil produced from the North Slope, not 36 percent; ARCO owns 30 percent, not 61 percent; Exxon Mobil and other oil companies own the remaining share. BP Amoco and ARCO have signed an agreement with Alaska to reduce their combined ownership to about 55 percent, not 60 percent, if the deal is approved.
The chart also misstated the amount of oil produced in Alaska. Through November last year, it was 350 million barrels, not 350 billion. Finally, the article misstated the percentage of oil refined by BP Amoco and ARCO in Alaska. ARCO refines about 34 percent and BP Amoco does not refine any; their total is not close to 70 percent.

HEADLINE: Henry Fowler Is Dead at 91; Former Treasury Secretary

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Henry H. Fowler, who as Treasury Secretary in the Johnson administration helped raise the money to meet the soaring costs of the Vietnam War and who proposed what turned out to be the last Federal budget surplus in a generation, died on Monday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va. He was 91.
A cherubic and courtly Virginian, Mr. Fowler, commonly called by his nickname, Joe, alternated a distinguished private law career with numerous influential Government posts over four decades. 
 He presided over fiscal policy at a time of major expansion of the Vietnam War, eventually lobbying vigorously in 1968 for a 10 percent tax increase that many analysts said should have been imposed sooner. President Lyndon B. Johnson's long insistence that the nation could afford both guns and butter is widely thought to have been a catalyst, along with the rise of OPEC, for much of the inflation that subsequently bedeviled the country.
His unwavering support of President Johnson, who contended that a tax increase could not be won in Congress, accounted for Mr. Fowler's delay in publicly favoring the higher taxes for which he is said to have pressed within the administration.
"He was a great loyalist," said Paul A. Volcker, then a Treasury official and later chairman of the Federal Reserve. "He wasn't going to get out of step with Johnson."
With the surcharge and spending cuts, the 1969 budget, which Mr. Fowler helped assemble, turned out to be the last one without a deficit until 1998.
In early 1968, the financially strapped administration became so alarmed about the country's trade imbalance that Mr. Fowler proposed a detailed plan to Congress to curb foreign travel by imposing a tax on spending outside the Western Hemisphere at rates of 15 or 30 percent, exempting only the first $7 a day. The levy was never adopted.
But with the dollar under attack and the nation's gold reserves dwindling, Mr. Fowler put forward a drastic plan to create a new reserve currency, later called special drawing rights, managed by the International Monetary Fund. S.D.R.'s, sometimes called paper gold, still exist, though their importance has waned since currencies were unhooked from the pegged system adopted toward the end of War World II that linked the major world currencies to the dollar and the dollar, in turn, to gold.
"He was always proudest of his being creator of the S.D.R.'s," said Roy C. Smith, a son-in-law, who teaches at New York University's Stern School of Business.
Another legacy was co-founding a precursor to what has become the annual economic summit meeting attended by top officials of the biggest Western countries plus Japan and, more recently, Russia. Mr. Fowler's 1967 suggestion for a "seminar" of five finance ministers to harmonize policies was promptly taken up by James Callaghan, then Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Mr. Fowler's tenure as Treasury Secretary also saw the replacement of America's largely silver coinage with the cupronickel "sandwiches" that still prevail. This action was forced when the market price of silver climbed enough to make it profitable to melt coins down.
Mr. Fowler resigned a month before Richard Nixon's inauguration as president in 1969 to give his deputy, Joseph W. Barr, a chance to serve briefly as Treasury Secretary.
Born in Roanoke, Va., the son of a railroad engineer, Mr. Fowler graduated from Roanoke College, earned law degrees at Yale University and in the years leading up to America's entry into World War II took a job as an apprentice with the noted Washington law firm of Covington & Burling. In 1934, he joined the legal staff of the Tennessee Valley Authority, where he helped in a long and ultimately successful defense of a constitutional challenge to the agency's electric power program. He met his future wife, Trudye Hathcote, from Amory, Miss., who was also working at T.V.A. headquarters in Knoxville, Tenn. They married in 1938.
Mr. Fowler served later as special counsel to the Federal Power Commission, negotiating arrangements with Canada and New York State for the St. Lawrence Seaway project.
During World War II, Mr. Fowler was assistant general counsel for the War Production Board and economic adviser to the American economic mission in London, which helped coordinate production and supply activities of the United States, Britain and Canada before and after the D-Day invasion.
At the end of the war, Mr. Fowler founded the Washington law firm of Fowler, Leva, Hawes & Symington, composed initially of former War Production Board colleagues.
His 14-year stint there was interrupted when he took a leave during the Korean War to head the Defense Production Administration and to serve as a member of the National Security Council and of President Truman's cabinet.
In 1961 he became Under Secretary of the Treasury, then the department's No. 2 post, before briefly rejoining his law firm in 1964 only to leave again when President Johnson named him Treasury Secretary in 1965 to succeed C. Douglas Dillon. Mr. Fowler is said to have been recommended by his longtime friend Sidney J. Weinberg, senior partner at the Wall Street investment company Goldman Sachs and an adviser to presidents since the 1930's.
Though he lacked banking credentials, Mr. Fowler held generally conservative views acceptable to the business community and was regarded as an effective politician, notably in helping win Congressional passage of tax-cut legislation in 1962 and 1964 as well as the 1968 increase.
A staunch Democrat long active in the politics of his home state, Mr. Fowler turned aside suggestions that he run for governor of Virginia against candidates supported by the state machine of Senator Harry F. Byrd, whom he strongly opposed. He was a delegate and alternate, respectively, to the Democratic National Conventions of 1956 and 1960.
At the state's 1956 Democratic convention, 9 of the 10 Congressional districts had supported a move to withdraw the state's support from the party's national ticket, headed by Adlai E. Stevenson, when delegates from Mr. Fowler's 10th District in northern Virginia cast their lone dissenting vote. This brought shouts of "Yankee go home" from supporters.
After Mr. Fowler left Washington in 1969, Mr. Weinberg recruited him to a partnership at Goldman Sachs, where he worked mainly to expand the firm's international operations and its dealings in government securities. He headed the Goldman Sachs International Corporation until 1984 and remained a limited partner until Goldman went public in May 1999.
Mr. Fowler is survived by his wife, two daughters, Marianne Fowler Smith of Montclair, N.J., and Susan Fowler-Gallagher of Staatsburg, N.Y., four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
How Mr. Fowler got his nickname, Joe, which he used to sign letters but declined to explain, is uncertain. According to one version, it was conferred on him as a teenager by a Greek-immigrant restaurant owner in his hometown who had difficulty pronouncing other American names. But Mr. Smith, his son-in-law, says it came about because Mr. Fowler was called "Gentleman Joe" or "Joe College" by Yale classmates.

HEADLINE: Construction In U.S. Surged For November

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4

 BODY:
Construction spending rose 2.6 percent in November, the biggest increase in 17 months, led by much higher government spending on highways and schools.
The Commerce Department reported today that the escalation in November followed three consecutive monthly declines. It was the largest advance since a 3.7 percent surge in June 1998. The big jump in building activity caught economists by surprise. They had been expecting a much smaller three-tenths of 1 percent advance for the month. 
 Many analysts said that the strength in construction, one of the economy's most interest-rate sensitive sectors, meant the Federal Reserve would feel compelled to raise interest rates further in coming months to slow down the economy.
Joel Naroff, an economist in Holland, Pa., said that the Fed would view November's construction report as a clear indication the three rate increases it delivered in 1999 were "not enough to overcome the demands created by the soaring economy."
Mr. Naroff predicted that the Fed would raise rates again in early February, its first meeting of the year.
The construction report showed widespread gains in both private and government building. Stan Shipley, an economist with Merrill Lynch, said he believed much of November's strength could be attributed to "unusually mild weather which boosted construction activity."
Private construction spending rose by 1.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $549.8 billion. That gain included a 1.1 percent increase in residential projects, with both single-family homes and apartment building showing increases.
Nonresidential activity was up an even stronger 3.3 percent, led by a 9.1 percent jump in spending in a category that includes commercial structures. Government construction spending was up 5.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $165.3 billion. Spending on highways jumped 11.5 percent, and spending for educational buildings was up 5.6 percent.
The overall increases in construction activity pushed total spending to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $715.1 billion in November, 5.1 percent higher than the November 1998 level of $680.1 billion.
