HEADLINE: For Latino Laborers, Dual Lives;
Welcomed at Work, but Shunned at Home in Suburbs

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Jan. 4

 BODY:
Gladys and Pedro Rueda are treated respectfully in the palatial houses they clean throughout northern Westchester and Fairfield Counties, with generous tips during the holiday season, offers of stylish hand-me-downs and compliments for their reliability and hard work.
But here in the Westchester County town where they've lived for 11 years, started a business, learned halting English and taken leadership responsibilities at church, a simple trip to the store can be an occasion for humiliation, as it was recently when Mrs. Rueda went shopping for a cellular telephone. "The man looked me up and down," she said of the store owner. "He said: 'You need a lot of money. Do you have money?' Why was he asking those questions?" 
 Mrs. Rueda, a Peruvian, knew the answer. She is a Hispanic immigrant, one of about 140,000 in Westchester County who make the good life possible by doing the jobs nobody else wants to do. And the differences between her life at work and her life at home reflect one of the newest quandaries of suburbia: while Hispanic immigrants have become an essential part of the economy in these wealthy precincts, they have yet to be fully embraced by their neighbors and do not blend in as they would in the melting pot of New York City.
There are some food banks, community centers and literacy programs to meet the needs of the suburban immigrants. And some residents welcome the diversity as a counterweight to the homogeneity of the largely white northern suburbs.
But the efforts to accommodate the immigrants have not kept pace with their growth. In addition, there is very little affordable housing in northern Westchester and few efforts to bridge the cultural gap between the poor immigrants and the affluent whites who surround them. As a result, the cultural and economic issues tend to play out conspicuously in the few mixed communities like this town of 9,100 people, where the Hispanic population increased by 195 percent, to 1,180 from 401, between 1980 and 1990 and has continued to grow since then. By contrast, neighboring towns like Katonah, Pound Ridge and Bedford see the immigrants only as workers, not as residents.
"We want them to be invisible," said Luis H. Zayas, a professor of social work at Fordham University and director of its Center for Hispanic Mental Health Research. "We don't want to look at them except as laborers. During the day they can be in our streets, but we don't want to see them at night or on Saturday."
Most problematic to many who live in Mount Kisco are the single men, mostly from one Guatemalan province, who far outnumber immigrant women or families. Each morning, they congregate near the railroad station waiting to be picked up for jobs in landscaping or construction or on the stone masonry crews that fan out through northern Westchester and Fairfield County.
At night, they congregate outdoors as they would in a Central American village. On warm weekends, they set up Ping-Pong tables outside their modest dwellings. To some of their neighbors, the mere presence of the immigrants can feel threatening, even when their behavior is beyond reproach. And a minority are drunk and surly, making suggestive remarks to women or urinating on the street.
"I live in Armonk and if that happened there it would scare people to death," said the Rev. Jack S. Miller, minister at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, which has reached out to the immigrants with food, clothing and English classes.
In Mount Kisco, the discrimination has become more subtle and less pervasive than even in the mid-90's, when white residents wrote blatantly racist letters to the local weekly newspaper. But the immigrants say they still get a wide berth when they gather on street corners to socialize. The neighborhoods where they live have seen gradual white flight. And advocates for the immigrants say they often hear remarks like, "I bought a half-million-dollar house up here to get away from people like that."
Mr. Miller wishes the immigrants were treated more kindly by the Mount Kisco residents, including some of his own congregants, and also by town officials, who have been sued repeatedly for discriminating against the day laborers and have settled the cases. But, the minister said: "It's easier to be generous with people and situations not close to us."
The difference in attitude depending on where one lives is personified by two women, both retired school teachers, who volunteer at a food pantry in nearby Katonah. The center, the only one of its kind in the area, serves mainly Hispanics from Mount Kisco.
One of the volunteers, Ella Saunders, lives in Katonah, the other, who asked not to be identified, in Mount Kisco. "She cares just as much as I do," Mrs. Saunders said of her friend. "She has no animosity toward them. She just feels uncomfortable in the streets. She says to me: 'You don't live here. Our town is not what it used to be.' "
Some of the immigrant men living in Mount Kisco say their neighbors grow more welcoming if they speak English, hold steady jobs and have spouses and children. But Edgar Chacon, a Guatemalan who has progressed from a dishwasher to a landscaper to a financial analyst at Citibank in 13 years -- and now has a wife and children -- said acceptance was still based on appearance, not accomplishment. "When I wear my name tag from work in the street, I'm treated with respect," he said. "If I dress casual, they treat me like garbage."
It is impossible to say whether the disdain the Latino laborers perceive is the result of racism, xenophobia or discomfort with unfamiliar people and their habits.
Graciela Heyman, the director of the Westchester Hispanic Coalition, said, "It's a class thing," because "the men are scuzzy, they're short and they're brown." But the Rev. Douglas Phillips, a minister at the Presbyterian Church here, argues that "anybody different is automatically suspect." He cites the outdoor socializing: "Anglos don't do that, so we assume they're up to no good."
Both the church and the coalition hope to educate the laborers about the local customs at a storefront community center being built on Route 117 south of downtown, where there will be classes in English, culture, vocational skills and citizenship. The center, supported by $100,000 in donations, 60 percent from two local families, will have a lounge with a large-screen television and snacks so the laborers have a place to congregate inside. And there will be a food pantry and clothes giveaway.
But Mr. Miller, who spearheaded the project, is treading carefully, mindful that the center could provoke community opposition. He chose a storefront in what he described as a "Hispanic friendly" strip mall, a few doors down from a coin laundry that is already an immigrant hangout. The zoning is retail and so the center will sell coffee for a dime or sweatshirts for a quarter so as not to run afoul of the town planning board.
Mr. Miller has not discussed the center with neighboring merchants, lest they label it a "handout place" before they see it. And he is being quiet about plans for a job bank, matching contractors and laborers, so there is no fear of another pickup stop in a town that is unhappy about the one it already has.
"It's all so tender," he said. "So we are dancing around this stuff."
Some public policy experts argue that communities like Mount Kisco -- or Brewster in Putnam County and Farmingdale on Long Island -- deserve help from neighboring villages that reap the benefits of cheap labor, perhaps by modifying zoning laws to permit affordable housing, by educating some of the non-English-speaking children or by contributing to costly social services.
Anthony A. Cupaiuolo, a professor of public administration at Pace University, who lives in nearby Bedford Village, suggests a task force of political, civic and religious leaders. "I can't come up with a legal argument, but there is a moral argument for a regional solution," he said, "and I don't see anybody trying."
Kenneth T. Jackson, a Columbia University historian and author of "Crabgrass Frontier," a critique of suburbia, calls the concentration oflaborers in one town "a basic unfairness." He knows this firsthand because he owns a home in Chappaqua, where his wife is a school teacher. There his lawn is cared for by a crew of Central Americans whom he does not know and rarely sees.
"Our lifestyle benefits from the sweat of people we don't want to legitimize or honor," he said. "If everybody benefits, 50 of them should live in every town."
The increase in the Hispanic population in Westchester County has been remarkable -- almost 90 percent during the 1980's, when the rest of the county's population grew by just 1 percent. In the 1990 census, Hispanics represented 10 percent of the county's population, at 86,194. The county's planning department projects that the 2000 census will show an increase to 16 percent and another jump to 24 percent by 2020. Census figures generally do not include undocumented immigrants and thus significantly understate the Hispanic population.
Religious institutions and school service clubs throughout northern Westchester are the most reliable sources of support for the immigrants. Children preparing for bar mitzvah at Temple Shaaray Tefilia in Bedford, for instance, volunteer at the Katonah community center. And students at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua teach English as a Second Language classes at Mount Kisco's Presbyterian Church.
Eric Sigmon, a senior who heads the tutoring corps, said that he and the others from Horace Greeley were motivated by a desire to "get out of the box" of their upper middle class, suburban lives.
Still, the teenagers struggle to transcend vocabulary and grammar and make human contact. "We come to help them, but there's still that distance," Eric said. "Basic questions you'd ask someone you meet -- 'How old are you? How long have you been here?' -- we tend not to ask."
A recent holiday party helped break the ice. Although some of the immigrants and tutors clustered in separate corners, others nudged forward to hear Ronnie Morales, nearly fluent in English just three years after leaving Guatemala, sing a bilingual version of "Feliz Navidad."
Mr. Morales, accompanying himself on the guitar, followed with two Spanish-language ballads about the terrifying flight of immigrants across the border, their arduous work in America and their yearning to go home when it is time to die. Several of the tutors wept.
But not Mr. Morales. He had much to celebrate: a steady job as a roofer, language skills sufficient to attend the Presbyterian Church here instead of the Spanish-language Fuente de Vida Eterna and enough money to buy a camcorder.
With it, Mr. Morales's uncle recorded his performance. He would send the tape home to his parents and 10 siblings, who have not seen him since he came to America.

HEADLINE: Computer Technicians Learn They Are Indispensable Parts

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The managers of the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company's Chicago office know how to butter up the corporate V.I.P.'s. As a holiday gift, they flew a quartet of jazz singers to the Hartford headquarters last month to parade around in Mickey Mouse sweaters and sing Christmas carols to the people who hold real power over their professional lives.
The quartet sang for the board of directors, of course. But they also made a special, 25-minute stop in a nondescript room of cubicles to sing for a group that the Chicago managers wanted to please as much as anybody else: the computer help-desk staff. 
 When the foursome had finished with "O Holy Night" (a favorite of the man who answers the help desk's phone, they had heard), "Silent Night" and "We Wish You a Merry Christmas," it seemed clear that the effort at ingratiation had worked: The woman who runs the help desk was crying.
At a time when millions of white-collar workers depend on a desktop computer to perform virtually every function of their job, computer help-desk technicians are fast achieving a position of unofficial influence rivalling that of the office secretary.
Indeed, behind all the flattery is a serious issue. Computer industry experts say there are still too few help-desk technicians across the country. Some 250,000 and 300,000 employees now fit the description of internal technology support staff, up from about 100,000 in 1992, according to Howard Rubin, the chairman of the computer science department at Hunter College in Manhattan. They typically are paid about $25,000 to $50,000 a year.
Given how frequently office computer networks break down, it is technology support workers who often decide whether people must sit stewing unproductively for hours or whether a software bug is just a minor nuisance. As a result, staying in the good graces of the help desk -- and figuring out which of its members are truly helpful -- has become a delicate science for many of the nation's office workers.
The help desk's phone number is usually one of the few that virtually all company employees know by heart. Some executives have forged a friendship with a technology staff member they hope will become their personal computer consultant. And, like the managers at Phoenix Home Life, employees at all levels are using gifts to curry favor with computer techies -- or perhaps make up for screaming at them in a moment of frustration.
In the last month, as relief over the lack of Year 2000 computer problems has followed the gift-giving of the December holidays, help-desk workers across the country have been bombarded with homemade cookies, chocolate samplers, fancy lunches and thank-you notes that are carbon-copied to key executives.
At PricewaterhouseCoopers in New York, help-desk workers have filled a wall with appreciative e-mails recounting their triumphs. At the insurance company Marsh USA, word has gotten around that technology workers in Memphis like salsa and chips, and orders have been arriving from a nearby Mexican restaurant. And at Burson-Marsteller, the New York public relations firm and a unit of Young and Rubicam Inc., the chief financial officer planned to treat the entire help desk for lunch at Angelo & Maxies, an upscale steakhouse, to celebrate the trouble-free Year 2000 changeover.
"We think computer systems have gotten easier," said Paul Danos, the dean of the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. "But the networks have gotten so complex that you can't do anything for yourself anymore. You need to get someone to help you.
"There are usually a handful of people," Professor Danos added, referring to help-desk employees, "who could really bring an organization to its knees."
Despite a growing recognition of the importance of help-desk workers, the increase in their ranks has not kept pace with the explosion of computer troubles that have accompanied the growth of office PC's, internal corporate Web sites and complicated cybernetworks. In the last four years, the number of calls to help desks around the country has been increasing by about 20 percent a year, said Kris Brittain, a research director at GartnerGroup, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. And with unemployment low, technically savvy help-desk workers are in strong demand, particularly by Internet start-ups that can offer stock options.
As a result of the shortages, computer users at large companies must often hold for minutes before their calls are answered and even wait hours to have their troubles fixed.
More than 11 percent of all calls to help desks at large companies are abandoned, according to GartnerGroup. On average, callers wait about 53 seconds before hearing a human voice, the firm said.
To deal with the overload, many companies have begun asking employees to describe their problems in e-mail messages -- assuming that the e-mail system is functioning -- rather than by calling.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida is typical. Its help desk in Jacksonville has grown from 8 employees to 23 in the last decade, said Anna Guy, who oversees it. But with about 24,000 phone calls coming in every month, it remains understaffed, and it is not coming close to meeting its goal of answering every call within 30 seconds, Ms. Guy said.
"We're short on staff," she said. "We're in a slump."
An overworked help desk that must tend to more urgent requests first and keep everybody else waiting is, of course, an inevitable target of office apple-polishers. Recently, Ms. Guy and every member of her staff received a road atlas from the marketing department, which for the last two years has not had a secretary and now relies on the help desk for many more tasks. Another group of employees drove 20 minutes across Jacksonville to deliver a box of Whitman's chocolates.
"They wanted to go around and meet every single person on the help desk," Ms. Guy said. "Obviously, your human nature is that when someone is nice to you, you're nice to them back."
That is especially the case for technology-support workers, who spend their days talking to callers angered by both computer problems and help-desk delays. The waits only aggravate their frustration, office workers said, causing technology support workers to receive some of worst verbal abuse in corprate America.
"Help desks are a pretty tough environment," said Rushdi A. Ariss, the information technology manager for C. A. Rasmussen, a construction company in Simi Valley, Calif., where help-desk workers received both sweets and thank-you cards last month. "Not a lot of people are courteous" when they call, he said, and partly as a result, most help-desk workers quit or change jobs in 18 months or less.
The abuse is another reason for all the gifts of the last month. "I may not be the nicest person" to the help desk sometimes, acknowledged Rhet O'Neill, one of the managers of the Chicago office of Phoenix Home Life. She doubles as a member of the quartet that sang in Connecticut last month. So, Ms. O'Neill said, she wanted to make sure that the help desk understood she did appreciate their work.
"You become important to them," she said, of meeting the support workers in person, "and therefore your problems become important to them."
Many executives have another strategy: They skip the help desk and call a technology worker whose fix-it skills they revere and whose number, likely as not, they keep hidden away from their colleagues as though it were a state secret.
At Towers Perrin, a management-consulting firm with 8,500 employees, everybody is supposed to start with the help desk for all problems. But some top executives, like the chief information officer, find a favorite "level two" technology expert they call directly, said Steve Stull, the director of office technology and services. That allows them to avoid the help-desk lines and help-desk workers who might not recognize their names.
"Often," Mr. Stull said, "the younger people haven't been around the firm very long, so they don't even know who the senior executives are when they call in."
Of course, a generous gift can get their attention rather quickly. The 10 members of Burson-Marsteller's help desk, for example, are unlikely to forget that for all the obsequious e-mail, fancy fruit baskets and succulent chocolates that they received last year, it was Kurt Krauss, the chief financial officer, who took them out to a steak lunch.
That is, if they all actually made it through lunch. The help-desk manager deliberately picked a restaurant on the same block as Burson. The workers, he realized, were too important all to be far away from the office at the same time.

HEADLINE: Clinton Breaks an Impasse At the Israel-Syria Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va., Jan. 4

 BODY:
President Clinton made a second trip here today, breaking an impasse between Syria and Israel over the agenda for their peace talks and convening the first face-to-face talks between Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara of Syria.
Mr. Clinton's reappearance in this small West Virginia town came after Israeli and Syrian negotiators bogged down in a dispute over whether the first topic of discussion would be Syria's demand for the return of the Golan Heights, which Israel has controlled since the 1967 Middle East war, or Israel's search for security guarantees. 
 Mr. Barak knows that if he has any hope of making the return of the Golan politically palatable in a national referendum, he must be able to convince Israelis that the buffer zone they have considered so vital for more than a quarter-century is no longer necessary for national survival.
American officials said little about the content of the talks, under the terms of a news blackout that has largely been respected by both Israelis and Syrians.
But Mr. Clinton's arrival here plainly indicated that his intervention was needed just to get substantive discussions going. After hours of procedural talks, Israel and Syria agreed to discuss both land and security simultaneously.
Mr. Clinton then held a half-hour "social event" in a lounge area of the Clarion Hotel, where the talks were held, inviting a half-dozen negotiators from Israel and Syria. An administration official said Mr. Clinton had talked about the Civil War battle of Antietam, which took place in Sharpsburg just across the Potomac River in Maryland, the cost of war and the need for the negotiators to consider the fate of millions in the Middle East whose lives are affected by the talks.
This evening, the first meetings were scheduled of four working committees addressing specific areas of dispute.
"I think they're both very serious," Mr. Clinton said at the White House this morning, after announcing that he would nominate Alan Greenspan for a fourth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve. "They both want an agreement."
So does Mr. Clinton, who sees an accord as a key element of his legacy. He was so determined to get here that when winds and rain prevented a helicopter flight, he traveled the 70 miles in a motorcade.
His arrival was intended to force the first three-way meeting with the president, the Israeli prime minister and the Syrian foreign minister, which failed to take place as planned on Monday.
Several officials speculated that the Monday night impasse over the agenda may have been intended for domestic political consumption in both Syria and Israel. If an agreement is reached, both governments have an interest in showing that they fought over every point -- even the sequence of the discussions.
Briefing reporters today, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, continued to play down the prospects of any early accord. He said the goal of the negotiations was to come up with a core agreement -- which he described as more specific than a framework but far less detailed than a treaty that would specify new borders and the details of troop withdrawals and security arrangements. But he expressed doubts that that would occur in this round of talks.
"You shouldn't read 'Great Expectations' or 'Bleak House' into every arrival or departure of the president," Mr. Rubin said, reaching for a Dickensian metaphor to describe the talks.
Despite Mr. Rubin's caution, American officials are clearly preparing for the prospect of an accord -- and coming to grips with what it might cost American taxpayers.
American officials acknowledged that they had begun separate conversations with Israel over how many billions of dollars in American aid it would take to upgrade the Israeli Defense Force, and thus strengthen its deterrent capabilities if it could no longer depend on the buffer zone of the Golan Heights.
Reports out of Israel said Mr. Barak had presented Mr. Clinton with a $17 billion shopping list -- everything from Awacs radar planes to Tomahawk cruise missiles. Mr. Rubin called those reports "wildly premature." He did not, however, say they were wrong.
In Israel, leaders of the opposition Likud were quick to attack Mr. Barak's presumed call for American aid, saying it would undercut the country's autonomy and make it more dependent than ever on Washington's whims.
Moshe Arens, the hawkish former defense minister, said: "It's obvious, and I have not heard the Prime Minister deny, that he is prepared and committed to giving up all of the Golan Heights. He's already discussing with the U.S. government the need for $20 billion. Certainly part of it is presumably for Israel leaving the Golan Heights."
Meanwhile, about 20 rabbis in Israel issued a religious ruling today saying the Golan Heights was part of the land of Israel, and thus could not be surrendered in negotiation.
Many Israeli experts say that if the referendum on returning the Golan Heights were held today, it would probably be defeated. But that may not mean much, because Mr. Barak does not yet have a full package to sell to the Israeli public.
He hopes that the package will include a pullback and reduction of Syrian forces near Israel's border, more arms and aid from the United States and more sophisticated early-warning systems to alert Israel to any Syrian military action.
But Syria has said virtually nothing about how much it is willing to give. The state-run radio in Damascus said today, "Syria is serious about making peace, and it is normal that it demands an Israeli commitment to withdrawal from all its lands."
But it did not discuss the price that Syria might have to pay, whether in pulling back its forces, allowing Israelis to travel across the country to open an overland pathway to Europe, or tolerating some economic integration and Israeli diplomatic presence in the Syrian capital.
The expectation is that those issues will get an airing here this week, but probably no resolution. It is unclear if Syrian negotiators will return home for the end of the holy month of Ramadan this weekend, or whether Mr. Barak will return to Israel for an expected visit this weekend by the former Russian president, Boris N. Yeltsin, perhaps accompanied by the acting president, Vladimir V. Putin.
Nor is it clear how frequently Mr. Clinton, who returned to the White House tonight, plans to return to push the talks along, reprising the role he played at the Wye Plantation in talks between Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat.
"We've cleared out the week," one of Mr. Clinton's aides said. "If he feels the need, he'll just get on his helicopter."

Orthodox Jews Protest
 SHEPHERDSTOWN, W.Va., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Protesters led by Orthodox Jews demanded today that Israel immediately stop negotiating with Syria over a possible Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights.
"Traitor, go home!" they chanted here in a message to Mr. Barak.
They staged the demonstration in a light rain outside the makeshift news media center at Shepherd College, about a mile from the Clarion Hotel, where today's meeting was held.
Relinquishing the strategic Golan Heights, which Syria has set as the price for peace, would leave Israel's northern border unprotected, contended the leader of the protest, Levi Huebner.
"The Golan is our security," Mr. Huebner said. "Peace will be in security and trust in our neighbors."
Mr. Huebner arrived this morning with about 40 other people in a convoy of nine vans from Brooklyn, headquarters of the Lubavich Hasidic movement.
They were joined at an hourlong demonstration this afternoon by about 40 representatives of the New York-based group America for a Safe Israel and about 40 children from a Hebrew school in Silver Spring, Md.
Herbert Zweibon, chairman of America for a Safe Israel, urged American citizens to oppose proposals for using American troops or money to enforce a turnover of the Golan.
"The last thing we need to do is spend money on a deal that will not work," he said.
The Lubavichers arrived in vans plastered with slogans including, "We will not move from the Golan." Honking horns and chanting, they drove several times past the Clarion on the outskirts of town.

HEADLINE: Iowa Turns Its Presidential Caucuses Into a Cash Cow, and Milks Furiously

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
Iowa Republicans knew they were onto something big when the presidential candidate Steve Forbes said he could get his good friend, former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, to come to Iowa and help raise money for local statehouse candidates.
So, accepting Mr. Forbes's offer, the party hung British flags on a downtown hotel, invented an honor for Mrs. Thatcher -- the Freedom Without Borders medal -- and made her the featured attraction at a $250-a-ticket luncheon that raised $500,000 for Iowa Republicans during the 1998 mid-term elections. 
 Such is the power of presidential politics in Iowa, where local politicians and civic boosters have figured out how to turn their first-in-the nation caucus status into a money-raising device and a tool for economic development. In Iowa, more than in other states, presidential candidates, Congressional leaders and world figures, like Mrs. Thatcher, have been crisscrossing the state to help local politicians with personal appearances and, in some cases, direct donations.
Everyone, it seems, is climbing on the political bandwagon here, from Iowa economic development officials who see the January caucuses as a way to burnish the state's image, to hotels and restaurants whose reservations swell during the caucus season, to Iowa legislative candidates who have the pick of presidential hopefuls to campaign on their behalf.
"This is entrepreneurial politics at its best," said Steve Grubbs, former chairman of the Republican Party of Iowa. "Where else can the state party call up a legislative candidate and say, 'We're bringing a presidential candidate to fund-raise for you,' and have the candidate get picky about which one?"
A September dinner appearance by Gov. George W. Bush raised $100,000 for Iowa Republicans, the same amount Elizabeth Dole raised a few months earlier. A joint Al Gore-Bill Bradley appearance in October netted state Democrats $500,000. The biggest money-raiser is the Ames Straw Poll, a Republican event last August with little real political meaning that brought the state party over $1 million through the sale of things like admission tickets and advertising sites most from the pockets of Republican presidential candidates.
"The biggest beneficiaries of the Iowa caucuses have been the state political parties," said Hugh Winebrenner, a political science professor at Drake University here. "They have events with presidential candidates and raise lots of money. It's allowed them to have excellent headquarters, big bureaucracies and throw lots of money into legislative races."
Ron Corbett, former speaker of the Iowa House, added, "Legislators in other states are jealous of us."
The key to this money machine is the Jan. 24 caucuses, where Republicans and Democrats come to precinct meetings and cast votes for the 2000 presidential race in a ballot that is not binding on Iowa's delegates to the national conventions. The largely symbolic event slowly took on real meaning after the state's Democratic Party in 1972 pushed the caucus date up to January, making it the first event of the primary season.
In the 1976 race, Jimmy Carter used the caucuses as a springboard to the Democratic nomination -- much to the astonishment of the national media. Since then, all presidential candidates have had to pass through Iowa on their road to the White House. In their wake are journalists from all over the world -- by last count, over 650 came for last August's straw poll, and more are expected for this month's caucuses.
"Between Denver and Chicago, the candidates would just drop leaflets on us as they flew over, if it were not for the caucuses," said Kayne Robinson, chairman of the Iowa Republican Party. "The caucuses allow us to get celebrity candidates out here and allows the rest of the nation to see them in the raw. In the process, everyone spends a heck of a lot of money here."
Money is spent in many ways. For starters, in the two years before the caucuses, potential presidential candidates and Congressional leaders come here to gain publicity for themselves and for their party. In doing so, they become the celebrity draw at local fund-raisers, buy tickets to political events and host lavish receptions for the party faithful.
"Local party activists will call you and say they want the national party or a national campaign to send someone to Iowa to appear at a local event," said the campaign manager for one presidential candidate. "Then, the local guys say they need you to buy tickets to the event. Then they charge you a registration fee. And you have to hold a reception for them. You provide all the food and the entertainment. In fact, you are the entertainment."
In fact, Iowa politicians say there is nothing like a political star to draw a crowd and separate people from their money.
"People will come to an event to support the legislative races when you've got a candidate there like Bush," said Mr. Robinson of the Iowa Republican Party. "And Bush's people will also buy tickets to the event. Without the celebrity, it's just an event and maybe all you would raise would be $10,000. A celebrity will get you over $50,000."
Republican officials estimate that presidential candidates have attended at least 50 Iowa fund-raisers for local candidates in this election cycle and have appeared in around 40 of the state's 99 counties. They have attended events ranging from small coffee klatches to a "Candidate Cavalcade" at the party's Cedar Rapids convention, where presidential candidates, after having bought tickets, paid for receptions and picked up their own travel expenses, got 10 minutes to speak before being gonged off the stage by a loud buzzer.
In addition, presidential candidates write checks directly to statehouse candidates. The state Republican Party and the presidential hopefuls -- with the exception of Mr. Bush -- gave $2.1 million to Iowa legislative candidates in the 1998 mid-term elections, while Democratic legislative candidates received $615,772 from their party. By comparison, state-level Republican candidates in Missouri received $1 million from their party over the same period and Democrats, $540,902. In Minnesota, the Republican Party gave its state candidates $401,998 and Democrats gave $324,135.
"I visited with all the presidential candidates," said Lynn Schulte, a defeated Republican statehouse candidate who got contributions from $875 to $1,500 from Dan Quayle, Lamar Alexander and Steve Forbes. "They are trying to build good will."
Mike Sexton, a Republican who won his state Senate bid, said, "Last fall, you could get any of the presidential candidates to come around and, if they liked you, write a check. Iowans are spoiled."
No fund-raising opportunity is too small. At a recent Republican training session, Mr. Robinson, the party chairman, was passing around a "county caucus buck bag," which volunteers will use to raise money for the county party on caucus night. He showed how to get caucus-goers to whip out a $5 bill and put it in the bag. "Make it fun," Mr. Robinson said. "The point is, you pass the hat and the county party gets to keep it."
Iowa Republicans and Democrats differ, however, in their tactics. Rob Tully, the Democratic chairman, is far less aggressive in approaching presidential candidates for help.
"We don't drain the presidential campaigns of cash for the benefit of the state party" Mr. Tully said. "Dumping money into the state party is not in the best interest of the presidential candidates."
Still, the Democrats are not shy in tapping into presidential celebrity. The annual Jefferson-Jackson dinner in October was the largest in Iowa history, with 3,000 attending the $300-a-plate event, with its joint Gore-Bradley appearance "We ran out of tables and tablecloths in Iowa and had to got to Omaha to get more chairs shipped in," Mr. Tully said.
Even that pales against the straw poll, in which Republicans are bused to Ames for a day. That event raised $1,050,000 for the state party, which put a price tag on items ranging from space in parking lot (the Bush campaign paid $40,000 to put its tent in the best location) to a spot on the scoreboard ($5,000) of the Iowa State Center, where the poll was held.
Moreover, anyone voting in the straw poll had to buy a $25 ticket -- which, of course, the presidential candidates bought for their supporters. Steve Forbes, who came in second in the straw poll, paid $290,553 for his appearance there: $158,275 to buy tickets for his supporters, $50,000 to rent space and the remainder for food, music, a sound and light system, balloons and decorating.
In addition, the state Republican Party has built a powerful computer data base: names, phone numbers and addresses of voters and donors and sells it to all presidential candidates, starting at $10,000. "The big boys will pay for this and they are glad to get it," said Mr. Robinson.
State economic development officials welcome the media frenzy. "This is our chance to showcase Iowa as something more than cows and pigs," said Mike Blouin, chief executive of the Des Moines Chamber of Commerce.
Local officials work hard to make life easier for the hundreds of journalists who come here -- providing foreign journalists with translators, laying fiber optic connections and satellite uplinks for television transmission and having a Web site chock full of information on political history and such practical matters as where to get clothes cleaned.
And the economic development officials -- who say they have made no studies of the economic impact of this activity -- are, nonetheless, taking a page from this political playbook. The Des Moines chamber says tickets to its annual fund-raising dinner are flying out the door, even at $125 each.
The reason? Just a week before the Iowa caucuses, the Chamber has lined up a former president as its keynote speaker -- George Bush.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Pataki Proposes Tax Cuts

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Saying that business tax incentives spur economic growth, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday proposed more than $700 million in new business tax cuts that he said would equal $2.3 billion in tax savings by April 2001 when added to previous tax cuts.
He said he wanted to eliminate the gross receipts tax on energy, give a new tax credit to spur job growth in cities, give new tax cuts to farmers and environmentally friendly companies, create upstate high-tech enterprise zones, expand low-cost power for businesses and cut taxes for small businesses. 
 Mr. Pataki will outline more of his plan in today's State of the State address at the Capitol in Albany.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
STOCK PRICES DROP IN U.S. AND EUROPE

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN and FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell sharply in the United States and Europe yesterday on concerns that interest rates will rise higher than had been anticipated. End-of-year tax moves and investing strategies were also cited as reasons.
The Dow Jones industrial average had its worst day since the autumn of 1998, when world markets were roiled by Asian economic problems and the collapse of the Russian ruble. 
 All the main American indexes fell by at least 3 percent, with the Dow dropping 359.58 points, or 3.2 percent, to 10,997.93.
But the worst performance, a fall of 5.6 percent to 3,901.69, was turned in by the Nasdaq composite index, which was the best performer of 1999 with a gain of 86 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 55.8 points, or 3.8 percent, to 1,399.42. There were also declines of 2 percent or more in most major European indexes.
In Asia, Hong Kong took the American selloff hard, losing 1,000 points in the first minutes of trading today, with the Hang Seng index dropping 7.8 percent by midmorning. Shares were off sharply elsewhere, including South Korea, whose composite index fell 5.9 percent in morning trading.
Alan Greenspan, nominated for another term yesterday as Federal Reserve chairman, is widely expected to push short-term interest rates up another notch when the Federal Open Market Committee meets next month, but in recent days concern has grown that further increases may also be in store after that.
In the past, higher rates have often hurt stock prices. Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said yesterday that he expected the Fed to raise rates twice, and added that "the risk is for more after that." He said the bond market could fall sharply if the employment report to be released on Friday showed that the economy was stronger than expected.
The bond market fell sharply on Monday, but it regained some of those losses yesterday, even as stock prices tumbled. "The stock market couldn't ignore the bond market forever and ever, and maybe today is the day," said Jeffrey Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. He noted that interest rates, both long-term and short-term, rose during much of 1999, even as stock prices also increased.
Still, there was little new to explain the sudden fall in stock prices, a fact that left analysts searching for seasonal explanations. Investors with large capital gains had a good reason to delay selling until the new year -- and thus not owe the taxes until April 15, 2001, rather than selling at the end of December and owing the money this year. Moreover, institutional investors may have wanted to buy stocks at the end of the year so that their year-end portfolios would show they were fully invested, rather than holding onto cash, and thus had no money left to invest now.
"This should be seen in the context of the last four to six weeks, in which there were significant inflows into the market," said Abby Joseph Cohen, a partner and chief equity strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The magnitude of the selloff is a little surprising," she added. "But the fundamentals did not abruptly change from last week to this week." Ms. Cohen, who has been the most bullish, and most accurate, strategist in recent years, has forecast a gain of around 8 percent this year.
Ms. Cohen said fears about rising interest rates are overblown. "Over the last month bond yields have climbed to a fairly high level of between 6.5 percent and 6.6 percent, with underlying inflation at between 2 percent and 2.5 percent," she said. "The Fed will raise short-term rates, but we don't think there is much more damage to come at the long end of the yield curve."
Other analysts painted yesterday's drop in stock prices as a mild reaction to the explosive rise recorded in late 1999. "An awful lot of money had been made in a very short period of time," said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own stock market research firm, adding, "This is only a correction."
Mr. Greenspan is widely respected on Wall Street, given credit both for saving the banks after they ran into problems a decade ago and for helping to engineer the current period of economic growth, which will soon become the longest in the nation's history. "You'd have thought the market would go up 300 points on Greenspan's reappointment," said Byron R. Wien, an equity strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The fact the market didn't go up is troubling."
Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, said one factor pushing rates higher and stocks lower might be Fed actions to reverse the flow of billions of dollars into the economy at the end of 1999, when the Fed wanted to assure that the transition to 2000 would go smoothly.
The declines in Europe, which included a 3.8 percent drop in the leading British index, a 2.4 percent fall in the leading German index and a 4.2 percent plunge in the French index, were blamed both on expectations of higher interest rates there and on a reaction to Monday's declines in American stock prices, when the Dow fell 139.61 points.
Throughout the 1990's, the American stock market had frequent bad days, but usually bounced back quickly as investors took advantage of lower prices. For example, on April 19 of last year, the Nasdaq composite plunged 5.56 percent, virtually the same amount it fell yesterday, as technology stocks had an especially bad day. The market bounced back quickly, recovering the entire loss in two days.
Historically, January has often been a good month for stocks, but that has not always held true at the beginnings of decades.
Yale Hirsch of the Hirsch Organization, a market research firm, said that the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks has gone up in 33 of the past 50 Januaries. But the three worst performances, with declines ranging from 6.9 percent to 7.6 percent, came in 1970, 1960 and 1990.
After two trading days this year, the S.& P. 500 is down 4.8 percent, a result in part of big drops in bellwether technology names like America Online, Oracle and Microsoft.
The Russell 2000 small-capitalization stock index shed 18.04 points, or 3.6 percent, to 478.38, and is down 5.2 percent in 2000.
The Nasdaq composite, which had been alone in moving to a new high on Monday, fell 5.55 percent. Internet companies like Yahoo and CMGI, which were darlings for much of last year, were hammered. Yahoo fell $32 a share, to $443. CMGI, the Internet holding company, lost $32.6875 a share, to $293.75. Cisco Systems dropped $6.0625 a share, to $102.
The biggest losers among Dow stocks included Hewlett-Packard, off $8.9375 a share, to $108.50, American Express, down $5.9375, to $151.3125, General Electric, off $5.6875, to $144.3125, and J. P. Morgan, down $6.0625, to $115.375. Financial stocks were especially hard hit.
Volume was heavy, but not spectacular. Volume on the Nasdaq was 1.49 billion shares, while Big Board turnover was 990 million shares.

HEADLINE: With Mild Winter, Snow Business Is Slow Business

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: MILTON, Mass., Jan. 4

 BODY:
Is there a more melancholy midwinter New England sight than a melting ski slope defiled by great patches of mud? Can there be a glummer calling than that of Stanley Beers, manager of the Blue Hills Ski Area here, on days like this when nobody stops by the lodge but the occasional rubber-booted hiker?
This morning, said Mr. Beers, who has taken a second mortgage on his house to keep the ski area open, his ski school director, Jim Sutherland, told him, "I feel like the Maytag repairman," the advertising character who never got any business. 
 "Every year," Mr. Sutherland said, "you think you've seen the worst of it, and then the next year comes and it gets even worse."
The unusually warm and snowless weather that has been breaking records over New England may mean pleasant shirtsleeve strolls for some, but it means ulcers to businesspeople dependent on snow, from snowmobile stores in Maine to ski centers in Connecticut.
Even the major ski resorts of northern New England, with their extensive snow-making, have shown signs of snow shortage. The American Skiing Company, the financially precarious skiing giant, promised package guests at its six major New England resorts that if 70 percent of the slopes were not snow-covered when they arrived Christmas week, they would receive future discounts and $500 toward a stay at two company resorts in the West. Four of the company's six New England resorts did not make the grade by Dec. 25, a spokesman said, so American Skiing is giving the discounts to all its Christmas week guests.
Skiing areas in the West, too, have reported less snow than usual and late openings of some trails. At Crested Butte Mountain Resort in Colorado, only 45 percent of groomed trails were open by Monday, said a spokeswoman, Gina Kroft. And in Utah, some resorts reported that a combination of millennium fears and little snowfall had cut the number of skiers by one-third or more.
In New England, some smaller alpine ski resorts and other businesses, like cross-country ski centers that depend on snow from clouds rather than machines, report feeling pinched by the pre-spring spring that continued in much of the region today. Providence, R.I., reported a near-record temperature of 60, and Boston has not seen measurable snow for 395 days, two days short of a record. From Portland, Me., to Providence, New England towns saw record high temperatures on Monday, as well, and spots from Burlington, Vt. to Portland report snowfall to date at only a fraction of the usual level.
In Greenville, Me., Paul Fichtner III, the owner of Big Lake Equipment, said that during a typical Christmas season, he sold $5,000 in accessories and a half-dozen snowmobiles. This winter, the most snowless in his memory, he has sold just $500 in accessories and one child-sized snowmobile.
Greenville, once a lumber town, is heavily dependent on snowmobile tourism, Mr. Fichtner said.
"And if there is no snow, there's no business," he said. "It's as simple as that. I haven't put my cash drawer in the register since a week before Christmas."
"There is some snow up here and there is snowmobiling going on, but the only people going are the real hard-core guys; they are hitting rocks and stumps and banging up their machines," he said.
In Connecticut, some ski resorts reported that the unseasonal weather had forced them to open later than desired.
"It's been staying warmer, and we've been getting less snow the past few years," said Ed Beckley, general manager of the Mount Southington Ski Area in Southington, "and the major impact it's had on us is having to open later in the season, sometimes as late as Dec. 25. Natural snow is the best advertisement for skiing, and after a snowstorm we always have a 50 percent increase in attendance, and there haven't been many snowstorms the past couple of years. We've definitely seen a dip in attendance."
That dip can also be observed at cross-country skiing resorts, which make far less snow than their alpine counterparts. Today, those who called on the "snow phone" of Ski New Hampshire, a consortium of 35 New Hampshire skiing centers, to check on cross-country skiing conditions heard a disheartening summary: "It looks like we're off to a soggy start today, and that's limiting terrain for us." The picture in Vermont has been similar.
In New York State, Ann and Olavi Hirvonen, owners of the Laplan Lake Cross Country Ski and Vacation Center in Benson, said that on a normal winter weekend they had 350 to 600 lodgers and skiers. But recently, they have been averaging about 100. Mr. Hirvonen, a native Finn and former member of the United States Olympic cross-country ski team, has been introducing his guests to kyykka, a Finnish game similar to bowling, to entertain them in lieu of skiing.
But not everyone is suffering. Some stores say the disappointing outdoor climate is more than offset by the luxurious economic climate.
"We've been bombed with business," said Danny Canton, assistant manager of the ski shop at the Alpin Haus in Amsterdam, N.Y. "It's hard to explain, but the economy is good and people are optimistic that winter will eventually arrive."
Larger ski areas are also buffered from the vagaries of the weather by their ever-expanding snow-making capacity. In New England, several resorts that closed in the mid-90's have re-opened, usually with infusions of capital that went in part for snow machines. Even so, resorts large and small pray for snow, both for the money they would save on snow-making and for the enthusiasm it ignites in skiers.
"If they see snow in the backyard, they'll come," said Mr. Beers of the Blue Hills Ski Area.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Lots of Bad-Natured Floridians and One Good-Natured Dog

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

SICK PUPPY
By Carl Hiaasen
341 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
 It's hard to find someone to root for in Carl Hiaasen's latest over-the-edge comedy, "Sick Puppy," about avarice and corruption in what one of the novel's characters refers to as "the swamp of teeming greed known as Florida."
There are plenty of people to root against: the developers who want to cement over the entire Florida shoreline, the lobbyists who know which politicians to bribe to get the cementing done and the politicians themselves, particularly Gov. Dick Artemis, a former Toyota salesman who describes himself in interviews as "a people person's people person," inspiring groans from his staff. 
 Hemmed in by such repellent riffraff, the reader's heart inches out toward Twilly Spree, introduced by the text as "an unemployed 26-year-old college dropout with a brief but spectacular history of psychological problems." The narrator adds, "Not incidentally, he also had inherited millions of dollars."
You want to like Twilly because he's for the right things. He hates the developers and the despoilers of Florida's natural beauty. The trouble is that he carries things a little far, having been traumatized early in life by a developer-father who helped ruin the skyline of Marco Island with "a concrete picket of towering hotels and high-rise condominiums." Twilly carries things so far that early on we meet him in an anger-management course that he has to take because he blew up his uncle's bank for lending millions "to a rock-mining company that's digging craters in the Amazon River basin."
When the instructor suggests this might be acting out something subconscious, Twilly announces that he has no subconscious; he doesn't even dream. You want to like Twilly, but he's hard to identify with.
One day on the turnpike north of Yeehaw Junction, Twilly sees a Burger King hamburger carton fly out the window of a Range Rover, followed by a cup, a wadded paper napkin and another hamburger carton. To punish the litterbug, Twilly follows him home and arranges to have his wife's BMW convertible submerged in a ton of garbage.
When Twilly catches the driver littering again, he invades his house and dognaps his big black Labrador retriever, Boodle, whom he renames McGuinn after a favorite musician. When he discovers that the dog's owner, Palmer Stoat, is a lobbyist helping a developer to turn nearby Toad Island into "a golfer's paradise," Twilly tries to get him to stop by threatening the dog's life and sending Stoat what appear to be parts of the animal, although in fact Twilly is getting fond of McGuinn and wouldn't dream of harming him.
The developers retaliate by sicking nasty people on Twilly. The battle steadily escalates, and Mr. Hiaasen uses the resulting mayhem to spit poison at all he finds excessive about Florida, where of course he was reared and lives and writes a column for The Miami Herald.
It isn't so much that you grow fond of Twilly as that you come to revile most of the characters surrounding him, who often edge over into extremes. Besides the lobbyist Stoat, whose hobby is to shoot crippled big-game animals at the Wilderness Veldt Plantation near Ocala, there's the Toad Island developer, Robert Clapley, who has a fetish for Barbie Dolls and is arranging to convert two of his female friends into a life-size pair.
There's the menacing Mr. Gash, who collects recordings of 911 calls and sets them to music, including one from a hysterical man on a cell phone in a plane that is about to crash near Duluth, who wants the operator to cover for him by telling his wife why he isn't in Eau Claire. There's the conservative call girl who sleeps only with Republicans. There's the Toad Island project supervisor who hates all nature because as a child he was bitten on his scrotum by a chipmunk. There's the ex-governor who has retired to the Everglades and survives by eating road kill.
By comparison, Twilly, despite his unmanaged rage, seems positively benign. And he improves as the story progresses, falling in love with Stoat's beautiful, disaffected wife, Desirata, who begins to tame him. He even starts to dream. But the character who really keeps you involved in the plot is the black Lab, Boodle-McGuinn, the literal "sick puppy" of the title (something he swallowed has to be surgically removed), the less literal ones being legion in the story.
It is this galumphing creature that softens the novel's brutality and brings out the occasional burst of joy in Mr. Hiaasen's prose: "That's the thing about being a Labrador retriever -- you were born for fun. Seldom was your loopy, freewheeling mind cluttered by contemplation, and never at all by somber worry; every day was a romp. What else could there possibly be to life? Eating was a thrill. . . . And everywhere you went were gullible human beings who patted and hugged and fussed over you."
It is this animal that with its innocent clowning lends the story its moral perspective and gives some meaning to the novel's message, delivered by the road-kill-eating ex-governor, an angry counterpart to Twilly: "I will tell you there's probably no peace for people like you and me in this world. Somebody's got to be angry or nothing gets fixed. That's what we were put here for."
In fact, almost everyone in "Sick Puppy" seems to be angry. But this big, affectionate dog amid all the novel's cartoon sadism makes it possible for the reader to laugh.

HEADLINE: A Wild Ride That's Not Over Yet

BYLINE: By FRED BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THEY had promised their children a New Year's Eve ride on the British Airways London Eye, the 450-foot Ferris wheel that stands over the Thames across from Big Ben.
Instead, David Marks and Julia Barfield, the husband-and-wife architects who designed the structure, had to entertain their family on the ground. The children -- plus several hundred guests of British Airways, the wheel's primary sponsor -- were unable to ride after it failed an 11th-hour inspection. 
 For Ms. Barfield and Mr. Marks, who went into debt to get the $40 million wheel built, the failure of a clutch mechanism in one of its 32 passenger compartments was only the latest indignity. There were problems in October raising the 1,600-ton structure, which was constructed horizontally over the Thames, then hoisted to its vertical position. A few days later, nine environmentalists climbed the wheel and stayed overnight, in a protest against dam construction in India.
Now this. Jamie Bowden, a British Airways spokesman, said that the clutch failed during a Dec. 30 simulation and that it is being disassembled and tested. He added: "If we have found a 'rogue' clutch, it could be fixed by possibly the end of this week." If the problem is not just with that clutch, repairs could take longer, he said.
"Everyone was a bit gutted," Mr. Marks said, using a Britishism for disappointed. Yet, he and Ms. Barfield, who have lived in the same modest South London house for 25 years, are philosophical. "It was still a great New Year's Eve," Mr. Marks said. The couple were honored by Tony Blair (they're now Members of the British Empire, he said) and got to see the wheel illuminated by fireworks. Mr. Marks continued, "A friend called from Wilkes-Barre, Pa., to tell us how gorgeous the wheel looked on TV." He added, "We're chuffed," which, he explained, means happy.
The mixed emotions -- gutted and chuffed -- were shared by 250 Britons who had won tickets to the wheel's debut in a national competition. As compensation, British Airways said it would give them round-trip tickets to any of its destinations, and it promised rain checks when the wheel opens. Mr. Bowden said he was still hoping for Feb. 1, with a celebration two weeks later, on Valentine's Day. (Several hundred Londoners have already applied to be married on the wheel.)
Seven years ago, when the couple proposed the wheel, their small South London architecture firm was in the midst of a recession. "We proposed it as something uplifting for the country for the millennium and, frankly, something uplifting for ourselves," Mr. Marks said.
He said computers allowed them to design an unusually thin wheel. "It's twice as tall as the original Ferris wheel, in Chicago," he said, "but only half the weight." The lightness also meant that the wheel needed few supports and that it could be cantilevered over the Thames. That, said Mr. Marks, who has ridden the wheel several times, means that "as soon as you get into the capsule, you're experiencing an amazing view."
Still, Mr. Marks and Ms. Barfield, both 47, had no reason to assume that their wheel would be built. Then, a London newspaper, The Evening Standard, made the structure, said to be the world's largest Ferris wheel, a pet cause. Mr. Marks said, "They interviewed celebrities about the idea, and only published the favorable quotes."
Eventually, Mr. Marks and Ms. Barfield formed a corporation and began seeking sponsors, a process that, they say, left them heavily in debt. "It's almost as if people test you, to see how much you're willing to sacrifice to get it built," Mr. Marks said in an interview in December at his home, where he and his wife were both suffering from the flu. They admit to spending too much time away from their three children during the years they devoted to the wheel. When their son, Benjamin, now 13, presented Ms. Barfield with a painting of the wheel for her recent birthday, they considered it a peace offering.
The wheel's 32 capsules, shaped like Airstream trailers and hanging from the wheel like jewels, will each hold 25 passengers. The ride will take 30 minutes, and is, Mr. Marks said, "an efficient way to get people up to great heights." (Indeed, Ben doesn't look so Big next to the wheel, which is said to be one of the tallest structures in London. On a clear day, the view will take in Windsor Castle, 25 miles away.) So far, more than half a million tickets have been sold at 7.45 and 4.95 for children, about $12 and $8, meaning the sponsors could well make back their investment. The wheel is expected to remain up for five years.
Now, Ms. Barfield and Mr. Marks, who let the rest of their architectural practice languish during their wheel years, say they need to focus on finding other work.
Eight miles east of their wheel, the Millennium Dome, which cost 30 times as much (and was paid for by a national lottery), is languishing. (The couple, who both worked for its architect, Richard Rogers, say he has been very supportive of their competing project.) The Guardian's architecture critic, Jonathan Glancey, called the dome "a 70's mall in a grimy tent."
By contrast, the wheel has been a crowd pleaser. Even Richard Branson, whose Virgin Airways competes with British Airways, praised the wheel's beauty, adding, "It's the best thing British Air has done in 20 years." One Londoner observed, "It's captured the imagination, so people are forgiving of its problems."
Ms. Barfield, at her home in South London (where the biggest wheel is on her daughter's hot pink bicycle), displayed a Christmas card from the family's dentist. It featured a drawing of the Millennium Dome, under a gentle snowfall, Currier & Ives style. Oh, the indignities. Next year, she hopes, the card will show the millennium wheel.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
New York State Receives A Low-Tech Rating

BYLINE: By BRUCE HEADLAM

 BODY:
Is New York State at the corner of Silicon and Nowhere? According to a recent report by Forrester Research, the home of Silicon Alley is closer to a digital Dogpatch than a technological nirvana.
The report mapped the country according to "receptiveness to and adoption of technology," by comparing states on number of computers in homes and offices, online purchases and a subjective category, "optimism about technology." Among the "fast lane" states were Texas, Georgia and Connecticut. New York was ranked a giant step down as a "middle of the road" state. 
 Ekaterina Walsh, an analyst with Forrester, said that a surprisingly large factor was the proportion of urban and rural areas. "The rural parts really set off the advances of the big cities," she said.
New York can take heart that Washington, home to Microsoft, was another also-ran. "Again, rural areas," Ms. Walsh said. "Of course, you have a concentration around Seattle and Redmond. But in other parts of the state, you might as well be in Montana or Idaho." BRUCE HEADLAM

HEADLINE: Let Them In, to Work

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Home Aides for Elderly in Short Supply" (news article, Jan. 3): 
 In a world troubled by extreme poverty, it is absurd for Americans to lament a shortage of low-wage workers. We forget the thousands of people on this planet who would treasure the chance to earn $7 an hour. It is time to share the prosperity of this booming economy by loosening our immigration laws, a simple yet often overlooked solution.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rally EndsAbruptly in Asia As Stock Markets Plummet

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Stock markets across much of Asia plummeted today, abruptly ending a post-millennium rally, as investors here reacted with alarm to Wall Street's stumble on Tuesday.
Fears that the United States plans to raise interest rates prompted investors to dump shares in blue-chip companies from Seoul to Singapore. The selloff was most severe in Hong Kong, where the benchmark Hang Seng index plunged 7.2 percent, or 1,226 points, its second-largest point loss in history. 
 But while the flood of losses seemed to echo the tumultuous first days of the Asian economic crisis, analysts said there was little reason to panic. They said that investors were mainly seeking to lock in their profits after a powerful year-end rally, particularly in high-flying technology stocks.
"It's not a surprise because virtually every day over the last two months, we have been waiting and wondering when the market would correct," said Dong Tao, a regional strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong. "Asia's recovery is still very much alive," he added.
In Tokyo, the benchmark Nikkei index fell 460.31 points, or 2.4 percent, to 18,542.55. But importantly, more shares gained value than lost value, as investors took their money out of technology and Internet stocks and put it into traditional sectors like construction, steel and chemicals.
"These are the stocks to be looking at," said Craig Chudler, a strategist at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. "There are real opportunities in those bombed-out areas of the market, whereas the Sonys and Softbanks have been oversold," he said, referring to two popular Japanese technology stocks.
In other Asian markets, it was hard to see the big picture as the losses piled up. South Korea's market dropped 6.9 percent, or 72.73 points, its worst single-day point loss ever. Shares in Singapore declined by 5.5 percent, while the markets in Malaysia and Thailand fell 2.2 percent and 6.5 percent, respectively.
China's stock markets took some hits as well, though not as badly. In the southern city of Shenzhen adjoining Hong Kong, the stock index representing shares that can be purchased by foreign investors fell 2.5 percent, and a similar index in Shanghai ended unchanged. Shares of companies available only to Chinese investors rose, however, with the main index in Shanghai gaining 3.6 percent.
Taiwan avoided the rout. Taipei's weighted price index rose 1.1 percent as investors bought shares of semiconductor companies. Taiwan's market is driven by technology manufacturers -- as opposed to Internet-related concerns -- which makes it less vulnerable to wild swings.
Though stock markets in Asia have always paid attention to Wall Street, the link has become closer as Asian countries have come to depend on the United States as the locomotive pulling them out of recession. Investors here worry that if the Federal Reserve raises interest rates, as is widely expected, it would diminish the appetite of American consumers for goods from Asia.
That fear is magnified in Hong Kong because the former British colony ties the value of its currency to the United States dollar. When the United States raises interest rates, Hong Kong's banks must follow suit to defend the value of the Hong Kong dollar. Hong Kong has put last year's recession behind it, but some people fear that higher rates could strangle the recovery.
Asia's sensitivity to the United States has also been heightened by the recent surge in popularity of technology stocks here. Shares of companies like Softbank in Japan and Pacific Century CyberWorks in Hong Kong have propelled the broader markets to record levels.
As a result, when the Nasdaq composite index, which lists many top American technology stocks, fell 5.6 percent on Tuesday, its reverberations were felt in Asia. Pacific Century -- an Internet-related company that has been the toast of Hong Kong, even throwing the most talked-about New Year's Eve party -- slid 15 percent, to $16.05 a share.
Analysts said such setbacks were to be expected, given the torrid performance of most Asian markets in the last six months. Shares in Tokyo rose 37 percent in 1999, buoyed by hopes that Japan is finally pulling out of its chronic downturn. Hong Kong's market plowed through 17,000 points on the first day of trading in 2000, after soaring from one record after another last week.
Today, the Hang Seng index plummeted more than 1,000 points in the opening minutes of trading, to less than 16,000, before stabilizing. The steep decline prompted Hong Kong's financial secretary, Sir Donald Tsang, to appeal for calm among investors. The market recovered in the afternoon, closing at 15,846.72, 158 points above its lowest point of the day.
But Asia is worlds away from October 1997, when a market crash in Hong Kong augured a financial crisis across the region. In those tense days, investors were unnerved by a series of currency devaluations and the dawning recognition that hundreds of Asian banks and companies were effectively insolvent.
Now, after two painful years, most Asian countries are emerging from recession faster than expected. And while the region's initial recovery was driven by exports -- particularly in Korea and Malaysia -- economists say domestic consumption is perking up in these countries as well.
"If this had happened a few months earlier, it would have much more threatening," Mr. Tao of Credit Suisse said. "Asia's recovery depended much more on exports, and investors were still very fragile."

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 437 words

HEADLINE: The State of New York State

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki, offering an intriguing wish list in his State of the State address yesterday, focused on public education, the environment and boosting the lagging upstate economy. The New York governor's opening proposal on education shifts attention to a hot political topic that has seldom appeared high on his priority list. While the tendency is to see this speech as a semaphore signal to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to consider Mr. Pataki as a running mate, the worth of some of these proposals makes such assessments secondary, especially if Mr. Pataki follows through.
Governor Pataki offered a promising plan to relieve an acute shortage of qualified teachers expected in New York over the next few years. He proposed such environmental advances as a research institute to study rivers and estuaries, which he characterized as a "Woods Hole on the Hudson." And he laid out a questionable $700 million package of tax cuts and economic incentives to spread the nation's economic boom to upstate New York. 
 Although this annual speech is traditionally designed to sell concepts with little supporting detail, Governor Pataki's five-point education plan outlines ways to attract new teachers to disadvantaged schools. The idea of providing free tuition for CUNY or SUNY students who commit to teaching in these high-risk areas sounds especially encouraging. So does a summer school tutoring program using college juniors, and his proposal to allow retired public employees to teach without losing their retirement benefits. A plan to help uncertified teachers and to allow talented people to teach without going through the normal vetting system deserves a fair hearing.
The governor's tax and incentive proposals -- especially his effort to phase out a $500 million energy tax primarily on large businesses -- are aimed at his constituency in upstate New York. But the resulting revenue cuts would strain a state budget already facing multibillion-dollar gaps in the next two fiscal years. Even more troubling is his proposal to cap local school budgets and require two-thirds of the voters to approve going above those state-imposed limits. Such a plan would make it difficult for school boards trying to meet new academic standards in less affluent districts.
The governor failed to mention his proposal for campaign finance reform last year or the need to open the state's primary ballot to a broader array of candidates on March 7. Still, the teacher plan was worth the effort. Now Mr. Pataki must add the detailed legislation and necessary funds to go along with yesterday's pronouncements.
