HEADLINE: Japan's Investors Become Bullish On Merrill Lynch;
Focus on the Personal Touch

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TAKAMATSU, Japan

 BODY:
The "ginza," or shopping street, of this quintessential Japanese town on the island of Shikoku looks much like the ginza of any other moderately sized city here.
Covered to protect shoppers from rain, the thoroughfare is lined with mom-and-pop stores selling everything from ramen to slippers. 
 It is also home to one of the most successful Japanese branches of Merrill Lynch and Company, which has placed the biggest, riskiest bet so far in the effort by foreigners to sell ever-so-wary Japanese on American-style asset management.
"In places like Takamatsu, Sendai, Mayabashi, we have really built some momentum," said Ronald Strauss, head of Merrill's retail operations here. "If you had asked me a year ago whether some branch in a place I'd never heard of would be our leader, I would have laughed. But so much here depends on the branch manager and his relationships."
A year ago, the "thundering herd," as Merrill is known, had a pronounced limp in Japan. Competitors and the news media were clucking over the stunningly frank and gloomy assessment by David H. Komansky, the chairman, of the firm's progress in building a retail business here. Analysts wondered aloud why Merrill had not tackled Japan via the Internet, surely a less expensive, less risky route.
But Merrill stuck to its original hunch that an old-fashioned approach would work best -- that a personal touch, a focus on the whole customer, was far better than the bells and whistles of electronic trading. And this approach seems to be paying off.
Merrill, to be sure, had a rocky start. Losses were greater and assets far harder to come by than it had expected when it picked over the bones of the bankrupt Yamaichi Securities firm, which it used to lay the foundation for its initial network of 33 branches.
Japan's gossip-hungry magazines were filled with stories of mass defections by unhappy brokers, and Merrill's branches always seemed to be empty.
"It was rather difficult," conceded Kenichi Hayakawa, manager of Merrill's branch in Sendai, Japan's 10th-largest city, about 200 miles north of Tokyo.
But things have picked up. In April, the Sendai branch became profitable, he said, and has now garnered more assets than Yamaichi had collected there in 60 years. "It's like being in a samurai battle in which we've won one small castle," Mr. Hayakawa said proudly.
This fall, Merrill hit a target of 1 trillion yen, or $9.59 billion, in assets; it has more than 60,000 clients; and it was recently identified as one of the top places Japanese youth would like to work for.
The pickup in the Japanese stock market certainly helped, Mr. Strauss said, but that is not the main reason for Merrill's success.
And as Japanese investors ponder where to put some $475 billion in high-interest-rate deposits that will start maturing in April, Merrill is perhaps best positioned to capture a good part of it.
"While one may pick apart the initial projections for asset gathering and break-even time, it is tough to dispute that the firm is ahead of its U.S. peers in gaining a foothold," Joan S. Solotar, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, wrote recently in a report.
Why? Precisely because of Merrill's presence in places like Sendai and Takamatsu, the largest town on Shikoku, the smallest of Japan's four main islands.
What many skeptics seem to have overlooked is that this is Japan, home of the world's most cautious investors. They were burned badly in the stock market almost a decade ago, when the Nikkei index plunged more than 60 percent in a little over two years. Basic concepts like asset allocation, compound interest and diversification are poorly understood here. Merrill brokers can help explain these concepts.
In addition, the government has for decades used a variety of tax and other incentives to encourage saving and discourage investing, so it seems unlikely that older Japanese, who hold the bulk of the nation's wealth, would be raring to hop onto the World Wide Web to invest.
But the elderly do know that with government and private pension funds vastly underfinanced, they will have to finance their own retirements. And young families are keenly aware that housing allowances and tuition credits subsidized by corporations are things of the past.
"I had hoped I could live off the interest generated by my savings, but Japanese interest rates are now at zero," said Mirei Shoji, a 67-year-old customer in Sendai. "I know stock and other investments have risks, but they also have rewards, and that's a chance I have to take."
It was her former Yamaichi broker, Yoko Nitta, who brought Mrs. Shoji to Merrill. "I didn't know anything about Merrill Lynch, but I trusted Nitta-san," Mrs. Shoji said.
So far, she is pleased. "When you deal with Japanese brokers, it's like dealing with a cloud," she said. "They bring you a pamphlet touting a stock, that's it."
She waved around a dog-eared copy of a Merrill report on the NEC Corporation. "This is the most wonderful thing about Merrill," she said. "The openness and the information is wonderful."
As Mrs. Shoji demonstrates, the skeptics have paid too little attention to the premium placed on relationships in Japan, face-to-face ties that deepen with time. Merrill's style of catering to customers may seem outmoded by American standards, but in Japan, where the stock market is regarded as little more than a casino, the personal touch will be needed to lure money out of government-insured bank accounts and the family chest.
"I'm not interested in making a huge profit," said Kensaku Yano, the 84-year-old founder of a regional supermarket chain that went public a few years ago. "I just want a good, trusting relationship with my broker."
Mr. Yano was one of the first to open an account at Merrill in Takamatsu. He had had an account at the local Yamaichi branch and still has accounts at other brokerage firms as well.
But he gets better treatment at Merrill, he said, adding that Japanese brokers urge him to trade stocks almost daily to generate commissions.
"I lost so much money at Nikko Securities because they put me in such bad stocks that my broker there gave me seven shares of NTT DoCoMo to try to make up for it," Mr. Yano said, using the popular name for the NTT Mobile Communications Network Corporation.
As it happens, those NTT shares did well -- they are now worth roughly $239,000 -- but he closed his account at Nikko anyway.
Such eyebrow-raising practices are the way most Japanese expect to do business with brokers, and convincing them that Merrill is any different has been a tough sell.
The typical office of a Japanese brokerage firm resembles an off-track betting parlor, with clusters of older men sitting around chain-smoking and watching a big screen flashing stock prices.
Asset management is an alien concept, with a heavy reliance on "churning" -- moving clients in and out of stocks rapidly, whether it makes sense or not.
"The typical Japanese client has gotten an impression that investing is sitting around and watching the board, buying a stock one day, selling it the next, maybe making money and maybe losing a lot," said Hidekazu Yoshimoto, manager of Merrill's Takamatsu branch.
Merrill wants clients' assets to grow, since bigger assets mean bigger fees. That requires brokers to have a certain understanding of clients' financial profiles, how much they already have invested in other securities, whether or not they have mortgages, what their goals and aspirations are.
In privacy-mad Japan, getting that kind of information is a challenge. "It's difficult to drop in on a client and say, 'So, what have you got in the way of assets?' " Mr. Yoshimoto said.
Indeed, many potential clients thought that Merrill wanted to know too much, that its fledgling brokers were too insistent on obtaining information, and it cost Merrill business.
"Clients are still very accustomed to the ways of traditional Japanese securities firms," Mr. Yoshimoto said. "When they receive a call from a broker, they expect to hear about new products, but we're telling them about new services and ways they can manage their money to build value. I think it was a bit of a severe culture shock."
One client was so skeptical when Mr. Yoshimoto told him Merrill had abolished the flashing screen from its branches that he drove halfway around Shikoku Island to see for himself. Satisfied, he deposited 100 million yen.
"The majority of clients we've signed up have never had accounts at a securities firm before," Mr. Yoshimoto said. "They're looking at how low interest rates are and worrying about the future, when they'll have to pay for retirement."
The former Yamaichi brokers who joined Merrill have also had to adapt: to managing assets rather than pushing stocks; to a pay system based increasingly on performance; to new responsibility; and even to a new freedom. Many have left, grumbling, but others, particularly women, have embraced the changes.
"We can say no to no-good products," said Seiko Takahashi, a financial consultant at Merrill's Sendai branch who had worked part time at Yamaichi. "We can honestly say what we think. It's a great feeling, a feeling like you're clean."
Her advice would have saved one of her more reckless clients, Soichiro Miura, quite a bit of money, had he listened. "I told him not to purchase Sansui," she said. "I said no three times, and when he overrode me the fourth time, I told him, 'well, if you want to throw your money into the sewer, go ahead.' "
He did. "I lost a lot of money," Mr. Miura said. "But next time, maybe I'll listen more carefully."
Mr. Miura, a dentist, is a typical Japanese investor. He has dabbled in futures and options and more exotic investments and lost plenty. He has even tried his hand at online trading. "I bought a PC in 1998," he said. "I didn't know what to do with it, but my friend was interested in stocks and trading stocks online. I got so submerged in trading online and all the information you can get online that I couldn't go to sleep, so I had to stop."
He regards equity investing as gambling, he said, but he was attracted to Merrill by its pledge to help him accumulate assets. He met with Mrs. Takahashi and liked what he heard. She supplies him with quarterly reports on companies, faxes him updates, sends him Merrill's research and calls him when the market makes any big move.
Japanese firms "were only calling me to tell me I should buy this new stock and sell that one," Mr. Miura said. "They didn't really care whether I made money."
While he still likes to play the market, he has set a certain goal for building his assets, at which point he will allow Mrs. Takahashi to make recommendations about diversifying. "Takahashi-san gives me peace of mind," he said.

HEADLINE: Ivory Coast Says It Is Halting Payments on Debt

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Accusing the ousted government of plundering state coffers, Ivory Coast's first military ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, said today that he was suspending the country's staggering foreign-debt payments.
General Guei's announcement apparently reversed his pledge last week to honor international commitments inherited from the elected government that he ousted in a coup on Christmas Eve. 
 "We have temporarily suspended payments of foreign commitments," General Guei said in a statement, explaining that coffers were empty. "Only after a thousand gymnastic moves were we even able to pay salaries."
"As you can imagine, the pillage was immense and systematic," General Guei said in the statement. He said his administration had begun auditing state accounts to learn who is responsible for missing funds.
He did not say whether Ivory Coast intended to resume debt payments later on to the World Bank, European Union, International Monetary Fund and other lenders.
On Tuesday, General Guei named himself president and defense minister in an interim coalition government. The new cabinet was sworn in today.
Ivory Coast, long one of Africa's most stable and prosperous countries, built up a huge debt -- estimated at $19.7 billion in 1996 -- during nearly four decades under the party of the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie.
The junta's move to halt debt payments threatens to aggravate the financial crisis. Last year, the monetary fund and the European Union slashed aid to the country after corruption allegations against the Bedie government.
Since the coup, the United States and Canada have also cut aid to the West African country. France, the former colonial ruler, is scaling back its support. And the European Union's representative, Catherine Travin, said today that European officials were scheduled to hold talks with the junta that could lead to further aid cuts.
The coup came during an economic decline linked to falling prices for Ivory Coast's main exports, coffee and cocoa. Tensions increased sharply during the final months of Mr. Bedie's government, which was widely accused of corruption and stirring ethnic enmities.

HEADLINE: Rule on Ads for Diet Supplements Is Revised

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The makers of vitamins, herbs and dietary supplements may market products for natural conditions like morning sickness, hot flashes and memory loss in aging without proving they are safe or effective, the Food and Drug Administration announced today.
The decision, which reverses an earlier proposal, marks the latest in a series of legal and regulatory victories for the dietary supplement business, which has been growing by leaps and bounds since Congress passed a law in 1994 that severely restricted the F.D.A.'s authority to regulate the industry. 
 The move enraged and startled consumer advocates, who said it would weaken patient protections.
"This is a snake-oil exemption," said Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen's Health Research Group in Washington. "It's a complete cave-in to the industry."
But drug agency officials said the new rule, which will take effect 30 days from Thursday, was an important part of their 10-year strategy to increase consumer confidence in the safety, composition and labeling of vitamins, herbs and other nutritional aids that have become an integral part of the lives of millions of Americans.
"This is not a free-for-all," said Peggy Dotzel, the associate acting commissioner for policy at the F.D.A. "What the agency is doing is faithfully carrying out the intent of Congress in passing the law."
The law is the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act, which distinguishes between products that makers say "affect the structure or function of the body" and those that are said to prevent, treat or cure disease. The law allows supplement manufacturers to sell products without F.D.A. approval -- and therefore without the rigorous safety and efficacy review that is required of drugs -- as long as they make only structure or function claims, and not claims related to disease.
But the law was not specific. So the F.D.A. decided it needed a new regulation to clarify its authority, and to delineate which claims fall into which category.
The rule put forth today was first proposed nearly two years ago, in April 1998. At the time, the agency said that while natural states like aging, pregnancy, menopause and adolescence were not diseases, they could be associated with abnormal conditions -- like morning sickness or premenstrual syndrome -- that are diseases. Products intended for those conditions would then have required F.D.A. approval.
But after reviewing thousands of public comments from industry representatives, consumers and others, Ms. Dotzel said, "the agency was convinced that these, in fact, are not diseases."
"These are normal, common conditions that are associated with the different stages of life." she said. "So claims about these conditions are not disease claims."
However, the rule states that uncommon or serious conditions associated with these life stages will still be treated as diseases. So a company may market a dietary supplement for teenagers who have acne, but not for acne so severe that the symptoms include cysts.
Industry representatives said they had not had time to review the new rule, which is 281 pages long, and could not comment on it in detail. But Corinne Russell, a spokeswoman for the Consumer Healthcare Products Association, a trade group representing 80 manufacturers of over-the-counter drugs and dietary supplements, said her organization was "cautiously optimistic" about the way the regulation had narrowed the definition of what is a disease.
"We thought the proposed rule was way too broad," Ms. Russell said.
The final rule precludes manufacturers from making what the F.D.A. describes as express disease claims or those that are implied. For instance, manufacturers cannot state that a product "prevents osteoporosis" or even that it "prevents bone fragility in post-menopausal women," without obtaining F.D.A. approval. But a company could say its product "maintains a healthy circulatory system" or that it promotes relaxation.
One academic expert said today that it was a tricky business to draw distinctions between diseases and a natural life passages.
"If they are going to make a distinction between diseases and normal states, they are on a slippery slope," said the expert, Dr. Richard A. Friedman, director of the psychopharmacology clinic at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University.
For instance, Dr. Friedman said, there is no laboratory test for dementia, so a person who takes the herb ginko for memory loss due to aging might in fact be in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease.
And he cautioned that just because a product was natural did not mean it was necessarily safe. Dr. Friedman and others were especially worried that, under the F.D.A.'s interpretation of the law, a pregnant women might endanger her fetus by taking an herbal product for morning sickness.
"It doesn't make any difference whether a product is synthetic or found in a plant," Dr. Friedman said. "It can be just as potent biologically."
Legal experts said the F.D.A. had little choice but to act as it did.
"F.D.A. has not done well in this area," said Robert G. Pinco, a food and drug lawyer who, in the 1970's, ran the agency's division for regulating over-the-counter drugs. "Every time they have gone into court to try to limit one of these claims, they have lost. It's because Congress has really changed the paradigm."

HEADLINE: Croatian Victors Fret About What Awaits Them

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Jan. 5

 BODY:
In the midst of the euphoria and high expectations following their convincing victory in parliamentary elections on Monday, leaders of Croatia's democratic opposition are growing concerned about when they will be able to take power and what they will find when they do so.
Ivica Racan, the moderate former Communist who will become the country's new prime minister, said in an interview today that it could be a month or more before Croatia's cumbersome constitutional process allows him to form a government. 
 "Of course we have a program of political and economic change," Mr. Racan said wryly. "But we'll have to see what the real situation is with the budget and everything else. It will be much worse, I think."
Mr. Racan, leader of the Social Democrats, and his coalition partner, the presidential hopeful Drazen Budisa of the Social Liberals, will govern with the help of an allied four-party coalition. They will replace the Croatian Democratic Union, which has run the country since the late president, Franjo Tudjman, took Croatia out of Yugoslavia in 1991.
"Tudjmanism -- this mixture of authoritarianism, nationalism and socialism -- is dead with its creator," said Mirko Galic, editor in chief of the independent weekly Globus. But with the death of Mr. Tudjman last month and the rebuff to his party, known as the H.D.Z., "we're really entering a period of instability," said Damir Matkovic, a television journalist. "It's a sort of paradox, but real freedom has come. And the problems the H.D.Z. is leaving are so deep and complicated you can't solve them quickly or without real pain."
Dividing up the spoils among six opposition parties of different ideologies and constituencies will be hard enough. But it will be easier than pulling the country out of the habits and shoals of a formerly socialist economy already in deep recession. Unemployment is well over 20 percent, there is a large budget deficit and a $10 billion national debt, foreign investment is declining and a fifth of the 4.8 million Croatians are due some kind of government pension while the pension fund is practically bankrupt.
"Racan and Budisa have to move quickly, in the next two or three weeks, to lay out a comprehensive plan of economic reform," a Western diplomat said. If they do not, he said, "they'll be dead, and this euphoria will turn against them."
Mr. Racan and Mr. Budisa are discussing some symbolic steps to distance themselves from the past, including giving up state control over Tito's resort on Brioni, which Mr. Tudjman loved, and moving the presidential apparatus out of the former Tito villa where it now operates as a separate fief, bringing it closer to Parliament.
Washington is already preparing a package of moves, both substantive and symbolic, to aid the new government, whose election the Clinton administration supported. That package will include economic advisers, a quick opening of talks with Croatia about joining a NATO program called Partnership for Peace, and a visit by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, perhaps for the new president's inauguration.
Proposals for more substantive American aid are still being discussed, officials said, and Washington will expect the new government to take quick action first on promises to free up the media, respect human rights and cooperate better in Bosnia and with the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
But Mr. Racan will want to move carefully so as not to leave himself open to attacks in a Croatia that remains "extremely, even rabidly nationalist," a senior European diplomat said. Another Western diplomat expressed concern that the tribunal will ask too much of Mr. Racan's government just as it is trying to push unpopular economic changes.
Much will also depend on who is elected president, with the first round of voting on Jan. 24 and a second round expected Feb. 7. The main opposition candidate, Mr. Budisa, is also a strong nationalist, and the current foreign minister, Mate Granic, the H.D.Z. candidate, is considered relatively moderate, at least in the context of his party.
Either would be easier to work with than Mr. Tudjman. Diplomats say Washington would have preferred Mr. Granic to run as an independent and not as the candidate of the H.D.Z. American officials are wary of what promises he may have made to more conservative or nationalist officials to obtain his party's nomination. But the H.D.Z.'s stinging defeat in the parliamentary vote has hurt Mr. Granic's chances and helped those of Mr. Budisa.
Mr. Racan is also concerned about the high expectations that Croatians now have about rapid change from a new government. People tell him, he said, that "we know it will be difficult for you, and that you must change many things in Croatia, but don't change yourself." They want honest government, he said; that at least he can try to provide them.
But a spokesman for the winning coalition, Tihomir Ladisic, thinks there is real danger in the long gap between winning the election and forming a government.
The state electoral commission found irregularities in 11 polling places, and there is talk of vote-rigging among Bosnian Croats. New voting in those polling places will take place on Jan. 16, the commission announced, thus delaying both the official results and the convening of a new Parliament. The current acting president, a member of the H.D.Z., has the right, under the Constitution, to wait for up to 20 days after the official results are in to call a new Parliament into session.
The new Parliament must elect a new speaker and acting president, who must then ask a political leader, presumably Mr. Racan, to form a government. But it might not be called into session until after at least the first round of presidential voting on Jan. 24, or even until the new president is elected and inaugurated, and some diplomats here think that could take until mid-February.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1894 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Radio Squeezes Empty Air Space for Profit

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
Rush Limbaugh said he noticed it about two months ago. Listeners to his daily radio show were sending in e-mail messages by the thousands, asking why there were more commercials on his three-hour talk-radio program.
"At first I didn't know what they were talking about," Mr. Limbaugh said. "I was talking for the same amount of time every day." 
 He may have been speaking for the same amount of time, but his words were, without his knowledge, being sucked into a temporal never-never land. A new kind of digital technology was literally snipping out the silent pockets between words, shortening the pauses and generally speeding up the pace of Mr. Limbaugh's speech.
In New York City, listeners to WABC heard the accelerated version of Mr. Limbaugh's program, causing Mr. Limbaugh to complain about it during a broadcast.
With no fanfare, the digital program -- called Cash in the direct manner of software nomenclature, because that's what it makes -- has established a foothold in the radio industry in the last six months. General managers at about 50 radio stations across the country are using it, to quicken talk programs so that they can wedge in more commercials. Radio stations are adding as many as four minutes of commercial time an hour -- or eight 30-second commercials. At one point, some stations added as many as six minutes of commercials, the maximum allowed by the technology, but eventually pulled back.
While the radio industry has previously used devices to speed up programming, this is the first time that time compression has been applied on live programming to expressly make room for more advertising. And the new device has angered radio denizens like Mr. Limbaugh, who says he uses pauses for emphasis much like an actor raises an eyebrow on stage. He spared no hyperbole when he spoke in an interview of its potential impact on radio: "I think it is potential doom for the radio industry," he said.
Mr. Limbaugh may be accustomed to predicting doom, but in an economy where advertising dollars are plentiful and radio stations can, as a result of deregulation, run as many commercials as listeners will tolerate, some say the radio industry is like a hungry child staring at an open cookie jar.
While radio executives say the impact of the Cash technology is often imperceptible to consumers, advertising executives complain that there is already too much clutter on the dial, making each commercial less effective. Other critics point to a larger issue: that the growth in commercials in recent years, combined with listeners drifting toward other media, may be helping to eat away at the radio audience.
Shrinking radio's content reflects the growing impulse to cram in advertising wherever and whenever possible. Once punctuating the cultural landscape, commercials now dominate it, from the flashing computer screens at the local deli cash register to the piped-in advertisements on corporate telephone lines to airport baggage carousels and supermarket floors.
Critics say that jamming too many ads on radio is one of the first places commercial overload becomes swiftly apparent. James Duncan, president of Duncan's American Radio, a Cincinnati-based broadcasting industry consulting group, said that asderegulation has loosened the industry's limits on commercials, their number has jumped to 20 commercials an hour, from about a dozen. That typically represents a rise of about 10 minutes an hour to, in some programs, as much as 30 minutes.
Since 1990, the total time Americans have spent listening to radio programming has shrunk by 12 percent, Mr. Duncan said. According to figures from Arbitron, the independent research agency that tracks radio ratings, time spent listening has indeed fallen in the last decade, to 21 hours 15 minutes a week, from 23 hours 45 minutes a week -- a decline of 10.5 percent.
"We are throwing way too many commercials at our listeners," Mr. Duncan said. "I think stations will slowly realize that there is a maximum that listeners can stand, and if they don't they will seriously downgrade their listenership."
But expanding commercial time has proved too tempting for the radio industry, which is experiencing boom times thanks to the healthy economy but also partly because the industry is now owned by a small cluster of giants like Clear Channel Communications, which has a pending deal to buy AMFM; the Infinity Broadcasting division of CBS; and Walt Disney's Capital Cities/ABC Broadcast Group. As the industry has consolidated, the economics of radio management have become more efficient, streamlining ad sales and centralizing programming.
The Radio Advertising Bureau estimates that radio sales will have reached $15.5 billion for 1999. Advertising revenue was up 14 percent on the local level and 27 percent on the national level through October 1999, compared with the same period the previous year, the bureau said.
When Cash became available last spring, it seemed a natural outgrowth of the advertising boom. Prime Image, a Silicon Valley technology company, introduced it after its device for television stations -- the Time Machine, which compresses audio and visual signals to make more time for commercials on live programming -- caught the eye of a radio station owner in Philadelphia.
The notion of time compression began to take hold in television about a decade ago, and has been used to moderately shrink syndicated programming like talk and game shows. But the time-compression equipment was not aggressively marketed as devices to create extra time for commercials until about three years ago.
The promotional literature for the Time Machine, for example, reads in part: "Use the Time Machine to add commercials to your program schedule and profits to your bottom line." Bill Hendershot, the president of Prime Image, said that more than 250 television stations -- affiliates from NBC, CBS, ABC, and Fox; several owned and operated stations, and a handful of cable networks -- own the Time Machine. The Inspirational Network in Charlotte, N.C., has used it to speed up sermons and religious programming.
Use of time-compression devices on television generally create less time for extra advertising, so the impact on the bottom line is proportionally less than for radio. Because television viewers and executives are much more sensitive to commercial clutter, the quantity of commercials on television has not reached the numbers of those on radio.
To squeeze in those vast numbers of commercials, Cash works on live radio by digitally recording the entire broadcast. It begins by recording the first couple of minutes of live radio -- depending on how many commercials the manager wants to insert -- then replays it, condensing the silent parts throughout the rest of the broadcast. It is used primarily by local radio stations that apply it to syndicated programs.
For example, one day last month, WWDB-FM in Philadelphia, which broadcasts Mr. Limbaugh's national program every day at noon, sought to gain almost three extra commercial minutes in one hour. The engineer inserted a one-minute commercial block at noon, and Cash silently recorded Mr. Limbaugh during that minute. At 12:01 p.m., the program began to play Mr. Limbaugh's now not-exactly-live broadcast; during the next 21 minutes, the digital program eliminated pockets of silence between Mr. Limbaugh's words and also removed what is known as "redundant" data from within words -- for example, shortening a long syllable. The station gradually earned back the one minute lost at the top of the broadcast.
The impact of Cash is minimized by Phil Boyce, the program director of New York's WABC-AM who experimented with Cash on Mr. Limbaugh's show in November -- until Mr. Limbaugh complained about it during a broadcast, a contretemps reported in The New York Post.
Mr. Boyce said that he had not yet decided if he would continue to use Cash. "Yes, you can shoehorn more commercials in," Mr. Boyce said. "But it really wouldn't be noticeable with the naked ear unless some station was using it to its maximum capacity by removing five or six minutes an hour."
But that is already happening. Dennis Begley, the general manager of WWDB-FM, has squeezed as many as six extra commercial minutes from an hour of Mr. Limbaugh's program, prompting complaints from listeners. But, he said, the benefits outweigh the disadvantages. "When I first heard about this thing, I knew we had to get it," he said, "because I knew the money-making potential was ridiculous."
But because listeners complained, he said, these days he aims to squeeze no more than four minutes an hour.
Mr. Boyce of WABC, the only New York station to experiment with Cash, said that the station used Cash because there was an unprecedented demand for commercial inventory.
"When you're in a sold-out situation, you look for any way possible to manage more advertising," Mr. Boyce said. Because of sensitivity to listeners and Mr. Limbaugh, WABC has suspended its use of Cash for the time being.
And that feast for radio stations has turned out to be a famine of sorts for advertisers, who are becoming sensitive to the quantity of commercials on radio. Jackie Davenport, a vice president and broadcast supervisor at Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York, said that the problem of clutter was much more apparent in radio than in television. Unlike television, where they closely watch how many minutes they will devote to commercial time, "radio will just add more minutes when the demand increases," she said. "The clutter has gotten out of control."
Ms. Davenport said advertisers had become wary of getting lost in a long commercial block, so that not only price but placement had become part of the negotiating process.
The compression technology has certainly given radio purists pause -- or maybe a lack thereof. Michael Harrison, the editor in chief of Talkers, a weekly magazine that chronicles the talk-radio industry, said that compression reflects trends in both radio and in the commercial-polluted American culture at large.
"It's a syndrome of our times," Mr. Harrison said. "We have no patience for anything that might seem superfluous. We're at a time when we're so caught up in speed and greed that we have no qualms about bastardizing artistic integrity."
Kraig T. Kitchin, the president and chief operating officer of Premiere Radio Networks, the subsidiary of Clear Channel that distributes "The Rush Limbaugh Show," said he had studied Cash to see if its speed had any adverse affects on Mr. Limbaugh's ratings and found that it did not. He called Cash's innovation inevitable.
"In life, everything moves faster now," Mr. Kitchin said. "You get more e-mails and voice mails than you can keep up with. But you still have the same number of hours in the day."
Even Mr. Limbaugh's complaints are not all tied to purist motives. Mr. Limbaugh, who receives a percentage of the advertising revenue raised during his program, said he was concerned about advertisers' perception of Cash.
"Nobody is going to listen to a radio program where 30 of every 60 minutes is advertising," Mr. Limbaugh said. "And no advertiser wants to be sandwiched in between six other commercials. But of course, to the technology nerds, this is a fascinating device."

HEADLINE: In Death of Abandoned Newborn, Echoes of an Earlier Case

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 5

 BODY:
It is only 10 miles from the nearby town of Wyckoff to the railroad tracks here where passers-by on Saturday found an unclothed newborn baby amid the detritus of a poor urban neighborhood: an empty bottle of Laird's gin, old discarded tennis shoes, a cracked toilet tank, a rusted tire rim.
But when the abandoned baby died in a local hospital on Saturday and his 14-year-old mother was charged with murder, an unlikely link was forged between the forlorn railroad yard and the upscale community to which Brian C. Peterson returned yesterday, after spending a year and a half in jail for his part in the death of his newborn baby when he was 18 years old. 
 On Tuesday the girl here, whose name has not been made public, pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and endangering the welfare of a minor. Judge Nestor F. Guzman of the family division of State Superior Court ordered her held for two days in the county juvenile detention center until a probable cause hearing on Thursday.
Prosecutors say they are considering asking Judge Guzman to charge the girl as an adult.
But along with their sorrow over the tragedy here, many residents found telling differences in the attention given to the two cases and the way they are being handled by the legal system.
Mr. Peterson was released yesterday after serving 18 months in prison for the widely publicized death of his baby in 1996. Prosecutors said that after Amy S. Grossberg, who was then his girlfriend, gave birth in a motel in Delaware, Mr. Peterson placed his newborn son in a plastic garbage bag and threw the bag into a Dumpster.
He returned yesterday to his neighborhood of sprawling lawns and three-car garages and said he was sorry for his role in the baby's death.
He and Ms. Grossberg pleaded guilty to manslaughter charges for their part in the death. Ms. Grossberg is to be released this summer.
Many here thought their penalties were light for the death of a baby and a stark contrast with the murder charges against the girl here.
"They had money, that's why they got away with it," said Rodney Green, a 28-year-old neighborhood resident.
The chief assistant prosecutor for Passaic County, William Purdy, said on Tuesday that a preliminary autopsy showed that the baby died of multiple blunt-force injuries and hypothermia. The baby's liver was severed, it had lacerations on its lungs and it suffered facial bone fractures, he said.
"I'm not going to speculate as to how the baby got those injuries," Mr. Purdy said. "That is still under investigation."
Investigators identified the father as a boy about the same age as the mother, but said they planned to file no criminal charges against him. They are still, however, investigating whether the girl had help in discarding the baby.
The girl lived with her mother and father and two siblings in a second-floor apartment in a white three-story house that abuts the railroad track, next door to the Express Tire Center and cater-corner to a market. There are Barbie stickers on windows of the first story. Only a rickety chain-link fence separates the girl's backyard from the tracks.
People in the neighborhood talked sadly about the abandoned baby, and wondered how it was that parents could not know what was happening to their own child living under the same roof.
"She acted like a kid because she was a kid herself," said Quasheema Miller, who is 34 and recalled seeing the small girl taking a younger sister to school every day.
The girl's lawyer, Frank J. Sciro of Paterson, said the parents want the daughter tried as a juvenile.
"She's 14 years old," Mr. Sciro said. "She had absolutely no history of trouble with the law. She's a B student at the Passaic County Technical and Vocational High School. Her parents are good, hard-working people. This incident is obviously completely out of character for this girl."
He also mentioned the case of Ms. Grossberg and Mr. Peterson.
"The community has told me loud and clear -- in calls from the clergy and City Council members -- that they want this girl treated the same as the children from Bergen County," he said.
Bob Grant, a spokesman for the Paterson mayor's office, said today that the message of the two cases was that family tragedies play out in both poor and rich communities.
"The juxtaposition of these two cases shows that it goes all across the economic and geographic lines," Mr. Grant said. "We need to make sure that our children aren't lost, whether they're from upper-echelon neighborhoods like Columbine, Colo., or from less economically advantaged areas."

HEADLINE: Capitol Hill Memo;
Dueling Agendas Herald Fight for Control of Congress

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The battle for control of Congress officially began today.
At opposite ends of Pennsylvania Avenue -- on Capitol Hill and at the White House -- Democrats and Republicans sketched competing legislative visions that will dominate the Congressional calendar and campaigns this election year. 
 Two dozen House Republicans commemorated the fifth anniversary of taking control of Congress by releasing a glossy brochure heralding what they said were their accomplishments, among them a balanced budget, welfare reform and a stronger military.
What they did not say was just as striking. Republicans mentioned the Contract With America only once in an hourlong news conference. A two-and-one-half-minute video shown to reporters featured smiling children and even the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, but not Newt Gingrich. The former speaker led Republicans out of their 40 years in the political wilderness as the minority party, but his scorched-earth tactics led to surprising losses in the 1998 elections, and his messy divorce has deeply embarrassed many former acolytes.
"It's like Moses has been airbrushed out of the Bible," said Marshall Wittmann, director of Congressional relations at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative advocacy group.
At a White House news conference, President Clinton and the Democratic leaders, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, took their share of the credit for the nation's booming economy, soaring surpluses and lowest unemployment figures in 30 years -- no doubt recurring themes this election season.
The three leaders emerged from a private meeting to announce what they described as a united agenda that would include school reconstruction money, targeted tax cuts, reforms in Medicare and Social Security, a patients' bill of rights, an increase in the minimum wage and hate crimes legislation.
Mr. Clinton announced an expanded effort to rebuild the nation's deteriorating school buildings. He said he would reintroduce a $3.7 billion federal tax relief program to help local school districts float construction bonds backed by the federal government. The initiative was blocked by Congressional Republicans in recent years.
Election years are notorious for producing little legislation of significance, and it is unclear whether this year will be any different.
The best hope may be for compromises on a minimum wage increase and a patients' bill of rights. After that, the prospects dim considerably for any meaningful effort to deal with Social Security, Medicare or gun control, because both sides are likely to be more concerned about using those issues to draw the lines in the election debate.
Under another theory, Mr. Clinton and Congressional Republicans could set aside their mutual animosity to hammer out some legislative accomplishments. For opposite reasons, of course. Mr. Clinton wants to burnish his legacy, while Republicans are eager to produce enough accomplishments to earn voters' support in November.
But many Democratic and Republican strategists discount that theory as counter to Mr. Clinton's chief goal of keeping a Democrat in the White House, preferably Vice President Al Gore, and regaining control of the House and maybe even the Senate. Democrats relish the chance to run against a "do-nothing" Congress.
Even the backdrop of today's dueling political events caught the mood of the respective camps and foreshadowed what is likely to be a running Washington melodrama this year.
House Republicans held their news conference in a dowdy third-floor room at the Capitol Hill Club, a Republican redoubt. After the event, Republicans began a two-day retreat to discuss their legislative agenda. Sixty-three lawmakers, less than one-third of the conference, volunteered to fly in during the recess to attend. Congress officially returns to work on Jan. 24.
Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Daschle spoke to reporters at the White House with the Congressional math giving Democrats reason for hope. House Republicans outnumber Democrats, 222 to 212, with one independent usually voting with the Democrats, leaving them within a net change of five seats of reclaiming the House. At present, Republicans have 21 open seats to defend; Democrats only 6. In the Senate, Democrats face a much tougher challenge, with Republicans outnumbering them 55 to 45.
So the focus is clearly on the House. Despite repeated assurances today from Representative J. C. Watts Jr., an Oklahoma Republican who organized this week's events, that Republicans would go on the offensive, the prevailing mood among many rank-and-file Republicans seems to be simply to hang on to power.
Representative Jennifer Dunn, a Washington Republican who served two years in the minority before 1994, told reporters today, "We don't ever want that to happen again."
Indeed, the Republicans' revolutionary days of 1995 and the Contract With America, tempered by the government shutdowns and losses at the ballot box, have given way to cold-eyed pragmatism and political survival.
When asked today for the House Republican legislative priorities, Mr. Watts ticked off a tax cut, the size of which would not be determined for two or three more weeks, and vague pledges to remove more American soldiers from food stamp rolls by increasing their pay and to return more control of education to local officials. An important refrain today in the brochure and the news conference was something they would not do: dip into the Social Security surplus.
In the end, Congressional Republicans seem likely to follow the lead of their presidential nominee, even if it means adjusting their own priorities. Gov. George W. Bush, the party's front-runner in national polls, has distanced himself from House Republicans, some of whom have come across as partisan ideologues.
"Our agenda ought to reflect the fundamental platform of our most likely presidential nominee," said Representative John R. Kasich, an Ohio Republican who backs Mr. Bush. "To muddle a message or not do much would be a mistake."

HEADLINE: Budget to Cut 1,000 Positions

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Budget Group Inc., the No. 3 car-rental company, said that it planned to cut 1,000 jobs, get out of the car-sales business and take a fourth-quarter charge of as much as $65 million as it cuts operating costs by $100 million a year.
Budget, which is the second-largest truck-rental company, said it would cut about 1,000 jobs as it combined offices of its truck unit, Ryder TRS Inc., into its North American vehicle rental division. 
 The company said fourth-quarter results would be in line with the average analyst estimate, a loss of 45 cents a share based on a survey by First Call/Thomson Financial.
Budget, based in Daytona Beach, set up a joint venture to get out of the car retail business. It has transferred seven sites into the venture, sold three others and closed one more.
It planned to sell its a van-leasing business and its Cruise America recreational-vehicle sales and rental unit and said it had received some inquiries about the divisions.
The company also said it had reached an agreement with the Ford Motor Company under which Ford would remain the main source of rental vehicles. It declined to disclose the terms of the agreement.

HEADLINE: U.S. Factories Rebounded In November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
New orders to American factories for manufactured goods rose 1.2 percent in November, the first increase since August, as companies producing electronic products enjoyed a surge in demand.
The Commerce Department said today that the November increase in factory orders followed no gain in October and a 1 percent decline in September. Orders had risen 1.3 percent in August. 
 The rebound in manufacturing was the latest evidence that the United States economy was still growing at a robust rate as the year ended.
Investors have grown increasingly worried that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates again at its meeting in early February. The Fed raised rates three times last year.
President Clinton said on Tuesday that he would nominate Alan Greenspan for a fourth four-year term as chairman of the Fed. While Wall Street holds Mr. Greenspan in high regard, Mr. Clinton's announcement did not overcome investors' jitters about future rate increases.
The government said that November factory orders rose $4.5 billion, pushing the total for the month to a seasonally adjusted $365.2 billion.
Much of the strength came from a $3 billion rise in orders placed with makers of electronic equipment, reflecting strong demand for components, including semiconductors.
The 8.4 percent advance for electronic manufacturers was the fifth increase in the last six months and the biggest since July 1998.
Orders for fabricated metals, like steel, rose by 2.6 percent, to $20.6 billion. The sector is struggling to recover from a flood of cheap imported steel that forced the layoff of thousands of United States steelworkers and led the industry to successfully petition for penalty tariffs to stem the tide of foreign imports.
Orders for cars, airplanes and other transportation equipment fell by 3.5 percent in November to $45.1 billion, largely reflecting a drop in demand for aircraft and parts.
Excluding the volatile transportation category, orders would have been up by 1.9 percent in November, the biggest advance since a 2.6 percent rise in July.
Orders for durable goods -- items expected to last three or more years -- rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in November. This represented a downward revision from an advance report two weeks ago that estimated durable-goods orders had risen 1.2 percent in November.
Orders for nondurable goods were up 1.6 percent in November following a 1.1 percent October increase.

HEADLINE: Car and Truck Sales in 1999 Set U.S. Record

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Automakers sold 16.89 million cars and trucks in the United States last year, exceeding a record established in 1986 by more than 800,000 vehicles, according to sales results released today. The strong sales, up 5.2 percent from the previous record 13 years earlier, helped many automakers earn what are expected to be record profits.
Despite increased sales, however, both Ford and DaimlerChrysler lost market share over the course of the year. General Motors eked out a small gain over its results in the previous year, which had been plagued by a long strike, but failed to meet its own target for market share, finishing 1999 with less than 30 percent for the auto market for the first time since the 1920's. 
 The big gainers were European-based automakers, led by Volkswagen, and South Korean companies selling relatively inexpensive cars, mostly to people who previously drove used cars.
Purchasers spent freely in all ranges of the market, encouraged by the long-running economic prosperity.
"It was an extraordinary year," said Diane C. Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation. "As good as it was, it still was one of the most brutally competitive markets."
Auto stocks were mixed in trading today. G.M. closed unchanged at $71.625. Ford edged up 18.75 cents, to $50.8125, and DaimlerChrysler gained 62.5 cents, to $74.875.
Industry executives and economists predicted robust sales again this year. "A strong economy, confident consumers and innovative products were the major factors driving our record-breaking sales and earnings in 1999," said Robert Rewey, a Ford group vice president. "The good news is these factors are alive and well as we kick off 2000."
General Motors said today that its December sales rose 6.2 percent, with car sales down 7.2 percent and the sales of pickup trucks, minivans and sport utility vehicles up 21.5 percent.
"We've worked very hard to profitably improve our mix this year," said Roy S. Roberts, G.M.'s group vice president for North American vehicle sales, service and marketing. Last year, high-profit trucks made up 49.3 percent of G.M.'s sales, an increase from 46.7 percent in 1998. "We said we'd improve mix, we did, and we will continue to improve our mix in this highly competitive marketplace," Mr. Roberts said.
For the year, G.M.'s car sales rose 5.5 percent, its truck sales increased 12.8 percent and its overall sales rose 8.9 percent. That was enough to nudge its market share to 29.45 percent, just above the 29.4 percent share for 1998, when a strike shut down the company for two months. But last year's 29.45 percent market share was well below the 31.29 percent in 1997.
G.M. also predicted that industrywide sales this year would be strong, even though the company does not expect to match 1999's level.
Ford said its December sales rose 3.2 percent, with cars 17.6 percent higher and sales of pickup trucks, minivans and sport utility vehicles down 5.3 percent. That rounded out a year in which Ford's car sales rose 9.4 percent and its truck sales rose 4 percent, for an overall gain of 6.1 percent.
Because the auto market was so strong, Ford's increase was not sufficient to keep pace with industry sales, which rose 8.7 percent over all. Total car sales for the industry were up 6.9 percent and truck sales up 10.7 percent. As a result, Ford's market share fell to 24.4 percent for the year from 25.5 percent in 1998.
DaimlerChrysler also saw its market share drop, to 16.75 percent last year from 17.25 percent in 1998. Sales rose 2 percent in December.
The decreasing market shares have led automakers to scrape for customers by offering rebates, discount loans and cheap leases, which in turn have helped keep sales high. On Tuesday, G.M. said it would offer discounts on almost all its cars and trucks, and DaimlerChrysler said it might accept the coupons on its vehicles. Ford was still considering its options today.
Analysts said that G.M.'s move amounted to the first shot across the bow in a price war. "Clearly, the big competitors are going to respond to G.M.'s action, and G.M. will respond to that action," said John A. Casesa of Merrill Lynch, adding, "We could see some pretty heavy incentives by the spring selling season."
Today's figures also showed that the Toyota Camry was again the most popular car in the United States last year, with sales of 448,162. The Honda Accord was not far behind, with sales of 404,192, and the Ford Taurus was third, with 368,327. Outselling them all by a big margin were a couple of pickup trucks: the Ford F-series pickups, with sales of 869,001, and the Chevrolet Silverado, with 636,150.
South Korean automakers gained customers in 1999. Daewoo won two-tenths of 1 percent of the United States market in its first year selling cars here. Hyundai saw its share rise to 0.97 percent last year from 0.58 percent in 1998, and the share for Kia rose to eight-tenths of 1 percent from 0.53 percent. Volkswagen, the biggest European gainer, saw its market share rise to 2.26 percent last year from 1.72 percent in 1998. BMW rose to 1.09 percent of the market from 0.98 percent.
Some other large automakers struggled with market share. Toyota declined to 8.73 percent from 8.76 percent last year, and Honda's share fell to 6.38 percent from 6.5 percent.

Stocks Reverse Deep Slide But Still End the Day Mixed

'Tokyo Joe' Accused of Fraud
The Securities and Exchange Commission accused one of the Internet's best-known stockpickers, Yun Soo Oh Park -- known as Tokyo Joe -- of securities fraud, contending that he enriched himself at his customers' expense, lied about his past returns and secretly accepted payment in exchange for recommending one company's stock. HEADLINE: More Focus on Education While Still Cutting Taxes

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has largely anchored his reputation on a trinity of issues -- tax cuts, crime and welfare -- but in his annual speech to the Legislature today, he made clear that he wanted to be known as more than a fiscal puritan with a penchant for law and order.
By unexpectedly focusing on education, Mr. Pataki indicated that he considered improving the schools in New York unfinished business. Five years after taking office, he seemed to be acknowledging that while the public might be pleased with his overall performance, he could suffer politically if he did not address disenchantment with the education system, particularly in urban areas. 
 He first hinted at this shift soon after winning his second term in 1998, when he pushed a proposal to create charter schools through a reluctant Legislature. He followed up last year by setting up a special commission to investigate corruption in the New York City schools. And today, he capped those moves by laying out an education agenda that featured a program to provide free tuition to college students who agree to teach in the public schools.
"A new era for New York must begin with a renewed commitment to our children's education," he said.
While there is no shortage of news to spur Mr. Pataki to demand change -- from turmoil in governing New York City schools to disappointing scores statewide -- he also cannot help but notice the success of Republican governors like George W. Bush of Texas in broadening their images by championing higher standards and other education measures.
In his speech, Mr. Pataki did not exactly shove aside the mainstay issues of his first term, but he gave them less emphasis. Well into his text, he announced an unremarkable proposal for business tax cuts, many aimed at revitalizing the beleaguered upstate economy. Still later, he repeated his longstanding proposal for ending the parole system.
Besides education, another issue featured prominently in the speech was health care, an area that also suggests a shift in Mr. Pataki's stewardship. Last month, the governor and the Legislature nearly doubled the cigarette tax to pay for a significant expansion for health care for the uninsured, the first major tax increase of his tenure. The move angered some conservatives, who questioned Mr. Pataki's devotion to their tightfisted fiscal principles.
Education and health care to some extent symbolize a new style, but it would be wrong to characterize Mr. Pataki as a onetime conservative firebrand. Aware that he is a Republican in a mostly Democratic state, the governor has not neglected policies that appeal to moderates, especially on abortion rights, which he supports, and the environment.
And though he did not promote a clarion-call educational agenda in his first term, he did sign off on record increases in state education aid sought by the Legislature.
The speech today was striking because Mr. Pataki had been expected to pursue such a change in the course in his annual address last year, the first of his second term. He instead clung last year to the priorities of his first term, reeling off a list of accomplishments and essentially calling for more of the same.
Oddly enough, some lawmakers had predicted that Mr. Pataki would swing to the right today -- repeating something akin to last year's speech -- because he would feel wounded by criticism of the cigarette tax increase. He has been mentioned as a possible vice presidential candidate and so it would seem natural that he might want to reassert his conservative credentials.
He did not, however, and his tone today indicated that he believed that he had put the state's house in order on matters like the budget and welfare, and could now focus on education, which is arguably a more nettlesome issue because localities exert so much control over the schools.
"All of his priorities from the past four years are still in place, but there is no question that he is targeting education," said State Senator Thomas W. Libous, a Binghamton Republican. Herman Badillo, whom Mr. Pataki appointed as chairman of the City University of New York, said the tuition program harked back to when CUNY tuition was free.
"It's a new tone and a new focus," Mr. Badillo said. "The fact that he put it at the top of his agenda is an indication that he is very much aware of giving a real priority to education. The idea of having free tuition -- it's very dramatic. I mean, that's really moving to the left."
Tellingly, Mr. Pataki did not announce an initiative for educational vouchers, favored by conservative Republicans but anathema to many Democrats. As a result, Democratic lawmakers expressed grudging support for the proposals in the speech, while also trying to portray Mr. Pataki as having stolen their agenda.
"Everybody's polls show that the public cares very much about education," said State Senator Martin Connor of Brooklyn. "It's the No. 1 issue. And it's clear that the governor and the Republicans are trying to appease that public desire by addressing it. But it raises the question of credibility. Where have they been the past four years?"
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Education Committee, said he was skeptical. "We have to remember that this comes from a governor who vetoed just a year ago teacher mentor intern programs out of existence, opposed teacher support aid, opposed teacher centers," he said. "But if his proposal represents a sincere conversion in the need to have better trained and prepared teachers, I welcome that."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1777 words

HEADLINE: PATAKI PROPOSES ADDING INCENTIVES FOR NEW TEACHERS

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a series of initiatives today intended to strengthen the state's educational system, including tuition subsidies for college students who pledge to teach in public schools and other plans to improve those schools that he said too often fail to live up to expectations.
In his sixth annual address to the Legislature, Mr. Pataki also listed several environmental proposals, including creation of a research institute to study the ecology of the Hudson River as well as an expansion of the state's main program for cleaning up toxic waste sites to include less dangerously polluted properties. 
 From education to the environment to health care, Mr. Pataki's stated goals signaled a shift in his priorities, especially since he had devoted much of his first term to pursuing a brand of fiscal conservatism that focused on halting what he contended were years of excessive spending in Albany. Although he committed no new major state spending for his proposals, the new direction seemed an effort to dispel the notion that he was inflexible about social programs.
Mr. Pataki, who in 1995 became the state's first Republican governor in 20 years, renewed his call for several measures that he had failed to push through the Legislature in previous years, including an end to parole for all violent felons, tougher penalties for people convicted of sex crimes and giving teachers the right to expel disruptive students from their classrooms. He also proposed a set of new tax cuts, many of them intended to revive the state's economically struggling upstate region and some of its urban centers under a Main Streets program.
Toward the beginning of his hourlong speech, the governor took a few humorous jabs, one at his former lieutenant governor, Betsy McCaughey Ross, and another at Hillary Rodham Clinton's quest for a United States Senate seat.
He reminisced about his first annual address, saying it "seems like just yesterday that I stood, or that Betsy and I stood up here" -- eliciting laughter from lawmakers and aides over the gaffe by Ms. McCaughey Ross when she stood through his entire speech.
"Now, we've succeeded to such an amazing extent that people from all around the country are recognizing that New York is the place to be," he continued. "Why, even people from Hope, Ark., understand that New York is the best state to live in."
He also used the latter part of his address to dwell on some of the accomplishments of his first term: reducing taxes, eliminating government regulation, cutting the welfare rolls to their lowest levels ever and fighting crime. The governor told lawmakers that those policies had helped turn the state around, and he urged them to work with him to do more of the same as the state entered the 2000's.
But it was Mr. Pataki's focus on education that drew the most sustained applause and the loudest cheers from Democrats and Republicans alike in the State Capitol's ornate Assembly chamber. The response suggested that all sides sense that education is a primary concern of voters in a year when members of both houses prepare for their re-election campaigns.
"A new New York must begin with a renewed commitment to our children's education," Mr. Pataki said from the dais, where he was flanked by most of the top elected officials in the state, including the leaders of both the State Senate and State Assembly, as well as Lt. Gov. Mary O. Donohue, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer and Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
"We have a long history of educational excellence to be proud of," he continued. "But today, although many of our schools still excel, some students are forced to settle for less. Too many of our children are victims of the most insidious enemy of excellence: low expectation. We must refocus their sights, and ours, on academic excellence."
The centerpiece of Mr. Pataki's education initiative is his proposal to cover the tuition costs for any student attending a public college in New York, provided he or she agrees to teach for four years in public schools that are facing a shortage of teachers. The program would provide students a scholarship of up to $3,400 a year, and would also let them use the money at any private university or college.
The Pataki administration estimates that the proposal would cost the state about $25 million a year, and would help it attract as many as 50,000 new teachers into the public school system over the next 10 years.
The proposal comes at a time when New York City faces its worst teacher shortage ever: during the next five years, the city's public school system will lose more than half of its 78,000 teachers as an unusually high number of them, 54,000, reach age 55 and become eligible for retirement. The looming exodus is threatening to drain the school system of many of its most experienced teachers.
"We need to attract the best teachers of tomorrow to work in our neediest schools," the governor said. "Each year, thousands of new graduates are produced by New York's fine colleges. But many don't go into teaching, and often our most disadvantaged schools don't get the benefit of the best new teachers. We can change that."
The speech drew effusive praise from Mr. Pataki's fellow Republicans, who frequently broke into applause as he spoke. "It truly had something in it that would benefit every New Yorker -- man, woman, child -- and every aspect of life," said Joseph L. Bruno, an upstate Republican who is the majority leader of the State Senate. "It truly builds on the success of the last five years."
Democratic lawmakers also expressed support for the speech, while leveling a few barbs at Mr. Pataki, saying he was supporting the new proposals because his early education policies had proved to be unpopular among New York's largely moderate electorate.
"The governor has moved from the radical right wing to espouse many of the principles that we have been talking about for the last four years," said Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, a Democrat and the speaker of the State Assembly. "I think we have proved that the people respond to the issues that he talked about, issues of education, of health care, of higher education and of job creation and getting New York State into the national economic expansion. I think the governor has finally heard the message and he is responding."
Mr. Pataki also proposed an initiative intended to encourage college students to perform volunteer work in the state's struggling inner-city schools, like tutoring children enrolled in summer programs. In return, the college students would earn college credits.
The governor also proposed creating a tuition assistance program to help the state's 9,000 uncertified teachers cover the cost of college courses they must complete before being eligible to be fully licensed as a teacher in New York. And he proposed that they be allowed five years, instead of two, to get a master's degree for completing certification requirements. There was no cost estimate for the governor's proposals to relax those requirements.
The governor's plan would also let professionals from other fields teach without having to meet the educational requirements a person must now fulfill to become a licensed teacher in the state.
"Right now, Colin Powell can't teach in the New York schools that he grew up in," the governor said. "Billy Joel is not qualified to teach piano to kids on Long Island. Eileen Collins can pilot the space shuttle, but she can't teach science in Elmira, her hometown. More importantly, thousands of less famous New Yorkers -- engineers, chemists, journalists -- could be great teachers as well. Let's open the teacher qualification process so that people with valuable life experiences can share them with our children."
The proposal received tempered support from the powerful teachers union, a group with considerable influence in both the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-led Assembly. Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said she was pleasantly surprised at the governor's proposal to provide scholarships to students who agree to teach after graduating, as well as his plan to provide financial assistance to unlicensed teachers who need to go back to school.
Ms. Weingarten said that the union itself had proposed a similar plan in the past, and welcomed the governor's support.
But she was wary of his proposal to establish alternative certification standards for obtaining a teaching license in New York, saying she needed to review the specifics.
"We have to see the details," she said. "If what he is talking about is getting the Colin Powells and Billy Joels into the classroom, that is unrealistic." She added: "You need to know your content, but pedagogy is also critical. Knowing how to teach kids is an art. The Colin Powells and Billy Joels and Warren Buffetts -- these folks are not going to fill 54,000 positions."
Besides education, another issue that Mr. Pataki's speech emphasized was health care, an area that Democrats have long accused him of neglecting. He highlighted a new program that he and legislative leaders from both parties created recently to provide medical coverage to as many as one million uninsured New Yorkers.
Mr. Pataki also pledged to cut cigarette smoking among teenagers by 50 percent over the next five years. His aides said he expected to achieve those reductions through a variety of antismoking initiatives, as well as a 56-cent tax that he recently agreed to add to the price of cigarettes in New York. The move raised the cigarette tax in New York to $1.11, the highest in any state. A pack of major-brand cigarettes in Albany now costs about $3.50.
It was the first time that Mr. Pataki had championed a major tax increase since taking office in 1995 on an aggressive tax-cutting platform. His aides reason that his tax-cutting reputation combined with the public's growing opposition to smoking gave him the political cover he need to support increasing the tax on cigarettes.
The governor also proposed $700 million in new tax cuts, most of them devoted to eliminating what is called the gross receipts tax, which adds several dollars a month to a typical New Yorker's gas and electric bills. Large manufacturers say it adds tens of thousands of dollars to the cost of business in New York.
Mr. Pataki also proposed giving tax credits to businesses in cities upstate. The program would provide a tax credit of up to $1,000 per job for employers who either open new companies or expand their existing business in the state, provided they employ at least 25 people.

Following are major proposals from Gov. George E. Pataki's annual address to the Legislature:
 
TEACHER SCHOLARSHIPS -- Would provide up to $3,400 per year to 5,000 new teachers who work in designated areas where there is a shortage of certified teachers. Additional money would be made available to help teachers with temporary licenses get permanent certification.
 
TAX CUTS -- Would provide $700 million in new tax cuts and economic development initiatives for a total of $2.3 billion in tax cuts for the fiscal year 2000-2001.
 
ENERGY TAX ELIMINATION -- Would phase out a tax on energy that raises about $500 million annually from residential and business consumers. The tax would be eliminated first for industrial and manufacturing businesses to enable them to compete with businesses in regions with lower energy costs.
 
LOW-COST POWER -- Would expand a program that provides low-cost power to businesses across upstate New York in exchange for their creating and keeping jobs in the region. The program would provide an estimated $20 million in savings to businesses.
 
ENTERPRISE ZONE -- Would create a high-technology enterprise zone in upstate counties where employment growth is below the state average. Technology companies that relocate or expand there would be eligible for a package of incentives that would include tax credits.
