HEADLINE: Excerpts From Comments by Gore and Bradley at Forum for Candidates

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Democratic presidential debate last night in Durham, N.H., involving Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
Q. Mr. Bradley, has Mr. Gore ever taken a vote of yours or a quote out of context?
MR. BRADLEY A vote or a quote? Yes.
Q. Mr. Gore, has Mr. Bradley ever taken a vote or a quote out of yours, out of context?
MR. GORE I haven't complained about any.
Q. The question was has he. . . .
MR. GORE I don't know that the answer is no, but if you want a no, I'll give you a no.
Q. O.K. Well then Mr. Bradley, being that you think Mr. Gore has taken a vote or a quote out of context, choose one that you think was particularly offensive. 

MR. BRADLEY The one that was most particularly offensive to me was when he said in this campaign that I was going to hurt African-Americans, Latinos with the health care program that I have offered. And he on any number of occasions has gone to groups and said that I am going to destroy Medicaid without saying what it's going to be replaced with. And to say to me who's had the deep commitment to the issue of racial unity in this country since I started in politics that I would go out and hurt African-Americans and Latinos, consciously, as a part of a policy, I think really offended me. What I'm trying to do with the health care program that I've offered is to take Medicaid and replace it with something that is better. Forty percent of the people in America who now live in poverty, do not have any health coverage. They're not covered by Medicaid. Under the proposal that I've offered they would all be covered. And I think Al has misrepresented that.
MR. GORE Well you know Harry Truman said in 1948 I'm not giving him hell. I'm just telling the truth and he thinks it's hell. Now, I didn't say any of the things that you heard. What I said is that poor people are disproportionately likely to be minorities, disproportionately likely to be African-American and Latino. And if you look at the groups that are hurt when Medicaid is eliminated and they're given instead a little $150-a-month voucher for H.M.O.'s or health care capped at $150, then that is going to -- I do talk about what is proposed as a replacement for Medicaid and it is entirely inadequate. Let me tell you why, Peter. He says use this capped voucher to buy into the Federal Employee Benefit Plan. Look here in New Hampshire. There are about a dozen different insurance health policies that are under the Federal Employee Benefit Plan. Not a single one of them can be purchased for anything close to $150 a month. . . . If you are in groups that are much more likely to be represented among impoverished Americans who receive Medicaid, then you're going to be more likely to be hurt by that. . . .
MR. BRADLEY Al is saying all the time about a hundred-and-fifty-dollar cap. That's not a cap. It's a weighted average. Someplace it'll be more, someplace it'll be less.
And I might point out that the average Medicaid cost in your home state of Tennessee is $91 a person. So you can say that the men -- that people in Tennessee haven't been very generous, but you can't say that my proposal would deny health coverage to Americans who need it. . . .
MR. GORE Well, what is a weighted average? I remember the old story about the man who had his feet on a block of ice and his head in the oven and according to the weighted average he was really comfortable there.
Now, the -- the -- the fact is that the -- the plan that you just cited for the mail handlers cost $182.72 for an individual as a premium. You cap that at $150. You said for a family of four it might work. Yep, that's right. That's right. But out of the dozen plans, that is the only one where a family of four might get a little bit of coverage. The individual would not and under all of the others ----
MR. BRADLEY Yeah, well, that's important.
MR. GORE Now, now, hold on -- hold on just a second, Bill.
MR. BRADLEY You've just said that that is so.
MR. GORE Look, this is serious. You have put forward a plan that would affect New Hampshire. And all of the people who would be affected in New Hampshire would be left out. They would be left high and dry ----
MR. BRADLEY They would not.
MR. GORE because there is no plan that they can buy into. . . .
MR. GORE We passed tough welfare reform, which I think has worked. You voted against it. I voted against those budget cuts; you voted for them. I voted, as I said a moment ago, for the resolution to use military force to push Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait; you voted against it. My question is not about the details of those votes. It's really more basic. Would you vote differently on any of those three votes if you had it to do over again? Were they mistakes and why?
MR. BRADLEY The answer is no I wouldn't have voted differently. In '81, if everybody in the Congress had voted as I had voted against the budge -- for the budget cuts but against the tax cuts, we would not have had the deficit of the 1990's. As a result of that we would had more economic growth. As you are well aware, given the economic growth now, when you have more economic growth, you have more revenue coming into the government, which would have meant more money to do things to try to help the people who are poor.
No on welfare reform. I don't think the answer to the problems of people who are poor in America is to take a pot of money from federal officials and send it to state officials and say, spend 80 percent of this as best you can. I think that this is a much more serious question. We have a booming economy, welfare is down, but deep poverty is up, it's not down, deep poverty. . . .
And on the issue of the Persian Gulf, no. The fact of the matter is when the vote was taken, I thought that we should continue sanctions, as did most people in my party. And I thought that you should continue sanctions and then later have the right to use force. I said I was prepared to use force at a later date. And that's a decision that I made then and I stand by it. . . .
Q. Mr. Bradley used the phrase and you both talked about gays in the military, you both believe that gays should have the right to serve openly in the military. President Clinton's had great difficulty , the Joint Chiefs as well as the Congress have been a principal obstacle to that particular policy. If you become president -- I'll ask you one at a time, you first Mr. Gore -- if you become president, will you nominate members of the Joint Chiefs who only support your gay policy? In other words, will it be a litmus test?
MR. GORE I have rejected the notion of litmus tests on the Supreme Court by saying that there are ways to find out the kind of judgment somebody has without posing specific litmus tests.
I think that it's a little different where the Joint Chiefs of Staff are concerned because you're not interfering with an independent judicial decision. As commander in chief, a president is giving orders in effect or he is the superior of the officers that are reporting to the commander and chief in the chain of command.
I would try to bring about the kind of change in policy, on the don't ask, don't tell policy, that President Harry Truman brought about after World War II in integrating the military. And I think that would require those who wanted to serve in on the position of -- on the Joint Chiefs to be in agreement with that policy. So, yes.
Q. So, if I understand you correctly, you would only nominate members of the Joint Chiefs if they supported your gay support --
MR. GORE I would think -- here, I think that the new policy has to be implemented in a way that accomplishes the goal and yet recognized the practical challenges that the military leadership will have to confront in making that change. I would insist, before appointing anybody to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that that individual support my policy. And, yes I would make that a requirement.
Q. Mr. Bradley, would you, sir?
MR. BRADLEY I consider it much shorter words, I think. And that is when you're president you are commander and chief and you issue orders and soldiers are good soldiers and they follow your orders. A consultation process takes place certainly in which you hear their view, but when you follow and order, no matter -- I'm sure that there are people in the military today who don't agree with President Clinton on 50 things. But my sense is that when you're president of the United States, military people are loyal to their commander and chief whatever the policy is that the commander in chief calls for for the country. And that's what I expect them to do if I'm president of the United States and we move toward gays in the military, which I intend to do.

HEADLINE: While Calling for a Positive Campaign, McCain Is Accused of Being Negative

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Senator John McCain urged presidential candidates today to "help turn the practice of politics toward a higher plane." But his own campaign was soon accused by aides to Gov. George W. Bush of practicing negative politics.
Mr. McCain, of Arizona, set down his challenge in a broad speech about citizenship. Mentioning only Mr. Bush, the Republican front-runner from Texas, and Vice President Al Gore by name, Mr. McCain said, "Let us lead by example." 
 "We should refrain from attacking each other," Mr. McCain challenged the presidential contenders of both parties, "directly or through surrogates, with the negative advertising that has disgusted the nation, and pledge ourselves to a high standard of accuracy in discussions of our own agendas and those of our opponents."
He spoke as the Republican race was intensifying. Mr. McCain also found himself on the defensive over accusations that he had intervened with the Federal Communications Commission to urge it to resolve a matter of interest to a contributor. He insisted his actions had been "entirely appropriate."
In his speech, Mr. McCain told voters: "Judge us not by the promises we make, the stories we tell, nor the ads we run. Measure us, by all means, by the policies and proposals we lay forth for your consideration. But judge us as well by the example we set; by the way we conduct our campaigns; by the way we personally practice politics."
But at the same campaign stop, with Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush in an escalating battle over tax cuts and Social Security, the senator's aides distributed a "backgrounder" on the issues that seemed at odds with his call for a different kind of politics.
It was titled "McCain's Mature Vision for America's Future v. Bush's Political Plan for the 2000 Election." Mr. McCain later called the title "a cheap shot."
Mr. Bush's aides promptly went on the offensive and criticized the entire flier as a "woeful misrepresentation" of Mr. Bush's positions.
"It's the same type of attack politics that the Democrats are engaging in," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, pointing to the flier's contention that Mr. Bush's tax cut plan would use the entire federal surplus and leave "Social Security in danger."
Mr. Bush was not as pointed in his remarks. "I know people want a fight and a slug fest, but I'm not going to allow this campaign to deteriorate into a slug fest. John McCain is a good man; we have a difference of opinion as to the size of tax cuts, how they ought to work."
Mr. Bush has said he would not dip into the part of the surplus generated by Social Security revenue for tax cuts. He would then use a large part of the non-Social Security surplus to pay for his plan to cut taxes.
Mr. McCain has argued that if the economy does not perform according to projections, the surplus could shrink and Mr. Bush's tax cut could eat into the Social Security surplus or require an increase in the Social Security payroll tax.

HEADLINE: Two Democrats In Debate Back Gays in Military

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: DURHAM, N.H., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore and his Democratic opponent, Bill Bradley, said tonight that if they were elected president they would require their appointees to the Joint Chiefs of Staff to fully support allowing homosexuals to serve openly in the military.
Although both candidates had previously opposed the Clinton administration's "don't ask, don't tell" policy their comments in the fourth Democratic debate of the primary season, here at the University of New Hampshire, were a strikingly forceful embrace of gay rights and were bound to come under attack by the Republican candidates. 
 Their remarks came in response to a question of whether they would support a "litmus test" on gays in the military in nominating members of the Joint Chiefs.
Of the two, Mr. Gore was the more expansive, saying he wanted to make the same sweeping changes toward allowing homosexuals to serve openly in the military that President Harry S. Truman made toward racially integrating the armed forces.
"I think that would require those who wanted to serve on the Joint Chiefs to be in agreement with that policy," Mr. Gore said. "I would insist before appointing anybody to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that that individual support my policy, and yes, I would make that a requirement."
The vice president drew a distinction between applying a litmus test to Supreme Court justices and military officials, saying this was "not interfering with an independent judicial decision."
Mr. Bradley said simply that the commander in chief issued orders and soldiers followed them. He said that while many in the armed forces probably did not agree with President Clinton on some military matters, "My sense is that when you're president of the United States, military people are loyal to their commander in chief whatever the policy of the commander in chief calls for the country, and that's what I'd expect them to do if I'm president of the United States and we move toward gays in the military."
Mr. Bradley's aides said later that while he objected to the concept of litmus tests, they could not imagine that he would appoint anyone to the Joint Chiefs who did not back his policy.
Despite the candidates' agreement on homosexuals in the military, the debate tonight was punctuated by edgy exchanges as Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley picked at details of each other's past votes and present proposals.
Mr. Bradley portrayed the vice president as having been so trapped in a "Washington bunker" that he had lost the ambition to fight for proposals on health care and gun control. Mr. Gore suggested that his rival was living in an ivory tower and lacked the know-how to get things done.
But the exchange over a gay-rights litmus test for top commanders is almost certain to renew controversy in the military, where many high-ranking officers strongly oppose allowing gays to serve openly.
President Clinton had originally pledged to allow homosexuals to serve openly, but backed away from the plan after a near revolt by Gen. Colin L. Powell and other members of the Joint Chiefs early in his presidency. A result was "the don't ask, don't tell" policy, which Mr. Bradley and Mr. Gore say is a failure.
Retired members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and other military experts warned tonight that subjecting future members to a litmus test would hurt the armed services.
"Military officers certainly execute the orders of the president, but a litmus test beforehand would place an officer in an untenable position saying, 'Do you believe what I believe?' " said Gen. Carl E. Mundy, a retired commandant of the Marine Corps. "I think it would be unworkable."
"An officer's judgment has to be tempered by his judgment of what's best for the armed forces, not for a political agenda," said General Mundy, who opposes allowing homosexuals to serve openly.
The candidates' comments tonight about homosexuals in the military underscored the degree to which Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley are intent on courting the liberal base of their party. In fact, earlier in the debate, neither candidate objected to being described as a liberal -- a label that Democrats, including Bill Clinton, have eschewed in recent years.
"Liberal, progressive, whatever," Mr. Bradley said. "I'll accept whatever label you want because that's who I am."
Mr. Gore, who earlier in the day was endorsed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, said, "I really don't care what kind of label people apply to those positions and views."
Perhaps the harshest remark during the hourlong debate came from Mr. Bradley after he was asked when Mr. Gore had ever taken one of his quotes or votes out of context. "The one that was most particularly offensive to me was when he said in this campaign that I was going to hurt African-Americans, Latinos with the health care program I have offered," Mr. Bradley said.
"To say to me, who's had the deep commitment to the issue of racial unity in this country since I started in politics, that I would go out and hurt African-Americans and Latinos, consciously, as part of a policy, I think really offended me."
Mr. Gore defended his comments, saying, "Well, you know, Harry Truman said in 1948, 'I'm not giving him hell. I'm just telling the truth and he thinks it's hell.' " He said he had simply explained that "poor people are disproportionately likely to be minorities" and would be affected the most by Mr. Bradley's replacement of Medicaid with an alternative program.
Both contenders were trying to score points with a precious few weeks before the Feb. 1 primary here. Polls in this state show that Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley are within shouting distance of each other.
The face-off here, the first in 2000, opened a flurry of debates among the White House hopefuls. Republicans will debate here on Thursday and in South Carolina on Friday. On Saturday, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley will debate in Iowa. And the Republican candidates will appear at a forum here on Sunday and then at a debate in Michigan on Monday.
In tonight's debate, Mr. Bradley appeared particularly aggressive and was more willing to take issue with Mr. Gore than he had been in the past. But he also had a relaxed air and displayed an easy humor.
At one point, for instance, Mr. Gore insisted that he respected his rival. "I respect Bill, I really do," he said. "I'm not just saying that as a ploy. I think he's a genuinely good person."
Asked by Peter Jennings, the moderator and ABC News anchor, if he agreed with Mr. Gore, Mr. Bradley drew laughs when he replied, "I agree with what he said, yeah. I think I'm a genuinely good person."
At times, Mr. Bradley verged on condescension, as when he said, "Let me explain to you, Al, how the private sector works, O.K."
Mr. Gore seemed calmer than in his earlier performances as he fielded questions, but still did not shrink from criticizing Mr. Bradley's record. He was particularly persistent in upbraiding the former senator from New Jersey for what he depicted as mistaken votes, such as supporting President Ronald Reagan's budget cuts.
"We passed tough welfare reform, which I think has worked; you voted against it," Mr. Gore said. "I voted against those budget cuts; you voted for them. I voted, as I said a moment ago, for the resolution to use military force to push Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait; you voted against it."
Mr. Bradley said he did not regret any of those votes. "In '81, if everybody in the Congress had voted as I had voted," he said, "we would not have had the deficit of the 1990's. As a result of that we would have had more economic growth." And Mr. Bradley said he was still not convinced that the welfare reform effort was working or that it would have been wrong to try sanctions before using force against Saddam Hussein.
Mr. Bradley sought to depict the vice president as thinking like a Washington insider and afraid to try ambitious proposals.
"When I hear you talk, Al, it reminds me of a Washington bunker," Mr. Bradley said. "I can understand why you're in the bunker because of Gingrich, there was the fund-raising scandal, the impeachment problem. And I think that the major objective in the last several years in the White House has been political survival."
"I understand that," Mr. Bradley continued. "But the reality is the Democratic Party should be thinking big things, with big ambitions."
But Mr. Gore portrayed Mr. Bradley as out of touch with the realities of Washington. "I believe that the presidency is not an academic exercise," Mr. Gore said. "It's not an extended seminar on theory. It has to be a daily fight for the best interests of the American people."
He added: "The country can ill afford big mistakes by a president who stumbles into something that could be avoided with the kind of judgment and experience that our people ought to have the right to expect in any president."

HEADLINE: Visions of Greener Pastures Reinvent the Lower East Side

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
TENEMENTS, yes. Luxury housing? It's not what leaps to mind about the Lower East Side.
But a loft-style condominium at 18 Orchard Street, near Canal, sold recently for $1.1 million in a bidding war that surprised even the developers. Four smaller units in the warehouse building sold in the high $600,000's. At 130 Orchard Street, the Beckenstein Home Fabrics building, still cheek by jowl with discount men's suit stores and sidewalk leather-jacket merchants, is being converted into rental apartments priced as high as $3,000 a month for a 450-square-foot studio. 
 In the last year, residential redevelopment has been undertaken in 25 percent of the 230 commercial or mixed-use buildings at the heart of the neighborhood, according to the Lower East Side Business Improvement District.
Orchard Street, with its narrow grove of grim tenements, hasn't seen fruit this sweet since it was cut through an orchard in the 18th century, on Lt. Gov. James De Lancey's 340-acre farm.
By 1903, with the arrival of hundreds of thousands of immigrants, one square block of Orchard Street between Delancey and Broome Streets was said to be the most crowded place on earth. "My grandparents, forced to settle here, couldn't wait to get out," said Mark Federman, 54, the third-generation owner of Russ & Daughters, a smoked fish business started in a pushcart on Orchard Street.
Now, people are fighting to get in. If they can afford to.
Pushed south and east by rising "uptown" prices in the East Village and SoHo, and pulled by the magnet of a thriving bar and boutique scene, young professionals are looking to LoHo, as real estate agents have re-named the stretch of the Lower East Side between East Houston and Canal Streets and Forsyth and Clinton Streets. It is fashion's new frontier.
"A couple of generations later, my kids want to live down here," said Mr. Federman, whose store has been at 179 East Houston Street for 70 years. "They think it's the coolest neighborhood."
A six-story hotel is on the drafting board for a lot at East Houston and Forsyth Streets; another hotel is being developed four blocks away.
At 175 Broadway, the Jewish Daily Forward Building, built in 1912 for the Yiddish-language Socialist newspaper, is also being converted into condominiums. The World War I-era Sunshine Theater at 139-43 East Houston Street, an early cinema and later a Yiddish vaudeville hall, is reopening this summer as a $8 million, five-screen art-film cineplex.
"There's a lot of energy and excitement there," said Doug Freed, vice president of Landmark Theater Corporation, the nation's largest art-house chain, which is developing the site for its first theater in New York.
Even Ratner's, a Delancey Street landmark since 1905, is renovating. Its Lansky Lounge, popular with the newer club crowd, is expanding, at the expense of the dairy kosher dining room. "The lounge caters more to the neighborhood now," said Robert Harmatz, its third-generation owner. "The Ratner's part -- most of those customers have moved away."
To meet the demand for renovated apartments, 19th-century tenements, sealed over the last 50 years by landlords whose rents couldn't compete with the cost of successive building code requirements like fire-proofing and indoor toilets, are being reopened. In 1978, Mr. Federman let the apartments above his store become vacant. Now, he is renovating them as rentals. "My son's waiting for me to finish the building," Mr. Federman said. "Real estate in the neighborhood has gone through the roof." Mr. Federman's son, Noah, 24, a student at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, was at the store, helping out during the holidays.
"Hopefully I'm not taking over the business," he said, with nervous cheer.
"I'm the only Jewish father who wants his son to drop out of medical school," the elder Mr. Federman said. "Who needs another doctor? What we need are people who can slice salmon."
Sol Einhorn, owner of the Bridge Merchandise Company at 98 Orchard Street, renovated his building four years ago. "In the last two years, everybody's into the game, to make apartments out of old tenement houses," he said.
WHO'S moving in?
Brian Edwards, director of leasing for the Halstead Property Company, which is representing the Beckenstein's building, said that tenant applicants included "the dot-com crowd" -- young bankers, photographers, architects and alternative music record label entrepreneurs.
"This is not your mother's Lower East Side," he said.
Sven Harding, an associate with Ernst & Young, moved onto Orchard Street in December. He pays $1,695 for his renovated one-bedroom apartment.
"I love the neighborhood," said Mr. Harding, 29, adding that he thought his apartment was a bargain. "You see how it's changing. Little boutiques, interesting bars at night. I hear that there's some resistance to people like me, yuppies, moving in, driving up rents, but I haven't experienced it."
For Phillip Toledano, a senior art director at Merkley Newman Harty, an advertising agency, who purchased an 800-square-foot penthouse at 62 Orchard Street, with roof rights, for $682,000, the Lower East Side is still the discount district. The ground floor of Mr. Toledano's building is G&G International Menswear.
"Everything I saw of that size was way beyond what I could pay," he said of spaces he was shown in the East Village, SoHo and TriBeCa. Mr. Toledano, who is Jewish, said that when he told his parents about his expensive new home on Orchard Street, "their friends were horrified." Julia Zervas, his real estate agent, recalled hearing a lawyer at the closing say, "My God, my father spent years getting out."
Mr. Toledano, who last lived in the East Village, was unconcerned about the lack of basic services, like a supermarket. "The last time I cooked, I gave myself food poisoning," he explained. "I'll be eating a lot of Chinese."
In fact, the Lower East Side's replenishing population of recent immigrants, which has maintained the neighborhood's living historical character since the 1820's, when Germans started arriving and building, is now largely Chinese. They predominate among the Asians, who represent roughly 77 percent of the area's recent immigrants, according to a City Planning Department study published in November. Dominicans are predominant in the other large group, Hispanics.
With advancing gentrification and new market pressures on real estate, there is growing concern that the Lower East Side's soaring celebrity status will displace its traditional tenants and end its era as the city's first home to its "huddled masses."
From city officials to community leaders to school administrators, there is apprehension about the character of the most current changes, in a neighborhood whose very stability and strength have been change and a revolving chance at opportunity.
Rosa O'Day, principal for seven years of Public School 42, an elementary school of 760 children on Hester Street, said, "We have heard from families that it's hard for them to afford the rents, that a lot of housing is becoming unaffordable."
Margarita Lopez, a city councilwoman for the area, expressed concern that the focus brought to bear on the district, through well-financed development, could fracture the kinship among diverse ethnic groups created in common hardships that has been the family tree of the neighborhood for 200 years.
The new upscale arrivals, she explained, "have the credit lines."
"These individuals are in the best position to come onto the market and buy this new housing," she said. "It's no longer a community that depends on rental, a community that would always be diverse. The implication is that it will be those who have the dollars to buy."
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, of the 63rd Assembly District, is also concerned. "People who assume that large groups of people will be quietly removed might be surprised at how unsocial this change could become," he said. "It would be wise to have a more coherent master plan for the Lower East Side that had a component of lower income housing. To just allow parcels of property to just be transformed one by one to high-price housing would be a mistake."
He added: "If we're careful, it could be a cultural renaissance. If we are not careful, it could prove to turn the Lower East Side into a huge battlefield."
But Susan Vaughn, chairwoman of Community Board 3, said that she had not yet seen evidence of residential displacements because of the arrival of new money.
"You have to understand that a lot of these new apartments are in buildings that were totally vacant above the storefront level," she said.
Many merchants say they are heartened by the fresh faces of both commerce and customers. Mr. Federman at Russ & Daughters sees the newest change in the neighborhood as part of a continuum.
"It's a renaissance, not gentrification," he said. "The neighborhood has gone through many changes and managed to perceive them in a positive way. This is just another group of people. For years, this neighborhood was in deep decline. The Jewish population started leaving en masse after World War II, to Long Island and Westchester. The older people expect the same places -- 'Oh my God, it's changed. It doesn't have the Jewish flavor.' It hasn't had that for a while."
Councilwoman Kathryn Freed, who also represents the area, agreed.
"The neighborhood was dying -- now it's come back," she said, citing shops like Zao at 175 Orchard Street -- a trance club crossed with a rave party and a newstand that also sells shoes and dishes and exhibits art. "Rents are skyrocketing, like they are everywhere," Ms. Freed added. "But the businesses are a success story, and by being successful they're bringing more people to the area. And that's good."
In an effort to preserve both its historic buildings and its Jewish community heritage, the Lower East Side Conservancy, a nonprofit organization, and the Lower East Side Business District have applied to put part of the area on the state and national registers of historic places. It expects the nominations to be approved by early spring. The registry would allow property owners tax abatements for renovations that conform to guidelines.
The proposal that could have the largest impact on the Lower East Side is the Economic Development Corporation's Seward Park Extension Urban Renewal Project, five parcels of land south of Delancey Street by the Williamsburg Bridge being offered by the city for both residential and commercial development. At least nine private development proposals have now been presented to the Mayor's office, said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the corporation.
Mr. Federman, hearing of the existence of the huge plan, responded like a local.
"That guy who bought the million-dollar loft," he said, "he should have bought a dozen."

HEADLINE: Haunted Orphans in Havana, Undone by the Sheer Passion and Problems of Life

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Like so many characters in Latin American literature, the three major characters in Fernando Perez's lush, hallucinatory film ''Life Is to Whistle'' walk around with an awareness of the supernatural that simultaneously inspires and oppresses them. As these passionate, troubled residents of Havana, all three of them orphans, go about their lives, we have an acute sense of their being haunted and held back by religious and ancestral specters.
 The director's master stroke is his portrayal of their internal conflicts as a metaphor for the political and economic anxieties gripping Cuba in the twilight of the Castro era. Although the Communist government is barely mentioned, all three characters ultimately find themselves forced to choose between clinging to their self-restricting beliefs and shucking them off to live more autonomously. 
 Elpidio Valdes (Luis Alberto Garcia), a swarthy young musician and fisherman abandoned by his mother (symbolically named Cuba), is consumed with guilt because he hasn't fulfilled his revolutionary destiny. Elpidio's chance for liberation arrives in the form of Chrissy (Isabel Santos), a Greenpeace worker who sails into Cuba in a hot-air balloon. The two carry on a passionate affair until it's time for her leave, and she invites him to fly away with her to the United States.
 Julia (Coralia Veloz), a middle-aged social worker with a job in a home for the aged, is subject to spontaneous fainting spells set off by the word ''sex.'' Pressured by her friends to consult a psychiatrist, she uncovers a traumatic love affair in her past.
 Later, as the patient and her doctor stroll through the streets of Havana, Julia discovers that half the city is living in a similar state of denial, with people keeling over right and left on the pavement when certain forbidden words are uttered.
 Finally there is Mariana (Claudia Rojas), a beautiful, ambitious young dancer with several lovers who vows to God that she will be celibate if she wins the coveted title role in a production of ''Giselle.'' When her prayer is answered, she is overjoyed. But the moment she and her handsome young co-star, Ismael (Joan Manuel Reyes), set eyes on each other, they fall wildly in love, and Mariana finds herself in a state of almost unbearable torment.
 ''Life Is to Whistle,'' which opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, views these characters through the eyes of Bebe (Bebe Perez), an enigmatic 18-year-old spirit who appears in various settings, including underwater. The film crosscuts among the three characters she conjures up for our amusement. As their frustrations escalate, all three find themselves propelled at the same moment on the same day to confront their possible destinies in Revolution Square in Havana.
 The movie strings out its characters' inner dramas a bit longer than necessary. Well before their rendezvous with fate we are impatient for them to make the break.
 Yet if ''Life Is to Whistle'' drags toward the end, it has many charms. Its surrealist imagery, inspired by Magritte paintings, lends it a thread of visual zaniness (although there are several too many images of shaved fish). And the movie is so deeply in sync with its characters' passions that it sustains a mood of heady sensuality.
 Love seems to bloom on every Havana street corner, and the throbbing music of Bola de Nieve and Benny More, which punctuates the film, makes its erotic pulse race even faster.

LIFE IS TO WHISTLE

Directed by Fernando Perez; written (in Spanish, with English subtitles) by Mr. Perez, Humberto Jimenez and Eduardo Del Llano; director of photography, Paul Perez Ureta; edited by Julia Yip; music by Edesio Alejandro; produced by ICAIC and Wanda Distribution S.A.; released by New Yorker Films. At the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Running time: 106 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Luis Alberto Garcia (Elpidio Valdes), Coralia Veloz (Julia), Claudia Rojas (Mariana), Bebe Perez (Bebe), Isabel Santos (Chrissy), Joan Manuel Reyes (Ismail) and Rolando Brito (Dr. Fernando).

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Opera
 
"DIE FLEDERMAUS." If you didn't get to hear "Die Fledermaus" on New Year's Eve, which is something of a tradition, however stale, in the opera world, you can still hear it at Amato Opera this weekend. The production, presented in English, with musical and stage direction by Anthony Amato, is apparently a favorite with fans of this small, scrappy company. Amato Opera; tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 and Sunday at 2:30 p.m., 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village). Tickets are $25; $20 for the elderly and children under 12. (212) 228-8200 (Anthony Tommasini). 

"THE GREAT GATSBY." Metropolitan Opera. The Met presents its long-awaited "Great Gatsby," commissioned from John Harbison. Look for two uproarious party scenes featuring vivid dancing and the composer's clever syntheses of 1920's popular style. The cast, with Dawn Upshaw, Susan Graham, Jerry Hadley and Dwayne Croft, is first rate, and the production has a handsome simplicity. The music never quite lives up to its surroundings, but the Met's earnest effort at new American opera deserves support. Tonight at 8. Tickets: standing room only, $12 and $16. (212) 362-6000 (Bernard Holland).
 
NEW YORK GILBERT AND SULLIVAN PLAYERS. Albert Bergeret's New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players are an inventive, experienced and energetic troupe, the only survivors of what was once a thriving Savoyard tradition in New York. The group's productions are solid and simple, with topical touches and good, enthusiastic casts and often a guest star. For its current offering, "Princess Ida," the guest is Frank Gorshin, as King Gama. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. (212) 864-5400. Tickets: $31, $41 and $46; $5 off each ticket price for children 12 and younger. The Saturday performance is preceded at 1:45 p.m. by "Family Overtures," in which the operetta is introduced by Mr. Bergeret. It is free to ticketholders. (Allan Kozinn)
 
"REGINA." A new film from the director Tim Robbins tells the story of the struggle by John Houseman and Orson Wells to present Marc Blitzstein's populist opera "The Cradle Will Rock" in 1937. This makes more timely the Bronx Opera Company production of Blitzstein's 1949 opera, "Regina," an adaptation of Lillian Hellman's play "The Little Foxes." While more traditional in concept than "Cradle," "Regina" is an innovative and interesting work. For more than 30 years this independent, community-based company has been giving performance opportunities to young singers and introducing audiences to opera. Michael Spierman will conduct, and Benjamin Spierman directs. Lovinger Theater at Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx. Tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets are $20 and $15 ($18 and $13 for students and the elderly). Information: (718) 356-4209; reservations: (212) 807-5636 (Tommasini).
 
"RIGOLETTO." Two new singers take over major roles at the Metropolitan Opera in Verdi's "Rigoletto." The title role will be sung by the baritone Leo Nucci, who sang it when this Otto Schenk production was introduced in 1989. The soprano Youngok Shin sings Gilda. The highly touted tenor Marcelo Alvarez continues in the role of the Duke. Mr. Alvarez boasts a bright tenor voice but is overly emotive in the role. Vladimir Jurowski, a 27-year-old conductor who was quite impressive with "Rigoletto" for his Met debut on Christmas Eve, is on the podium again. Metropolitan Opera House, Saturday night at 8. Tickets: standing room only, $12 and $16. (212) 362-6000 (Tommasini).
 
"TOSCA." Franco Zeffirelli's production of Puccini's "Tosca" has long been one of the Metropolitan Opera's most popular offerings. This weekend's production is nearly sold out, though some tickets remain and last-minute returns are usually available. Three stalwart interpreters of the main roles will be singing: the soprano Carol Vaness as Tosca, the tenor Richard Leech as Cavaradossi and the bass James Morris as Scarpia. Daniel Oren, a gifted young conductor, is at the podium. This is the last chance to see "Tosca" this season. Metropolitan Opera House, tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. Tickets: standing room only, $12 and $16. (212) 362-6000 (Tommasini).
 
Classical Music
 
AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA. As usual, the indispensable American Composers Orchestra is offering another interesting program at Carnegie Hall. Called "Roots," it offers two works by American originals, "Quartets" (for 41 players) by John Cage, and the Symphony in E Minor, "Gaelic," by Amy Beach. There will also be two world premieres: "Tomorrow's Song, as Yesterday Sings Today" by the acclaimed jazz composer Muhal Richard Abrams, and "Harlem Essay," for orchestra and digital audio tape, by the young composer Daniel Bernard Roumain, who integrates the sounds of urban pop into his concert works. Dennis Russell Davies conducts. Carnegie Hall, Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets are $46-$16. CenterCharge, (212) 247-7800. (Tommasini).
 
BARGEMUSIC. Having just completed a traversal of Bach's "Brandenburg" Concertos, the musicians who oversee the programming for this intimate, floating concert hall on the East River are turning their attentions to Beethoven. This weekend Paul Rosenthal and Mark Peskanov, violinists; Toby Hoffman, violist; and Nathaniel Rosen, cellist, offer Beethoven's Fourth, Fifth and Sixth String Quartets (Op. 18, 4-6). Tonight at 7:30, Sunday at 4. Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn. (718) 624-2083 or (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $23, $20 for the elderly, $15 for students (Kozinn).
 
EVANGELINE BENEDETTI. The cellist Evangeline Benedetti, the first woman appointed to the New York Philharmonic, in 1967, presents her annual free recital this weekend at West End Collegiate Church. She is presenting a program of "joyous music in major keys"; a brochure for the recital promises works by Beethoven, Hindemith, Schumann and Mendelssohn. Those looking for a totally happy concert experience should be warned that every now and then the pieces in question do sneak visits into related minor keys. The pianist is David Korevaar. West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue and 77th Street. Sunday at 3:30 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 787-1566 (Tommasini).
 
CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER. "Musical Evolutions II: Crisis and Creativity (1922-1945)" is the title of the Chamber Music Society's interesting series that begins this weekend. Offering six concerts and four lectures, the series will examine music composed during that historic period of catastrophic economic collapse, political turmoil, Fascism, world war and genocide. Yet paradoxically there were years of intense creativity and radical innovation in the arts, especially music. The series begins tomorrow with a lecture by the composer Bruce Adolphe, the society's education adviser, called "Innovation and Renovation," in which he will discuss how composers "reclaimed the past to discover the future," as the series brochure states. The first concert comes on Sunday when the violinist Joshua Bell and the pianist Frederic Chiu play works of Copland, Prokofiev, Ravel and Bartok. Lecture: Rose Rehearsal Studio, Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, 10th floor. Saturday at 11 a.m. Free, but reservations are required. (212) 875-5788. Recital with Joshua Bell: Alice Tully Hall, Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets, $25 and $35. (212) 875-5788; CenterCharge: (212) 721-6500 (Tommasini).
 
"ELIJAH." Mendelssohn's greatest choral work is heard more frequently on recordings than in concert, and opportunities to hear it live are worth pursuing. Whether this performance can capture its grandeur remains to be seen: the 16-year-old Ibex Chamber Orchestra is a small ensemble, but church acoustics may help give it the required heft. The orchestra, conducted by Martin Rutishauser, is to be joined by the Long Island Symphonic Choral Society (which is directed by the estimable Gregg Smith). The soloists are Meredith Stone, soprano; April Lindevald, alto; Howard Carr, tenor; and Thami Zungu, bass-baritone. Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets, $15; $10 for students and the elderly. Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Paul, 315 West 22nd Street, Chelsea. (212) 362-1732 (Kozinn).
 
MUSIC BEFORE 1800 PRODUCTIONS. The fine resident ensemble of Corpus Christi Church presents an annual Festival of Lessons and Carols, a service that commemorates the Nativity. Louise Basbas, the group's director, has assembled settings that span five centuries, with works by Sheppard, Byrd, Weelkes and Tomkins at the early end; Bach, William Selby and Joseph Stephenson covering the middle ground; and Catherine Aks, Hayes Biggs, Peter Maxwell Davies and Harvey Burgett representing the 20th century. Mr. Burgett's work, an organ fantasy, "Das Alte Jahr Vergangen Ist," is a world premiere. Sunday at 4 p.m., Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights. (212) 666-9266. Tickets: $20, $15 for students and the elderly (Kozinn).
 
NEW YORK VIRTUOSO SINGERS. This polished chamber choir, conducted by Harold Rosenbaum, is undertaking a series devoted to choral works of the last century: that is, the 20th. The first installment is devoted to American music, and includes Randall Thompson's "Allelluia," Ives's setting of Psalm 67, Barber's "Twelfth Night," Copland's "In the Beginning," the Dawson arrangement of the spiritual "Ezekial Saw the Wheel," Charles Wuorinen's "A Solis Ortu," John Harbison's "Concerning Them Which Are Sleep" and works by George Perle, Milton Babbitt, David Lang and William Schuman. German, Austrian, Swiss and French works follow in concerts in March and April. Tomorrow night at 8, Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan. (212) 501-3330. Tickets: $18; $10 for students (Kozinn).
 
WILD GINGER PHILHARMONIC. David Goodman, an enterprising percussionist, composer and conductor, leads this colorfully named orchestra of recent graduates from a handful of prestigious conservatories. Among its stated goals is the presentation of classical music in a way that "breaks down barriers between performers and listeners." Its program includes Beethoven's "Coriolan" Overture and Fifth Symphony, and the Shostakovich Chamber Symphony (arranged from his searing String Quartet No. 8). Tomorrow night at 8, Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 879-5770. Donation, $20; $10 for students and the elderly (Kozinn).
 
Dance
 
BETONTANC. The Slovenian avant-garde modern dance and theater company returns to La MaMa's Annex Theater in a return engagement of "Secret Sunshine Schedule," performed in November at the theater. Imbued with the company's trademark, sometimes brutal physicality, the eveninglong piece is set in and under an aquarium representing a utopia. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 (Sunday); Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village; (212) 475-7710 (Jennifer Dunning).
 
FIRST WEEKEND. The Brooklyn Arts Exchange, formerly known as the Gowanus Arts Exchange, continues this monthly series with a program of new choreography by, and conversation with, Christalyn E. Wright and Aviva Geismar. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $12; $6 for low-income audience members. Brooklyn Arts Exchange, 421 Fifth Avenue, at Eighth Street, Park Slope, (718) 832-0018 (Dunning).
 
FLAMENCO EXTRAVAGANZA. The cast may change from performance to performance, depending on which guest artists turn up at this intimate club to sing, dance or play flamenco guitar. But the star of the evening is Carmen La Sala, featured with Paco Ortiz, Juan Amaya, Sandra Rivera and Natalia Brillante. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30. "Scheherazade's Tales," an evening of belly dancing, may be seen on Tuesday nights at 8:30, and there is a variety show on Wednesday nights, also at 8:30. Tickets: $20 for the flamenco program and $10 each for "Scheherazade's Tales" and the variety show. El Patio del East Side, 211 East 60th Street, Manhattan (212) 838-9090 (Dunning).
 
FLAMENCO!: MARIA PAGES AND CANIZARES, Maria Pages, who has appeared in flamenco films by Carlos Saura and in Riverdance, will perform with an ensemble that includes Canizares, the flamenco guitarist, and Eileen Ivers, an award-winning Irish fiddler. A World Music Institute presentation. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $35. Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street, near Park Avenue; (212) 772-4448 (Dunning).
 
FOOD FOR THOUGHT. A philanthropic project to aid the hungry also offers a choreographic feast for the eyes. American choreographers hoping to be selected for this year's Bagnolet choreographic competition in France will present works in two spaces. Tonight at 6 (Eun Me Ahn, Ben Munisteri); tomorrow night at 6 (Wally Cardona, Donna Uchizono); Sunday night at 6 (Gina Gibney, Dorothy Jungels/Everett Dance Theater), Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479. Tickets: $10. Tonight at 8:30 (Mark Haim, Jeremy Nelson, Luis Lara, Wil Swanson); tomorrow night at 8:30 (Sean Curran, Mark Jarecke, Lisa Race); Sunday night at 8:30 (David Dorfman, Dan Froot, Allyson Green, Koosil-ja Hwang), St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $5 and two cans of food, or $10 (Jack Anderson).
 
FOUR JAPANESE DANCE COMPANIES. Young companies from Japan make their American debuts, acquainting audiences with a new generation of choreographic talents. Participants include Condors (an all-male group), Arrow Dance Communication, Fisherman's Art Factory Yan-Shu, and Kenshi Nohmi and Dance Theater 21. Saturday night at 8, Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 832-1155. Tickets: $12 (Anderson).
 
NEW YORK CITY BALLET. There tends to be a special verve to the dancing in the first week or so after the end of the New York City Ballet's "Nutcracker" season. And this weekend will be a feast for fans of Wendy Whelan, a ballerina of special glamor, who will be in at least one ballet at every performance. Another highlight is likely to be the performance tonight of George Balanchine's "Mozartiana" lead by Miranda Weese, whose instinctual dance intelligence and subtlety promises much for this luminous prayer of a ballet. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $45 to $72. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; (212) 870-5570 (Dunning).
 
FAY SIMPSON DANCE THEATER. Dedicated to performing that blends dance and acting, the Fay Simpson Dance Theater will present a return engagement of "Trapped in Seven," an autobiographical solo work about living with H.I.V. The work was conceived and performed by Ms. Simpson, who was diagnosed in 1987 and who suspects, she says during the piece, that she is still alive for a reason. Tomorrow at 4 and 7 p.m. Tickets: $12. Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 647-0202 (Dunning).
 
SARAH SKAGGS DANCE. Sarah Skaggs, her dancers and D.J. Steven Harvey and dancers will perform in "Paradise," a work that is part dance concert, part participatory dance party. The piece, which takes place in a gymnasium, is the first in a series presented by the Danspace Project's Artists in the House program, which takes performers and performances into places where people live. Tonight and next Saturday night at 7 and 9. Tickets: $10 (one show); $15 (both shows). St. Patrick's Youth Center, 268 Mulberry Street, between Houston and Prince Streets, Little Italy, (212) 674-8194 (Dunning).
 
STUTTGART BALLET. On its five-week American tour the acclaimed Stuttgart Ballet will present a repertory that concentrates almost exclusively on works created for the company within the last three years by choreographers who include Maura Bigonzetti, Christian Spuck, Kevin O'Day and Uwe Scholz. Old favorites by Hans van Manen and John Cranko will also be presented. The tour opens with performances tomorrow and Sunday at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, with other performances at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., (Jan. 10-11) and City Center in Manhattan (Jan. 19-22). Tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12-$56. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark; (888) 466-5722 (Dunning).
 
SWEET MOVES: DANCE ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE, Work by eight choreographers and companies, chosen by Alyson Pou, will be performed in this three-hour showcase. Included are the companies of Jody Oberfelder, Yanira Castro, Yoshiko Chuma, Risa Jaroslow and Trajal Harrell. Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $12; $7 for students and the elderly. University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, Lower East Side, (212) 674-9120, extension 183 (Dunning).
 
DOUG VARONE AND DANCERS. As part of a season of varied programs, Doug Varone offers five new and dramatically different dances. "Sleeping With Giants" tells of a man whose weaknesses are treated with disdain. "Tomorrow" is tender and lyrical. "Agora" choreographically evokes a serene setting for communal discussion and thought. "Polonaise No. 44" is a gently humorous duet. "Eclipse" begins in a seemingly abstract manner, then gradually builds emotional tension. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets, $35 (Anderson).
 
"VAUDEVILLE 2000 -- MILKING THE MILLENNIUM." For this scrappy, good-naturedly funny show, the producer, Laraine Goodman, has assembled a cast of first-rate tap dancers who include the Young Hoofers, Tony Waag and Toes Tiranoff and performance artists like Ann Kilkelly, whose ukelele playing is a feast of deadpan hilarity. There is also a storytelling aerialist named Montana Miller, a Russian tap vaudevillian act called Sergei and Vasilli, and the Naughts, a chorus line composed of the performers Nada, Gatz, Zip, Bupkes, Zero, Zilch and Nil. The scenery trembles. The cut-and-paste props are inspired. If Ms. Goodman's 1998 vaudeville show is any guide, it will all be good, scrappy, nutty fun. Through Jan. 16. Thursdays through Saturdays at 10 p.m.; Sundays at 5 p.m. Tickets: $12; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village (212) 475-7710 (Dunning).

PUB-DATE: January 7, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 30; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3371 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AMERICAN MOVIE," featuring Mark Borchardt and friends. Directed by Chris Smith (R, 104 minutes). An insightful, funny, not-to-be-missed documentary about a no-budget Wisconsin filmmaker who makes a horror film as if his life depended on it. And as Mr. Smith so affectingly reveals, Mr. Borchardt's hopes really do hang in the balance. This knowing and often hilarious look at try-anything indie filmmaking becomes a moving portrait of one man's uphill struggle and finds Mr. Borchardt often describing success and prosperity as his goals. Meanwhile his own life is eloquently presented as a very different, no less authentic kind of American Dream (Janet Maslin). 

"ANNA AND THE KING," starring Jodie Foster and Chow Yun-Fat. Directed by Andy Tennant (PG-13, 140 minutes). The same story that inspired the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical "The King and I" is the basis for this movie about the British schoolteacher Anna Leonowens (Ms. Foster), who travels to Bangkok in 1862 to educate the 58 children of King Mongkut (Mr. Chow). Although the story has been given a contemporary multicultural perspective that is critical of British imperialism, the picturesque film tells essentially the same story but without the beloved songs, which are badly missed. Ms. Foster's Anna is another of her nobler-than-thou ice queens, and Mr. Chow's king is authoritative but less than thunderous (Stephen Holden).
 
"BICENTENNIAL MAN," starring Robin Williams, Embeth Davidtz, Sam Neill and Oliver Platt. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG, 132 minutes). This year's gushy Christmas card from Robin Williams follows the 200-year quest of a household robot named Andrew to become human. Directed by the schmaltzmeister Chris Columbus, who steered this star through "Mrs. Doubtfire," the movie is a joke-strewn sentimental man-machine allegory determined to make us feel good about being human that is punctuated by corny speeches exalting freedom, the joys of sex and the mystery of mortality. Except for Mr. Williams, the acting is strictly of sitcom caliber (Holden).
 
* "DOGMA," starring Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Linda Fiorentino, Chris Rock and Salma Hayek. Directed by Kevin Smith (R, 130 minutes). Mr. Smith's idea of angels in America is the notion of two cool dudes who take a hair-splitting, legalese approach to Roman Catholic doctrine and think it would be amusing to nullify all existence. And nothing in this wildly brazen, unexpectedly devout comedy is any less outrageous than that. Mr. Smith again shows off a rare gift for fusing his comic-book sensibility with serious debates and big, big laughs, even if some parts of his film (Ms. Fiorentino's performance, Mr. Rock's and semi-repartee from the ubiquitous Jay and Silent Bob) work better than others (an excrement monster). Making a gutsy leap into matters of faith, Mr. Smith miraculously emerges with his humor intact and his wings unsinged (Maslin).
 
"DOUBLE JEOPARDY," starring Ashley Judd, Tommy Lee Jones and Bruce Greenwood. Directed by Bruce Beresford (R, 106 minutes). In a touristy thriller that roams from the coastline of Washington State to the French Quarter of New Orleans, Ms. Judd plays a woman who is free to kill her husband because she has already gone to prison for the crime (see title). Not even she is beautiful enough to get away with rote acting and a far-fetched plot, but she perks up as her character becomes less of a victim. In this coed homage to "The Fugitive," Mr. Jones is on hand as another weathered sourpuss with a knack for barking orders. Mr. Beresford directs so unremarkably that it takes a line like "I feel like I've grown in the last six years" to signal the passage of time (Maslin).
 
* "EVEREST," directed by David Brashears with Greg MacGillivray (not rated; 45 minutes). If life in New York City doesn't provide enough in the way of thrills, those in search of a vicarious near-death experience can make their way to the American Musuem of Natural History (Central Park West at 79th Street) for a go at "Everest." There, images of the world's highest mountain -- 29,028 feet -- find a frame worthy of the peak's spectacular, lethal beauty. This account focuses mainly on the efforts of three people to scale the peak in 1996 despite yawning chasms of ever-shifting ice, thundering avalanches, the perils of air so thin that it addles the brain and sudden, blinding storms. While this expedition was on the mountain, other teams made their way into the so-called death zone, at 25,000 feet, where a violent storm overtook them. Eight people perished in the worst single disaster on the mountain. "Everest" makes it possible for armchair adventurers to share the risks and glory of the team's climb toward heaven (Lawrence Van Gelder).
 
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The new millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science-fiction title and the IMAX-size screen on which it's being shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of George Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird Suite") in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Movie star introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street,, Manhattan (Holden).
 
"FLAWLESS," starring Robert De Niro and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Joel Schumacher (R, 110 minutes). Mr. De Niro is a retired New York City policeman recovering from a stroke and Mr. Hoffman the drag queen upstairs who gives him speech therapy in the form of singing lessons in this stridently campy comedy. Their flashy performances can't add dimension to a movie that is a message-laden duet for two caricatures, a homophobe and the angry, self-loathing drag queen who gets him out of his depression (Holden).
 
"GALAXY QUEST," starring Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver and Alan Rickman. Directed by Dean Parisot (PG, 102 minutes). Whether you love "Star Trek" or laugh at it, your starship has come in, docking in the form of this amiable comedy that simultaneously manages to spoof these popular futuristic space adventures and replicate the very elements that have made them so durable. The film spins out of a single joke, about a bunch of washed-up actors from a canceled television series who are enlisted by some credulous interplanetary simpletons to champion them in a conflict with a scaly, bellicose villain who has all but exterminated their people. And soon they are off on a genuine space adventure. If "Galaxy Quest" never attains consistently giddy heights as it plays out its combination of knowing satire and heroic adventure, it nevertheless keeps its tongue firmly in its cheek, offers a few genuine laughs, moves swiftly, if not at warp speed, and is led by a talented cast (Van Gelder).
 
"HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL," starring Geoffrey Rush, Taye Diggs and Peter Gallagher. Directed by William Malone (R, 115 minutes). If the ever vigilant Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is truly determined to snuff out inflation aborning, then he can do no better than to take sharpened pencil in hand, make his way to the nearest theater showing this film and strike fearlessly until its feeble pulse beats no more. This is a sorry reincarnation of the 1950's William Castle horror film in which an eccentric millionaire played by Vincent Price offered five strangers $10,000 each to spend the night in a spooky old mansion. In the new version the ante for survival has been raised to $1 million apiece. Even allowing for inflation in the 40 years since the original opened, the reward in 1999 should come to only $57,113.47, according to the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis. But some things have not become devalued over the years: words like junk, for example. "Hill" was pronounced junk in these pages in 1959. And it is still junk (Van Gelder).
 
* "THE LIMEY," starring Terence Stamp and Peter Fonda. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 89 minutes). From a director for whom the quirky stylistic exercise is standard style, this is a handsome throwback to the salad days of its two iconic stars. Mr. Stamp, in a stony, magnetic performance punctuated by flashbacks to his early career, plays an ex-con seeking revenge for the death of his daughter. He becomes the nemesis of Mr. Fonda's slick Hollywood hipster, another role that's piquantly tailor-made. Mr. Soderbergh resurrects the lean, hard-boiled look of John Boorman's "Point Blank" as he dissects and considers these two tough customers from every conceivable perspective (Maslin).
 
* "MANSFIELD PARK," starring Frances O'Connor and Jonny Lee Miller. Written and directed by Patricia Rozema (PG-13, 105 minutes). In Ms. Rozema's skillful screen adaptation of Jane Austen's third novel, the protagonist, Fanny Price (Ms. O'Connor), has been sharpened into a protofeminist heroine who triumphs over the materialist, patriarchal values of her wealthy relatives through a combination of wit, beauty and daring. Without bearing down too heavily, the screenplay (which incorporates fragments of Austen's letters and diaries) equates early 19th-century slave trading with the oppression of women. The message is leavened with smart humor and warm three-dimensional performances (Holden).
 
"THE MESSENGER: THE STORY OF JOAN OF ARC," starring Milla Jovovich, John Malkovich, Tcheky Karyo and Faye Dunaway. Directed by Luc Besson (R, 130 minutes). The Hundred Years' War feels twice that long in this shrill, frenetic account of Joan of Arc. It's a film whose main revelation is that the Middle Ages may have been a lot more lurid than previously reported. Mr. Besson directs plenty of grisly, hand-held battle scenes and absurd scenes of royal scheming, while Ms. Jovovich talks. Like this. And doesn't seem faintly plausible as France's teenage martyr. Here's a case where "Don't shoot 'The Messenger' " would have been sound advice (Maslin).
 
"MUSIC OF THE HEART," starring Meryl Streep, Aidan Quinn, Angela Bassett and Gloria Estefan. Directed by Wes Craven (PG, 110 minutes). Not many of us enjoy being lectured by dressed-down Hollywood stars in gritty classroom situations. But the true story of Roberta Guaspari, a music teacher in East Harlem and a single mother surviving a nasty divorce, has been given a blunt, no-nonsense tone that works. Ms. Streep gives a down-to-earth performance that is sheer award bait. The story is inspirational enough to take Ms. Guaspari from no job prospects to watching her proud students play alongside Itzhak Perlman, Isaac Stern and other violin stars. Not a bad reason for Mr. Craven to have sidelined the claws and hatchets for a while (Maslin).
 
"ONEGIN," starring Ralph Fiennes, Liv Tyler and Martin Donovan. Directed by Martha Fiennes (not rated, 106 minutes). As the directorial debut of Mr. Fiennes's sister Martha, "Onegin" diminishes Pushkin's epic 19th-century novel "Eugene Onegin" into a cramped little soap opera whose two stars are painfully mismatched. While Mr. Fiennes acts up a fine storm as the arrogant, cynical title character who doesn't believe in love, Ms. Tyler, who plays his romantic nemesis, is an inert cipher. Somehow, even the grand ballrooms of 1820's St. Petersburg look drab and chintzy (Holden).
 
* "PRINCESS MONONOKE," with the voices of Billy Crudup, Claire Danes, Billy Bob Thornton and Minnie Driver. Directed by Hayao Miyazaki (PG-13, 133 minutes). A landmark feat of Japanese animation from the acknowledged master of the genre. This complicated, exotically beautiful epic features gods and demons locked in battle for the future of the forest, and its visions are breathtakingly rendered. But it is the film's stirring use of nature, myth and Japanese history that makes it so special. Worth seeing just for its Forest Spirit, which takes animal form by day and roams the night as a diaphanous, Godzilla-like divinity. The image of plants and flowers springing to life beneath his hooves is ravishingly presented. Despite a superb blend of hand-drawn cels and fluid, computer-generated animation, the film's look is gratifyingly understated (Maslin).
 
"ROSETTA," starring Emilie Dequenne. Directed by Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne (R, 90 minutes). This grim quasi-documentary, filmed with hand-held cameras (it's almost as jiggly as "The Blair Witch Project"), picked up the Palme d'Or (the top prize) at the Cannes Film Festival last year. Ms. Dequenne was also chosen best actress for her portrayal of a miserable 17-year-old Belgian girl living in a trailer camp with her alcoholic mother. Her desperate quest for a job and what she calls a "normal life" leads her to betray her only friend, who works at a waffle stand, by stealing his job. Unlike the Dardenne brothers' last film, "La Promesse," this movie's social realist angst feels contrived, and its main character never fully comes to life (Holden).
 
"THE SIXTH SENSE," starring Bruce Willis and Haley Joel Osment. Written and directed by M. Night Shyamalan (PG-13, 107 minutes). What starts out as a horror movie about a troubled 8-year-old boy (Mr. Osment) who claims to see dead people, and the child psychologist (Mr. Willis) determined to cure him, eventually turns into New Age mush (think "What Dreams May Come" and "Simon Birch"). When you trace the plot backward after its big secret is revealed, the story doesn't begin to add up. Mr. Willis gives his usual smirking one-note performance. What empathy the movie generates comes from Mr. Osment's intense portrayal of the tormented child (Holden).
 
"SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS," starring Ethan Hawke, James Cromwell and Max Von Sydow. Directed by Scott Hicks (PG-13, 130 minutes). This director's follow-up to "Shine" is the cinematic equivalent of an arty coffee-table book. It is so busy illustrating the story (with elaborate flashbacks and montage sequences) that it forgets to be dramatic. Set in the Pacific Northwest in 1950, the movie looks back to World War II and the charged relationships between Japanese-Americans and whites on an island north of the Puget Sound. Mr. Hawke is the brooding reporter covering the trial and Mr. Von Sydow the defense lawyer who is the film's official conscience. Robert Richardson is responsible for the gorgeous cinematography (Holden).
 
* "STUART LITTLE," starring Geena Davis, Hugh Laurie and Jonathan Lipnicki. Directed by Rob Minkoff (PG, 92 minutes). E. B. White's 1945 children's classic has been adapted into a lovely family film about a little mouse (with the voice of Michael J. Fox) who is adopted by humans but runs afoul of their fluffy white Persian house cat, Snowbell (Nathan Lane). The movie creates an enchanted storybook version of New York and has what may be the most exciting toy boat race (in Central Park) ever filmed. Thanks to Mr. Lane's sly, wise-guy vocal impersonation, Snowbell nearly steals a movie that is funny and sweet but never cloying (Holden).
 
"THREE KINGS," starring George Clooney, Mark Wahlberg and Ice Cube. Written and directed by David O. Russell (R, 105 minutes). The prodigiously talented writer-director of "Spanking the Monkey" and "Flirting With Disaster" has made a much more ambitious film, with mixed results. His gimlet-eyed Persian Gulf war film has a "Catch-22" absurdist edge, but it also has an oversupply of visual affectations. Vertiginous music-video camera tricks jazz up the straightforward story of American soldiers who have larcenous designs on Saddam Hussein's captured gold and then develop conscience pangs about their own roles in Iraq. There are many clever peripheral touches, but there's something tamely conventional at the film's core (Maslin).
 
* "TOY STORY 2," with the voices of Tom Hanks and Tim Allen. Directed by John Lasseter; a Pixar Animated Studios film (G, 98 minutes). A wonderfully playful sequel, sustaining the first film's wit and novelty while bringing new sophistication to computer-generated animation. And here is welcome proof that Hollywood can still make movies to please audiences of any age or persuasion. From its opening (a perfectly adorable "Star Wars" parody) to its Capraesque conclusion, this is seamless work with more metaphorical cleverness than that usually found in the toy bin. Colorful new characters and more adventurous action enhance the story of how Woody falls into the clutches of a sleazy toy dealer, experiences new-found celebrity and needs to be rescued by his fabulous old friends (Maslin).
 
* "THE WAR ZONE," starring Freddie Cunliffe, Ray Winstone, Tilda Swinton and Lara Belmont. Directed by Tim Roth (not rated, 99 minutes). Mr. Roth is an actor known for roles in tough films, but never for anything quite as raw as this. In this searing first feature, the title battlefield is a rural English home where a teenage boy looks upon his own family with helpless rage and astonishment. Sensing the incestuous relationship between his father and older sister, the film's wordless, baleful young hero struggles to come to terms with this household horror. Understated but extremely graphic at times, and shot with mournfully expressive simplicity by Seamus McGarvey (Maslin).
 
"THE WORLD IS NOT ENOUGH," starring Pierce Brosnan, Sophie Marceau, Dame Judi Dench, Robert Carlyle and Denise Richards. Directed by Michael Apted (PG-13, 128 minutes). This director is much admired for his "Up" series chronicling the lives of former schoolchildren as they mature. And he has managed to make James Bond grow up a little, too. Mr. Brosnan has become much more comfortable with the role of Bond, and most of the other characters are also more interesting than might have been expected. Ms. Marceau slinks memorably through the role of a treacherous oil heiress. Ms. Richards seemed a lot smarter playing high school vixens than she does as a brilliant scientist here. The itinerary roams from Scotland to Central Asia. And Mr. Apted handles the action as well as he does the talk (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"WRITTEN BY ROBERT RISKIN." Flash back to the old Hollywood. Envision a man wearing silk pajamas while seated at a table on his lawn, writing scripts on an Underwood typewriter. His name is Robert Riskin. He collaborated on 13 films with Frank Capra, including "It Happened One Night" (1934), which won him an Oscar; "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" (1936); and "Platinum Blonde," (1931) with Jean Harlow and Loretta Young. Riskin (1897-1955) specialized in colorful characters, fast-paced plots and snappy dialogue. Beginning today, he will be the subject of a weeklong retrospective of a dozen films that concludes Film Forum's 75-film Columbia Pictures 75th anniversary celebration. The opening attraction is a double bill of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" and "It Happened One Night," and at the 7:05 p.m. screening of "Mr. Deeds," the Writers Guild of America will pay special tribute to Riskin with a panel that includes the columnist Sidney Zion, the historian Foster Hirsch, the screenwriter Walter Bernstein and the actress Fay Wray, who married Riskin in 1942. The moderator is John Martello, the Players Club executive director. The series continues through Jan. 13 at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, in the South Village. Tickets: $9; $5 for members. Information: (212) 727-8110 (Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: It's Boring. It's Ignored. Maybe It's a Good Investment, Too.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
MAY you live in interesting times.
So goes the ancient Chinese curse. And these days the stock market is nothing if not interesting. Internet stocks double within days, then lose most of the gains within a few more. The Nasdaq composite index has hundred-point swings within minutes. 
 When a show is providing a thrill a minute, there is a risk that the competing act down the block will be ignored. That is what has happened to the least risky -- and therefore least exciting -- investment around. As cash flooded into Nasdaq stocks, nobody seemed interested in a boring investment that can't lose money, but that has only a limited upside. So it kept getting cheaper.
The competing investment is inflation-indexed bonds. They are not very exciting, and, to tell the truth, they have not been very good investments in the three years during which they have been available. Inflation has been quiet, and interest in the bond, never high, has declined.
As a result, the real yield on such bonds -- the amount a holder gets in addition to the increase in the Consumer Price Index -- has risen to 4.39 percent, half a percentage point higher than the yield last spring.
That is about what the yield is expected to be when the Treasury auctions a new issue of 10-year inflation-indexed bonds on Wednesday. Buy one, and you will get a coupon payment of that amount that will rise with inflation. And when the bond matures, the principal you get back will be increased to reflect all the inflation there was during the life of the bond.
By any historical standard, 4.3 percent is an extraordinary real return on a safe investment, and it is not easy to explain why it is available. Inflation-indexed bonds in other countries -- Canada, Britain, France and Australia offer them -- used to offer higher yields than the American bonds. Now the situation is reversed. Perhaps it indicates a strong demand for capital in this country, which pushes real rates higher.
But mostly it reflects the fact that there is little fear of either inflation or bear markets. "Investors are expecting great things from the equity markets, so inflation-indexed bonds have to have higher yields," says Dan Bernstein, the director of research at Bridgewater Associates, a money management firm.
In the three years that such bonds have been available, the public interest in them has gone from moderate to something close to nonexistent.
This week's stock market volatility is not all that greater than the volatility at peak points last year. That volatility did not scare investors away from speculative stocks, and this turmoil may not either. Many investors see all stock market declines as buying opportunities.
But it will be interesting to see if individual investor demand for inflation-indexed bonds does rise at next week's auction. For there are basically two ways to use historical patterns in making investment decisions. One way is to assume that Mr. Market, as Warren E. Buffett likes to say, sometimes offers things cheap and sometimes offers them dear, and good investors buy them when they are cheap. By that standard, these bonds are very attractive.
The other way is to go with the theory that stocks have been proved to be the best long-term investment, period, and that there is no need to worry about things like valuation or the risk of losing money over the long term. Those who subscribe to that theory no doubt will ignore this auction. Time will tell which view was the more profitable one.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
