HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Goldman and Kyocera Said to Be Starting Japan Investment Fund

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Goldman Sachs Group and the Kyocera Corporation, the world's largest maker of ceramic packages as well as a substantial force in the mobile telephone business, are expected to announce Friday that they will collaborate in an investment fund to take stakes in Japanese companies.
The fund will combine Goldman's expertise in using its own capital to make investments and Kyocera's deep pockets and entree to the clubby world of Japanese business. 
 Representatives of Kyocera and Goldman declined to comment. People connected to the collaboration, however, confirmed a story in today's Nihon Keizai Shimbun, which said the fund's size was $385 million.
Private investors have been active in Asia since the region's economic crisis hit two years ago, but until recently, Japan had remained relatively aloof to their advances.
Now, though, as old barriers to entry fall to deregulation and as companies once financed by bank loans find themselves struggling to tap other sources of capital, more companies are taking a second look at foreign direct investment.
Direct investment by foreign companies and investors hit a record 1.34 trillion yen, or about $12.9 billion, in the fiscal year that ended March 31, small by global standards but still seen as indicative of the potential here. That was a 97 percent increase over the previous year.
And foreign direct investment into Japan in the first six months of the current fiscal year nearly equaled the total investment for all of fiscal 1998, at 1.33 trillion yen. Ripplewood, a private equity firm, is in the final stages of completing its deal to buy the bankrupt Long-Term Credit Bank from the government, the largest such deal so far.
But there have been smaller deals taking place. Last week, Olympus Capital Holdings Asia, a $250 million private equity fund established in 1997 to make investments in Asia, bought half of Tomen Mediacom, a group of five cable television companies that serve roughly one million households in Tokyo.
"I think there's a role for private equity in Japan now," said Lawrence S. K. Miao, one of Olympus's founding partners. "The Japanese like to have partners who are committed for the long term, and in that sense, private equity investors are more attractive than institutions that simply raise capital."
Goldman's proprietary investment activities, which include investments in Kookmin Bank in South Korea, luxury hotels in Asia and several high-technology ventures in the United States and Europe, generated $950 million in revenue after interest expenses last year.
Kyocera is a longtime Goldman client. Most recently, Goldman was adviser to the DDI Corporation, Japan's second-largest long-distance telephone service operator, on the merger announced last month with the KDD Corporation and the IDO Corporation. Kyocera will be the largest shareholder of the combined company with a 15.8 percent stake.
"Working with people you know and who know you is an enormous benefit in Japan," Mr. Miao said.

HEADLINE: Slower Sales Of New Homes In November

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Consumers bought new homes in November at a slower-than-expected pace and the number of Americans filing jobless claims rose, the government said today, offering signs the economy may have begun to slow.
The Commerce Department said the number of new single-family homes sold in November fell 7.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 865,000 units, compared with a 931,000-unit pace in October. The October rate was revised down sharply from a previously reported pace of 986,000 units. 
 The 7.1 percent decline was the largest since an 8 percent fall in December 1997.
"While a home sales rate of 865,000 is still very strong on a historical basis, it is off over 12 percent from November 1998," Joel Naroff, an economic consultant, said.
The data helped soothe financial markets, and the 30-year Treasury bond and the Dow Jones industrial average ended higher. But the technology-laden Nasdaq index dropped sharply as investors continued to take profits.
In mid-November, the Federal Reserve increased interest rates for the third time last year in an effort to cool the robust economy and head off potential inflationary pressures.
The Fed's moves helped push the interest rate on the average 30-year mortgage close to 8 percent, a full percentage point above levels a year earlier.
But despite the slackening home sales pace, there was one worrisome aspect to the report: rising house prices. The median home price rose to a record $167,400 in November from $159,000 in October while the average home price rose to a record $209,700 from $201,300 in October, an indication that Americans were still buying luxury homes.
Separately, the Labor Department reported the number of newly unemployed Americans filing for state benefits jumped by 33,000 last week, the largest one-week rise in a year.
Initial jobless claims, which are viewed as an early indication of the strength of the labor market, rose to 309,000 in the holiday-shortened week ended Jan. 1.
That was much steeper than the 280,000 expected by Wall Street.
Sales of new homes slowed in all areas of the country, most notably the Northeast, where sales plunged 31.5 percent to an annual pace of 50,000 units from a 73,000-unit pace in October.
Sales slowed 7.8 percent in the Midwest, fell 5.4 percent in the West and dropped 3.1 percent in the South.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
United takes a warmer, fuzzier course after a campaign unsettles customers and employees.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
MAJOR new campaign for United Airlines, replacing a contentious recent series of advertisements carrying the theme "Rising," has no theme. But if there were one, it might proclaim "United we stand, divided we fall."
Of course, "fall" is not quite the type of word fliers want to see invoked in airline advertising. But as it turned out, "Rising," as in rising above the difficulties that vex customers, was not a word they -- or United's almost 100,000 employees -- welcomed either. 
 The reason? "Rising" took a nontraditional approach to convince customers that United was tackling the travails of travel, detailing the problems as well as the solutions. But, according to executives at United, part of the UAL Corporation, and at Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, the United agency, that only reminded passengers how unfriendly the skies can get and put off employees who felt they were being chastised for lost luggage or delayed flights.
So after almost three years of "Rising," which was abruptly curtailed in October while Fallon McElligott explored other ideas, United is bringing out a feel-good campaign centered on its name: "Be United," "Worlds United," "Feel United."
The warmly emotional appeals, underscored by reprises of "Rhapsody in Blue" and reassuring words from the actor Liam Neeson, evoke the pitches that epitomized United during the days when the carrier and its previous agency, the Leo Burnett unit of the Leo Group, promised perfection to those who chose to "Fly the friendly skies."
The switch in strategies, which begins tomorrow on television and Monday in poster-style newspaper advertisements, is emblematic of the midcourse corrections that marketers must make when they realize their decisions to take different directions in advertising require rethinking. Sometimes, it seems in this instance, you have to leave home to learn there was, all together now, no place like home.
"We've got to get back to the heart of United, some of our roots, what makes us unique," John D. Kiker, vice president for advertising and corporate communications for United in Chicago, said in an interview yesterday as he presented a preview of the campaign.
"In all honesty, senior management's opinion is that 'Rising' did us a lot of good," he added. "It was interesting, intriguing and made us focus on what we had to fix. But employees felt it laid a lot of blame on them and that was unfortunate."
Another shortfall came, Mr. Kiker said, when research determined that "Rising" was believed to "be talking to 'road warriors' and global travelers, the people in the front of the plane; we gave the agency the challenge to be more inclusive, to talk to all our passengers."
The result was the new campaign, which Mr. Kiker characterized as striving to portray the airline as "United to create a better journey." The budget for the ads domestically in 2000 was estimated at around the $80 million spent in 1999. United spends another $40 million or so on campaigns abroad, which are created by offices of Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York; that agency's new work is due in March or April.
"A client once told me, 'A brand is the sum of everything it's been,' and those are wise words," said David Lubars, president and creative director at Fallon McElligott, which landed the United account when United stunned Madison Avenue by dismissing Burnett in 1996 after 31 years.
"We went back to the core values that are relevant today," Mr. Lubars said. " 'Friendly skies' was meant back then to have people feel comfortable about going up in the air. Now people are more concerned about efficiency, achieving what needs to be done.
"But what's as relevant now as it was to the guys who started United is that it's all about uniting people," he added. "Others can say they bring you together, they connect you, but it's not in their name."
On TV, the theme is brought to life in one spot by Mr. Neeson's narration of scenes of people from Japan to New Orleans to Spain gathering in courtyards, plazas and squares: "Why is it that every city, every town, every neighborhood, no matter where you are in the world, has something in common? A place for people to come together. It's quite simple. Humans are a social bunch. That's why we fly more places than anyone else. Because it's important for the human race to stay United."
That spot, and a second one centered on the fast pace of contemporary life, both end with heroic shots of United pilots flying their planes through skies that look even more majestic, if that's possible, than Burnett made them appear during the "Friendly" decades.
"For an airline to say it's time for us as an industry to do better for our customers was a controversial point of view to take," said Eric Block, general manager at Fallon McElligott. "Much of 'Rising' focused on better flights, better seats, better meals.
"But the comments that the employees felt undue pressure were fair because when you raise the ante, say 'We have to do better,' that puts the pressure on," he added.
"A new management team at United feels it's important now to focus on why our improvements are better than our competitors' and on how United cares about its customers and its people," Mr. Block said. "We'll continue to talk about the planes we fly, such as Economy Plus, taking seats out to give more room to our best customers in coach, but in the context of what's true to the soul of this brand."
How the new campaign fares is crucial for Fallon McElligott, still stinging from the failure of a midcourse correction on ads for another high-profile account, Miller Lite beer; that client, the Miller Brewing Company unit of the Philip Morris Companies, deemed the agency's revampings ineffective and the account was lost to the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group.
"We're very confident about Fallon," Mr. Kiker said. "They understand the business, they understand the category and they're putting 110 percent into this."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Equities' FallSpurs Buying Of Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly yesterday, up for the second time in three days as a downturn in overseas stock markets and expectations of further losses in the United States equity market encouraged traders to buy fixed-income securities.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond increased 23/32 to 94 12/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.56 percent from 6.62 percent on Wednesday. 
 Market analysts, however, said investor expectations of further interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve Board had limited the day's price gains. The central bank's monetary policy committee is expected to raise rates by at least 25 basis points, or one-quarter of a percentage point, at the conclusion of its two-day meeting on Feb. 1 and 2.
"Basically the market has priced in a Fed move and given the central bank a green light to raise short-term rates," said Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla. "It now becomes a question of how much of an increase the Fed is planning."
Few expected the market to mount any significant rally, particularly ahead of today's employment report. Bonds found some support yesterday from the weekly jobless claims report issued by the Labor Department, which said claims rose by a more-than-expected 33,000 last week, to 309,000. The number was well above the increase of 12,000 that was anticipated, indicating the labor market's tightness may be easing, potentially reducing pressures on wages.
"Activity was thin and any uptick today is not justifiable until we see the jobs report on Friday," Mr. Pugliese said.
Traders said the market had already priced in strong numbers in the jobs report and probably would not go much lower unless today's numbers prove far stronger than expected. The report is expected to show the economy added 250,000 new payroll jobs in December, with the unemployment rate remaining at 4.1 percent. The average hourly earnings are expected to rise 0.3 percent.
Yesterday, the market got both good news and bad news in the home sales data. "The positive implication was the decline in home sales for November and the very sharp downward revision to the statistics for October," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The bad news, she said, was the sharp increases reported in home prices on both a monthly and a year-to-year basis.
Late in the day Treasuries also rose from market talk that the Treasury would release details of its buyback program and would increase the number of callable issues.
Elsewhere, the World Bank said it would sell $3 billion in debt securities in what would be the first global electronic bond offering to be sold, distributed and traded online. Lead managers will be Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Investors Flee Technology; Dow Rises and Nasdaq Falls

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Investors accelerated their shift from high technology into less expensive smokestack and consumer stocks yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq market moved in opposite directions for the third time this week.
The Nasdaq composite suffered a midafternoon swoon and finished 150.41 points, or 3.88 percent, lower at 3,727.13, bringing its loss since Monday's record close to 9.8 percent. A decline of 10 percent in any stock gauge is widely regarded as a correction. 
 Then, after normal trading hours, prices of many of Nasdaq's high-fliers slumped further when Lucent Technologies, the maker of telephone equipment, warned that profits and sales would be well below estimates.
Paced by an 8-point gain in Minnesota Mining, to 100 1/4, the Dow Jones industrials rose 130.61 points, or 1.17 percent, to 11,253.26. That was 2.1 percent below its Dec. 31 record. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.34 points, to 1,403.45.
"There is a very pronounced rotation" into stocks like DuPont, Caterpillar and Exxon Mobil, said Donna Van Vlack, head trader at Brandywine Asset Management in Wilmington, Del., which invests in such issues. As for computer-related stocks, she added, "it seems everybody is headed for the same exit."
Despite the swing from high technology into blue-chip standbys -- some money also moved into bonds, pushing interest rates down -- analysts noted that various calendar-related factors were at work and that the selloff in technology might prove little more than a normal pullback after a giant increase in 1999.
"If you're going to ride this horse you have to realize there's a lot of bucking in this group," said Andrew M. Brooks, head of stock trading at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore.
Among the seasonal crosscurrents were investors taking profits this year instead of last year to defer capital gains taxes, and the usual January inflow of pension and bonus money and reinvested dividends.
Still, analysts said the warning by Lucent -- which plunged as low as 53 after its warning, compared with 69 at the close and 73 3/16 at its best level of the day -- made them nervous as they awaited the government's report this morning on the nation's job market in December.
A big jump in jobs or a decline in the unemployment rate, already at its lowest in three decades, would add to the pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again. Fed policy makers, who are to convene the first two days of February, are already expected to raise the short-term rate target, 5.5 percent since mid-November, by at least one-quarter of a point.
"The interest rate rise is cause for concern," said Alex Meitzner, chairman of Ranson & Associates in Wichita, Kan., which runs a mutual fund indexed to the Nasdaq 100. But he pointed to financial history in contending that a correction in technology stocks from "not sustainable" levels would probably be limited to 15 percent.
"We've had several pretty dramatic corrections and it's always come back," Mr. Meitzner said of this group. "It's pretty resilient."
Trading remained heavy, with 1.6 billion shares changing hands on Nasdaq, the seventh busiest on record, and 1.1 billion on the New York Stock Exchange.
Japan and Europe set a negative tone, with the main London index down 1.4 percent, Frankfurt and Paris lower by fractions of 1 percent and Hong Kong and Tokyo down 4.4 percent and 2 percent, respectively.
Joining Minnesota Mining among the Dow's biggest gainers were Procter & Gamble, which was raised to a strong buy from accumulate by Prudential Securities, Exxon Mobil and J. P. Morgan, all up more than 4 points. In contrast, the three biggest drags were all technology companies. Intel was down 4 7/8, to 78 3/4, Microsoft, 31 3/16, to 110, and Hewlett-Packard, 4 5/8, to 103 1/4, but as low as 101 after the Lucent warning.
Brokerage stocks gained, aided by strong earnings at Lehman Brothers, which added 2 15/16, to 72 7/8. Goldman Sachs surged 3 3/8, to 82 1/4, and Merrill Lynch 2 3/4, to 76 3/8. Citigroup rose 3 5/8, to 54 1/4, and Bank of America 315 3/16, to 49 3/8.
Utility stocks gained, though not as much as on Wednesday, as did drug shares and such gritty sectors as chemicals and railroads. Union Pacific, Burlington Northern Santa Fe and Kansas City Southern each advanced more than 2 points.
Tiffany fell 3 1/4, to 77, despite reporting exceptionally strong holiday sales, while AnnTaylor Stores fell 6, to 24, after reporting a slim sales gain that failed to meet some estimates.
More Big Board stocks rose than fell, 1,971 to 1,161, but new 52-week lows again surpassed new highs, 77 to 45.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Push Through 40% Raises Of Their Own

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
New Jersey lawmakers agreed to give themselves a 40 percent raise as part of a package of salary increases for a host of government officials and state judges that was hurriedly approved today by budget committees in the Senate and Assembly.
The raises are expected to be adopted on Monday, the last day of the 208th Legislature's session.
The pay package, agreed upon this week by leaders of both houses and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, would raise legislators' salaries to $49,000 a year, from $35,000. New Jersey lawmakers hold other jobs, but they say they work an average of 35 hours per week on legislative business. 
 Senators and assemblymen have not had a pay increase since 1990. Even if approved by the full body, the salaries will not go into effect until 2002, because of a rule requiring lawmakers to stand for election between voting for a raise and getting it.
The governor's authorized salary would rise, also in 2002, to $175,000 from $130,000, a 35 percent increase, although Mrs. Whitman has accepted only $85,000 a year since taking office in 1994.
The pay package was hustled through the two budget committees in short order, with no advance notice. The bill was added to the Senate Appropriations Committee's agenda 15 minutes after the scheduled start of its meeting, and was passed unanimously after less than a half-hour of testimony and discussion.
In the Assembly committee, 11 members voted for the raise and three against it, one member abstained, and one left his seat in the chamber shortly before the bill was called, missing the vote.
The bill would also create a permanent Public Officers Salary Review Commission that would meet every four years, therefore avoiding another 12-year pay freeze and the resulting need for a huge raise in one step. Some lawmakers had pressed to index their pay to inflation to avoid "falling into the same trap again," as Assemblyman Steven J. Corodemus, a Republican of West Long Branch, put it.
The bill approved today differs notably from the special commission's recommendations in that, at Governor Whitman's insistence, the increases for her cabinet members and for judges, county prosecutors and members of the Casino Control Commission and the Board of Public Utilities would be granted in three phases. For example, Superior Court judges, who now earn $115,000, would receive $133,330 this year, $137,165 in 2001, and $141,000 in 2002.
"The governor felt that an immediate jump to $141,000 was excessive," said Peter J. McDonough Jr., a spokesman for the governor. He said the $133,000 salary level would amount to a cost-of-living increase for the judges since their last raise, in 1994.
All told, the increases will add no more than $14.1 million to the state's budget, said Richard H. Bagger, chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee.

HEADLINE: A Bidding War for Teachers Spreads From Coast to Coast

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
On Wednesday, only hours after Gov. George E. Pataki asked lawmakers to subsidize tuition for college students who commit to teach in selected New York public schools, Gov. Gray Davis of California addressed the Legislature in Sacramento with what, in effect, amounted to a more lucrative counteroffer.
California, Governor Davis proposed, should offer candidates who agree to teach in low-performing schools $10,000 loans for buying a home, $30,000 bonuses for attaining advanced certification and $11,000 to repay college loans. 
 But even before such incentives can be proffered, the two states -- neither of which apparently had any idea what the other was planning -- face heavy competition across the country in their efforts to woo prospective teachers and to keep good ones from fleeing to other states or professions.
"It's a bidding war," said Richard Mills, the state education commissioner in New York. "And you can't recruit with rhetoric."
Two years ago, as the nation began to feel the effects of a virtually unprecedented wave of teacher retirements, Baltimore offered to badly needed special education teachers starting salaries equivalent to those of teachers with four years' experience, as well as reduced-rate mortgages and reimbursement of moving expenses. During the same period, El Paso, Tex., lured new math teachers with $2,000 signing bonuses, which it was forced to do after Dallas began a similar effort.
Such offers have multiplied and intensified in recent months: at least 20 states -- including Florida, Georgia, Mississippi and Massachusetts -- have begun to pay bonuses of up to $6,000 a year, sometimes for several years, to teachers who pass a new, rigorous national certification test.
New York has traditionally had difficulty keeping pace. The state is among several that produce thousands of new teachers a year who choose, often for reasons of quality of academic life or salary, to teach outside the state.
Of the 21,000 students who graduated with teaching certificates from New York colleges and universities last year, fewer than 7,000 took teaching jobs in New York, according to Carl Hayden, the chancellor of the Board of Regents. This movement is happening at a time when the city alone is seeking to replace nearly 10,000 teachers who have temporary licenses.
Several factors are driving the proposals by New York, California and the other states.
With tens of thousands of teachers, many of them born in the first years of the baby boom, becoming eligible for retirement, the nation must recruit and hire two million new teachers in less than a decade. There is also a national effort, much of it subsidized by the federal government, to reduce class sizes, particularly in burgeoning urban school districts.
Meanwhile, the demand for highly skilled teachers has, arguably, never been greater: new high-stakes tests often link a teacher's job evaluation to student performance, and new state standards, written or in place in every state but Iowa, seek to outline what teachers should be teaching, and when.
The need for good teachers has also been affected by the persistence of flush times, making education more of a public concern than the economy is. Voters have told pollsters, for example, that improving education is among their greatest priorities.
And the growth in technology jobs and other employment tied to the Internet has further sapped the ranks of potential science teachers, among others.
Moreover, Mr. Mills and Mr. Hayden said that women, once the backbone of the nation's teaching force, now can seek out opportunities in more lucrative fields once closed to them.
Still, for all the perks states are offering teachers, few politicians have been willing to take the far more costly step of increasing teachers' salaries permanently and across the board.
"These are all good things," said Sandra Feldman, a former New York City elementary school teacher who is president of the American Federation of Teachers, the nation's second-largest teachers union. "But ultimately the salaries will have to be raised. You are talking about a need for 250,000 teachers a year for the next 10 years. You are talking about a full-employment economy where knowledge workers are in great demand. It's going to take a significant increase in base salaries to attract the educated people we need to become teachers."
According to figures provided by the union, the average beginning teacher's salary nationally, at the start of the 1998 school year, was $25,735. That compared with $42,862 for beginning engineers, $40,920 for new computer scientists and $33,702 for accountants.
The gap between teachers and those other professions typically widens with each year of experience.
One of the few officials who has stepped forward to advocate boosting teachers' base pay is Vice President Al Gore, who said that if elected president, he would propose federally financed salary increases of up to $10,000 for veteran teachers willing to serve in the nation's poorest districts.
Governor Pataki's proposal, which came in his sixth annual address to the Legislature, would provide an annual tuition subsidy of $3,400 -- enough to cover full tuition at a state university for a state resident, or to reduce the much higher tuition at private schools -- to those college students who promise to teach for at least four years in those New York public schools with teacher shortages. Most of the teachers, presumably, would be placed in New York City, though few details have been worked out.
The Pataki administration estimated that the proposal would cost the state $25 million a year, and attract perhaps 50,000 new teachers over the next 10 years. New York City is expected to lose more than half that number, most to retirement, over that period.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, also said the state should pay for more than 9,000 uncertified teachers to take the courses they need to become licensed teachers.
The sweeteners proposed by Governor Davis of California, a Democrat, would be even more generous.
Teachers would be eligible for $10,000 home loans that would be forgiven after they teach in the state's public schools for five years. Those who teach in schools ranked in the lower half in the state would also have $11,000 in college loans forgiven if they stay in such schools for five years.
And $30,000 bonuses would be awarded to California teachers who work in low-performing schools and who take the courses and pass the tests required to be certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, a nonprofit organization that seeks to make the criteria for good teachers uniform across the country.
Governor Davis did not specify the cost of those proposals, but said he hoped to devote a significant portion of an expected $3 billion budget surplus to education.
"To our youth, let me say, there is no higher calling, no greater public service, no contribution more valued than to join the front lines of the future in the classroom," Governor Davis said. "This is our generation's call to arms."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PENNZOIL-QUAKER STATETO CLOSE PENNSYLVANIA REFINERY

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Pennzoil-Quaker State Company plans to close its refinery and packaging plant in northwestern Pennsylvania, cutting about 300 jobs, and is trying to sell its refinery in Shreveport, La. The company said yesterday that it would charge $293 million against after-tax earnings for the plant closing in Rouseville, Pa., and for a write-down in the value of the Shreveport refinery. The Rouseville refinery processes crude oil and ships it to other oil companies. A nearby packaging plant prepares Pennzoil and Wolf's Head oils for market. The company said that oil production at the refinery would cease on Jan. 31 but that the making of waxes derived from oil would continue until June. Pennzoil has had a refinery at the site since the 1880's.

HEADLINE: Shoppers in U.S. Spent Big During the Holiday Season

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
At Costco, shoppers hoarded batteries. At Bloomingdale's they gorged themselves on day-after sales, and at Tiffany's they indulged in white gold. But everywhere Americans went this holiday shopping season they spent big.
A booming economy, combined with fears and celebratory impulses related to the new century, propelled sales in big chain stores open a year, a crucial industry measurement, to rise 5.1 percent in December, according to the Goldman Sachs retail index. The gain was particularly impressive because it came on the heels of an unusually strong 5.4 percent gain in December 1998. 
 Not only were sales strong, but merchants reported that they kept inventories tight and controlled price cutting so that fourth-quarter earnings would be robust as well. Industry analysts could not effuse enough. "It was a barn burner of a holiday season," said Jeff Feiner, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.
Many patterns that dominated Christmases past reappeared like Marley's ghost this season. Discount stores reported the strongest sales, while department stores trailed. Americans held back their shopping, postponing purchases until just before Christmas and even the week after the holiday to get the biggest sales -- a habit that was abetted this year by the fact that both Christmas and New Year's fell on Saturdays. "When the day after Christmas is a Sunday, it gets people out to take advantage of gift certificates and sales," said Bruce Van Kleeck, vice president of the National Retail Federation.
The biggest surprise of the month were the warehouse clubs, which as a group turned in spectacular numbers. At BJ's Wholesale Club, sales rose 14.7 percent. At Sam's Club, a unit of Wal-Mart Stores, sales advanced 14.2 percent, and at Costco Wholesale, sales jumped 18.2 percent. Costco said it had benefited from Year 2000 concerns, selling precautionary items like generators and flashlights, as well as celebratory products like wines and Champagnes.
But the chief financial officer of Costco, Richard Galanti, said that the chain, which has been doing well all year, did well across the board this holiday season -- especially in such nonbasic items as electronics, computers and jewelry. Diamonds were a particularly coveted purchase. As if to drive home the point that warehouse clubs are not just for canned tuna and toilet paper anymore, Costco said it had sold a "six-plus carat diamond" by special order for $98,000.
Jewelry retailers also experienced outsized sales increases in a category that has historically been tied very closely to the economy. At Zale's, sales for November and December climbed 16.3 percent over the comparable period a year earlier; at Tiffany & Company's United States operations, sales soared 27 percent. Michael Kowalski, president and chief executive of Tiffany, said that in addition to good economic conditions the chain had done well because it had stepped up the pace of product introductions. A square-cut engagement ring called the Lucida was especially popular this year, he said.
Department stores as a group experienced a 1.4 percent gain, but they were held back by the fact that the two giants in the category, J. C. Penney and Sears, Roebuck & Company, continued to struggle. Those two lost market share to both low-priced specialty retailers like the Gap's Old Navy and discounters like Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation.
Some of the big-name department store chains did, however, experience a very respectable holiday season. Neiman Marcus, which focuses on more upscale customers, saw December sales rise 14.4 percent over December 1998. Saks, which had a bumpy summer and fall, had a nice Christmas recovery, reporting a sales increase of 5 percent. And Federated Department Stores, owner of Bloomingdale's and Macy's, reported a sales rise of 6.4 percent
Many analysts also credited the department stores with planning far enough in advance to preserve profits even in the face of widespread cost-cutting and coupon promotions. "Federated has been doing a great job of planning for promotions and building awareness of private brands," said Jeff Edelman, an analyst with Paine Webber.
Even Sears, which had a slight sales decrease for December, has said that earnings will rise far in excess of expectations, partly because it did not engage in heavy price cutting.
Among the specialty store chains, AnnTaylor Stores, which was expected to be a big winner as women snapped up velvet and beaded slip dresses for New Year's Eve parties, reported December sales rose only a modest 0.9 percent. In a statement, the retail chain said that it "could have benefited from traditional gift-giving items like classic twin sets."
With the Federal Reserve likely to raise interest rates in the coming months, analysts were skeptical that merchants could continue to expand at the same pace.
"We could see some hangover as early as January, as some of that Y2K merchandise comes back," warned George Strachan, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs.

HEADLINE: A Peacemaker for the Germans

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
The historian weighs his words. Because his subject is Germany and the modern history of that nation is a minefield, this precision is understandable. Yet it is evident that in the crafted phrases of Fritz Stern, in the sentences that circle a subject like a hunter closing on his prey, a personality as well as a calling are revealed. He is a man of nuances; when he defines himself, it is with a kind of fastidious detail.
"I am a full-blooded non-Aryan," he says, an amused twinkle in his small eyes, hands so mobile they appear to be plucking each shade of thought from the air. "That is a definition I like. Of course, I am completely of Jewish descent. But my stumbling block with the description of myself as a Jewish historian is that it was Hitler that decided I was a Jew. My grandparents converted to Christianity; my parents were baptized at birth; I, too, was baptized. It took Hitler's racial laws to turn me into a Jew, and that provokes a certain -- let me put it like this -- a certain hesitation in me." 
 Born in 1926 in the German town of Breslau (now Wroclaw in Poland), later a child-escapee from Hitler, now an American citizen, Mr. Stern is a natural builder of bridges. For without such connections -- between Germany and the United States, between Jews and Germans, between Berlin and Warsaw, between the horror of then and the hope of now -- what chance would he have to make himself whole?
His historical writing amounts to a quest to go beyond the fragments offered by memory. "Memory may be mighty," Mr. Stern said in Frankfurt, "yet it can also be inaccurate. It keeps us on our toes, but it brings us only to the threshold of historical understanding." At a time of intellectual turmoil in Germany, this quest for understanding has earned Mr. Stern, a professor at Columbia University, a special role in the country of his birth. He has emerged as a sort of moral arbiter.
For the last year, Germany has been seeking a new 21st-century identity. It has manifested impatience with the stigma of the Nazi past, a thirst for normality, a new readiness to talk openly of German power, and a hankering for some acceptable German patriotism. Many Germans feel the "constitutional patriotism" of the philosopher Jurgen Habermas -- the neutered national identity that substituted values like democratic government for the treacherous emotions of anthem and flag -- is no longer enough. In short, Germans are unbuttoning themselves.
But as Germany searches for its new self, Germans are still a little unsure, giddy with the new vocabulary of interests, great European power and influence where once the talk was only of Europe and detente. They tremble at their boldness in moving beyond the self-imposed constraints of the postwar years. In this shifting environment, symbolized by the move of the capital from small-town Bonn to brash Berlin, Mr. Stern has emerged as perhaps the closest thing to a trusted external judge of the country's bitter internal debates.
Germans often turn to Americans when problems of memory are particularly intense. It is not for nothing that an American, Michael Blumenthal, runs the new Jewish Museum, whose architect, Daniel Liebeskind, is also an American, or that the planned Holocaust Memorial was designed by Peter Eisenman, another American. The basic difficulty behind these choices is an old one: how should the perpetrator commemorate or simply remember the crime?
Mr. Stern, the author of several books on Germany, including "The Politics of Cultural Despair," is a victim. His world began to fall apart in 1933; the family fled to New York in 1938, when the young Fritz was 12. But as a historian he has been little interested in victimhood. This flight from emotion to reason reassures Germans.
Rather, Mr. Stern has been interested in trying to recreate the time in which his father, a prominent doctor named Rudolf Stern, long thrived, in order to understand the political, cultural and economic forces that ultimately destroyed the fecund German-Jewish world of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. His affection for the pre-Nazi Germany of his parents is unmistakable.
Roland Ulmer, the president of the German Booksellers' and Publishers' Association, said: "The skill of Fritz Stern's depictions and his integrity have generated an atmosphere that provides the descendants of the victims and the descendants of the perpetrators with the building blocks from which to fashion a shared memory of a time when German-Jewish patriotism was thinkable."
In other words, he is seen as a conciliator at a difficult time. Mr. Ulmer led the jury that in 1999 awarded Mr. Stern the Peace Prize of the German Book Trade, the country's highest literary honor. In effect, a Jewish American professor was asked to step into another storm over the Nazi past and calm it. For the recipient of the prize a year earlier was the German author Martin Walser, who chose to speak aloud what many Germans silently feel.
Auschwitz, Mr. Walser declared in late 1998, should not become "a routine threat, a tool of intimidation that can be used at any time, or a moral cudgel." Apparently speaking of claims for compensation that have led to a 10-billion-mark settlement for forced and slave laborers put to work by the Nazis, he deplored the "exploitation of our shame for present purposes."
A storm duly erupted. Ignatz Bubis, the late Jewish leader in Germany, called Mr. Walser a "mental arsonist." Abruptly all the unhealed wounds of Germany's trauma were suppurating once more.
So it was no surprise that, a year later, Mr. Stern should be chosen to apply some balm. He duly obliged. His response, in a speech delivered in October, was typically measured, balanced, shaped at some level by the hesitation of a man who has done something essentially perverse: grown close to the country that murdered his uncle and aunt and hounded his parents from their home.
Mr. Stern declared that "any instrumentalization or trivialization of the Holocaust, consigning the millions of other victims to oblivion, is a crime against the victims themselves." He noted that the "first victims of National Socialism and the revival of torture were so-called Aryans," including pastors in Breslau. He recalled "how greatly attached my parents were to their home country, how naturally -- up until 1933 -- they saw themselves as Germans."
All this was certain to provide some comfort to a German audience. But Mr. Stern was also stringent in his admonitions. He deplored the government's adoption of the phrase Berlin Republic, saying "the result is simply to underline undesirable discontinuity." He warned that what he has called Germany's second chance could be undone if understanding did not overcome suspicion between Germans and from the west and the east. Above all, he suggested that the enormity of the Holocaust was such that "every attempt to escape into 'normality' is vain."
The speech was marked by a favorite word: context. It was the absence of context, as he saw it, that led Mr. Stern to a sharp condemnation of the most controversial recent work on Germany, Daniel Goldhagen's best-selling "Hitler's Willing Executioners." In an essay reprinted last year in "Einstein's German World," Mr. Stern's latest work, he charges Mr. Goldhagen with "the indictment of a people."
Mr. Goldhagen, a social scientist at Harvard, retorted that Mr. Stern's was the "reaction of the old guard, and one of striking intellectual bankruptcy." He continued, "I was accused by him of defaming the German national character, but all I said was Germans believed certain things at a certain time, just as it is clear that in the 1860's most whites in the American South were racist."
The Goldhagen book was troubling to Mr. Stern because he has been concerned with steering a repentant postwar Germany toward the stable democracy with strong trans-Atlantic bonds that it is today. For Mr. Stern, the Goldhagen work -- with its thesis of a deeply rooted, widespread and peculiarly German anti-Semitism as the basis of the Holocaust -- was shallow and dangerous.
For him, it underplayed the role that the national humiliation of Versailles had in igniting anti-Semitism; it ignored the participation or complicity of other European nations in the annihilation of European Jews; it might only reignite "latent anti-German sentiment among Americans, especially Jews."
The argument simmers on. Mr. Goldhagen makes a powerful case that anti-Semitism was part of the "cultural cognitive model" of the German society that produced Hitler; Mr. Stern says that "is an incredibly simplistic view." His reality is another: the ambiguity of German sentiment toward the Jews and the Jews' painful German patriotism, which together made up the unquiet world of his forebears. Anti-Semitism was not the whole story as the Sterns lived it in Breslau.
Mr. Stern, unlike some Germans, has no illusions that the world of interwoven German and Jewish culture into which he was born can be restored. The Jews arriving from Russia, drawn by financial enticements, will not recreate what Hitler destroyed. Germany must help bring Central European states like Poland firmly into the Western fold. For in illusion about the past lies the danger of another departure down some shimmering, unique and volatile German path, which Mr. Stern has always feared and always fought.
In his latest book, Stern quotes Einstein on the Germans: "A country of mass murderers." He also quotes another brilliant scientist and German Jew, Fritz Haber: "The nation is bourgeois to its very depths." Germany, of course, has been both those things. Therein lies its fascination. Einstein never converted; Haber was baptized at the age of 24. Both veered between love and despair at their homeland.
These are the intellectual struggles between attraction and repulsion that intrigue Mr. Stern; in some measure they are his own. "In retrospect," he says, "I can understand what motivated my paternal grandparents to convert, as I think a historian must understand things in the context of when they occurred. I am not necessarily happy about it, because I do not like the idea of changing religion for national advantage, but I can certainly comprehend."
This baptized German Jewish family was not simply persecuted, for it first advanced thrillingly in the politically unstable, fast-growing, inventive and finally humiliated German world of the first third of this century. Germans, ever torn between the light and dark of their natures, ever harboring secrets, are drawn to Mr. Stern because he has sought to portray all these shadings of the German tragedy. At another moment of uncertain change, he helps them believe in themselves -- with wariness.

HEADLINE: The Artist's Friend Turned Enemy: A Backlash Against the Copyright

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

 BODY:
Shakespeare was great at writing plays but lousy at inventing plots. So he borrowed them.
"Romeo and Juliet," for instance, was lifted from "The Tragicall Historye of Romeus and Juliet," a 1562 translation of a tale by Matteo Bandello, an Italian writer, soldier and monk. "Julius Caesar" came out of Sir Thomas North's 1579 translation of Plutarch's "Lives of Nobel Grecians and Romans." 
 Nobody sued for breach of copyright because there wasn't any. By and large, the work of artists, inventors and scientists was available for others to copy, improve or improvise on at will.
Of course, that hasn't been true the last couple of hundred years. The idea of a copyright -- to establish personal ownership of artworks, ideas, techniques and other intellectual property -- was included in Article 1 of the United States Constitution. In 1989 Americans took out 95,537 patents; in 1998 the number reached 147,521 and 72,395 more were issued to foreigners.
In 1998 Congress extended existing copyright protection for an additional 20 years. Major beneficiaries were corporations like Disney, whose copyright on Mickey Mouse, for example, was to expire in 2004 but has now been extended through 2023.
Since then criticism has been building in the academic world, with many arguing that the growing privatization of knowledge will threaten traditional intellectual and artistic freedoms.
"Industries and governments always favor strong intellectual property protection; academics tend to favor weaker protection," said Robert P. Merges, an expert on intellectual property law at the University of California at Berkeley. "If you took a poll of American academics, you'd find most believe the knowledge grab has gone too far."
This year a group of Harvard University law professors asked the United States District Court for the District of Columbia to declare the Copyright Extension Act of 1998 unconstitutional. They argued that it violated guarantees of free speech by reprivatizing works that would otherwise have become public property. They also said it breached a constitutional requirement that copyright laws "promote the progress of science and useful arts."
"Extending a dead author's copyright won't encourage him to write another book," said Lawrence Lessig, one of the Harvard professors bringing the case. "Would Shakespeare have written 'Romeo and Juliet' if he had to get permission from Bandello and pay royalties?"
The court rejected the argument, and the professors have appealed.
Patents and copyrights are essentially a monopoly that the government grants for a limited time to encourage art and invention by publicizing new discoveries while ensuring the authors a fair return.
In his book "Knowledge Diplomacy," a study of the international diplomacy of intellectual property rights, Michael P. Ryan of Georgetown University explains: "From its beginning the basic contract between the innovator and society has been that, rather than safeguarding the know-how of an innovation through the darkness of trade secrets, the innovator discloses the know-how in exchange for a limited period of exclusivity to produce and authorize to produce."
After World War II, he writes, "industrial diplomacy" created global markets for manufactured goods. Today that has been replaced by "knowledge diplomacy," which is "institutionalizing trade in products of invention and expression, offering innovators the incentive to make their products for the global market."
While some of the fastest growth in copyrights has been in the field of computer software (where the number of patents granted is expected to increase to 22,500 for 1999 from 1,300 in 1990), companies are increasingly patenting such innovations as methods of doing business.
Amazon.com, the on-line bookseller, for example, has patented its "one click" sales system, allowing customers to place new orders with a single press on the computer mouse. And priceline.com has done the same for "reverse auctions," which enable buyers to name a price and find a seller. Applications for such "business method" patents have risen 70 percent this year, according to the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
Critics say that the current laws on intellectual property may shrinkthe pool of freely available artworks and ideas from which artists and inventors often draw their inspiration.
In "Shamans, Software and Spleens: Law and the Construction of the Information Society" (Harvard University Press), James Boyle of American University argues that the present system overemphasizes the rights of the romanticized author at the expense of "the public domain necessary to give the magpie genius the raw material she needs."
Already many universities and colleges have stopped providing students with photocopied anthologies of learned articles as an introduction to their courses. Those that still do may charge an additional fee to cover royalties.
Ronald V. Bettif, a communications professor at Pennsylvania State University, writes in his book "Copyrighting Culture: the Political Economy of Intellectual Property" (Westview Press): "The consequences of expanded intellectual property rights are always the same: the continuing enclosure of the intellectual and artistic commons.
"More and more knowledge and culture are being privately appropriated and submitted to the logic of the marketplace."
What is patented is supposed to be novel, useful and not obvious. Today many critics feel the United States Patent and Trademark Office is granting patents too readily with insufficient research to establish that what it protects really is new and useful.
"The P.T.O. refuses to give examiners enough time, money and resources to search for relevant 'prior art' to establish novelty," said Gregory Aharonian, who runs the specialist Internet Patent Newservice in San Francisco.
As examples of what he calls "ridiculous patents" he cites one for a disposable razor with a small mirror attached so the shaver can watch himself shave and another for a dog collar that discourages dogs from barking by buzzing them when they do.
Professor Lessig agrees. "It takes $1.2 million on average to challenge the validity of a patent, which means it is often cheaper simply to pay the royalties than establish that a patent isn't deserved," he said.
Although many academic experts say copyrights can have suffocating side effects, few argue for their abandonment. Professor Boyle, for instance, favors establishing a new property right that would encourage native peoples to preserve forests and their tribal lore by receiving royalty payments from pharmaceutical companies that use the plants they live among and the natives' knowledge of them to make profitable drugs.
Sales of a drug derived from the rosy periwinkle found in Madagascar is used to treat Hodgkin's disease and are worth about $100 million a year, he points out. But Madagascar gets nothing and its people chop down their forests to live. "Who knows what other unique and potentially valuable plants disappear with the forest, what generations of pharmacological experience disappear as the indigenous culture is destroyed?" he asks.
Others argue that not only researchers but also participants in experimental research should benefit from resulting medical advances. Mr. Boyle cites the case of John Moore v. the Regents of the University of California, in which American courts decided that a patient had no rights deriving from medical information about proteins that regulate the immune system discovered through research on his spleen.
Mr. Ryan writes that the United States, at the urging of business, has been aggressively pushing other countries to accept its system of intellectual property rights in international trade negotiations. The results are mixed, however.
Susan K. Sell, the author of "Power and Ideas: North-South Aspects of Intellectual Property and Antitrust," argues that despite "their glaring vulnerability to trade threats, developing countries have not enforced intellectual property protection" and "do not believe in it at this point."
Washington is nonetheless likely to press for enforcement. Mr. Ryan puts the cost of foreign piracy to American industry at more than $10 billion in 1996, including $1.8 billion in the film industry, $1.2 billion in music, $3.8 billion in business application software and $690 million in book publishing.

HEADLINE: Detention Given in Theft of Secrets

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 7

 BODY:
A Taiwan executive who paid an employee of the Avery Dennison Corporation to pilfer corporate secrets from the company, a United States adhesives maker, was sentenced on Wednesday to six months home detention in the first case tried under a United States law aimed at combating trade-secret thefts.
A federal judge in Youngstown, Ohio, sentenced the executive, P. Y. Yang, chief executive of the Taiwan-based Four Pillars Ltd., to two years probation along with home detention for violating the Economic Espionage Act. Mr. Yang's daughter, Hwei Chang Yang, was sentenced to one-year probation on the same charge. 
 The Yangs were convicted in April 1999 of paying Ten Hong Lee, a senior research engineer at Avery Dennison, $160,000 over eight years to obtain adhesive formulas and other innovations developed by the company, which is based in Pasadena, Calif. Four Pillars and Avery Dennison compete in the Asian adhesive-label market.
Four Pillars itself also was convicted on the espionage charges. United States District Judge Peter Economus fined the company $5 million for accepting the pilfered secrets.
The government's experts estimated Avery Dennison lost to be at least $30 million because of the theft, the court papers said.
The Yangs' lawyers countered that the Four Pillars' officials never used any of the information they obtained from Avery Dennison to gain a competitive advantage and the executives have already served two years home detention waiting for the case to come to trial.
The Yangs each faced a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines for violating the espionage law. Four Pillars could be fined up to $5 million.

HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch Reimburses Client For Loss Linked to Ex-Employee

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company said today that it reimbursed money to a client and was pursuing prosecution of a former Egyptian employee who may have misappropriated the funds. Merrill Lynch paid back about $40 million, The Financial Times reported today.
Merrill's private banking group reimbursed the money to the Arab International Bank, and said it was pursuing criminal and civil charges against the former employee, Ashraf Raffa, 47, who was arrested in Egypt on Dec. 9. It is trying to recover the misappropriated money through legal proceedings. 
 The former employee is believed to have made several transfers of fixed income securities from Arab International Bank's funds to an account with UBS A.G. in Geneva between 1996 and 1998 by forging the signature of a former employee of the bank who died three months before the transactions started. The former London-based employee is being held in an Egyptian prison.
The incident highlights one of the risks financial services firms such as Merrill, based in New York, face in managing far-flung networks of brokers and offices worldwide, analysts said.
"The important thing is that Merrill spotted it, acted quickly and no counterparty lost out," said Philip Middleton, European head of banking strategy at KPMG. "There is a growing awareness within financial institutions of operational risk. Fraud and staff malfeasance is one of these issues."
Merrill said it paid the money back to the bank at the end of last year after it uncovered the extent of the misappropriation of funds. The incident first came to light in September, when Mr. Raffa stopped working for Merrill.
"Merrill Lynch has paid its client in full for losses incurred as the result of an apparent misappropriation of securities by one former employee of Merrill Lynch's private-banking group," Merrill Lynch said in a statement.
Merrill handles $1.5 trillion in assets for individual investors and institutions and has offices throughout the Middle East.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Surged in November

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers ballooned in November, as credit purchases helped push auto sales toward a record year and kicked off the best holiday shopping season since 1992, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Consumer credit rose by $15.6 billion in November to $1.39 trillion, the biggest leap since borrowing increased $15.3 billion in January 1999. Borrowing rose at an annual rate of 13.7 percent in November, compared with a rate of 4.6 percent in October and 5.3 percent for all of 1998. 
 The burst in credit exceeded the $6.4 billion expected by analysts and shows that consumer spending is behind an economic expansion on track to become the longest in United States history next month. Loans for automobiles and other purchases like boats, vacations and schooling accounted for more than two-thirds of the jump in borrowing, rising to $11.2 billion after an increase of $5.5 billion in October. Credit card and other revolving debt rose $4.4 billion after a decline of $225 million during October. The statistics omit popular home equity loans and other borrowing secured by real estate.
Borrowing had risen $5.2 billion in October, originally reported as an increase of $4.2 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
The 3 Main U.S. Stock Gauges Rally to End a Turbulent Week

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The stock market rallied across the board yesterday, wiping out most of the losses of a topsy-turvy week that began with interest rates surging and equity investors running for the exits.
The Dow Jones industrial average, after falling 4.3 percent Monday and Tuesday, rallied the last three days to finish the week at a new high, eclipsing the record set New Year's Eve. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks bounced back to just 28 points shy of its record. The Nasdaq composite index, which fell prey to the rush to dump technology stocks, was off 9.8 percent through Thursday. But its 4.2 percent rally yesterday left it down a more modest 6 percent for the first week of the year. 
 The selling in New York early in the week sent stocks in Europe and Asia tumbling. But those markets also rebounded.
The rally showed that investors, despite a surge in interest rates since mid-November and the threat of more increases by the Federal Reserve, still want stocks -- even if they are ones they had avoided before. The rally also makes one wonder if selloffs will ever unnerve investors.
As all three major stock gauges rose together for the first time this year and trading volume neared record levels, investors bought nontechnology stocks that were shunned last year. At the same time, they picked up some of the technology stocks that had been hammered Tuesday through Thursday.
Staples, the office equipment retailer, which plunged almost 29 percent last year, climbed 1 1/4, to 255/16 , and is up 22 percent this week. Caterpillar, the manufacturer of big machinery, climbed 111/16 , to 535/16 , rising for a third consecutive day.
On the technology side, Qualcomm rallied for the first time in three days, rising 915/16 , to 150. After being one of the top-performing stocks last year, surging 2,616 percent, Qualcomm fell 21.9 percent from Tuesday through Thursday. Yahoo and Cisco Systems also rose yesterday after falling this week. The three stocks led the Nasdaq composite index up 155.49 points, or 4.2 percent, to 3,882.62 -- 248 points below the high it hit Monday.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 269.30 points, or 2.4 percent, to 11,522.56 -- 25 points above its previous record. The Standard & Poor's index rose 38.02 points, or 2.7 percent, to 1,441.47.
"I think the market hit a speed bump this week," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, alluding to the incredible 53.7 percent increase in the Nasdaq index since Oct. 19. "But the appetite is there to buy stocks. Money doesn't want to leave the stock market so it is searching out safe havens."
Among these are drugs, consumer staples and old-line industrial companies. Another sign of that shift was the jump in the price of Coca-Cola yesterday, which rose 3 3/4, to 60 3/4, after the company announced some top executive appointments.
The rally in stocks came after the Labor Department announced that 315,000 new nonfarm payroll jobs had been created in December and that the nation's unemployment rate had remained at 4.1 percent, a 30-year low. While the jobs increase was higher than the 240,000 to 250,000 predicted by analysts, it did not seem to worry investors, nor did the jump in average hourly earnings. Treasury bond and note prices fell after the jobs data was announced but rallied later in the day. The yield on the 30-year bond slipped to 6.54 percent, from 6.56 percent on Thursday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 6/32 , to 9418/32 .
Stephen D. Slifer, chief United States economist at Lehman Brothers, said one reason for the muted response was that the yields of Treasury bonds and notes have already risen sharply in anticipation of interest rate moves by the Federal Reserve, probably beginning with a quarter-point increase at the Feb. 2 policy makers' meeting. He also said that although wages were rising, the rate of increase was below the pace of more than 4 percent of early 1998.
One of the forces driving selling earlier this week was the fear of an increase of at least a half of a percentage point in the Fed's short-term interest rate target as the central bank seeks to slow the economy to an acceptable, noninflationary pace of growth. With the economy growing at a 5 percent rate in the last six months there is no sign of a slowdown yet. That concern sent the yield on the 30-year bond up to 6.62 percent on Monday and again on Wednesday, the highest in more than two years.
Many investors with profits in technology stocks in 1999 seemed to have delayed their move to lock up their gains until the new year so that their due date for capital gains would be put off as long as possible.
The surge in interest rates and some negative earnings announcements from technology and Internet companies, including Amazon.com, Gateway and Lucent Technologies, helped accelerate selling.
But as investors abandoned technology they picked up other stocks, including hard-hit financial shares, helping to turn around the Dow and the S.& P. 500 indexes, which are less heavily weighted in technology than the Nasdaq.
Lucent Technologies, the maker of telecommunications equipment, set a one-day trading volume record with 179 million shares changing hands, including 136.6 million on the New York Stock Exchange and the rest on other trading systems. Lucent plunged 24.7 percent in after-hours trading Thursday, a fall reflected in yesterday's results, with the stock down 15 1/4, at 53 3/4. Lucent announced late Thursday that its first-quarter revenue and earnings would fall well short of analysts' expectations.

HEADLINE: Trump Speaks Out on Just About Everything

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: BROOKLYN PARK, Minn., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Taking potshots at Ed Koch, all the Republicans running for president, North Korea, Fidel Castro, Japan, Russia and candidates of humble background, Donald J. Trump today brought his presidential exploratory campaign to Minnesota, where he outlined his vision of a Trump administration and helped raise money for his Reform Party ally, Gov. Jesse Ventura.
Mr. Trump, who called himself "the biggest developer in the hottest city in the world" -- that would be New York -- spoke at a Chamber of Commerce lunch and later at a dinner where more than 200 people paid $100 a ticket to attend. Aides to Governor Ventura, the Reform Party's highest-ranking elected official, said the money would be used to spread the party's gospel around the state. 
 By day's end, however, Mr. Trump seemed no closer to announcing whether he would compete for the party's presidential nomination than when he arrived.
"I am looking very, very seriously at whether or not it can be won," he said at a news conference with Mr. Ventura that was sandwiched between his scheduled events. "Instinctively, I want to know if I have a good chance of winning."
For Mr. Trump, the visit was a chance to share with appreciative audiences his views of, well, just about everything. He said New York City's inability to fix the Wollman skating rink in Central Park, which Mr. Trump repaired for the city at cost in 1986, showed that Mr. Koch was a bad mayor. Mr. Trump said he watched the Republican candidates debate on Thursday night and concluded: "Are these people stiffs, or what? It was pathetic."
He described North Korea as the United States' greatest foreign threat, a country "run by some very bad people." He called himself "a big, big fan" of the economic embargo against Cuba, whose president, Mr. Castro, is "a bad guy." He said that Japan had been "ripping us off for 25 years," and that Russia was "totally mixed up, and they have missiles run by people nobody ever even heard of."
And he struck a blow for rich people as national leaders, chiding candidates who express pride in their humble backgrounds.
"They're losers," Mr. Trump said. "Who the hell wants to have a person like this for president?"
Without criticizing anyone, he reviewed his proposal to eliminate the national debt with a one-time tax on the nation's wealthiest people and said he would put forth his ideas on health care and overhauling the welfare system within a few weeks.
Mr. Trump said he came to Minnesota as a favor to Mr. Ventura, not to get his endorsement. But the governor made it clear that Mr. Trump would get it if he decided to run. Otherwise, Mr. Ventura said, he would endorse someone else, anyone but Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican-turned-Reform candidate who is seeking the party nomination.
Because of policy differences with Mr. Buchanan, the governor said, "It would be very difficult for me to support him."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unemployment Rate Stayed At 4.1 Percent in December
Employers created 315,000 new nonfarm jobs in December, 75,000 more than economists had predicted and the biggest one-month gain since July. With more people entering the work force, the unemployment rate remained at a 30-year low of 4.1 percent, where it has been for the last three months. The report showed that unemployment for all of 1999 averaged 4.2 percent, down from 4.5 percent in 1998 and the lowest rate since 1969, when it was 3.5 percent.
Average hourly earnings for the month rose by 0.4 percent, slightly more than expected. But because workers are producing more for each hour worked, the growth in wages so far shows few signs of setting off a surge in inflation. The figures increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would increase interest rates next month. Page A1. 

Granada Group Plans to Buy a Rival
Granada Group, a leading British operator of television networks, hotels and restaurants, said it planned to buy either Carlton Communications or United News and Media in an effort to block the $6.6 billion merger of the two companies and win control of Britain's commercial television industry. B2.
 
Army Set to Change Its Advertising
With recruiters struggling to fill its ranks, the Army plans to overhaul its advertising and marketing. It will end its contract with the Young & Rubicam advertising agency after 12 years and plans to stop using its slogan, "Be all that you can be." Officials have had a difficult time putting their finger on what it is about the slogan, or its intended audience, that makes for a fit that is not quite comfortable. They simply have a general sense that the motto does not seize today's young people, and that the service could also do a better job of marketing its mission to older people. A9.
 
Brazil's Internet Providers Protest
The Brazilian Association of Internet Providers protested plans by two prominent banks to provide free access to the World Wide Web. The association said the move might inhibit competition because its members -- small providers of Internet access -- may be forced out of business by the big competitors. B2.
 
Morgan Stanley Wins Name Dispute
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter won a fight to take possession of an Internet domain name for its new online trading site. The name was given up by a California teenager who had registered the names of dozens of well-known brands and Wall Street brokerage firms. B2.
 
Merrill Lynch Reimburses a Client
Merrill Lynch said it reimbursed millions of dollars to the Arab International Bank and was pursuing prosecution of a former Egyptian employee who may have misappropriated the funds. B3.
 
ABC and N.A.A.C.P. in a Job Pact
Two days after NBC announced an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, ABC said it reached its own deal with Kweisi Mfume, the president of the N.A.A.C.P. ABC said it intended "to increase opportunities for qualified people of color in the network television industry" both in front of and behind the camera, and underscored its existing diversity plans, such as formal mentoring efforts and programs to encourage minority writers. A8.
 
McLeodUSA to Acquire Splitrock
The telecommunications company McLeodUSA said that it would buy the data communications provider Splitrock Services for about $1.75 billion in stock to widen its service offerings beyond voice telephone services. B3.
 
Israeli Central Banker Nominated
Israel's Prime Minister nominated a senior central bank economist, David Klein, as the bank's next governor, signaling a continuing hard line against inflation. B2.

HEADLINE: Army, Its Recruiting Not All It Could Be, Decides to Overhaul Its Advertising

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
With recruiters struggling to fill its ranks and with public perceptions of its role apparently blurring, the Army plans to overhaul its advertising and marketing campaign, among other steps ending its contract with Young & Rubicam after 12 years.
The most immediate and perceptible effect of the changes, which the Army announced today, may be the demise of "Be All That You Can Be," its slogan for two decades but one that officials said might no longer attract the enlistees the service desperately needs. 
 " 'Be All You Can Be' is a great slogan," said P. T. Henry, assistant secretary of the Army for manpower and reserve affairs. "It is the trademark of the Army, known around the world, and it has served the Army well. The question is, Is it the right slogan today to recruit young men and women for the Army of the 21st century?"
Officials have had a difficult time putting their finger on what it is about the slogan, or its intended audience, that makes for a fit that is not quite comfortable. They simply have a general sense that the motto does not seize today's young people, and that the service could also do a better job of marketing its mission to older people -- "influencers," as they are called -- who might steer the young toward an Army career.
The Army's announcement underscored the nagging difficulties all the armed services are having signing up recruits at a time when the economy is booming and more young people than ever are finding college an attainable goal. Despite higher bonuses and grants for tuition, the services' recruiters have been scrambling, often unsuccessfully, to meet their recruiting goals in recent years.
In the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the Army missed its goal of 74,500 recruits by 6,291, an 8 percent shortfall, while the Air Force was shy of its goal of 32,673 by 1,727, or 5 percent. A year before, the Navy fell short by nearly 12 percent.
Young & Rubicam took over the Army's advertising campaign in 1987 and built on the "Be All That You Can Be" motto, which had been developed seven years earlier by the advertising agency N. W. Ayer. Now the secretary of the Army, Louis Caldera, has decided to exercise the Army's option not to renew the Young & Rubicam contract when it expires on July 31.
The current contract, worth about $14 million a year, was negotiated in 1997. It provided for an initial year plus four options of one year each. Had the Army kept renewing, the contract would have continued into the summer of 2002.
The Army, whose move was first reported in The Wall Street Journal today, said it would now invite major advertising agencies to bid for a new contract that would link payment to measurable results in enlistment increases. The Army has hired a consulting firm, Jones-Lundin Associates of Chicago, to help in the search.
The service said it hoped Young & Rubicam would compete for the new contract. But officials at the agency sounded irked by the Army's handling of the matter, particularly its decision to make a contract-termination announcement now -- seven months before the end of the current option year -- rather than use some of that time to work with the agency to bolster the campaign.
"We have not made a decision yet as to whether we'll take part as the Army recompetes the contract," said Bill Kelly, managing partner for the agency's U.S. Army Group. "We're not balking at recompeting. That's a fact of life for a government contract."
But he added, "We have real issues with the process and the timing."
While the Army's step is the most drastic so far, all the services have begun to rethink their advertising and marketing strategies after several years of recruiting difficulties.
No longer content with public service announcements, the Air Force last year began paying for television advertisements for the first time. So far the service has spent $29 million in the current fiscal year to put them on the air, though officials say it is too early to tell whether those spots have helped bolster enlistments.
And last fall the Navy took the unusual step of mailing letters to 65,000 retired sailors and officers, asking them to consider rejoining.
The Army's changes grew in part from a study completed last fall for Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen by two prominent political consultants: Carter D. Eskew, a Democrat, and Michael R. Murphy, a Republican. The study criticized the services, saying that in addition to a failure to articulate their mission, they had spent advertising dollars inefficiently -- by broadcasting advertisements on telecasts of national sports events, for example, rather than taking aim at niche markets on syndicated or cable programs. The consultants recommended that the services conduct better research on young people in order to direct their advertising at a variety of young audiences.
The Army announced today that it was creating a marketing division to do just that. It also plans to hire market research firms to devise ways to learn more about attitudes and tastes of young people so that its advertising budget, which has risen to $115 million from $85 million two years ago, is better spent.
