HEADLINE: Growth in Jobs At End of Year Beats Estimates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Employers added jobs at a surprisingly robust rate in December, propelling the economy into the new year with considerable momentum, the Labor Department reported today.
The economy created 315,000 new nonfarm jobs last month, 75,000 more than economists had predicted and the biggest one-month gain since July. With more people entering the work force, the unemployment rate remained at a 30-year low of 4.1 percent, where it has been for the last three months. 
 The report showed that unemployment for all of 1999 averaged 4.2 percent, down from 4.5 percent in 1998 and the lowest rate since 1969, when it was 3.5 percent.
Among black workers, the rate for the full year fell to 8 percent from 8.9 percent a year earlier, the lowest since the Labor Department started keeping separate records by race in 1972. Among Hispanic workers, the rate fell to 6.4 percent in 1999 from 7.2 percent a year earlier, the lowest since the department began breaking out statistics on Hispanic employment in 1973.
Average hourly earnings for the month rose four-tenths of 1 percent, slightly more than expected. But because workers are producing more for each hour worked, the growth in wages so far shows few signs of setting off a surge in inflation.
While good news across the board, the figures substantially increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would act to keep the economy from overheating by raising interest rates next month.
On Wall Street, investors acknowledged that a rate increase was now all but certain, but concluded that inflationary pressures were so muted that the Fed would limit the increase to a quarter of a percentage point rather than the half-point increase that the markets had come to fear in recent days.
Both blue-chip and technology stocks surged. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 269.30 points, to 11,522.56, a record. The Nasdaq composite index reversed three days of sharp declines, rising 155.49 points, to 3,882.62. Bond prices rose.
"There's enough strength in this report to make it a virtual certainty the Fed will tighten in February," said Stuart G. Hoffman, an economist at the PNC Corporation in Pittsburgh. "But I think a quarter of a point is all that's likely to come from the Fed, and appropriately so because this report is not so exceedingly strong as to force the Fed into a more aggressive increase."
Job gains were particularly strong in retailing and construction last month, while a prolonged decline in manufacturing jobs slowed as exports showed signs of picking up.
The report also left little doubt that the economy would continue growing for another month, all but assuring that the current business expansion will become the nation's longest in February, at 8 years and 11 months, breaking a record set in the 1960's.
With the presidential campaign heating up, the figures suggested that the economy will only be a political issue during the primary season to the degree that Vice President Al Gore can claim credit for its strength or to the degree that the other candidates in both parties can convince voters that they can keep the good times rolling.
But the economy's resilience presents a tricky challenge for the Fed, whose chairman, Alan Greenspan, was nominated to a fourth four-year term this week by President Clinton.
Mr. Greenspan has been increasingly blunt in warning over the last few months that the economy is running out of workers, and that even the substantial gains in productivity growth generated by huge investments in technology are not sufficient to eliminate the risk of spiraling wages and prices.
The Fed raised its benchmark Federal funds target rate three times last year in quarter-point increments, to 5.5 percent. The central bank's policy-setting committee meets again on Feb. 1 and 2, and analysts are almost unanimous in expecting another quarter-point increase then.
"The numbers suggest that economic activity continues to be strong, and undoubtedly stronger than the Fed believes is consistent with holding down inflation," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
So far there is little hard evidence that inflation pressures are taking root. Although wage growth is running slightly higher now than it was last summer -- average hourly earnings were up 3.7 percent last month over the corresponding month a year earlier, compared with 3.4 percent in August -- the average increase in the fourth quarter was actually lower than in the first half of 1999.
Mr. Hoffman said today's numbers provided some clues that productivity growth continued to be strong at the end of the year, allowing employers to absorb higher wage costs without having to raise prices.
And there have been tentative signs that higher interest rates are beginning to slow the housing market, a possible precursor of a more generalized economic slowdown.
But Mr. Kasriel cited two statistics watched closely by Mr. Greenspan that suggest potential for trouble.
One is a broad definition of the number of available workers -- people who are officially unemployed, plus those not actively looking for a job but interested in working. By that measure, joblessness fell last month to its lowest level during this business cycle, 4.5 percent, down from 4.6 percent a month earlier and 4.8 percent a year earlier, he said.
The other is the "quit rate," or the number of people who have left their jobs voluntarily as a percentage of total unemployed workers. That rate rose to 14.4 percent from 14.3 percent last month, also a high for this business cycle, indicating that workers are increasingly confident they can find a new, better-paying job.
"The implication is that you're going to have to pay more to retain your staff," Mr. Kasriel said.
Many economists say the Fed is likely to have to raise rates a number of times this year to slow the economy to a noninflationary pace. Economists at Salomon Smith Barney forecast today that the Fed would raise rates at least three-quarters of a point, and perhaps a full percentage point.
But Mr. Greenspan has proved to be a gradualist when it comes to adjusting monetary policy, raising and lowering rates a quarter of a point at a time and reassessing the economy every few weeks or months. He has not raised interest rates by half a percentage point since 1995.

HEADLINE: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty In Brick Attack on Woman

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

 BODY:
The man charged with attacking a woman with a brick in Midtown Manhattan in November pleaded not guilty yesterday and said he was in his girlfriend's apartment in the Bronx at the time.
The man, Paris Drake, 32, made his plea in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He is charged with attempted murder, attempted robbery, assault and weapons possession in the attack on Nicole Barrett, 27, a native of Texas. She was hit with a six-pound paving stone on the afternoon of Nov. 16, and needed two brain operations as a result. 
 Immediately after the incident, it was thought that the attacker was homeless and mentally ill. The attack prompted a crackdown by the Giuliani administration on homeless people who sleep on the street.
But from details presented yesterday in a police report, it appeared that Mr. Drake was neither homeless nor mentally ill. He had no history of psychiatric problems and had lived at least temporarily with his girlfriend on the Grand Concourse. A woman sat with his lawyers in the courtroom yesterday, holding an infant, but the lawyers would not identify her.
And Mr. Drake is being represented by a lawyer with offices on Park Avenue who was hired by his family.
"He's not the attacker, and he's not the panhandler the press has painted him," said the lawyer, Louis A. Zayas. "Quite frankly, I think they've got the wrong person."
"He's got family members that care a great deal about him," Mr. Zayas said.
In a police statement made public yesterday, Mr. Drake said he was unemployed and could not remember the last time he had worked. He routinely spent his days on Eighth Avenue, between 34th and 41st Streets, where he bought almonds, crushed them and sold the powder, pretending it was crack, the statement said. With the profits, he took the subway to 146th Street, bought crack and got high, according to the statement. He repeated the trip two or three times a day, depending on how much money he made, he told the police.
Mr. Drake was arrested after an inmate at Rikers Island told the police that he had bragged about the crime after his Nov. 23 arrest on drug charges.
Mr. Drake first told the police he spent Monday, Nov. 15, going in and out of the apartment on the Grand Concourse, buying crack and food. But when asked how he spent Nov. 16, he said he had stayed in the apartment both Monday and Tuesday, resting from the weekend.
Some legal experts have said they thought prosecutors were relying on too little evidence in charging Mr. Drake and that they might have a difficult time convicting him. Officials have said there are no fingerprints or other physical evidence to link him to the crime.
One of six witnesses who viewed a lineup identified Mr. Drake as the suspect. But papers from the district attorney's office show that another witness identified a photograph of a different person as the attacker and had earlier identified a third person in a lineup as the person who hit Ms. Barrett. The other witnesses failed to pick Mr. Drake out of a lineup.
After the arraignment, Mr. Zayas said the police had found the wrong person to charge in the attack.
"The entire New York Police Department's detective bureau was mobilized to find someone who was responsible for this," Mr. Zayas said.
The prosecution offered no new evidence against Mr. Drake yesterday. If convicted of all the offenses, he could be sentenced to 72 years in prison. He is scheduled to appear in court again on Feb. 19.
Ms. Barrett, who has returned to her family in Texas, is recovering faster than expected, but doctors have said she may have permanent brain damage.

HEADLINE: Museum Project Boasts Money And Big Names, But No Museum

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER

DATELINE: ENFIELD, Conn., Jan. 7

 BODY:
Ever since the day in 1983 when residents broached the idea of building a National Purple Heart Museum here, the museum has remained just that: an idea -- whose time came, went and kept on going, for 17 years.
Despite an advisory panel that includes Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf and the actor James Garner, more than $1.2 million in state grants, and the support of Gov. John G. Rowland, the military museum today is little more than an aging set of computer-enhanced blueprints and an unfulfilled flight of fancy for an unknown town seeking a tourist lodestone. 
 A report this week by the Connecticut attorney general's office offers a detailed explanation of the reasons. According to the report, the 12-member board charged with planning, financing and building the $18.75 million museum was so incompetent that it frittered away more than $500,000 in public and private funds and allowed the museum's former executive director to handle tens of thousands of dollars in ways that would make any banker shriek with horror.
"Management was inept and shoddy, and record keeping was completely inadequate; accounting was essentially incompetent," the attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said in a telephone interview today. "We believe the blame lies with the board."
The museum was conceived as a one-of-a-kind shrine of history and memorabilia dedicated to the hundreds of thousands of Americans who have received the Purple Heart medal, which is awarded to members of the military wounded in battle. The museum was to be situated in this middle-class town of shopping malls on the Massachusetts border, because according to local lore this is where Gen. George Washington in 1774 enlisted one of the first soldiers to receive the medal.
State officials were so enthusiastic about the museum that the powerful State Bond Commission, headed by the governor, voted in 1998 to grant $1 million to make it a reality. The names of General Schwarzkopf, Mr. Garner and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman were featured in brochures as members of the museum's prestigious panel of advisers. Town officials envisioned streams of tourist dollars.
But none of the glitter and high hopes, Mr. Blumenthal says, could offset the gross financial ineptitude of the museum's directors, 10 of whom are veterans of World War II and the wars in Korea and Vietnam.
To date, the board has spent more than $500,000, mostly in state grants, for about $33,000 worth of architectural plans, Mr. Blumenthal said. Shoddy bookkeeping and a lack of the most fundamental accounting measures make it unclear what happened to the rest of the money, he said. Despite their bad judgment, Mr. Blumenthal said, board members had only the best intentions for the museum.
Many of the financial problems were tied to the dealings of the museum's former executive director, Joseph Donohue, who according to the state report was hired in 1997 without a contract, used state grant money to pay his personal health insurance premiums and federal tax bills, and often filtered private donations to the museum through his own bank accounts.
In one convoluted exchange in 1998 that Mr. Blumenthal said typified Mr. Donohue's method of handling the museum's money, he cashed a $6,000 check given to him by a private museum donor and simply kept $500 of it. Mr. Donohue then deposited the remaining $5,500 into the museum's bank account, then wired it -- minus a $15 wire fee -- to his wife's bank account in Texas, Mr. Blumenthal said.
"There needs to be much stronger oversight so as to assure competent management," Mr. Blumenthal said. He added that he had referred his findings about Mr. Donohue, who resigned as executive director of the museum in April, to Connecticut's chief state's attorney, John Bailey, for possible criminal prosecution.
Mr. Donohue, who now works in Washington, could not be reached for comment today. But his successor, and the museum board's current executive director, Charles Alfano, called Mr. Blumenthal's report "flawed" and said it gave the false impression that hundreds of thousands of dollars had been wasted. In fact, Mr. Alfano said, mismanagement by the board, which he said has been corrected, added up to less than $20,000.
The $6,000 Mr. Donohue ran through his and his wife's accounts, he added, was meant as a salary payment to him, even though it came directly from a private donor. "That was his money legitimately," said Mr. Alfano, a volunteer, "but he used poor judgment in how he handled it."
Mr. Blumenthal said he began investigating the Purple Heart Museum project about three months ago, after complaints from contributors and volunteers began filtering into his office. Since then, the state Department of Economic and Community Development has stopped the disbursement of the $825,000 in remaining state grant money until the museum can prove it will be managed prudently.
Since Wednesday, when the attorney general's report was made public, Mr. Alfano has been meeting with state and town officials to coax them into releasing the money. Once that begins, he said, the museum will send out 125,000 direct-mail solicitations for donations and begin mapping out a fund-raising strategy with a California public relations firm that has agreed to work at no charge.
"We're ready to kick off our national campaign in early spring," Mr. Alfano said. "If all went well, we probably could have broken ground in May 2001." But, he added, "We can't move forward unless we get the remainder of the state grant." The earliest the museum may be ready for visitors is in late 2002, he said.
For now, the land reserved for the museum remains an expanse of scrub stuck between a nursing home, a cemetery and the southbound lanes of Interstate 91.
How much of the $18.75 million cost the museum board has on hand even Mr. Alfano did not know today. But, he said, "We probably could get by with $15 million."

HEADLINE: Investor Ordered To Give Up Gold

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A judge yesterday ordered a renowned market forecaster to produce $16 million worth of gold bars and rare antiquities in an attempt to recover the assets of investors who allegedly were bilked out of about $1 billion.
The forecaster, Martin A. Armstrong, 50, the founder of Princeton Economics International in Princeton, N.J., violated a court order to turn over the valuables to a court-appointed receiver, the judge ruled. Mr. Armstrong was ordered to produce them by Tuesday afternoon. 
 Prosecutors said they believe Mr. Armstrong has 102 bars of gold, a $750,000 bust of Julius Caesar, hundreds of rare coins, a bronze helmet and other antiques.
Mr. Armstrong, who is free on a $5 million bond, had no comment following the hearing, but his lawyer, Lawrence S. Feld, said, "Mr. Armstrong has authorized me to say that he will turn over whatever is in his possession."
Mr. Armstrong has pleaded innocent to fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the United States Attorney.
Mr. Armstrong's companies raised $1 billion from Japanese corporate investors to invest in safe bonds. Instead, he made risky bets on currencies and derivatives, the authorities said.

HEADLINE: Everything Is Rotten in the State of Florida

BYLINE: By Joe Queenan; Joe Queenan writes a bimonthly column for GQ. His book "My Goodness: A Cynic's Short-Lived Search for Sainthood" will be published in February.

 BODY:

Sick Puppy
 By Carl Hiaasen.
 341 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $25. 
 TRADITIONALLY, citizens of this great country have believed that the most horrible Americans live in Washington, New York or Los Angeles. For the past few years, Carl Hiaasen, a longtime resident of South Florida, has been laboring to correct this misimpression. In books like "Strip Tease" and "Tourist Season," he has made a persuasive case that the most barbaric, ignorant and just plain awful people living in this country today reside, nay flourish, in the state of Florida. And now, with "Sick Puppy," he may have finally clinched the argument.
As with Hiaasen's previous novels, "Sick Puppy" begins with an absurd premise and then gets nuttier. Palmer Stoat, an appalling human being, chucks some litter out his window while cruising down the freeway. Not even aware that Stoat is a crooked lobbyist and butcher of defenseless animals, Twilly Spree, an emotionally unstable tree-hugger seated in the vehicle directly behind him, decides to trash Stoat's car, vandalize his house, kidnap his dog and seduce his wife. Spree, who once took a court-ordered course in anger management after blowing up his uncle's bank, has a lot of time on his hands.
In the course of his depredations, Spree discovers that Stoat is pals with Florida's corrupt governor. He thereupon informs Stoat that if he ever wishes to see his dog again, he must persuade the governor to deep-six a new development that will further despoil the Florida wilderness. Now the narrative is invaded by an unusually psychopathic hit man who likes to listen to 911 calls made by people who are in the process of being murdered, in some cases with fondue forks; a drug lord turned real estate developer who is determined to surgically transform two hookers into human Barbie dolls; the Barbie dolls themselves, who become addicted to the aphrodisiac powers of the rhinoceros horn; and a swamp-dwelling vigilante who turns out to be the previous governor of Florida. Much mayhem ensues.
Hiaasen is often likened to Elmore Leonard, but this comparison goes only so far. Despite the similarity of the milieus in which they operate, Leonard is a far more economical writer than Hiaasen, perhaps persuaded that brevity is the soul of wit. And in his best books, such as "Get Shorty," Leonard achieves a much wider satirical sweep. This is largely because Leonard's characters, even the most depraved, are more believable; Hiaasen's stock in trade is to assemble a menagerie of stereotypes -- the crooked developer, the sleazy politician, the deranged environmentalist -- and then fish-gut them. Unwilling to go completely over the top, Leonard is much closer to Thomas Berger or Donald Westlake; Hiaasen is closer to Harry Crews and Eugene Ionesco. This is, by the way, very good company.
Among the delights of "Sick Puppy" are the subplots that enliven the proceedings. One concerns Stoat's efforts to locate a passive rhinoceros that the real estate developer can kill in a staged big-game hunt somewhere in the wilds of Florida. Another concerns the current governor's peculiar relationship with the previous governor, who at one point tosses him onto the floor, drags down his trousers and seems poised to re-enact one of the least appetizing scenes from the film "Deliverance." As the incumbent puts it:
"Even worse than the threat of public humiliation was the potential political fallout. Was Florida ready to re-elect a defiled chief executive? Dick Artemus had his doubts. He remembered how the audience felt about the Ned Beatty character at the end of the movie -- you were sorry for the guy, but no one was standing in line for his next canoe trip."
A sick puppy, indeed.

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD: PHILANTHROPY;
Education . . . Capitalist Tool

BYLINE: By Davidson Goldin

 BODY:
Venture capitalists who have helped make I.P.O. a synonym for fast cash are betting their investment skills will translate to education.
John Doerr, the money man behind success stories like Amazon.com, and a dozen other entrepreneurs have created the nation's first venture capital fund for education, the New Schools Venture Fund. 
 The fund solicits tax-deductible gifts to "invest" in nonprofit educational ventures, either through grants or low-interest loans, and makes traditional investments in for-profit schools in the hopes they will generate revenue. But any profits are reinvested in education. The arrangement, known as a venture philanthropy fund, is increasingly common as a way to finance charitable causes.
The bottom line is "a social return on our investment, not making money on our investment," says Kim Smith, a co-founder of Teach for America and of New Schools.
The idea for the fund, which has raised $10 million to date, evolved after a meeting with Vice President Al Gore, for whom Mr. Doerr is a prominent fund raiser. He remembers Mr. Gore asking, "If you Silicon Valley types are so smart, why can't you do something about education?" Mr. Doerr sought help at Stanford Business School, where Ms. Smith was working on her M.B.A. She devised the fund's structure and outlined a business strategy -- in short, to invest in ventures whose concepts can be expanded nationwide.
New Schools has made four major investments: a $500,000 grant to University Public Schools, which operates charter schools in California that focus on college preparation; a $1 million loan at 3 percent interest to a literacy program run by Johns Hopkins University; a $1 million investment in Learn Now, a for-profit company trying to start charter schools in New York City with a technology and math focus; and a $100,000 grant to greatschools.net, a Web site devoted to California schools.
"The fund's an equal opportunity investor," Mr. Doerr said. "It doesn't care if an entrepreneur is for-profit or not-for-profit, as long as the goal is to improve education on a large scale." DAVIDSON GOLDIN

HEADLINE: COLLEGE PREP;
Dear Admissions Committee:

BYLINE: By GLENN C. ALTSCHULER; Glenn C. Altschuler is both the dean of the School of Continuing Education and Summer Sessions and the Thomas and Dorothy Litwin Professor of American Studies at Cornell University.

 BODY:
Last year, a colleague asked for my advice about his son's application to Harvard. He suspected a teacher had written a less-than-stellar letter of recommendation and wondered whether he should call undergraduate admissions in Cambridge to try to persuade a secretary to yank it from the boy's folder.
Professors of politics may be more paranoid than parents in other professions, and considerably more Machiavellian. But in the importance he attached to the letter of recommendation, my colleague was no different from thousands of high school students and interested adults. 
 He need not have worried. Most recommendations do not help, and they virtually never harm, college applicants.
William Hiss, the vice president for administrative services at Bates College, advised students and teachers as dean of admissions for 20 years. Mr. Hiss tells teachers to be "cautious about making red-flag comments" about a student's personal and disciplinary problems. One misstep, and litigation is likely, he says, citing the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, Americans With Disabilities Act and state statutes on the confidentiality of discipline records.
On academic matters, too, the epistolary equivalent of grade inflation has set in. As a member of Cornell University's admissions committee for a decade, I would search applications in vain for even subordinate clauses like "While Susan did not participate often in discussions." With such Boy Scout merit-badge recommendations as "Josh is courteous, kind, resourceful, thrifty and brave," to quote one recent submission to Cornell, little wonder most letters have no impact on the fate of an applicant.
In an informal survey of several dozen high school teachers last semester, almost all said they see their role as helping students get into the college of their choice, not helping institutions select the best-qualified candidates. They also write upbeat letters for anyone who asks. (Popular teachers might evaluate three dozen students a year; guidance counselors as many as 150.)
"I emphasize the best qualities I perceive," said one advanced-placement history teacher at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan. "I ignore the negative, even when I'm well aware of it."
The results are brief essays that differ little, if at all, from one another. With so many recommendations opening with, "The first words that come to mind when I think of X are . . . ," one wonders if there's a software package out there facilitating the formulaic. Gerry Cox, an admissions dean at Cornell, says he dismisses missives with generic content when considering applicants. "The more they sound alike, the less difference they make," he says.
Some letters, however, do make a difference. While no recommendation will complete a Hail Mary pass, in colleges and universities with many more applicants than spaces in the freshman class, a thoughtful, detailed letter can make a qualified student stand out.
But pressed for time and inspiration, teachers may need help in this mission. Instructions on application forms are vague. Cornell, which guarantees confidentiality by promising teachers it will "destroy all subjective evaluations after the selection process is over," asks only for candid comments on "intellectual and personal promise" and "qualities that make this candidate unique."
To increase your chances of getting an effective recommendation, you do not have to take your daughter's social studies teacher out to dinner come application time, as a set of panicked parents at Scarsdale High School recently did. Here are a few dos and don'ts for students and teachers:
* Waive your right to see letters written on your behalf. The risk that the contents are damaging is slight, and admissions committee members give greater credibility to confidential communications.
* Do not submit more than two or three letters, unless you are certain they are all insightful gems. There is much truth in the admissions adage, "The thicker the folder, the thicker the applicant."
* Unless they know you, do not solicit letters from graduates of the university to which you are applying, your parents' business or law partners, members of Congress, governors, ex-presidents of the United States or titans of telecommunications. A recommendation letter from an eminent person who is not well acquainted with you will be a perfunctory testimonial. Remember, too, that generous donors have an impact, if at all, only on the applications of their own children.
* Employers can help if they supervised you themselves. A few years ago, a roofer wrote about a young man from a comfortably middle-class family who had worked as a manual laborer one summer, carrying shingles up the ladders to the more skilled roofers. To the surprise of his boss, "the kid" worked without complaint through stifling heat when several of the more experienced crew groused, took long lunches and asked to leave early. I have seen few letters address motivation more effectively. Cornell admitted the young man.
* The most influential letters of recommendation are filled with concrete details and a comparative assessment of the applicant. Supply teachers with copies of essays you have written for their classes, descriptions of science projects and other quotable material. Perhaps you'll get a letter like this one, submitted with an application to Brown University: "Stefan used spirituals, sermons and slave narratives in an essay about dissimulation, double-entendre and psychological resistance among African-Americans before the Civil War. Deftly crafting his own interpretation of the slave personality, he was unafraid to challenge the assumptions of the distinguished scholars Stanley Elkins and Eugene Genovese. The result was one of the two finest papers in the junior class." Brown accepted the student, even though his high school grades were not outstanding.
* The same specificity can be used to describe activities outside of class, as this recent recommendation did from a teacher at the Commonwealth School in Boston: "Noah was the organizing spirit behind our weekly luncheon discussion group that brought speakers to the school. The kind of student who read the whole book, even when a chapter is assigned, Noah was the most incisive and well-informed questioner in such public assemblies, whether the speaker was a law professor or an ecology activist."
* If teachers ask for your high school transcript and a list of extracurricular activities, remind them, in a tone that is at once deferential, diplomatic and direct, that either a guidance counselor will make a general assessment, or members of the admissions committee will have this information and can interpret it for themselves. Ask the teachers instead to focus on particular academic and personal skills drawn from observation in the classroom and evaluation of exams, essays and lab assignments.
* With recommendations, as with every other component of a college application, strategy and tactics are no substitute for performance. Those who do their very best give their teachers the material for an excellent evaluation.

LENGTH: 2604 words

HEADLINE: Frugal Traveler;
Amid Traffic and Glitches, Manila Offers an Embrace

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE

 BODY:
GO on . . . go ahead and dance with Alberto," urged Mrs. Besa, gently nudging me toward a lithe, middle-aged man wearing baggy pleated trousers and shiny loafers. I tried to demur, but my protests were muffled by thumping bass and drums and blasting trumpets -- a disco version of "Malaguena."
I bit my lip, checked my embarrassment, and acceded, limply offering my hand to Mrs. Besa's dance instructor (or D.I.), who immediately proceeded to pull my arm from its socket as if it were the string of a top and snap my severely jet-lagged body into a series of athletic whirls straight out of the John Travolta manual. Just six hours after arriving in the Philippines from New York, here I was, spinning under a disco ball on a November Saturday night in Manila. 
 "Manila?" friends in New York said disbelievingly when I told them of my plans to visit the Philippine capital for five days as the first stop of a six-week trip to three countries in Southeast Asia. Even many of the Filipino acquaintances whom I contacted for tips before leaving hinted that I should skip through the city as quickly as possible as I made my way to the Philippines' major attraction: its rural southern islands.
On paper, it is true, Manila didn't appear to have much tourist appeal. Most of its fine Spanish Colonial buildings and prewar neighborhoods had been flattened by American and Japanese bombs in World War II, and its infrastructure was eroded by years of political turmoil, corruption and neglect. The traffic jams, my sources said, made the snarls of Bombay or Bangkok look like a Sunday drive. And I was crestfallen to discover that one of the Manila sights at the top of my list, the shoe collection of Imelda Marcos, had been discreetly removed from display in the Presidential Palace museum after she returned to the political scene.
But I've learned not to judge a place by appearances, because my most interesting experiences often happen in the least likely locations. What's more, I had a personal connection with Manila. For 14 years, I had rented an apartment in a two-family house in Brooklyn owned and occupied by a Filipino-American couple, Amy Besa and Romy Dorotan. I was a frequent guest in their kitchen, where I learned how to dip my spring rolls in garlic-flavored vinegar, enjoy the crackly skin of lechon (the roast suckling pig that is the centerpiece of a big Filipino meal), and to bravely savor the lethally fishy aroma of bagoong, a Filipino shrimp paste. Amy and Romy introduced me to their extended families and to friends who came to visit from back home. All had proper Spanish first names -- Vicente or Reynaldo, Consuelo or Antonio -- that no one ever used. Instead, everyone called each other by euphonious Filipino nicknames like Binky, Ching, Ding or Dong.
To say that Filipino hospitality is expansive is an understatement -- it rolls forward like a juggernaut. Within hours after telling Amy that I was planning a visit to Manila, she sent a list of phone numbers by e-mail -- her brother Binky, her mother (Mrs. Besa) and assorted cousins, in-laws and friends. All had been put on red alert to expect my arrival, and I knew from experience what that meant: food. New Yorkers have cocktail parties, Filipinos have feasts. I ruefully realized that I'd just doomed a handful of squealing piglets to the chopping block, and I could forget about my plans to shed those pesky five pounds in Asia.
When I got over the guilt, I set about organizing my Manila hotels.
One bonus of traveling in Southern Asia is the affordability of luxury accommodation. In London or Venice, $80 a night gets a minuscule room that might not have a toilet; in Asia, with luck and planning, that same amount could land a five-star palace. One evening while surfing the Internet, I hit upon an online hotel broker, Asia Travel (www.asiatravel.com) that proved to be a mother lode of great bargains in Manila and beyond (they deal with hotels in most major Asian cities).
The site listed various hotels at discounts. For $82 a night, including taxes, I could have a room at the five-star Pan Pacific, one of the newest hotels in Manila (it has a rack rate upward of $150). I sent an e-mail message to the agent at Asia Travel, and asked about dates. She replied the next day and said I could have the three nights I wanted. There was a catch: I had to pay in advance, either by credit card, Western Union or bank transfer, to get the special rate. I hesitated, wondering whether to risk such an online transaction with a company I didn't know, but I decided to go ahead and pay with my credit card. The swift responses, friendly letters and faxed confirmation of my payment reassured me.
I figured that three nights in a luxury hotel would help me get over the stress of 25 hours of flying and an 11-hour time difference. For the remaining two nights, I'd move down-market, relying on legwork and word of mouth to find cheaper hotels, since the guidebooks I found were several years out of date.
Besides the discount, there was another advantage to staying at the Pan Pacific: location. One reason Manila traffic is so bad is that the city is a splinter of satellite districts, connected by inadequate roads. The old walled Spanish Colonial downtown, Intramuros, is where you want to be for sightseeing because it has most of the city's historic treasures.
But it has almost no restaurants and one small hotel. Business visitors usually pick the expensive hotels in the Houston-like skyscraper district of Makati, six miles and 60 minutes by cab from downtown.
The Pan Pacific, however, is in Malate, a neighborhood more or less in the middle of greater Manila that in the 50's was an upper middle class suburb. That was when Mrs. Besa, and her husband, both doctors, built their two-story house on Nakpil Street, which is now around the corner from the Pan Pacific. Manila's urban sprawl overran the area and many residents fled to the gated enclaves and shopping malls of Makati. Long neglected, Malate has recently found a second life as a district of restaurants, bars and clubs. The hip scene in Manila has shifted from Makati malls to Nakpil nights. The Besa home now stands, incongruously, on a street jammed with trendy places to eat, dance and drink.
"Out there are the denizens of the night," bemoaned the elegantly attired Mrs. Besa, sweeping her hand in a grand gesture toward her balcony windows. Already, Nakpil had begun to buzz with traffic and revelry. Her son, Binky, had a more pragmatic attitude toward his neighborhood's transformation. "There are lots of excellent restaurants here now that you can walk to, and I know the good ones," he said. "What kind of food would you like to eat?"
Binky assured me that the prices, even in the fanciest places, would be far below what I would expect in New York. He was right.
Our bill in Bistro Remedios, a restaurant specializing in upscale versions of Filipino dishes like a rich goat stew, and a hearty mix of taro leaves and coconut milk, came to $29 for two, including two rounds of beers, tax and tip. On subsequent evenings, the biggest check we managed to run up (for three courses and a bottle of Chilean merlot) was $55. This was at Sala, a fashionable restaurant decorated in Miami mint greens that served first-rate eclectic food, like perfectly grilled lamb on a bed of couscous with sun-dried tomatoes, and walnut baklava with homemade ginger ice cream. I liked Sala so much that I went back for lunch, which is an even better deal -- four courses, for a prix-fixe $16.50.
My faith in Asia Travel wasn't misplaced -- the Pan Pacific reservation was in order when I arrived. The marble tub in the bathroom won me over, but the dirty scuff marks on the lemon-yellow walls and the stained bedspread didn't. If this were a cut-rate hotel, I wouldn't have cared, but the Pan Pacific is a deluxe hotel about two years old. Later, I found that the front desk had lost one of my messages.
The Pan Pacific's slightly frayed edges, I soon discovered, are not unusual in Manila. Negotiating daily life takes energy and patience, even at the top end of the economic ladder. Power failures are unremarkable occurrences.
Potholed streets become lakes in the rain. There are few public buses, but rather a confusion of brightly painted converted trucks called jeepneys, run by private operators.
With high hopes, I moved to the Hotel Intramuros, a new small hotel in a converted old mansion in the historic district. How perfect, I thought, when I saw the big room with Spanish-style furniture and windows overlooking a cobblestone street (a single cost $45). I dropped off my luggage and got into sightseeing mode. Just across the street was Manila's oldest church, the Spanish Colonial San Agustin Cathedral, which has remained intact since 1599, through earthquakes, invasions and bombardments. Inside, in a small church museum, was a fantastic collection of centuries-old hand-carved wooden saints, or santos, similar to the religious sculptures found in Latin America, but much more detailed and luminous, with shining eyes fabricated from glass.
Strolling in Intramuros brought me back to walks I'd taken in the colonial districts of Cartagena, Santo Domingo and Old San Juan -- I was intrigued at how the Spaniards (who ruled here for over 300 years) had managed to build nearly exactly the same cityscape half a world away.
I walked through Fort Santiago, where the father of Philippine independence from Spain, Dr. Jose Rizal, had been imprisoned and executed. The footsteps of Rizal's final walk to the firing squad have been painted on the cobblestones in yellow.
The buildings were generally in good condition. With a touch of improvement here and there, some new shops and restaurants, Intramuros could be a really lovely district, a central Manila tourist attraction.
Then I returned to my hotel room, where a sewerlike smell wafted out from the bathroom, and the water had stopped working. The desk clerk told me -- politely and regretfully -- that they didn't know when the water would be on again. Oh, Manila. Gritting my teeth, I packed up my belongings and made plans to move to another hotel the next day.
"We're off the tourist track for you because we're Asian, but we're not exotic like Thailand -- we're too much like America," Mark Medina explained as we drove through Makati on the way to his family's farm in Pampanga province, on the city's outskirts. (In typical Manila fashion, my phone call to Mark's mother, a Filipina journalist I'd met in New York, had turned into an impromptu invitation to come out to the country with 12 other friends on Sunday and eat all day.) Looking out the window at the spewing concrete fountains of Makati's Las Vegasy Peninsula Hotel, I could see his point.

BUT later, lazing in a cane planters chair in the huge dining room of his family's old wooden and thatch house in the shadow of Mount Arayat, recovering from a marathon feed of roast lechon in a Pampanga-style liver sauce, it seemed to me that colonial Spain, not the United States, had the deeper influence here in Manila. For better and for worse: from the warmth and hospitality of extended families like this one that made visiting Manila such a pleasure, to the legacy of cronyism and corruption that made traveling in Manila so challenging.
In five days, I got a pretty good initiation into the life of the city. I'd gone ballroom dancing, eaten my way along Nakpil Street, spent a Sunday in the country, and worn out shoe leather exploring colonial streets. There was only one key experience missing, and on my last afternoon, heading for the airport and a flight to the Philippine islands of the Visayas, I filled that gap: I got stalled in a world-class traffic jam.
As the taxi crawled, millimeter by millimeter, along the bayside Roxas Boulevard, I ran the gamut of emotions in 45 minutes, from boredom to minor irritation, to full-blown, finger-hammering frustration. My taxi driver, meanwhile, cheerfully sang along with the radio, and no one in the jam so much as tooted a horn. In that moment, I was glad I'd ignored the naysayers and gotten to know Manila. I made a silent wish that my Manila friends would someday have a city as hospitable and charming as they are. Then I let my imagination lift my taxi like a helicopter out of Manila's snarl, toward islands and beaches, due south.
 
The bottom line in Manila
 
I spent about $82.50 a day on hotels, taxis, meals and activities in Manila.
 
Air Fare
The San Francisco air ticket consolidator Adventure Travel Network, (800) 467-4595, www.atntravel.com, is an excellent source for deals to Asia. They quickly booked a New York-Manila-Bangkok-New York round-trip fare of $1,250 that combined legs with Cathay Pacific and Thai Airways.
 
Hotels
The online travel agency Asia Travel, www.asiatravel.com, specializes in deeply discounted rooms all over Asia. In Manila, they found a rate of $82, with tax, at the Pan Pacific, Adriatico at Malvar Street, Malate, Manila; telephone (63-2) 536 0788, fax (63-2) 536 6220.
The Hotel Intramuros, Urandeta and Cabildo Street on Plaza San Luis, Intramuros, Manila, (63-2) 524 6730, fax (63-2) 527 5093, in a renovated old mansion in the heart of the historic district, has spacious rooms, Spanish-style furniture and views of the old city. But I had no water.
In desperation, I searched Adriatico Street in the Ermita-Malate district. There are many inexpensive business hotels along that strip, but most were filled. I found a room at the Palm Plaza, Pedro Gil at Adriatico, Malate, (63-2) 521 3502, fax (63-2) 524 8384, an older high-rise with decent, if somewhat dusty, rooms -- and a hot shower. The price: $38 a night with tax.
 
Restaurants
At Sala, 610 Nakpil, Malate, (63-2) 524 6770, a three-course dinner for two with a bottle of wine cost $55. A four-course lunch is $16.50.
Bistro Remedios, 1911 Adriatico in Malate, (63-2) 523 9153, specializes in haute versions of Filipino cuisine. Dinner for two with several beers came to $29.
The current craze for Cuban culture has reached Manila. Cafe Havana, (63-2) 521 8097, next door to Bistro Remedios, is a theme restaurant in the style of the Bodeguita del Medio. The dishes were sweeter and less piquant than in Cuba. Lunch for one came to $15, with tip.
 
Activities
Ballroom dancing is de rigueur for Manila's fine ladies; many have instructors on 24-hour call. I spent an enjoyable evening mamboing and foxtrotting at the GQ club, 1179 Quezon Avenue, Quezon City, with a live band, a disco ball and a squadron of dance instructors (D.I.'s) who charge $7.50 an hour. The cover is $5, beers about $1.50.
Admission to San Agustin church is free; the adjacent museum with its excellent collection of antique santos charges $1.10.
Next to the Hotel Intramuros, in the same courtyard complex, is Casa Manila, a beautifully restored 19th-century colonial mansion replete with period antiques and fittings. Admission: $1
Admission to Fort Santiago is $1.
 
Getting Around
Manila taxi drivers have a reputation for being sharks, but I found most of them friendly and professional. Insist that the driver turn on his meter (they always complied), and it is hard to spend more than $3 on an average ride from, say, Makati to Malate. Airport transfers are negotiable, ranging from $4 for a metered ride from Malate to $8.25 (a hired car from the airport desk). Try to avoid rush hours, and have a map and an idea of how to get where you are going, since drivers often don't. DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Showcasing a Century of Design

BYLINE: By Eric P. Nash

 BODY:
Chicago, the cradle of modern American architecture, is the site of an ambitious exhibition, "At the End of the Century: One Hundred Years of Architecture."
The emphasis of the show, which runs through Feb. 27 at the Museum of Contemporary Art, is on broad themes in architectural and urban thinking, including the Bauhaus movement, Internationalism, the evolution of suburbs, and the trend toward themes or "Disneyfication" as epitomized by recent Las Vegas casino hotels. Scale models, photographs, film footage, drawings, furniture and architectural sketches are among the exhibits. 
 In a segment on the politics of monumentality in the 1930's, connections are drawn between the colossal scale of Fascist architecture such as Hitler's grandiose vision of the Nazi capital Germania, and projects such as Hoover Dam, which was, according to the program notes, "equally intended to demonstrate the strength and stability of government during a time of economic crises and social upheaval."
A companion exhibition focusing on current work in Chicago, "Material Evidence: Chicago Architecture at 2000," deals with millennial design and fascination with new technologies and materials: one firm is experimenting with a pneumatic membrane that has the properties of a soap bubble for constructing bus-stop shelters, and another has designed a newsstand that doubles as a digital information display.
The architects Frank Gehry and Zaha Hadid, who recently won the design competition for a Center of Contemporary Arts in Rome, are scheduled to speak, and there will be a tour of Chicago's architectural jewels from the Loop to Hyde Park and the Gold Coast.
The museum, at 220 East Chicago Avenue, (312) 280-2660, is open Wednesday to Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays are free, and open until 8 p.m. Admission is $7. ERIC P. NASH

HEADLINE: Finland's Forte

BYLINE: By Geoffrey Wheatcroft; Geoffrey Wheatcroft is the author of "The Controversy of Zion."

 BODY:
After the shattering final chords of Jean Sibelius's symphonic poem "Kullervo" had died away, there was a shimmer of silence before the applause began. It was the sign of a good performance -- and of a good audience. This was one of the last concerts of the 1999 Helsinki Festival, and I was part of a large crowd gathered inside the handsome Johanneksen Kirrko, or St. John's Church. The setting was doubly apt. For many Europeans and Americans, art has become a 20th-century substitute for religion, attested to by the fact that churches are everywhere used
for musical performances. But Finland is something else again: a country where classical music could properly be called the true secular faith. 
 Drifting out that September night with the rest of the audience onto Korkeavuorenkatu, the street that runs from the great leafy Esplanade down to the sea, I thought not so much of Sibelius as of his successors -- and of something one of them had recently said to me. "Every country has its profile, its national image," the composer Aulis Sallinen said. "For us, it's all about music. It's extremely important to us."
And Finns have become important to music. Anyone who takes the most cursory interest in classical music today knows the names (even if they're practically unspellable) of Sallinen, Einojuhani Rautavaara, Joonas Kokkonen, Magnus Lindberg, Jouni Kaipainen and Kaija Saariaho. These are but a few stars from the expanding galaxy of contemporary Finnish music.
The work of living Finnish composers has been embraced in concert halls around the world, including the United States. One of the few contemporary works ever to be greeted warmly on the Metropolitan Opera stage was "The Red Line," Sallinen's powerful 1983 epic about Finnish farming life. Last November, New Yorkers heard the premiere of Saariaho's luminous choral symphony, "Oltra Mar," at Avery Fisher Hall, as part of the "Messages for the Millennium" program given by the New York Philharmonic. And this April, the Brooklyn Philharmonic, known for its championing of the music vanguard, will devote an entire program to symphonic works from Finland.
Like their fellow composers, Sallinen and Saariaho have been inspired and helped by the parallel flowerings of Finnish vocal, instrumental and conducting talent. In the 30 years since I first heard the wonderful bass Martti Talvela singing the role of King Mark in Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" at Covent Garden, the stream of Finnish singers has hit flood tide. Opera houses across the world fight for sopranos like Karita Mattila and Soile Isokoski, the mezzo Monica Groop, the baritones Jorma Hynninen and Raimo Laukka, and Talvela's heirs, the basses Matti Salminen and Jaakko Ryhanen.
There is an equally impressive generation of Finnish instrumentalists -- from the pianist Olli Mustonen to the dazzling 23-year-old violinist Pekka Kuusisto (who gave a lively recital at Avery Fisher Hall in November). As for Finnish conductors, they are waving their batons across the globe: Osmo Vanska in Scotland; Jukka-Pekka Saraste in Toronto; the celebrated Esa-Pekka Salonen at the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
All in all, this is an array of musical talent that would do credit to any of the larger European countries -- or even to the United States. And this eruption of musical genius comes out of a Scandinavian country with a national population of only five million, roughly that of Missouri or Indiana. If there is a more disproportionate cultural phenomenon today, it is hard to think of it.
Various theories, some quite charming but dubious, have been proposed to explain the recent crescendo in Finnish musical output. One musician I talked to said skittishly that the country's wealth of vocal talent comes from the Finns' historical need to shout to each other across great spaces. Juhani Raiskinen, head of the Finnish National Opera, attributed Finnish musical prowess to three things: "forests and oxygen and lungs."
But some argue that the Finns' odd language has helped inflame their musical passions. Finnish has few major linguistic relatives; Hungarian comes closest, and even that is a stretch. Living in such verbal isolation, there has surely been an incentive to communicate in a language that needs no translation and knows no boundaries.
Others point, not entirely facetiously, to the weather. It's well below freezing for much of the year in Finland. The cold of winter is compounded by almost constant darkness, especially in northern Lapland. It's enough to bring out the brooding artist in anyone. Perhaps this explains why Finnish composers so easily identify with the dark tonalities that dominate the palette of 20th-century music.
Perhaps the most grounded explanation is that Finns, like the citizens of many small nations, have learned that the best way to make a splash on the global cultural scene is to specialize. Think of the art that poured out of half a dozen Italian cities in the quattrocento, or the playwrights England produced within a few decades during the Elizabethan era. Certainly in the economic sphere, Finland has discovered the benefits of carving a niche. In recent years, the land of pine and reindeer has become the prosperous land of Nokia. The telecommunications industry now drives the country's economy. Perhaps the same logic that has turned Finland into Europe's Silicon Valley is responsible for its efflorescence in classical music.
The roots of Finland's current musical culture can partly be traced to two key events in that country's history: the publication of the "Kalevala," in 1835, and the birth of Jean Sibelius, in 1865. The "Kalevala" is the Finnish Saga, a series of verse epics passed down orally for hundreds of years before Elias Lonnrot collected and printed them at last. It's hard to exaggerate what this belated transcription meant for the small Scandinavian country. Even if they can't recite its many thousands of lines, all Finns know the "Kalevala." It became at once a touchstone of patriotic pride -- the country's first indisputably great work of art -- as well as the bedrock of Finnish cultural identity.
The rhythm and prosody of the "Kalevala" are now thoroughly embedded in the language of Finland -- and in the country's music as well. An English speaker can have a rough idea what the hypnotic-trochaic meter of the "Kalevala" sounds like, since Longfellow borrowed it for his poem "Hiawatha." (It sounds better in Finnish.) The stories of the "Kalevala" have directly inspired practically every major Finnish composer: Sibelius, Rautavaara and Sallinen have all set parts of the epic to music. You don't need to understand the language of the "Kalevala" to find it beautiful when sung; it is an inherently musical text. Indeed, the soprano Soile Isokoski told me that Finnish is "a bright and beautiful language, like Italian," and thus an ideal accompaniment to music. Some analysts have even detected a national musical character linked to the very grammar of the language. Finnish has no articles or prepositions -- and this is obliquely echoed in classical music, which so often begins a phrase on an accent, without a first upbeat.
As for Sibelius, he was not only the first great Finnish musician but also the first Finn the rest of the world had ever heard of. He is at once their Dante and Shakespeare. Although his greatest works were composed in the early years of this century, Sibelius died in only 1957; his legacy therefore remains a palpable one. Some of the leading musical lights of Finland today, like the composer Einojuhani Rautavaara, met him in the flesh and were directly inspired by his work.
Sibelius fell in love with the "Kalevala" when he was a schoolboy. Over his lifetime, he would set the text to music over and over again. The performance of "Kullervo" I heard at the Helsinki Festival takes a striking section where a girl picks fruit -- On the plains I gathered strawberries/Underneath the mountain, raspberries" -- until she is seduced by her brother, who then impales himself on his sword. That work, composed in 1892, made Sibelius a national hero when he was still in his late 20's.
A few years later came the even more patriotic "Finlandia," which won him international fame. A fully orchestrated Finnish Declaration of Independence, the composition solidified the country's psychological link with classical music. In his later symphonies, Sibelius honed his musical voice: a kind of melancholic Impressionism in which subtle sonic landscapes take precedence over distinct melody.
Finnish music today is diverse; it has escaped Sibelius's shadow. Yet his textural style continues to influence many of Finland's top composers. Kaija Saariaho's shimmering choral symphony, "Oltra Mar," builds up tonal effects in an attempt to evoke the sound of a churning sea. In one passage, the chorus mimics a crashing wave with a sustained "shhh." Even in the most cerebral modernist compositions, an open-air quality that seems derived from Sibelius keeps breaking through. Rautavaara's "Cantus Arcticus," for example, is a "Concerto for Birds and Orchestra" that combines atonal orchestral music with Arctic bird song recorded by the composer himself.
In 1939, the Helsinki Music Institute was renamed the Sibelius Academy. It was the first step in the Finnish government's effort to capitalize on Sibelius's fame and cultivate fresh musical talent. Einojuhani Rautavaara was one notable beneficiary of this effort. He was personally selected by Sibelius to be sent to Juilliard after receiving training at the Sibelius Academy. Rautavaara was made an arts professor by the government in 1971. This wasn't a teaching job or a sinecure -- but rather a kind of laureateship that allowed him to concentrate exclusively on composing.
And that's just what Rautavaara, now 71, has been able to do. Many modern composers struggle to land just one major opera commission. Rautavaara has seven operas to his name -- including the 1997 chamber work "Aleksis Kivi," a psychological portrait of the 19th-century Finnish novelist. Although his music is more insistently atonal than that of Sibelius, Rautavaara has also drawn equal inspiration from Finland's past. His 1985 three-act opera "Thomas" documents the crusade led by Sweden and the Catholic Church to convert the Finns in the 13th century.
The career of the composer Jouni Kaipainen offers another case study in the pleasures of being a musician in Finland. Forming part of a line of "apostolic succession," as he puts it, Kaipainen began his studies at the Sibelius Academy under Aulis Sallinen. But he was a pupil rather than disciple, and has since carved a distinctive musical voice. His best-known work is "Carpe Diem," a propulsive clarinet concerto that fully exploits the sonic range of the woodwind instrument, squonks and squeals included.
Kaipainen has enjoyed generous state grants for 15 years. He is now composer in residence in Tampere, an industrial town 100 miles north of Helsinki with a rich musical life of its own. And he benefits also from the numerous commissions of the country's orchestras and festivals.
"Young American composers are astonished when I say I'm writing symphonies for the Helsinki Symphony Orchestra," Kaipainen says. Such orchestras are run in a way that frees them from dependence on ticket sales, but the Finns have in fact been gradually educated to understand and love music. Kaipainen wonders, rationally enough, how composers in other countries can learn their craft if they never get to hear their work played.
As Kaipainen sees it, much of Finland's musical flourishing has to do with the way the government has helped bring together composers, conductors, orchestras and record companies. Along with any number of smaller ensembles, and too many choirs to count, the country has almost 30 professional or semiprofessional orchestras. There are 45 annual music festivals, several of international repute, like the Savonlinna Opera Festival. The Finnish government subsidizes a record label, Ondine, that specializes in home-grown music. In addition to featuring contemporary works by the likes of Saariaho and Sallinen, Ondine offers Sibelius's Violin Concerto in both the classic 1954 recording by David Oistrakh and the prize-winning 1996 version by the prodigy Pekka Kuusisto.
Just as important, notes Kaipainen, are collaborations between composers and conductors. It is a symbiotic relationship of a kind that has scarcely been seen in Europe since the days when Toscanini was conducting Verdi and Puccini at La Scala, and Bruno Walter conducted Richard Strauss, Pfitzner and Korngold in Munich. The "Kullervo" performance at Johanneksen Kirrko was conducted by Paavo Berglund, the doyen of Finnish conductors, who has recorded two of Kokkonen's symphonies. Both Sakari Oramo and Osmo Vanska have recorded new works by Kaipainen; Oramo and Saraste have recorded works by the modernist Magnus Lindberg; and Esa-Pekka Salonen and the Los Angeles Philharmonic have recorded Saariaho's lovely colorist work, "Du Cristal."
The extent of collaboration in Finland might have something to do with the fact that so many of the country's leading musical figures were schoolmates. Musical education in Finland is of a quality and quantity unmatched anywhere in the world. It's romantic to think of the Finnish musical explosion as some inexplicable, God-given miracle. In reality, it is a product of something far less exalted: taxation.
Public money pays for dozens of lavish conservatories that are spread around the country. At one school in Oulu, a distant port on the Gulf of Bothnia, more than 1,300 pupils have access to a pipe organ, three Steinway grands, a modern recording studio and a concert hall.
The gifted violinist Pekka Kuuisisto, the Wunderkind who looks several years younger than 23, was trained at one of these academies, named Ita Helsinki. The pupils there come from all walks of life; musical skill is all that's required. As one student boasted, "It's possible for the child of an unemployed man to come here."
The school's Helsinki Junior Strings Orchestra is just one of many ways Finland nurtures its young musical talent. The school's pedagogical method, known as the color-strings approach, is based on the recognition of two things about small children: they need mnemonics -- four different colors and four different cartoons stand for each of the strings of a violin -- and they love games. The teachers therefore make playing the fiddle or cello a game, "serving the happiness of the child."
Ita Helsinki produces promising players. In one classroom, a coed group of 8-year-old cellists perform a routine rather like a basketball drill, with one member of the team shooting musical hoops as the others listen. Next door, a violinist named Geza Szilvay coaches 6-year-old girls. His first rule is, "It mustn't be a chore." He is gentleness itself as he instructs, "Relax your thumb for vibrato," before taking them back to a simple pizzicato on the G-string. The hope, of course, is that these girls will one day be part of the Helsinki Philharmonic. Or become a composer, the way Kaija Saariaho did.
Those girls and boys won't be playing a large part in the festivities for the year 2000, but most other Finnish musicians will, and there is a keen sense of expectation. Saariaho's new opera will have its premiere at next summer's Salzburg Festival, and Finland itself will throb with new music. Sallinen recently delivered the score of his latest opera, based on "King Lear," to the Finnish National Opera. The work will have its premiere in September. In the summer there will be "The Age of Dreams," an operatic triptych with a libretto by Paavo Rintala -- the three parts composed by Kalevi Aho, Olli Kortekangas and Herman Rechberger. This will have its debut at the Savonlinna Festival, which is held in a medieval lakeside castle, and is one of Finland's most attractive offerings for the musical pilgrim. Both Jorma Hynninen and Monica Groop will be creating roles for the production.
As in any other field, countries get what they pay for, they get what they want and they get what they deserve. Perhaps it shouldn't be surprising, then, that Finns have become so dominant in the classical music world. Where else besides Helsinki does a new symphony elicit a long segment on the television news -- and a new-music concert sell out as quickly as a rock concert? Rautavaara summed it up with wry satisfaction. "Music is extremely respected in Finland," he said. "Even the politicians respect music here."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 01-09-00: Counter Culture;
The Simple Solution

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan

 BODY:
I suppose I first developed a fondness for the flat tax when both Jerry Brown and Steve Forbes supported it. It had that energizing right-left whiplash I've rarely been able to resist. But these days, not only the fringes of political life support it. This year, every Republican candidate but one -- Alan Keyes -- supports a version of flatness, and even the cautious George W. backs simpler, lower rates. One of Al Gore's core strengths against Bill Bradley is that he is less likely to raise taxes than his more liberal rival. Compared with 25 years ago, when pre-Reagan tax rates clobbered anyone even faintly successful, or even 16 years ago, when Walter Mondale quixotically campaigned for a fiscal hike, the tax climate may not be flat but it's surely flatter.
My fearless New Year's prediction is that the flat tax will be the central political reform of the next decade. And the reason we're headed for 180 degrees is at least partly cultural. There is almost no virtue more celebrated in America right now than simplicity. We are increasingly a one-click, one-rate, one-card, one-model culture. Once upon a time, companies might have broadcast their complexity to demonstrate their clout. Not so long ago, synergy was the buzzword. Now companies do all they can to project a simple image, a single product and a recognizable, simple brand. Amazon.com has one-click shopping; every consumer has a one-stop credit-debit card; most of Europe has one currency; and half the American continent has one tariff. If you want to think of the purest representation of this simple-is-beautiful trend, think of a Gap television ad: white background; simple images; no words; one brand. Or think of the E-Z Pass, the electronic card in your car windshield that instantly charges you as you enter a toll road or toll bridge. The most successful products -- from the iMac to AOL -- include as many features as possible in one standard model. Sooner rather than later, in a broad-band world, even the distinctions among telephone wires, cables and satellites will be erased. There will be one cultural-economic tube, and you'll be at the end of it -- eagerly clutching your single credit card that can make telephone calls, get cash out of A.T.M.'s and earn you frequent-flier miles. 
 In this general cultural drive toward simplicity, one thing stands out like a very sore thumb: the tax code. If taxpayers could pick a tax system for the new millennium, and if entrepreneurs could compete to provide one, the chances of the winning product looking like our current mess would be close to zero. Think of its current, salient features: multiple rates, thousands of possible deductions, a tax code of countless exceptions to endless rules fatter than the average Yellow Pages. There's a reason candidates get applause by vowing to abolish the I.R.S. and shrink our tax returns so they can fit on a postcard. It's not just that voters think they might pay less tax. (Keep dreaming.) It's that most people understand that paying taxes should surely be a little simpler in 2000 than the plot of a 19th-century Russian novel.
The standard objection to one-click tax payment is a political one, but even this is losing steam. It is the familiar liberal complaint that a simpler tax will inevitably favor the rich over the poor. In one sense, of course, this is a no-brainer. If you replace a tax system designed to ratchet up rates on the wealthy with a one-rate system, the rich pay less. But as the middle classes know, this is only part of the story. Complexity may be designed to penalize the prosperous, but it is also the rich man's friend. The current tax code is so byzantine that the wealthy are often the only ones who can afford the tax lawyers who can really foil it. More important, as the middle classes also know, the tax system is more than its rates. It's also the product of the myriad tax breaks, shelters and subsidies that the middle and upper classes demand in return for their higher tax rates. A result is a nominally progressive system with so many loopholes that it looks a lot less fair in close-up than it does from a distance.
Besides, the point of a tax system should not be to create a perfect society. There are plenty of ways to do that by spending the money you raise. The point of a good tax system is to raise as much revenue as simply and as efficiently as possible. No system does that as well as the flat tax. The best version would be both conservative and liberal. Start on the left by eliminating every tax deduction in the current code and scouring the federal budget for every juicy piece of corporate welfare you can find. Then shift right and remove the current multiple tax rates with one simple percentage tax, and tax income, capital gains and inherited wealth at this same, simple rate. Tack left again and start taxing at a high-enough income level to keep most of the working poor from paying any federal income tax at all; and where necessary, supplement income by keeping the Earned Income Tax Credit as a simple cash handout. By the time you're done, the I.R.S. is history, taxes are as easy as e-mail and the government looks as if it might conceivably belong in the 21st century.
Who's opposed? The naysayers are either corporate interests, tax lawyers or liberals who react to every attempt to change the system with a chorus that it's a giveaway to the rich. But this is as knee-jerk as the liberal response to welfare reform, which saw it as mere punishment of the poor. In fact, if only liberals could get their minds wrapped around it, a one-rate, loophole-free tax system could actually help rescue liberalism from its doldrums. In one swoop, a flat tax would remove one of the major reasons for the unpopularity of government: its complexity, bureaucracy and debts to special interests. By treating every taxpayer alike, a flat tax would help foster a deeper sense that no one has more of a claim on the government than anyone else, and help focus us on real social problems rather than on who gets what in the crapshoot of tax law. As a bonus, by ending the tax breaks special interest groups thrive on, you also remove much of the incentive for corporate soft-money campaign donations, getting through a flat tax what campaign finance reform will likely never accomplish. A flat tax in the context of more general tax reform could be the best thing to happen to faith in government since Nixon left office.
Politically impossible? That's what they said about welfare reform and deficit reduction. In fact, all the omens are good. Tax reform is always easier in good times; flat-taxers are almost a majority now in the Republican Party; and the candidates with the most mojo this winter are those most hostile to the special-interest groups who love the current system. I give it 10 years at the most. And we won't even have to elect Steve Forbes or Jerry Brown to get there.
